column2: An article last Sunday about the influence that South Korean Se Ri Pak's victory at the United States Women's Open in 1998 had on the increase in the number of golfers from South Korea and Asia on the L.P.G.A. Tour gave outdated information about a montage that accompanies the South Korean national anthem each morning on television. The montage features soldiers marching, fishermen and tradesmen working, and athletes performing, but no longer shows Pak. (At one time Pak was shown removing her shoes to hit a shot from the edge of a water hazard on the 18th hole during her 1998 Open win.)

To the Editor: Regarding ''Call Waiting: 'It's Me, Vacation' '' (July 1): The secret to a calm, relaxing vacation is to rein in your plans. Seven days is too short to fly nine hours to some exotic spot. The frustration of getting to and from the airport, plus the jet lag, will lead you to lose hours of true enjoyment. Explore an area close to home, see it with the eyes and enthusiasm of a tourist, and you'll see how many charming venues are just a few miles from the daily grind. You'll save money and aggravation. DAVID DAVIS Highland Park, Tex. To the Editor: Before going on vacation, I always sit down and make a list of all of the issues on my mind, no matter how big or small, from writing a new will to picking up dry cleaning. I think of it as downloading my mental computer. This way, while I'm on vacation, I don't have to worry about taking care of this or that. And when I return, I'm ready to go back to work without worrying that I've forgotten an issue. JACK ADLER Larchmont, N.Y.

MORTON--Penrod (Penny) Chanin, died peacefully after a sudden illness on July 2, 2012 in Davis, CA. She was 84. Daughter of the late Samuel and Edna Chanin; sister of Robert (Bobby) killed in Italy during WWII. Survived by children Robert Christopher (Chris) and his wife Lori Posin, Laurie and Jamie Morton and his wife Lena Baranova; grandchildren Josh, Marisa, Travis, Genevieve, Devon, and Emily Morton. She was predeceased by grandson Trevor Morton. She will be missed.
Two incomes would certainly help with the bills. But it's parenting, too. I wish I could say, 'Call your dad.' JESSICA SCHAIRER,

''WELL-MADE lingerie is key,'' says the designer Stella McCartney, who will launch a new line of not-too-pricey underpinnings called, simply, Stella, in August. ''Feeling constricted by one's underwear just isn't my thing. You need to rely on the quality, it has to fit, function and do its job first and foremost.'' Designed for every day, the Stella collection includes five different bra shapes including molded underwire, low plunge cups, a strapless style and a seamless underwire-free style -- in youthful pops of electric blue or python and more timeless hues of blush pink or black. They are all made from organic cotton and recycled metal (for the strap's gold Stella-incrusted rings). Bras are $55 and their matching knickers in lace, mesh and matte satin are $26; stellamccartney.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

GROBMAN--Arnold Arnold Grobman, Chancellor Emeritus of the University of Missouri, St. Louis, a renowned herpetologist, educator, and researcher in atomic science for the Manhattan Project, died July 8, 2012 in Gainesville, Florida. In the 1950s, Dr. Grobman was the Director of the Florida State Museum (now the Florida Museum of Natural History) in Gainesville, where he laid foundations for its development into a major university research museum. In 1959, he became the founding director of the Biological Sciences Curriculum Study in Boulder, Colorado, a group developing secondary school biology textbooks promoting the teaching of evolution and lab fieldwork. After a stint as dean of Rutgers College and a vice-chancellorship at the University of Illinois at Chicago, he was selected as chancellor of the University of Missouri-St. Louis, where he oversaw the addition of new schools of nursing and optometry. He has published dozens of educational and scientific articles, many focusing on reptiles, and written several books including "Our Atomic Heritage," "The Changing Classroom," and "Urban State Universities." The salamander Plethodon grobmani was named after him. Dr. Grobman was married to the former Hulda Gross, and is survived by a son, Marc Grobman of Fanwood, New Jersey, and a daughter and grandson, Beth Grobman and David Burruss, of San Jose, California. Services will be held at Oak Hammock in Gainesville.

10 P.M. (USA) POLITICAL ANIMALS Sigourney Weaver (above, with James Wolk, left, and Brent Jennings), in a role based on Hillary Rodham Clinton, portrays Elaine Barrish Hammond, a former first lady who ran for president and became secretary of state in this new mini-series. She's married to a philandering former president, Bud Hammond (Ciaran Hinds), but in this make-believe version, Elaine doesn't stand by her man -- she divorces him. Carla Gugino is Susan Berg, a journalist who won a Pulitzer Prize for writing about Bud's infidelities, and who has exclusive access to Elaine in exchange for keeping the news about the Hammonds' troubled son, T. J. (Sebastian Stan), quiet. (His twin, Douglas, played by Mr. Wolk, is Elaine's chief of staff.) And Adrian Pasdar is President Paul Garcetti, the charismatic candidate who beat Elaine for the Democratic nomination. ''It may be too soon to assess her place in history, but it is already clear that Mrs. Clinton has a huge hold on the public imagination: a woman so well known, and yet so unknowable, that writers and filmmakers keep turning to fiction to try to solve her mystery,'' Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. She added: ''Mrs. Clinton's life, with all its political triumphs and private torments, turned out to be juicier than any script a movie or television studio could conjure. And the writers, at least, don't want that to end. 'Can you keep a secret?' Elaine asks a Secret Service agent at her side. 'I'm going to run for president again, and this time I'm going to win.' '' 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago, a former White House chief of staff for President Obama, and Senator Kelly Ayotte, Republican of New Hampshire, discuss the presidential election.
Watch A. O. Scott and David Carr discuss culture high and low on ''The Sweet Spot'': nytimes.com/video

It is Outdoors@Hay, not Hay@Outdoors. (As the article noted, the Web site is training-activities.co.uk.)

It is now an annual tradition at the baseball writers' All-Star lunch with Commissioner Bud Selig. Someone asks Selig about his committee to study a new stadium for the Oakland Athletics - while pointing out how many months it has been since the study began. The current count is 39, but Selig offered no hope for a resolution, saying only that he still needed answers regarding the complicated turf war between San Francisco and Oakland. So the Athletics remain in limbo, blocked from moving to San Jose, Calif., forever preparing for a ballpark opening somewhere in the distance.

Tim McCarver will receive the Ford C. Frick Award for broadcasting next Saturday in Cooperstown, N.Y., a day before Barry Larkin and Ron Santo are inducted to the Hall Fame. McCarver's ceremony will have a St. Louis flavor, with three World Series-winning Cardinals managers - Red Schoendienst, Whitey Herzog and Tony La Russa - also being recognized. McCarver played in three World Series for St. Louis, winning two, and his former team was on the field for his first as a broadcaster, in 1985. He said he took two lessons from that experience.

NO one blinks at the sight of a 19th-century painting on modern walls. (Think Edward Hopper at the Whitney Museum.) But hang a contemporary artwork in a 19th-century house -- say, a sculpture made from a garden hose -- and see what kind of weirdness results. That was what the art consultant Mark Fletcher proposed to the eight young artists of the Still House Group, when he offered the Brooklyn-based collective an exhibition in a circa-1840 town house on Washington Square. They returned with ''Here Comes,'' a mixed-media show that confounded even Mr. Fletcher, a champion of young art. ''I was surprised by the level of subtlety in the installation,'' he said. He bought everything in it and opened the apartment (usually private viewing rooms for clients) to the public. The Still House Group is typical of a generation that gives every material, be it Scotch tape or oil paint, equal weight. Their work doesn't supply instant gratification. That may put off some viewers, but if anyone wants to see how the art of our time holds up in an environment built for another, ''Here Comes'' will do the trick. It's mysterious, inexplicable. And that is the attraction. Through July 27; 24 Washington Square North. LINDA YABLONSKY

The ''Streetscapes'' column on July 1, ''For Career Women, a Hassle-Free Haven,'' reported on the Martha Washington, a hotel for women only until 1998. Following is a selection of reader comments from nytimes.com: I recall the hotel being a rather frequent destination when I was a night-shift cabdriver in the late '60s/early '70s. It was one of those stops where the female passenger would ask me to please wait until they had entered the building. I always obliged. bugbitten,

KLEBAN--Edward M.,Loving husband of Carol, proud father of Richard (Robin) and Steven (Caroline), devoted grandpa to Jacob, Sarah, Alexandra, Charles and Lucy, big brother of Don. Uncle Ed and wonderful friend to many. He will be deeply missed. Donations: Hospice Buffalo.

We don't know what Hillary Clinton could really have accomplished if she had her way, because as Myers is forced to point out, she has subordinated her own views to those of the president despite differences on keeping a strong American presence in Afghanistan and Iraq, the need to resist Putin and to promote human rights. In each case, Clinton's instincts seem to have been on the right side of the issue, but as a dutiful servant of the president, she wound up being the public face of bad policies. JONATHAN S. TOBIN, posted on commentary.com

''THERE are Russians, and then there are Russian ballerinas from the Kirov.'' So observes the narrator in ''The Cranes Dance,'' Meg Howrey's new novel about an emotionally unhinged soloist in a New York company. Ah, Americans and our fascination with dancers from the great European houses. You could replace ''Russian'' with ''French'' and ''Kirov'' with the ''PARIS OPERA BALLET'' and the sentence would work just as well, no? Especially as New Yorkers are now enjoying a marvelous treat: the Parisians have arrived at the Lincoln Center Festival (which has been on an international ballet kick; last year it was in fact the Kirov). You have one last chance, on Sunday, to catch the program of 20th-century French ballets by Serge Lifar, Roland Petit and Maurice Béjart. Then you have your choice of full-lengths. The (relatively) new is Pina Bausch's dance opera ''Orpheus and Eurydice,'' which was first performed by the Parisians in 2005, and the (very) old is, what else, ''Giselle,'' choreographed by Jean Coralli and Jules Perrot almost two centuries ago for the Paris Opera Ballet. Hmm. You might have to see both. Through July 22, David H. Koch Theater, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org.

Detroit, a city whose declining fortunes have led to a precipitous drop in population, has found itself awash in vacant land and buildings. Recently, a native of the city came up with a novel suggestion: hire pretend zombies to chase around paying customers in a theme park set among abandoned buildings. The zombie theme park, called Z World Detroit, is the brainchild of Marc Siwak, who began a grass-roots campaign on the Indiegogo Web site seeking financing for research to further refine the idea. Inspired partly by zombie movies, the park would take up roughly 200 acres and would involve navigating vacant buildings, homes and open space overnight while avoiding a zombie hoard whose ranks would grow as other paying customers fell prey to the undead and became zombies themselves.

To the Editor: Regarding ''36 Hours in Turin, Italy'' (July 1), by advising against visiting the Museo Nazionale del Cinema, you are depriving visitors of the opportunity to experience the world's most delightful film museum. No collection of cinema-related material is as joyfully displayed, and no other institution captures the sheer childlike pleasure of going to the movies. What a pity that your effort to promote hip spots in the city has robbed readers of culture. JAY WEISSBERG Rome

'There's a whole bunch of evidence here. And we're saying that the reasonable conclusion from that evidence is he was an integral part of this active decision to conceal. I regret that based on the damage that it does, obviously, to his legacy.' LOUIS J. FREEH,

GRALLA--Milton. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of its long time former member of the Yeshiva University Board of Trustees. He also served on the Boards of Sy Syms School of Business and Wurzweiler School of Social Work. Milton and Shirley Gralla have been generous supporters of Jewish education, medical research, and programs to assist Russian Jewish students. Milton and his wife Shirley, have been devoted for many years to building, expanding, and strengthening Jewish education institutions and to perpetuating and revitalizing the Jewish heritage around the world. To show YU's appreciation to this extraordinary couple, YU presented both Milton and Shirley, on separate occasions, honorary doctorates of Humane Letters. Heartfelt condolences to his wife and partner in Mitzvot, Shirley, their children Mr. and Mrs. Edward Gralla, Mr. and Mrs. Todd Galinko; Mr. and Mrs. Dennis Gralla; six grandchildren and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor

FOR fans of musical theater the summer has been mostly dispiriting, with an onslaught of closings on Broadway, the brilliant Audra McDonald on leave from ''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess'' for extended vocal rest (she has now returned to the show) and only the imminent arrival of ''Bring It On'' to brighten the immediate horizon. So perhaps a road trip is in order, for the eagerly anticipated ''FAR FROM HEAVEN,'' from the creative team behind ''Grey Gardens.'' The Williamstown Theater Festival is hosting what is being described as a preview production of the musical, based on the Todd Haynes movie that paid luscious homage to the heavy-breathing 1960s melodramas of Douglas Sirk. The score is by the ''Grey Gardens'' team of Scott Frankel and Michael Korie, and Michael Greif once again is directing. Kelli O'Hara plays the central role of the 1950s housewife who finds her orderly life suddenly fraught with peril. ''Far From Heaven'' is already on the docket for the coming season at Playwrights Horizons -- but can die-hard musical-theater lovers really bear to wait? I'm betting not, although you'd better act quickly: there are only 13 performances. Thursday through July 29, 1000 Main Street (Route 2), Williamstown, Mass., (413) 597-3400, wtfestival.org; $30 to $65.

May 2011, Fenghuang, Hunan, China Every three years, my mother, Jie Wang, and I take a trip to visit family in Beijing, where we emigrated from 20 years ago. We always try to make time to sneak off for a small adventure in a remote province. On our last trip, we spent a few quiet days getting lost amid the ancient stone streets and wooden stilt houses of Fenghuang, a beautiful town in Hunan Province. At dawn, the town is particularly charming and peaceful. Local women gathered to wash clothes in the Tuo River, and farmers jogged across stone bridges, carrying tools in bamboo baskets on their backs. My mother knows I shy away from posing for photos, so she stealthily snapped this shot while I crossed the river, one careful step at a time.

It was heartwarming to read that this edgy punk alumnus faces physical changes like other baby boomers do. While most of us try to walk or run without pain, Iggy Pop is still attempting stage dives. JULIENNE B. RYAN, Hartsdale, N.Y.

The cover article this weekend about travel advice from frequent travelers in Silicon Valley refers incompletely to the legal issues surrounding one such tip, by the author Tim Ferriss, who discussed packing a starter pistol and declaring it at check-in as a way to insure that a checked bag is not lost. While Transportation Security Administration rules allow such items if properly declared and locked, some local jurisdictions, including New York City, have stricter rules. (A spokesman for the New York Police Department said starter pistols are illegal without a permit.)

WHAT'S little known, and certainly unmentioned on the campaign trail, is what Barack Obama and Mitt Romney have in common. Both have family histories with polygamy. Both had fathers born in foreign countries. Both went to Harvard. Both are wealthy. Taken together, it's a narrow niche; there aren't enough rich Harvard grads with multiple-wife family albums and a bit of foreign otherness to fill the car elevators in Romney's beach manse. Which leaves both candidates working the margins of different demographic fields. Mormons and African-Americans are taken. Same with passionate liberals and fist-pumping conservatives. The rural vote is pretty much all Romney's, and urban hearts belong to Obama.

ROCKOFF--Alan (August 23, 1934 - July 13, 2012) of West Palm Beach, FL and Hinsdale, MA, formerly of White Plains, NY. Beloved Husband of Judith (nee Beagle.) Devoted father of William, Elizabeth, and David. Adoring grandfather of Andrew, Daniel, and Alexandra. Services will be held on Monday, July 16th, 2:30pm, at Star of David, West Palm Beach. Shiva will be observed at his home in West Palm Beach through Wednesday evening. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Leukemia Society would be appreciated.

TRAUB--Marvin S. Marvin was a splendid human being. He was a brilliant retailer who took Bloomingdale's from a mediocre, run-of-the-mill store and developed it into one of the most dynamic and exciting retailers in the world. But more importantly, he was a magnificent husband and father, who raised three wonderful children; Peggy, Jimmy, and Andy; and had many close friends and a personal life which was warm and intense. He and Lee maintained a great romance that lasted all his life. Marvin was kind and intelligent with a great passion for life. Dalia and I will miss our dear friend very much. Larry

An article last Sunday about the dark films of the director Robert Siodmak misspelled the name of a work by Wagner used in Mr. Siodmak's ''Christmas Holiday'' (1944). It is ''Liebestod,'' not ''Leibestod.''

An article last Sunday about the computer science program at the University of Washington misstated the amount of time that Christophe Bisciglia, an entrepreneur and engineer, taught a course there. It was three academic quarters, not semesters; the university uses a quarter system.

Fans of ''The Walking Dead'' on AMC can't wait for the start of Season 3 in October, but it's worth noting that the franchise has just hit a significant milestone. Issue No. 100 of the comic book, which the TV series is based on, has just been published. Written by Robert Kirkman, No. 100 features variant covers by comic book heavyweights like Frank Quitely (right) and Todd McFarlane -- a wrinkle sure to please fans attending the San Diego Comic-Con International, which ends today.

Friends and finance aren't always a great mix, which can make going Dutch on a group vacation a dicey affair. The new Web site Crowdtilt.com, however, simplifies matters by ensuring that the trip planner doesn't get stuck footing the bill. A traveler who wants to pool money for, say, a rental in London to see the Olympics (above) can create a page indicating the price per person and distribute the link to those invited. The Web site then solicits each traveler's credit card information and charges the trip only after the number of travelers required to foot the bill have submitted payment information. It bundles the payments and sends the organizer the funds electronically overnight, less a 2.5 percent fee.

LANG--Stephen R.,passed away on Thursday, July 12 at the age of 77 at home in Pawling, NY after a long, valiant battle with lung cancer. He was the beloved husband of 54 years of Audrey; devoted father of Donna Cunningham (Garland), Michele Blair (Scott), and Patricia Roer (Gregory). He was the adored "Idgie" to Spencer and Madison Blair and Matthew and Nicole Roer and Grandpa Steve to Katherine and Connor Cunningham. Born in Brooklyn on December 26, 1934, he was a graduate of Brooklyn College and Brooklyn Law School. He enjoyed a long, distinguished career practicing law at the US Department of Justice, Antitrust Division, Breed Abbott and Morgan and its successor firms, ending his career as Vice President and General Counsel of Carter-Wallace Inc. He will be missed forever.

VOGEL--Franzi (Leopold), born in Hamburg, Germany, passed away at home in Stamford CT, Friday, July 13th. She was 99. Devoted wife, wise mother, versatile artist, beautiful homemaker, Franzi's warmth and style touched many people; she was loved by all and will be deeply missed. Formerly of Croton-on-Hudson and Somers, NY, she is pre-deceased by her husband of 65 years, George Vogel MD, and survived by her children Susan (Seymour) Shelsky and Michael (Beth) Vogel; her grandson, Peter (Barbara) Shelsky; and great-grandchildren, Clementine and Ginger.

ROSS--Stuart G. April 10, 1920 -- July 14, 2010. It is two years since you left me, but not a day goes by that I don't miss you with all my heart. I shall love you forever and "always" and in "allways". Evelyn
GIDDINS--Abe. Taken from us fifty years ago, July 13, 1962, you are remembered every single day since then. Barry and Gayle

Reading John Jeremiah Sullivan on ''Absalom, Absalom!'' was like revisiting this ''greatest Southern novel ever written'' after a long hiatus. Faulkner may have broken every rule of creative writing, but he knew what he was doing. RUTH ROSS, West Orange, N.J.

The cartoonist Marjane Satrapi first made her name with her ''Persepolis'' graphic novels, but she is also a filmmaker. ''Chicken With Plums,'' based on her book and directed by Ms. Satrapi and Vincent Paronnaud, tells the tale of Nasser Ali Khan, an Iranian musician who gives up his life for music and love. It opens Aug. 17. Above are Golshifteh Farahani as Irâne and Mathieu Amalric as Nasser Ali.

7:28 p.m. | Updated A fire at the South Street Seaport sent plumes of black smoke billowing over Lower Manhattan on Saturday afternoon, obscuring the Brooklyn Bridge and causing hundreds of people to flee the crowded shopping pavilion at Pier 17. The three-alarm fire began shortly before 4 p.m. and was concentrated around the pier, according to the police and fire officials. It seemed to be under control by 5 p.m. and there were no immediate reports of injuries, the officials said.

THE NEW MUSEUM is always at its best in group theme shows, at least if the curator Massimiliano Gioni has anything to do with them. Last summer his show ''Ostalgia,'' a survey of contemporary art from former Soviet-bloc countries, was one of the best exhibitions in the city in 2011. This summer's ''GHOSTS IN THE MACHINE,'' which opens Wednesday and runs through Sept. 30, could have comparable status. Covering a half-century of work by some 70 artists, largely from Europe and the United States, it considers the interrelationship of humans and machines. For the occasion Mr. Gioni and his co-curator, Gary Carrion-Murayari, will give physical form to imaginary devices cooked up by the likes of Kafka and Roussel. They will assemble some of the components of the outsider artist Emery Blagdon's healing environment, originally built on his Nebraska farm. And they will consider the many varieties of optical experience that went into the creation of Op Art. Given the dominance of digital technology today, an exhibition theme that might have sounded science-fictional a few decades ago seems completely reality-based now. 235 Bowery, at Prince Street, Lower East Side, (212) 219-1222, newmuseum.org.

A VIDEO posted to YouTube on Monday, in which the driver Ken Block maneuvers a 650-horsepower Ford Fiesta in San Francisco, accumulated about 12 million views by Thursday. Block and his producers were given the run of the city's streets and the Oakland Bay Bridge. With its seams well-hidden, little would suggest the 10-minute movie came together over four days of shooting in May.

STRAUSS--Armar A.,age 81, passed away suddenly from coronary complications on July 2nd at his home in Pacific Palisades, California. Two of his dearest friends were with him at the time. Everyone who met Armar-a wise and caring physician, loyal friend, and generous donor to liberal causes and those in need-could not help being touched by his concern for their own well-being. His generosity, ready laugh and good counsel will be hugely missed. He is survived by sister Lydia ("Witty"), brother Chris and daughter Irit. Dr Strauss had long insisted that no service be held for him; only that his ashes be carried back to Japan and interred alongside those of his late beloved wife, Umeko.

It's one of those secrets you normally don't learn in nursing school: ''Don't go to the hospital in July.'' That's the month when medical residents, newly graduated from medical school, start learning how to be doctors, and they learn by taking care of patients. And learning means making mistakes. There's disagreement in the medical literature about whether a so-called July Effect, where medical error rates increase in the summer, actually exists. But a 2010 article in the Journal of General Internal Medicine and a 2011 article in the Annals of Internal Medicine both found evidence of it. In an interview, Dr. John Q. Young, lead author of the latter review, likened the deployment of new residents to having rookies replace seasoned football players during ''a high-stakes game, and in the middle of that final drive.''

An article last Sunday about the contralto Kathleen Ferrier at the centennial of her birth, in citing a 1955 review in The New York Times, misstated the given name of the critic for The Times who wrote the review. As the byline on the archived article correctly noted, he was Howard Taubman, not Harold. The article also described incorrectly recording projects pegged to the centennial. EMI has released her complete recordings on that label, not her entire recorded oeuvre. And Decca has released a centenary edition with 14 CDs, not just a new film that explores her life.
''Rolling in the Deep,'' Adele Misheard lyric: Making a hoedown there, his manager won't be shaved.

An article on May 6 about the German artist Michael Riedel misspelled the surname of his collaborator on their version of the Frieze Art Fair catalog. He is Dennis Löesch, not Lösch. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail on June 15; this correction was delayed because The Times failed to follow through on the complaint.

AT an estimated cost of $15 billion to the British government, the Olympics will begin this month in London -- the first to be held there since 1948. Residents of cities that host the Olympics always debate whether all the security concerns, congestion and expense are worth the joys of basking -- albeit only briefly -- in the world's spotlight. But one particular group is decidedly in favor of these London games: the shop owners who are already profiting by selling tons of memorabilia tied to the events, including boxed commemorative coins, above, and various incarnations of those official, one-eyed London 2012 mascots, Wenlock and Mandeville.
LEWIS--Nancy. 1952-2001 Adventurer, caring doctor, loving daughter, sister. So very much missed! Mom, Amy, Tracy

IMAGINE you're the closest living relative of a child who just inherited $100 million after her parents died in a car crash. You're a distant cousin, but if something happened to her, you'd be next in line. She has juvenile diabetes. So you ''adjust'' her insulin prescription a bit yourself, doubling the dose. When that doesn't work, you tell her a different drug works just as well, and when she's reluctant, you offer her a trip to Disney World.

THE members of ALARM WILL SOUND, a dynamic new-music chamber orchestra formed in 2001 by graduates of the Eastman School of Music, trace their involvement with John Cage's circuslike magnum opus ''Song Books'' back to their student days. Now they are mounting an elaborately staged version of the work -- conceived, designed and directed by Nigel Maister with musical direction by Rob Haskins -- to conclude this year's River to River Festival. 7:30 p.m. Sunday, Schimmel Center for the Arts, 3 Spruce Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 219-9401, rivertorivernyc.com; free. Occupying what might be the opposite end of the aesthetic spectrum, ''I Capuleti e i Montecchi,'' Bellini's version of the Romeo and Juliet story, has a relatively rare outing as part of the BEL CANTO AT CARAMOOR series. As ever, the conductor Will Crutchfield has assembled an estimable company: Eglise Gutiérrez as Giulietta, Kate Aldrich as Romeo, Leonardo Capalbo as Tebaldo and, behind it all, the Orchestra of St. Luke's. 8 p.m. Saturday, 149 Girdle Ridge Road, Katonah, N.Y., (914) 232-1252, caramoor.org; $15 to $100.

Victor Cruz's rise from undrafted free agent to elite receiver in the N.F.L. is inspiring. But he may be best known for his salsa end-zone celebration, which had the ultimate showcase during the Giants' Super Bowl victory in February. It is even mimicked by his avatar in the Madden 13 video game. This is a busy month for Cruz, 25. His autobiography, ''Out of the Blue,'' written with Peter Schrager, will be released Tuesday, and training camp opens July 26. Q.

AS my colleague Matthew L. Wald noted on Wednesday, a filling station west of Kansas City, Kan., recently began pumping E15, the fuel blend of 15 percent ethanol and 85 percent gasoline. The formulation was approved for use by the Environmental Protection Agency late in 2010. Though the government cannot compel filling stations to stock the fuel, the Energy Department frames the use of E15 as falling within its broader objective of reducing petroleum imports. (The ethanol is produced primarily from corn grown in the United States.) However, the cost and efficiency benefits for the fuel's end user are not so apparent. As Mr. Wald wrote, ''Some car experts say that the savings are illusory, because a gallon of ethanol has only about two-thirds as much energy as a gallon of gasoline, so it will take a car fewer miles on a gallon.''

CHAMONIX-MONT-BLANC, France -- With the sun rising around 5 a.m. on Thursday, about 30 climbers reached a delicate passage high in the French Alps and slowed, closing ranks. It was then, without warning, that Mont Maudit -- the Cursed Mountain, in French -- lived up to its name. ''Suddenly the snow came,'' Daniel Rossetto, a veteran Chamonix mountain guide, said in a telephone interview from his hospital bed. ''It kept coming. We couldn't see anything. It was like being in a washing machine.''

PROWLER--Robert Hudes. January 3, 1923-July 10, 2012, was born in Brooklyn and attended James Madison High School and St. John's University. After serving on Okinawa in World War II he worked for many years on Madison Avenue and lived in Malverne, NY. Bob edited the Malverne Times community newspaper, was treasurer of the Malverne Historical Society, fed the homeless in a Long Beach shelter and was on the board of Amnesty International's local Chapter. He had a sharp but gentle wit and in moments could turn you into a friend for life. He is survived by wife Joan, sons Gilbert (Mindy) and David (Simone Perez), grandchildren Brienna, Alyssa, and Joey and mourned by many friends and family. The Memorial will be Sunday, July 22 at 10am at the Malverne Funeral Home, 330 Hempstead Avenue, Malverne, NY.

MAY--Bernard J.,(Bernie), passed away peacefully on July 6, 2012 following a struggle with tonsil cancer. He was 68. Born in Brooklyn, raised in Queens, he returned to New York, the city he loved, as an adult. He was a 1961 graduate of Bayside High School, and in 1965 graduated from Miami University in Oxford, OH. He served from 1965 through 1967 in the Peace Corps as a secondary school teacher in rural Thailand. He returned to attend Clark University, Worcester, MA for graduate studies in Geography and embarked on a long corporate career, largely in Real Estate. After 25 years, he retired in 2007 from Merrill Lynch as a Director of Real Estate Risk Management. He is survived by his beloved wife of 44 years, Suzanne (Lutz) and his loving son, Christopher, 36, of Denver. Other survivors include cousins Marjorie Sullivan O'Brien, Monica Ericsson Jonson and Ann-Christen Ericsson. A Memorial Service will be held at All Souls Unitarian Church. Contributions in Bernie's memory can be made to the Star Island Corporation, Portsmouth, NH or the Carl Schurz Park Conservancy, New York, NY.

TAYLOR--Carol Lee, 78, died on July 10, 2012 from cancer in a nursing home in Greenport, Long Island near her home in Orient, NY. She grew up in Bedford, NY, went to Chatham Hall in Virginia and Vassar College. While at Vassar she joined a very popular singing group called The G Stringers which appeared on The Arthur Godfrey Show. She formed a singing group in Orient called The Narrow River Singers which was also very popular. Carol first worked for Time, Inc and then for The National Audubon Society in New York where she produced several movies that were shown around the country and in New York City. She received many rewards for her work at Audubon. She is survived by her brother, Winfield Taylor, Jr and three nieces, Nancy Lynn Jaffer, Frances Alvino and Joanne Jaffer.

GoDaddy recently surprised Madison Avenue by hiring an advertising agency to develop a more professional image for the company, which became notorious for commercials, created internally, that featured scantily clad ''GoDaddy Girls'' and double entendres. A commercial that is the first work for the client from the agency, Deutsch New York, suggests that GoDaddy is trying to grow up in a hurry. The commercial for GoDaddy, which registers Internet domain names and is a Web hosting provider, is to start running during the NBC coverage of the Summer Olympics. The spot includes a barely dressed woman, but she is treated in a tongue-in-cheek manner. ''Behold Charlene,'' intones an announcer. ''Charlene is how GoDaddy attracts domain name customers.''

Dear Diary: I rarely if ever wear a wristwatch. When I am walking with friends I often ask what the time is, to my friends' great annoyance. New York City, however, has come to my rescue with the installation of the Muni-Meters. These wonderful boxes appear on every block and contain a window with the current time.

McCALL--James Wilson James Wilson McCall, of Hillsborough, California, on July 13, 2012, after a courageous struggle with cancer. Jim was the beloved husband of Jennifer Jordan McCall; devoted father of Peter Lewis Livingston McCall and Andrew James McCall; stepfather of Caroline Debevoise Clark and Hillary Sage Clark; son of Lewis Livingston McCall, Jr. and Dixann Wilson McCall; and brother of Mary Margaret McCall. Jim was knowledgeable in many subjects from sports, to history, politics, photography, music and Formula 1 racing. Jim was an avid reader, particularly of American history and international relations. Jim was always fun to be with. An entertaining conversationalist, Jim's wit and humor will be deeply missed. His family and friends admired him greatly for his insight and sensitivity, and for his thoughtfulness, modesty and courage. Jim set an example with his intellectual curiosity, dynamic yet gentlemanly manner and high moral character. He was a trusted advisor to many, and a loyal friend. Jim especially enjoyed advising his four children, and was proud that all four of them attended Princeton University. Jim took special pride in his sons and their accomplishments, both in sports and academics. Born in Norman, Oklahoma March 10, 1953, Jim graduated from the University of Oklahoma in 1974 with a B.A. in Letters with Honors, in History, Philosophy and English. Jim completed his undergraduate degree in five semesters, was a member of Phi Beta Kappa and was a Rhodes Scholar nominee from the State of Oklahoma. Jim earned a J.D. from the University of Oklahoma in 1977, where he was a member of the Law Review. In 1974 Jim attended Oxford University as a Scholarship Resident at University College in Economics. Jim earned his M.B.A. in 1984 from Harvard Business School and served as a member of the Faculty Judicial Review Board. Jim's work experience included McKinsey, Goldman Sachs and Security Pacific/Bank of America Venture Capital Group. Jim joined Intel Corporation in Santa Clara, California in 1997 where he remained to the present. He became an Assistant Treasurer for Mergers, Acquisitions & Strategic Investments and Managing Director, Digital Enterprise and Digital Home for Intel Capital Corporation, the venture capital arm of Intel. Jim was a talented athlete and sports enthusiast throughout his life. As a thirteen-year-old, Jim shot even par in a golf tournament; in high school he played football, golf and ran track, holding the State of Oklahoma record for the 220- and 440-yard dash. At the University of Oklahoma Jim played golf and followed professional baseball. Jim's love of golf stayed with him throughout his life. Jim was a member of the San Francisco Golf Club and Burlingame Country Club, San Francisco, the Merion Golf Club, Ardmore, Pennsylvania and The Creek Club, Locust Valley, New York. Jim's family and friends loved to play golf with him, not only because of his entertaining and friendly manner, but also because of his shot-making finesse. Jim gently offered tips to those who requested them, and was always a patient teacher. Jim was keenly devoted to his family and to the memory of his predecessors. Jim was a proud member of The Society of the Cincinnati, whose members are descendants of the Officers who served in General George Washington's Revolutionary Army. He belonged to The Society of Colonial Wars, The General Society Sons of the American Revolution, The Order of St. John of Jerusalem, the General Society of the War of 1812, the Order of Indian Wars of the United States, and the Aztec Club of 1847 Military Society of the Mexican War. Jim's warmth, enthusiasm, and intellect will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, July 17, 2012 at 4:00 p.m. at First Presbyterian Church of Burlingame, 1500 Easton Drive, Burlingame, CA 94010. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Cancer Center, Stanford University Medical Center, 875 Blake Wilbur Drive, Stanford, CA 94305, ATTN: Dr. Sandy Srinivas for research in kidney cancer.

BERNSTEIN--Roberta. The Executive Committee and membership of the Small Property Owners of NY, (SPONY), mourns with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed President, Roberta Bernstein. She was a true titan of the real estate industry in that she galvanized a group of small owners and led them to get much needed relief for owners, large and small, in the courts and in NY government. She created and held SPONY together for 26 years. She was deeply admired and respected by all her membership. Her passing is a sad day for us and a tremendous loss for every small property owner in New York.

Dear Diary: As I sat in the subway at rush hour with nothing to do, I playfully scrolled through the various ringtones on my iPhone. I suddenly realized the train had reached my stop, Grand Central, and I hurried out to catch the Metro-North train home. As usual, I walked down the Metro-North platform to get to the first car, known as the quiet car, so that I could read my Kindle in silence. I sat down opposite two men who proceeded to chat about mutual acquaintances.

Bringing clubs on the subway is something most city golfers do at some point, even if they're escaping the city to play. Joe Saladino, a two-time Metropolitan Golf Association Player of the Year and co-owner of Drive 495, the golf-focused fitness club in SoHo, has some good memories of riding the rails. ''I used to take the subway up to Penn Station and then take the train out to Long Island to play,'' he says. ''And I remember whenever I saw someone else with clubs on the train, it was like a little fraternity. Sometimes we'd give a little nod. It's like you don't know the person, but you know what they're up to.''

An article on Wednesday about Robert Nkemdiche, the top-ranked football recruit who committed to Clemson but created a stir when he said he would consider attending another university if Clemson did not offer a scholarship to his friend, misspelled, in some editions, the surname of a professor of sport management at Drexel University. She is Dr. Ellen Staurowsky, not Staurosky.

They can stream music, make restaurant reservations, and offer distractions for ornery children. But few things in life are free - least of all applications. Two new reports this week reveal how app developers are scooping up enormous amounts of data from mobile devices and serving up ads in unlikely places. Advertising revenues have long been the oil that greases the Internet. Mobile apps are its new frontier. Both reports nudge application developers to adopt standards for data collection and advertising.

Dear Diary: While I was on my way from Jackson Heights to Lower Manhattan a few weeks ago on the R subway line, one of those ubiquitous small-item vendors came through the car, loudly calling out: ''Yo-yos, Rubik's cubes! One dollar only!'' As he had some buyers - including me - he happily dispensed his wares from a large shopping bag he was carrying.

9 P.M. (HBO) BIRDERS: THE CENTRAL PARK EFFECT (2012) Each year more than a million birds stop in Central Park as they migrate through the area in the spring and the fall. And without fail several hundred birders are there to take in the sight. In this documentary the first-time filmmaker Jeffrey Kimball explores this phenomenon across four years through the stories of those who find joy in creatures ''so alive, active, varied and beautiful,'' says Anya, a 15-year-old birder, who is shown alongside obsessives like Jonathan Franzen, the author of ''Freedom'' (which features a cerulean warbler on its cover), and Starr Saphir, considered the matriarch of Central Park bird-watching. Mr. Kimball also speaks to scientists, who call the concentration of birds there ''the Central Park effect,'' and who, each Christmas season, attempt to count every bird in the park to produce the annual report of birds in decline, which now includes nearly a quarter of all species. (Above, a black-and-white warbler in the program.) In ''The Tsunami and the Cherry Blossom,'' an Oscar-nominated documentary short to be shown at 10, Lucy Walker looks at how cherry-blossom season inspired some survivors of the 2011 tsunami in Japan to rebuild their lives. ''Each flower is tiny, and you can't see one individually,'' a man says, explaining how the cherry blossom reflects the national character. ''But it's beautiful when you see lots of flowers together. Japanese people see themselves that way too.'' 2 P.M. (FX) MADAGASCAR: ESCAPE 2 AFRICA (2008) Ben Stiller, Chris Rock, David Schwimmer and Jada Pinkett Smith reprise their roles as the voices of a group of New York zoo animals -- a lion, a yakety zebra, a neurotic giraffe and a voluptuous hippo -- that crash-land their rickety plane in Africa in this animated sequel. Sacha Baron Cohen does a turn as a deranged lemur, Bernie Mac plays a lion's lion, and Alec Baldwin chimes in as the resident bad guy. In ''Ice Age: The Meltdown'' (2006), at 4, Manny (the voice of Ray Romano), Sid (John Leguizamo) and Diego (Denis Leary) high-tail it out of their melting homeland and meet Ellie (Queen Latifah), a female woolly mammoth who thinks she's a possum.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. -- The Subway to the Sea, a train that would tunnel more than 15 miles from downtown Los Angeles to the Pacific Ocean, has encountered no shortage of obstacles over the years: from how to pay for it to skepticism about a huge mass transit project in a region that once ripped out trolley car tracks to make way for automobiles. Now, a new impediment has stepped onto the tracks: Beverly Hills High School.
Dear Diary: Setting: Capezzi Pizza and Wine Bar across Ninth Avenue from the Port Authority Bus Terminal. Time: July 4, about half an hour before the Macy's fireworks display.

CRANE--David L. Age 90, of West Palm Beach FL, and recently of Dalton MA, passed away on July 6, 2012. Son of Aaron and Hannah Cohen, David was a native New Yorker. Often regaling his children with Runyonesque tales of his West Side childhood, he witnessed the building of the George Washington Bridge and he played street baseball with neighborhood boys. Babe Ruth tossed an occasional ball with them. Always a rascal, David once happened upon New York City Police routing a gang; he stayed to watch the firefight. However, he neglected to mention this to his parents who later saw a newspaper photo of the raid; young David was perched just outside of the line of fire. David attended the University of Illinois and served in the US Army during WWII. He co-founded Timpson, Kramer and Crane, a successful food brokerage business in the mid-60s. A lifelong Republican, he was surrounded by a family of staunch Democrats, providing fodder for his love of boisterous political argument. Above all else, David valued family, friends and a good party. When his final illness robbed him of his voice, he joined in a raucous dinner by whispering a joke to one of his daughters line by line so that she could broadcast it to the clan. His beloved wife, Carol, his daughters, Susan Crane (Terry Etapa), Andrea Crane-Rabe, and Nancy Crane (Tom Butler), his brother Gerald (Joan), his grandsons Eric and Dan Rabe (Paula), and numerous nephews and nieces survive him. When asked what he wanted his obituary to say David retorted: "Tell anyone who owes me money to send it to Carol."

At first glance, the urban jungle of New York might seem an inhospitable place for golf. But look again. There go two guys, clubs draped over their shoulders, hustling across West 34th Street and into Pennsylvania Station. A teenager rides the subway on a summer weekday to a nine-hole course in the Bronx, trading in his backpack for a golf bag. Farther downtown, members of a golf-focused fitness club enter a loft building in SoHo and receive instruction from P.G.A. professionals in a high-tech simulator.

Mark Teixeira's two-run homer in the ninth inning Sunday was not enough to get the Yankees back into the game, but it did make him the first American League player to do any damage against Ernesto Frieri, the Los Angeles Angels' breakout closer. Teixeira's hit was only the ninth that Frieri has allowed in 27 games for the Angels; amazingly, it was the first for extra bases.

It took 66 years for the British Open, first contested in 1860, to find its way to Royal Lytham & St. Annes Golf Club, south of Blackpool and north of Liverpool on England's western coast. By 1926, recent course improvements, including a laborious project to tear up the grass to expose the sandy subsoil in hundreds of places, had made Royal Lytham & St. Annes newly worthy in the eyes of the British golf establishment. It may have taken more than half a century for the British Open to be played at Royal Lytham & St. Annes, but the championship was forever changed that year as Bobby Jones won his first British Open in a stirring finish memorable for a wondrous shot. And for the next several decades, Royal Lytham & St. Annes -- increasingly notable for its sand (200-plus bunkers or roughly 11 a hole) -- seemed to have a definable quality for anointing celebrated champions.

Dearly loved by wife Pat and their pet "Gilda", his late parents, Bernard and Rose, his late siblings, Ann and Joseph, brother-in-law Martin Smolin, sister-in-law Marcia, sister-and-brother-in-law Kathleen and Gary Rosen, niece Naomi Rabkin (Michael), nephew Rabbi Daniel Braune Friedman (Hannah), nephew John Smolin, niece Ada Harverd (Dan), and grand nieces and nephew, friends, and the family's pets. A wizard with computers, acrostics, chess and musical instruments. See him play:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9ea1MfAiPW4. Funeral Tuesday July 17, 2012 at 12:30. Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway, Fair Lawn, NJ, 201-791-0015. Please make donations to: St. Hubert's Animal Welfare Center, www.sthuberts.org or MAZON mazonmail@mazon.org

Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman said Sunday that he believed it would be ''difficult to improve this roster'' with any moves before the July 31 nonwaiver trade deadline, suggesting that baseball's biggest spender may stand pat at the normally frenetic deadline date for the second year in a row. ''We have a championship-caliber team,'' Cashman said before Sunday's game against the Los Angeles Angels. ''We have strengths in every aspect of the roster.''

10:43 p.m. | Updated GlaxoSmithKline of Britain is near a deal to buy the biopharmaceutical company Human Genome Sciences on friendly terms for about $2.8 billion, potentially ending a long hostile takeover campaign, a person briefed on the matter said on Sunday. Under the new terms of the deal, GlaxoSmithKline would pay about $14 a share in cash, this person said.

ROTHKOPF--Ernst Z.,died peacefully at his home in Summit, N.J. on July 15, 2012. He was 86 years old. Born in Vienna, Austria he escaped the Holocaust and served in the 88th Infantry Division, 913 Field Artillery as an officer in World War II. He was a distinguished alumnus of Syracuse University and the University of Connecticut where he received his doctorate. After many years as head of the Learning and Instructional Processes Department at Bell Telephone Laboratories he went on to become the Cleveland E. Dodge Professor of Telecommunications and Education at Columbia University Teacher's College. Dr. Rothkopf wrote over 100 significant articles on educational psychology and developed the theory of mathmagenic behavior that aided in the understanding of learner's internal transformation of instructional content. He served as the president of Division 15 (educational psychology) of the American Psychological Association and was the winner of the Edward Lee Thorndike Award. Devoted husband of Carol Zeman Rothkopf and adored father of David, Paul and Marissa and father-in-law to Mark Bates and Adrean Scheid Rothkopf he is the grandfather of Cate and Oliver Bates and Joanna and Laura Rothkopf.

SCHIFF--Sara Kreisler, 57, on July 14. Loving wife of Carl. Wonderful mother of Jessica and Stephanie. Despite struggling with many illnesses for many years Sara remained cheerful and optimistic and led a full life as a wife, mother, homemaker, and nurse practitioner. She had a special "sparkle" and all who met her loved her. Sara will be dearly missed by her family and many devoted friends.

GRALLA--Milton. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of a cherished member of its extended family. Milton, together with his beloved Shirley, his partner in life and philanthropy, endowed BTJ's Shirley and Milton Gralla National Junior High School, giving countless youngsters from disadvantaged circumstances the gift of hope and opportunity. Milton, a valued member of Boys Town's Board of Directors, not only shared his wisdom, but also inspired others to follow his example of selfless philanthropy. Milton is sorely missed, but never to be forgotten. Heartfelt condolences to his loving wife Shirley, children and grandchildren. Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean, Josh S. Weston, Hon Chrmn Michael J. Scharf, President, Robert Kaswell, Chairman, Rabbi Ronald Gray, EX VP

The numbers are in from the PC industry's main scorekeepers -- the research firms IDC and Gartner -- and it looks as if one of the great growth hopes for the industry, ultrabooks, again failed to deliver. On Wednesday evening, both IDC and Gartner reported that worldwide PC shipments fell 0.1 percent in the second quarter from a year ago, a poor showing for an industry that has been searching for a growth stimulant. As in the past, there are a bunch of factors accounting for the stagnation of the PC business, including consumers who seem far more enamored with getting the latest smartphones and iPads than they are with buying PCs.

An article on Friday about divisions among House Republicans on overhauling the nation's nutrition and farm program misstated the surname of the president of the New York Farm Bureau, who would like to see action before the November elections. He is Dean Norton, not North.

Dear Diary: Dad had a thing for Bethesda Fountain. Mom loved any reason for getting out of our tiny apartment on East 83rd Street. Our countless adventures in Central Park always included a pass through the plaza and a stroll down Poet's Walk. Fifty-one years ago, August 1961, Dad; Mom; my brother, Rory, 5; and I, 7, death-marched through Central Park on a miserable 100 degree day. Fed up with the heat, Rory and I tortured our parents into letting us swim in Bethesda Fountain. They gave in, sick of our whining. We stripped down to our briefs and vaulted over the stone into the water.

THE poem ''The New Colossus'' by Emma Lazarus describes how the Statue of Liberty in New York Harbor asks for ''your tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free,'' along with ''the wretched refuse of your teeming shore'' and ''the homeless, tempest-tost.'' The poem says nothing about small, sporty Italian cars.

It's easy enough to get directions on a phone when outdoors -- but try finding your way around the mall. Soon, you may be able to pull up your location on an indoor map using a new mobile technology. The indoor location technology, which was developed by researchers at the University of Oulu in Finland, uses a smartphone's built-in compass, or magnetometer, to scan for variations in the Earth's magnetic field inside a structure. The information is transmitted to an online server for analysis, and then stitched together into a virtual landscape of the building.

EAGAN, Minn. -- It was four years ago this summer, when Tim Pawlenty ranked high on the list of John McCain's potential running mates, and Mr. Pawlenty and his wife, Mary, were plowing through a voluminous questionnaire probing deep into their finances and almost every other aspect of their lives. ''I remember the two of us joking one night at some inhumane hour, 'No way is Mitt Romney doing this by himself!' '' Mr. Pawlenty later wrote in his book. ''We had a good laugh over that.''

Today, the only sign that cash once flowed bountifully at 104 West 45th Street is the address the same as it was then? is a sleek bank branch on the ground floor of a black glass skyscraper. A century ago, the nondescript high-stooped brownstone that stood there masked a more pretentious interior. The lavish red-carpeted second floor was dominated by a cabinet of Japanese curios, copies of masterpiece paintings and expensive faro and custom-built roulette tables.

LONDON - British regulators will face further scrutiny for their role in a rate-manipulation scandal when top officials at the Financial Services Authority testify on Monday before Parliament. Lawmakers in London and Washington have been pressing regulators over what they view as a failure to address problems with the process for setting benchmark interest rates. British politicians are expected to ask regulatory officials when they were first notified about potential issues, and why they did not stop the activities.

As the creator and show runner of ''Breaking Bad,'' Vince Gilligan is charged with thinking up the most elaborate criminal capers he can imagine. It's the responsibility of everyone else on the show actually to pull them off. Take, for example, this scenario from Sunday's fifth-season premiere of that darkly comic AMC series: the increasingly nefarious Albuquerque drug lord Walter White (played by Bryan Cranston) and his accomplices Jesse Pinkman (Aaron Paul) and Mike Ehrmantraut (Jonathan Banks) realize that a laptop computer containing incriminating video footage has ended up in police custody.

TYNION--Julann C. (nee Callahan) on July 15, 2012. Lady Grand Cross of the Holy Sepulchre, Extraordinary Minister of Holy Communion and member of the Ladies of Charity, Julann was the beloved wife of the late Donald W. Tynion and fond "mother" to his son William F. Tynion and his wife Linda. Dear sister of the late Patricia Booth and James D. Callahan (killed in action during the Korean War). An article in some editions on Wednesday about a plan by DreamWorks Animation to bring its animated movie characters to a planned amusement park in the New Jersey Meadowlands referred incorrectly to some other places for proposed studio parks. It never announced plans for Abu Dhabi, and it is still working on plans for China. It is not the case that the studio's ''earlier plans'' for parks in China and Abu Dhabi ''failed to work out.'' (As the article correctly noted, DreamWorks's plan for a park in Dubai did not materialize.)

TRUTH--Edward. Beloved husband, father, uncle, and Zeyde (and all-around nice guy), formerly of Long Beach, NY. He is survived by his widow Hannah (Pelzig) Truth; two daughters, Debbie Blank and Sarah (John) Bonora; and three granddaughters, Jessica, Jenny (Adam) and Rachel. He also leaves behind a large extended family and many friends. A lifelong New Yorker, he loved music (especially opera), art, cooking, the Yankees and the New York Times crossword. Services July 17, noon, at Parkside Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd.

Moviegoer response to ''Ice Age: Continental Drift'' was a tad chilly. This fourth installment in 20th Century Fox's ''Ice Age'' franchise took in about $46 million in North America over the weekend, a No. 1 finish at the box office and on par with Fox's expectations. But ''Continental Drift'' also lacked the ticket-selling sizzle of its predecessor in this series, with franchise fatigue and competition from other animated movies the most likely explanation. ''Continental Drift'' is the third big cartoon release of the summer, arriving behind ''Brave'' and ''Madagascar 3: Europe's Most Wanted,'' both of which took in $60 million or more over their first three days. Perhaps reflecting its title, ''Continental Drift'' has been much stronger overseas, racking up a huge $339 million in ticket sales, according to Fox. ''The Amazing Spider-Man'' (Sony) was second for the weekend in North America, taking in an estimated $35 million for a two-week total of $200.9 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data.

Watching Robin Roberts tear up in front of millions of viewers on ''Good Morning America'' last month, I cried, too. With equal measures of courage and fear, Ms. Roberts, an anchor of the show and a breast cancer survivor, explained that the life-saving treatment she received five years ago was responsible for a new diagnosis, this time myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), a rare blood and bone marrow disease once called preleukemia.

An article on Monday about growing competition in the market for tablet computers misspelled, in some editions, the surname of a spokesman for Amazon, which makes the Kindle devices. He is Drew Herdener, not Herdner.

Iron supplements are often recommended as a treatment for fatigue in women, but evidence of their effect has been scarce. Now a randomized trial suggests that for certain women, these supplements do help. French researchers studied 198 menstruating women ages 18 to 53 who complained of fatigue but were otherwise healthy. They all had ferritin levels less than 50 micrograms per liter, at the lower end of normal. (Ferritin is a protein that binds to iron.) Half took 80 milligrams of iron daily, and the other half a placebo. The researchers measured fatigue using a validated questionnaire at the start and end of the study.

Last year's Encores! production of ''Cotton Club Parade,'' a musical revue about the celebrated Harlem nightclub during the Duke Ellington years, will return for a limited run from Nov. 14-18 at City Center, the show's producers announced on Monday. Most of the cast will return for the production, which again will be directed and choreographed by Warren Carlyle (''Hugh Jackman: Back on Broadway'') and will have music direction by Wynton Marsalis, Jazz at Lincoln Center's artistic director. Music will be provided by the Jazz at Lincoln Center All Stars, directed by Daryl Waters. Conceived by Jack Viertel, the song-and-dance show features jazz, blues and swing standards of the 1920s and '30s written by several composers, including Jimmy McHugh and the lyricist Dorothy Fields (''I Can't Give You Anything But Love''), Harold Arlen (''Stormy Weather,'' ''I've Got the World on a String''), and Duke Ellington (''Rockin' in Rhythm,'' ''Cotton Club Stomp''). The show received mostly positive reviews when it ran for six performances last November. Stephen Holden, in his review for The Times, called it a ''thrilling 90-minute celebration'' that ''made period jazz come to life with a focused intensity and rhythmic savvy.''

9:06 p.m. | Updated Marissa Mayer, one of the top executives at Google, will be the next chief of Yahoo, making her one of the most prominent women in Silicon Valley and corporate America. The appointment of Ms. Mayer is consider a coup for Yahoo, which has struggled in recent years to attract top talent in its battle with competitors. One of the few public faces of Google, Ms. Mayer, 37, has been responsible for the look and feel of some of the search company's most popular products.

In addition to its other benefits, a low-fat diet may also reduce menopausal hot flashes and night sweats, new research has found. Scientists studied 17,473 menopausal women who were not on hormone therapy. Forty percent were assigned to a low-fat dietary plan with increased intake of fruits, vegetables and whole grains. They met periodically with nutritionists to assure compliance. The rest ate their customary diets. All participants recorded night sweats and hot flashes with details about their severity.

10 P.M. (13, 49) FAST TIMES AT WEST PHILLY HIGH ''Frontline'' visits West Philadelphia High School, a public school serving one of the city's poorest neighborhoods, as students and teachers, above, build two superhybrid cars for an international competition and the chance to become part of a technological revolution. The prize for building an affordable car that gets 100 miles to the gallon: $10 million. Another segment, ''The Middle School Moment,'' looks at the theory that middle school may determine who drops out of high school and who stays the course. 10:35 A.M. (HBO Signature) 127 HOURS (2010) In April 2003, Aron Ralston, a 27-year-old hiker, fell in a narrow slot in Blue John Canyon in Utah and was trapped, his right arm pinned beneath a boulder. For five days he struggled to free himself, narrating his plight into a small video camera and reflecting on the mistakes that landed him in this mess -- not least, neglecting to tell anyone where he was going. Faced with the increasing prospect of death, Mr. Ralston decided to amputate his immobilized arm using the blade of a cheap multipurpose tool. James Franco earned an Academy Award nomination for his turn as Mr. Ralston in this film by Danny Boyle, which A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, called ''nearly flawless.'' There are scenes, he added, ''that are hard to bear -- the cracking of a bone, the severing of a nerve, the desperate consumption of a water bag filled with urine -- but what these moments communicate is more than worth a jolt of discomfort or a spasm of revulsion. To say that this movie gets under your skin is only barely a figure of speech. It pins you down, shakes you up and leaves you glad to be alive.''

An article on Thursday about a visit by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton to Laos misstated the origin of more than 580,000 bombing missions over that country during the Vietnam War, citing the text on a map at an artificial-limb center where Mrs. Clinton spent several hours. The missions were carried out by several branches of the American military, not just by the Air Force. The article also described incorrectly the bombs that were dropped, many of which remain as a deadly problem in rural areas of Laos. Several types of bombs were used; not all were cluster bombs.

MARSHALL--George M. 92, former resident of New Canaan, CT and retired senior vice president of the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company of NY in charge of international operations, died on May 7, 2012 at home in Orland, ME. Born in Brooklyn, NY in 1919, he went to sea at the age of 17, inspired by his sea captain grandfather Christopher Marsden of Elmhurst, Queens and Southold, L.I. From 1938 to 1946 he served in the U.S. Merchant Marine and was one of the youngest shipmasters in WWII at the age of 24. Captain Marshall was a graduate of the U.S. MMA at Kings Point (1942) and New York University (1951). His 30-year career with Atlantic Mutual began in 1946 and led to assignments in Mexico, Canada and Europe. Professional affiliations include the Council of American Master Mariners, Marine Society of the City of NY, and the Navy League. In 1976 he embarked on a second career with Maine Maritime Academy serving as a director of various programs. Following his retirement in 1986, he devoted his attention to volunteering with SCORE, genealogy, bridge, and travel - his last solo trip to Scotland at 91. For more information contact his son, James or daughter, Katherine Greenman at: POB 1997, Bucksport, ME 04416.

Two additional artists have resigned from the board of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, only a few days after the resignation of the artist John Baldessari raised new questions about the museum's direction. In a joint letter sent to the museum Friday, Catherine Opie and Barbara Kruger said they were leaving the board because of their dissatisfaction with the way it conducted business and because of worries that the museum was straying from its roots as a serious art institution. ''Parties and galas are O.K., but sometimes these things called 'museums' have to have things called 'exhibitions,''' the two artists wrote. ''Our concerns are with the art, the exhibitions, and how the money that makes the exhibitions possible is gathered and distributed. Our concern is for a continued curatorial practice that is both rigorously complex and pleasurably awesome.''

Following the opening of new galleries devoted to art of the Islamic world in November and its new American Wing galleries for paintings, sculpture and decorative arts in January, the Metropolitan Museum of Art announced on Monday that its attendance rose to nearly 6.3 million visitors during the fiscal year that ended on June 30. -That figure, which includes attendance at the Cloisters - the Met's branch for Medieval Art in Fort Tryon Park in northern Manhattan -- is the highest number since the museum began tracking attendance more than 40 years ago. It is also about 600,000 more visitors than it reported a year ago.

Much has been studied and reported, particularly in this newspaper, about the short-term effects of concussions on young athletes, as well as the potential longer-term outcomes for professional athletes who engage in high-level contact sports like football and ice hockey for many years, putting themselves at risk for multiple concussions and the lesser but still consequential subconcussive injuries. But until recently, far less has been understood about the long-term implications, if any, of concussions experienced years ago by recreational athletes. Does a 55-year-old man who played high school football in the '70s and perhaps grew dizzy or ''had his bell rung'' after a tackle or two need to worry about the state of his brain today, even if he never had a formal diagnosis of concussion? Or do I, because I bounced my head hard against the slopes several times while learning to snowboard 10 years ago?

When Ernie Els finished his final round at last month's United States Open, he had every reason to be filled with fury. He bogeyed two of the closing three holes at the notoriously unforgiving Olympic Club course and squandered his chance for a third Open title. In 2010, Els, burning with frustration, had marched past a swarm of reporters after a similar back-nine failure at the United States Open at Pebble Beach. But this was a different Els. Disheartened? Certainly. Disgusted? Perhaps. But discouraged? Not this time. He swallowed his anger, gathered his wits, and did not dodge any questions. As a matter of fact, he accepted his fate with equanimity and spoke candidly of looking forward to the next major. And with good reason: Els all but declared he was back.

7:50 p.m. | Updated Citigroup on Monday reported that both its revenue and profit fell in the second quarter, underscoring the anemic economic environment financial institutions face in the United States and abroad.

On a recent drizzly Saturday, the rain wasn't constant, but the flow into the canal was. Just below a grated metal bridge that connects Park Slope with Carroll Gardens, an almost-clear liquid could be seen streaming out of a cobblestone storm drain and into the Gowanus Canal. The liquid was rainwater mixed with raw sewage - paint thinner, last night's dinner scraps and human excrement, among many other possibilities. About 377 million gallons of sewage flow into the canal each year, according to a 2008 report by city officials.

An article on Saturday about Penn State Coach Joe Paterno's renegotiating his contract beginning in January 2011 while prosecutors were investigating his longtime assistant Jerry Sandusky for sexually assaulting young boys misstated the year the contract was set to expire. It was 2011, at the end of the football season -- not at the end of 2012.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau announced on Monday that it would begin supervising the leading credit bureaus, the companies that collect financial details of everyone's life. The bureau will oversee and make rules covering about 30 credit reporting companies, representing 94 percent of the $4 billion credit reporting market. The rules will apply to the three big credit reporting firms - Equifax, Experian and TransUnion - and others with more than $7 million in annual revenue.

An article on Friday about Arnold Schwarzenegger's reprising his career as a Hollywood action hero misstated the title of a film that Clint Eastwood had a hit with in 2009. The film is ''Gran Torino,'' not ''Grand Torino.''

July 17, 1902: It was another scorcher in New York. The week before, seven deaths tied to the heat had been reported. The city's public baths were jammed with people desperately trying to cool down. The newspapers, following President Theodore Roosevelt's vacation on Long Island, said he had been out horseback riding when a thunderstorm rolled in. It was so hot, he did not mind getting soaked. What the newspapers did not report was that something had happened involving the second floor of a Brooklyn printing plant -- something that changed everything.

Regular moderate consumption of beer, wine or liquor may reduce a woman's risk for rheumatoid arthritis, a new study reports. Researchers collected data from two Swedish national health registers on 34,141 women born between 1914 and 1948. They gathered information on alcohol consumption in 1987 and 1997, and then tracked the women's health for seven years, from 2003 to 2009.

HOLM--Celeste. The U.S. Fund for UNICEF notes with sadness the passing of its longtime and beloved supporter, Celeste Holm. At the height of her fame, Ms. Holm began requesting a 25 cent donation to UNICEF for each autograph request, generating nearly $35,000 for the world's children. The U.S. Fund for UNICEF is deeply grateful for her many acts of generosity and decades of steadfast advocacy for the world's most vulnerable children. Ms. Holm's legacy of service will be long remembered by the entire UNICEF family

8:55 p.m. | Updated The global bank HSBC has been used by Mexican drug cartels looking to get cash back into the United States, by Saudi Arabian banks that needed access to dollars despite their terrorist ties and by Iranians who wanted to circumvent United States sanctions, a Senate report says. The 335-page report released Monday also says that executives at HSBC and regulators at the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency ignored warning signs and failed to stop the illegal behavior at many points between 2001 and 2010.

SALT LAKE CITY -- In the mid-1800s, newly converted families from across the United States and Europe gathered in the growing Mormon town of Nauvoo, Ill., to help their prophet, Joseph Smith, build a New Jerusalem. Soon driven out by anti-Mormon neighbors who killed Mr. Smith and his brother Hyrum, they trekked westward by foot and on horseback, chased by Indians, cholera and even United States troops before settling together safely in Utah.

If you pack a music video with enough button-pushing imagery you will eventually elicit an angry response from someone, as Madonna has rediscovered (if she'd ever forgotten the lesson to begin with). France's far-right National Front political party has said it plans to sue the provocative pop star for showing a video that depicts Marine Le Pen, the party's president, with a swastika on her forehead, The Guardian reported. Ms. Le Pen, who placed third in France's presidential election in April and narrowly lost a race for a parliamentary seat in June, was one of several world leaders depicted in a video that was played when Madonna performed her song ''Nobody Knows Me'' at a concert in Paris on Saturday. The video also shows portions of the faces of Sarah Palin, President Hu Jintao of China and Pope Benedict as well as a rapid succession of familiar symbols including a Jewish star, a Christian cross, an Islamic crescent moon and star and a dollar sign.

In February, during the height of the Linsanity phenomenon, I attended a game at Madison Square Garden between the Knicks and the Sacramento Kings. The tickets cost an arm and a leg. But Jeremy Lin and the Knicks did not disappoint. Lin had just 10 points in 26 minutes of play, but many of his 13 assists were spectacular, a series of flawless alley-oops that sent Tyson Chandler and Landry Fields dunking on the Kings like the guys from Sacramento were the Washington Generals, the Harlem Globetrotters' perpetually hapless opponents.
