WASHINGTON -- Angela Byrde, 27, is getting only the second H.I.V. test of her life -- at the Department of Motor Vehicles. Her situation exemplifies what is wrong with Washington's AIDS epidemic, and America's -- and what the nation's capital is finally doing to fix that. As a diabetic with Medicaid coverage, Ms. Byrde has seen doctors several times a year since she was 12, but they never suggested that she be tested, even though she lives in a city with one of the country's highest H.I.V. infection rates.

Richard B. Scudder, a founder and former chairman of MediaNews Group, one of the nation's largest newspaper chains, and an innovator in recycling newsprint, died on July 11 at his home in Navesink, N.J. He was 99. His daughter Jean Scudder confirmed his death.

GRALLA--Milton. The Memorial Foundation for Jewish Culture mourns the passing of our long-time benefactor and cherished friend, Milton Gralla. An active philanthropist for Jewish causes, Mr. Gralla and his wife Shirley supported a number of ground-breaking initiatives at the Memorial Foundation for Jewish Culture, including the International Nahum Goldmann Fellowship, a program whose goal is the development of the social capital of the Jewish people, that is, the cultural and communal leadership of Jewish communities around the world. Mr. Gralla was also active in his support of the Foundation's efforts on behalf of Soviet Jewry in publishing books and educational materials for young Jews and their families. A journalist by profession, Mr. Gralla also played a pioneering role in helping the Memorial Foundation support the training of Jewish journalists in the former Soviet Union and the organization of the first Association of Jewish Schools and Principals there. We will miss his counsel and friendship. Our deepest sympathies to his wife Shirley, his children and grandchildren. Professor Ismar Schorsch, President Dr. Jerry Hochbaum, Executive Vice President
BROWN--Susan L. January 9, 1943-July 7, 2012. Survived by her daughter Megan McShane and her brother Steve Brown. Contact: 718-568-4888.

Alexander Cockburn, the acerbic left-wing journalist and author who though born in Scotland thrived in the political and cultural battlegrounds of the United States, died on Saturday in Bad Salzhausen, Germany, where he had been receiving medical treatment, his family said. He was 71. The cause was cancer, said Jeffrey St. Clair, a friend and colleague.

DirecTV and Viacom may have quarreled bitterly over the costs of a new contract this month, but they agree on at least one thing: the preservation of television as they know it, provided only to paying subscribers. After a marathon negotiating session Thursday, the two companies announced early Friday morning that they had reached an agreement to end a nine-day blackout of Nickelodeon, MTV, Comedy Central and other cable channels in DirecTV homes.

A theater review on Tuesday about the musical ''Dogfight,'' at Second Stage Theater in Manhattan, referred imprecisely to the writers of the songs. Benj Pasek and Justin Paul are jointly credited with the music and the lyrics. Mr. Pasek is not solely credited as the composer of the music and Mr. Paul is not given sole credit for the lyrics.

8 P.M. (HBO) CONTAGION (2011) A mysterious pathogen sets off a global pandemic after catching a flight from Hong Kong to Chicago in this Steven Soderbergh film. Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called it a ''smart, spooky thriller about a thicket of contemporary plagues -- a killer virus, rampaging fear, an unscrupulous blogger,'' adding that the movie is ''as ruthlessly effective as the malady at its cool, cool center.'' Gwyneth Paltrow, above, plays one of the first casualties, an executive who has traveled to Hong Kong. Matt Damon is her husband, who watches as the disease cuts down seemingly everyone who has been within touching, kissing or handshaking distance of a carrier. The ensemble cast is filled out by Laurence Fishburne, Kate Winslet and Jennifer Ehle as employees of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention; Marion Cotillard as a doctor for the World Health Organization; and Jude Law as a San Francisco blogger looking to turn a profit from the crisis. ''Once it may have been hard to buy the swift collapse of order that is made palpably real in 'Contagion,' if Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath had not already set the stage,'' Ms. Dargis wrote. ''Mr. Soderbergh doesn't milk your tears as things fall apart, but a passion that can feel like cold rage is inscribed in his images of men and women isolated in the frame, in the blurred point of view of the dying and in the insistent stillness of a visual style that seems like an exhortation to look.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Lucky Severson looks at the popularity of the practice of mindfulness meditation in schools, corporations and on Capitol Hill. Fred de Sam Lazaro reports on Deir Mar Musa, a monastery in the Syrian desert near Homs whose leader, a Catholic priest, has been expelled from the country. And Sheikh Mohammad Alraee discusses the practice of reciting the entire Koran during Ramadan.

Although the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the Bank of England advocated changes to the rate-setting process, they demanded anonymity. In shunning the spotlight, the regulators deferred to the British Bankers' Association, a private industry group that oversees the rate-setting process. ''They will obviously have to remove the references to us and Fed,'' a Bank of England official said in a June 2008 e-mail, referring to a draft of the trade group's proposal.

If you're aiming to save your money for a new home, a car, or perhaps even a vacation, you can't help becoming frustrated by the paltry interest rates being offered. Your savings can't even keep pace with inflation. So this week's Your Money column looks at the world of federally insured options, as well as possible alternatives for savers with short-term goals, including short-term bonds, and the risks they may entail.

An art review on Friday about ''Requiem for the Sun: The Art of Mono-ha,'' at the Gladstone Gallery on West 21st Street in Manhattan, misspelled, in some editions, the given name of an artist whose work is featured in the show. The error was repeated in an accompanying picture caption. The artist was Katsuro Yoshida, not Katzuro. The review, using information from the exhibition catalog, also rendered incorrectly at one point the name of a Japanese critic who wrote an essay for the catalog. The critic, Minemura Toshiaki, uses the traditional Japanese name order in which the family name is first. Thus he is Mr. Minemura, not Mr. Toshiaki. The review also misstated the given name of a Belgian artist whose work is on display at the gallery's West 24th Street site. He is Jan Vercruysse, not Jean.

An article on June 28 about the continued weakness of some European banks omitted a relevant detail about the French bank BNP Paribas, and in so doing may have left the impression that the bank was undercapitalized. While the bank was among those that the European Banking Authority listed last year as needing additional capital, it has since exceeded the capital reserve target the banking authority set.

10:13 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES -- Hollywood specializes in making movies that are escapes from reality. Now a film has been linked to an act of real-life violence, leaving movie executives scrambling to respond. Warner Brothers and its corporate allies spent Friday struggling with the deadly shooting in Aurora, Colo., at a midnight screening of ''The Dark Knight Rises,'' a brooding, apocalyptic film that has been at the center of a studio strategy built around superheroes, fantasies and brushes with violence.

When politics and sex meet it makes for great political theater. This summer they'll be theater when Mo Rocca (''CBS Sunday Morning''), Rachel Dratch (''Saturday Night Live'') and Sean Dugan (''Smash'') take the stage in ''Tail! Spin!'' -- a verbatim recitation of steamy e-mails, texts, interviews and Twitter messages that surfaced during recent political sex scandals. The show, created by the NPR contributor Mario Correa, is scheduled to play five performances, from Aug. 11-16, at the Kraine Theater as part of the 2012 New York International Fringe Festival. Directed by the Tony nominee Dan Knechtges (''Lysistrata Jones''), ''Tail! Spin!'' focuses on the sexual transgressions of four American politicians: Mark Sanford, the former governor of South Carolina who admitted to having an affair with a lover he had met while on vacation in Argentina; Larry E. Craig, a former Republican senator from Idaho who was caught in an undercover sex sting; and two former United States congressmen, Anthony Weiner of New York, who resigned over lewd online behavior, and Mark Foley of Florida, who resigned after he was caught sending sexually explicit texts to teenage Capitol Hill pages. The cast will portray some 30 different roles, including members of the media and the politicians' paramours and relatives.

WARREN--Lucie Bedford Cunningham Warren, of Greens Farms, CT, passed away peacefully at her home on July 16, 2012. Mrs. Warren was 104 years old. She is survived by her three children, Briggs S. Cunningham, III, and his wife, Elizabeth, of Lancaster, Kentucky, Lucie C. McKinney, of Greens Farms, CT, and Cythlen C. Maddock, and her husband, Paul "Jay" Maddock, of Palm Beach, FL. She was predeceased by her first husband, Briggs S. Cunningham, II, and her second husband, Lynne A. Warren. In addition to her children, Mrs. Warren was survived by her grandchildren, Paige Cunningham Garland, Brian Cunningham, Robert Cunningham, Blair Cunningham Newsome, Stewart B. McKinney, Jr., Lucie B. McKinney, Jean McKinney, Elizabeth McKinney Tritschler, John P. McKinney, John Dewing, Cythlen Dewing Moss, and Zachary Read. She was also survived by 25 great-grandchildren. She is survived by her sister, Ruth Bedford, and predeceased by her sisters, Helen McCashin and Mary Bedford. Mrs. Warren was also survived by her goddaughter, Lesley Cowenhoven, her good friend, Kathryn Ann Rabesa, and her loyal companions and sailing master, Walter and Lorraine Billings. Mrs. Warren was a woman who was ahead of her time well educated, well travelled, graceful and athletic. She was dignified, competitive and independent. She had vision, energy and a strong work ethic. Most of all, Mrs. Warren believed in helping others. She was known as the "working donor" and was a leader in her philanthropic pursuits. She was an extremely private person and always believed that her philanthropy did not need fanfare or notoriety. Mrs. Warren was a generous giver of time and philanthropy to many charitable worthwhile causes for over 75 years. She was deeply concerned about education and children. She supported Norwalk Hospital, especially the Lucie Bedford Warren Department of Pediatrics. She volunteered two days each week at Norwalk Hospital until she was 96 years old. She also supported the Wakeman Boys and Girls Club, Greens Farms Academy, the Chapin School in New York City, the Westport YMCA, the Connecticut Audubon Society, the Garden Club of America, the Mystic Aquarium Seaport for the Brilliant and many other worthwhile causes. She also volunteered at the Pequot Library Book Sale each year until she was 97 years old. In addition, she helped hundreds of individuals in supporting their personal education. When it came to education, Mrs. Warren never said no. Mrs. Warren was involved in many other activities and was exceptional in all she did including golf, tennis, basketball, and field hockey. She attended Smith College in Northhampton, MA. She was the golf club champion at the Country Club of Fairfield, many times. She was the only woman champion of the Star Atlantic Coast Sailing Championship. She enjoyed being a part of the support team when her husband, Briggs Cunningham, won the America's Cup in 1958 and when he raced in Le Mans in the 1950s. Lucie and Briggs also won numerous sailing championships in Europe. Mrs. Warren had tremendous care in her final years and the family is extremely grateful to all of the dedicated individuals who provided such exceptional care and who became a part of her life. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to any of the charities that Mrs. Warren was involved. She improved countless lives and we are better people because of her. She will be greatly missed. Services will be private.

Isuzu Yamada, a towering star of the Japanese screen and stage best known in the West for her chilling portrayal of the Lady Macbeth role in Akira Kurosawa's Shakespeare adaptation ''Throne of Blood,'' died on July 9 in Tokyo. ZALAZNICK--Sheldon, 83, passed away peacefully on July 19th with his loving wife of 59 years, Vera, and adored daughter Andrea at his bedside. Survived by son-in-law Joseph Burdick, cherished grandchildren Stephen and SaraJessica, elder sister Annette Weinreb, sister-in-law Gloria Zalaznick, and sister and brother-in-law Eleanor and Lawrence Newman. After earning his Bachelor of Arts from NYU's University College and Master of Arts from Teachers' College, Columbia University, Shelley taught for a year: just long enough to meet his wife. With a career spanning from Sports Editor at Newsweek Magazine, Associate Editor at Fortune Magazine, writer and Managing Editor at Forbes Magazine, Sunday Editor at the New York Herald Tribune and founding Editor of the Sunday New York Magazine section, to Vice President and Editorial Director of New York Magazine, Shelley left an indelible mark upon the profession of journalism. His dedication to integrity and high caliber work was clear throughout his career. After his retirement, Shelley was sent to Budapest by the International Executive Service Corps to help start a financial magazine, where he delighted and impressed his Hungarian audience at a special dinner by addressing them in their own language, which he learned just for that event. Shelley loved music and in his free time enjoyed playing piano, tennis, poker, skiing, horseback riding, golfing, as well as introducing his grandchildren to deliciously unhealthy breakfasts. Shelley was an intellectual's intellectual, renowned for his dry sense of humor, razor-sharp wit, and ability to weave a story. This modest and gentle man was loved and respected by all. A memorial celebration will be announced shortly.

HOPELESS is the word that Douglas Sirk used to describe the characters' struggles for happiness in ''IMITATION OF LIFE'' (1959), his great melodrama about race, women and the American dream. ''Both white and black,'' he said in ''Sirk on Sirk,'' ''are living imitated lives.'' Not surprisingly, show business -- rather than the pancake business of John Stahl's 1934 version -- is where those lives find their truest expression. That goes for Lora Meredith (Lana Turner, the ur imitation blonde), an ambitious actress, as well as for Sarah Jane Johnson (Susan Kohner), a light-skinned black woman who can pass for white and does so as a dancer in a tawdry floor show. Everything in Sirk's movie looks gloriously artificial, from the bubblelike jewels that float down in the opening credits, to the saturated color, to Lora's suburban home, whose horizontal lines fill the wide-screen frames like a series of dioramas or stage sets that contain the characters' imitated lives. One thing is very real: the emotion the movie generates. Bring a hankie or four to the Film Forum, which is showing ''Imitation of Life'' on a bill with ''All That Heaven Allows'' on Wednesday, as part of ''Universal 100.''209 West Houston Street, South Village; (212) 727-8110, filmforum.com.

GERTZ--Jerrold. It is with profound sadness that we mourn the loss of Jerry Gertz, board member and father of Ali Gertz. Since the inception of Love Heals in 1992, Jerry was deeply involved in our work carrying on the legacy of his daughter, the AIDS activist Ali Gertz. A grandfather to many, his quiet support, gentle manner and warmth fortified us all. We send our love to Carol, his wife of 48 years, and to Elise, Ali's grandmother. The Board and Staff of Love Heals

THE UNITED STATES SENT more than 300 athletes to the last Olympics in London, the 1948 Summer Games. Despite a food rationing program in effect after World War II and accommodations in barracks, veterans of '48 consider the experience some of the best days of their lives. Archival photos and audio clips from more than a dozen United States Olympians who competed in London, including their memories of winning and losing, of meeting royalty and celebrities, and of visiting a city much different from the one that will welcome the world this week, are at nytimes.com/olympics. 2012 LONDON

Frick Award for broadcasting described incorrectly a Cardinals game in 1985 for which he was a broadcaster. It was McCarver's first World Series game as a broadcaster, not his first game as a broadcaster. (His broadcasting career began in 1980.)

Plenty of global hotel brands have gone local, using nearby farms to supply their restaurants' produce, for example. But the Hyatt Regency Minneapolis has gone further, with a $25 million renovation that has transformed the place into what it calls a ''hotel for locavores.'' Hyatt enlisted regional manufacturers, artisans and artists in updating the 533-room property, with décor that pays tribute to the city's heritage and industry.

ARONSON--Mitzi, age 89, died May 21, 2012 six weeks following the passing of her husband of 70 years, Bernard. The Aronson's were originally from Huntington, New York and in recent years Boca Ration, Florida. Born in 1922 to Fred and Rhoda Hochstadt, raised in Brooklyn and Bronxville, New York, as a young girl Mitzi worked in her father's linotype setting business on Vesey Street in New York City. She attended New York University at age 16, striving towards a writing career by studying literature. She wrote poetry, film reviews for the NYU newspaper and excelled in public speaking. Mitzi, was president of the Huntington Hadassah chapter in the 1950's. People said that Mitzi could light up a room, had a smile for everyone and was truly beautiful. Her charm and wit were among her much strength. She is survived by her son Stephen Aronson, PhD of Portland, Maine, her daughter Judith Berkheimer of Coconut Creek, Florida, seven grandchildren and seven greatgrandchildren.

An article last Sunday about the Baltimore Symphony's BSO Academy, which brings together amateur and professional musicians for a weeklong program, gave an outdated figure for the drop in annual base pay for the orchestra's members. The minimum base pay has fallen to $65,000 from $78,000 -- not from $90,000, which had been agreed upon in a contract four years ago but was reduced over several further negotiations.

The Seattle Mariners entered the weekend ranking 13th among 14 American League teams in runs a game, at 4.01. Their production at first base and right field - two vital offensive spots - has been especially absent. Only two first basemen or right fielders had a combined on-base and slugging percentage of .650 or lower, with a minimum of 300 plate appearances, and both play for Seattle: first baseman Justin Smoak and right fielder Ichiro Suzuki. One productive major leaguer, who plays both positions, is a Mariners reject.

''We both have degrees from Harvard,'' President Obama told the White House correspondents at this year's annual roast. ''I have one, he has two.'' Pause. ''What a snob.'' Perhaps. With Mr. Obama (law) or Mitt Romney (law and business) in the White House, every president from 1989 to at least 2017 will have had a degree from Harvard or Yale. But the presidency has not always been elitist: 11 presidents never graduated college, and in the early years many had only a few years of formal schooling. We turned to the University of Virginia's Miller Center, whose mission is to expand understanding of the presidency, for a history lesson. 1. George Washington

THE LAST OLYMPICS IN LONDON were the 1948 Summer Games, the first after a 12-year hiatus caused by World War II. The United States sent more than 300 athletes, most of them arriving in England after a weeklong voyage on the S.S. America. In London, they found a city still devastated by years of bombings preparing for what became known as the Austerity Games. A food-rationing program was in effect, so many athletes were encouraged to pack food alongside their uniforms, sneakers, swimsuits or canoe paddles. The organizers could not afford to build an Olympic Village to house the competitors, so a large group stayed in barracks at an air base outside the city. With the Games set to return to London this week, veterans of '48 recalled some of the best days of their lives.

SCHIMBERG--Henry, former CEO of Coca-Cola Enterprises, died on June 29, 2012. He was 79. Born in Chicago in 1933 to Judith and Arnold. He received his BA from Beloit College. Starting as a truck driver for RC Bottling in 1958, he worked his way through the industry, becoming president and COO of Coca-Cola Enterprises in 1990 and CEO in 1998. During his tenure, CCE experienced the most financially successful period in its history. After his retirement in 2000, Henry served on numerous boards and lectured extensively on conducting business ethically. He was a loving father to his children; he touched many lives and will be missed. Henry is survived by his wife, Marjorie Layden; his two children, Aaron and Alexis, of his first wife Linda; and by his siblings, Elsa Dimick, Dorothy Gartman and Jake Schimberg.

Also, survived by dearest sister and brother-in-law Beth and Bill Niemi, and brother Jerry Bachman, numerous nieces, great-nieces, nephews and great-nephews, Predeceased by her mother Janet, brothers Frank and Chuck Bachman. She taught in the New York City public school system for 15 years. Rest, dear girl, you fought like no one has fought before. Funeral and burial in Sacramento, CA. A celebration of Jennifer's life will take place in New York City; date to be determined. Stars shining bright above you ...

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the HBO documentary ''Birders: The Central Park Effect'' misidentified one of the three birds shown. The small bird perched on a post and puffing its chest is a gray catbird, not a northern mockingbird.

That's the increase in total viewership for the AMC series ''Breaking Bad,'' to 2.9 million people for the Season 5 premiere on July 15 from the 1.4 million who caught the series premiere on Jan. 20, 2008. The serialized nature of the show -- about a chemistry teacher (Bryan Cranston, below) turned meth overlord -- would have made substantial gains in viewers difficult in the past. But in this age of instant gratification and binge viewing, thanks to DVRs, Netflix and on-demand video, it has more than doubled its audience.

Eddie Birchenough has been club professional at Royal Lytham & St. Annes since 1987, long enough to be the host professional for four British Opens and long enough to grow weary of suggestions that his club is not as close to the sea as a classic Open course. ''That's a myth,'' Birchenough said, rising from his chair in his office to refer to an aerial photograph in the pro shop. The photo shows the two dense blocks of housing that separate the course from the Irish Sea.

Darrelle Revis attended all of the Jets' off-season functions, from voluntary workouts to the mandatory minicamp, but he never guaranteed that he would report to training camp on time. He also never said that he would not -- just that he would be ready for the season. On Thursday, the Jets report to training camp in Cortland, N.Y. And Revis, instead of staging his second contract holdout in three years, appears poised to attend. Revis, the team's All-Pro cornerback and best player, will join the rest of his teammates, according to a report by The Associated Press.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Promise to Avoid Race-Day Drugs,'' July 20: Reports document the routine doping of thoroughbreds with steroids to mask painful injuries and keep them on the track when they shouldn't be racing. Instead of wasting time discussing race-day doping, the industry needs an across-the-board zero-tolerance policy.

LOW--Frances Levison, One of the first women to be recognized as a reporter at the Time-Life organization and a long-time resident of New York, died in San Francisco on June 18, 2012 after a short illness at age 92. After attending Horace Mann for 12 years, graduating from Vassar College (class of '41) with honors and earning an MA in History from Columbia University, Frances started as a researcher with Life Magazine. When she left the Time-Life organization in 1952, Frances was a full-fledged reporter and the lone woman reporter among the Time Washington Bureau staff. She worked in New York and Chicago, and after WWII in London, Paris, and Washington, D.C. Among her memorable articles for Life Magazine was an intimate study of Elizabeth Taylor who at age 17 was coming on the Hollywood scene as perhaps its most glamorous ingenue. Another was an in-depth study of Margaret Truman, daughter of former President Harry S. Truman. Frances also wrote of her experience as a student at Le Cordon Bleu Cooking School in Paris in which she described the peeling of a live eel among the culinary techniques of the French kitchen. This article, accompanied by a photograph of the chef performing the slippery operation, caught the eye of fellow student, Julia Child. Frances spent several nights in an Illinois prison for women to write an article about the inmates, many of them incarcerated because of violence against abusive husbands or boyfriends. She was forever moved by the screams and moans she heard in those nights behind bars. Frances left the Time-Life organization in 1952 to marry Robert A. Low, then an officer in the U.S. Department of State. She became a Special Assistant to Henry M. Jackson, Democratic Senator from Washington state. She and her husband became lifelong friends of Sen. Jackson. Frances and 'Bob' moved to New York City in 1954. Bob entered city politics and Frances played significant roles in her husband's campaigns for the New York City Council, where he served two terms, 1961-1969. He is best remembered for sponsoring and seeing the signing into law by then-Mayor John V. Lindsey of a local anti- pollution law that outlawed the burning of soft coal and outlawed apartment house incinerators, and gradually reduced the permissible content of sulphur in fuel oil. His campaigns for mayor and for president of the City Council in 1969, while unsuccessful had Frances all over Manhattan and the five boroughs getting deeply connected with the people and issues of the most important city in the world. After the birth of her two sons, Allen (now an airline pilot) and Roger (a long time hedge fund manager), Frances joined the New York City Partnership, a predecessor of the Partnership for New York. The Economic Development Council of New York City awarded her a medal of achievement for her work in connecting business leaders with the work of City agencies, particularly the public school system. Later she brought the program, now known as Open Doors, to the Board of Education. The Program focused on exposing young students to the world of work and included talks by representatives of various fields of work. It also included visits to work sites and offices. Part of her program introduced young people to the possibilities of employment in the Culinary Arts. She became an early member of Les Dames d'Escoffier, now an international organization of prominent women connected with the food world. Frances was a believer in the power of education and continued to support East Harlem School at Exodus House in New York City, a year-round middle school that teaches children from low-income families develop academic excellence, moral integrity, courtesy, and an unshakeable commitment to their future and the fate of their community. Since moving to San Francisco with Bob in 1996 to be near their family, Frances had dedicated herself to several charitable activities, including AIM High, an organization that conducts summer programs for middle school students in school sites around the Bay Area. She also built a family website to honor her two deceased sisters, Helene and Eleanor, ancestors and share family stories, photos and memorabilia. Frances is survived by her husband, Bob, as well as her son, Allen, his children Andrew, Alexandra and Elena (and their mother, Berta); son Roger, and his children Jesse, Gabriel and Sarah (and their mother, Virginia), and many nieces and nephews. Donations in Frances' memory may be made to East Harlem School, 309 East 103rd Street, New York, NY 10029. A gathering for family and friends to celebrate Frances' life will be held in New York City at a later date.

A news analysis article last Sunday about the ecology of infectious diseases described imprecisely the affiliation of Simon Anthony, a molecular virologist. While he works with EcoHealth, an organization of scientists devoted to wildlife conservation, his primary affiliation is as a postdoctoral research fellow at the Center for Infection and Immunity at Columbia University's Mailman School of Public Health.

MISHKIN--Jeanne. The Board of Directors, Officers and Staff of The Jewish Guild for the Blind mourn the death of Jeanne Mishkin, devoted mother of Joe Mishkin, former Guild Chairman of the Board. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire family. James M. Dubin, Board Chairman Alan R. Morse, Pres. & CEO

BUSTS by the German Baroque sculptor FRANZ XAVER MESSERSCHMIDT of men weeping or grimacing, yawning or looking as though they are about to scream have fascinated artists, collectors, scholars and museum curators for more than two centuries. Recent shows devoted to his work have been on view at the Louvre in Paris and the Neue Galerie in New York. Now the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles is taking a new look at Messerschmidt. Its show -- ''Messerschmidt and Modernity'' -- which opens at the Getty Center on Tuesday, will present these mid-18th-century sculptures. But rather than explore Messerschmidt's work by itself, the exhibition will include modern and contemporary works that underscore his enduring influence. During the last 13 years of his life -- between 1770 and 1783 -- he produced a group of 69 so-called character heads, which he intended as a way of representing the spectrum of human emotion and which he either carved in alabaster or cast in a lead or tin alloy. Eight of them will be on view at the Getty, including the museum's ''Vexed Man.'' To illustrate Messerschmidt's influence, the show will also feature work by Tony Cragg, Bruce Nauman, Pierre Picot and Cindy Sherman. (310) 440-7300, getty.edu.

An article last Sunday about Penny Pritzker, who managed fund-raising for the 2008 Obama campaign, gave an incomplete name for a union that has criticized her over the labor practices of the Hyatt hotel chain, which her family owns. It is Unite Here, not simply Unite.

Ilhan Mimaroglu, a composer best known for his electronic music and a record producer best known for his work with Charles Mingus, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 86. The cause was pneumonia, said Mehmet Dede, a family spokesman.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Paterno Won Sweeter Deal Even as Scandal Played Out,'' July 14: In the struggle between Joe Paterno's widow and the Penn State board of trustees, we see yet another example of how people who are hired to regulate are no match for the people they regulate.

ERIC MAZUR, a Harvard physics professor, has long worked to supplant lectures with more interactive classes. Students, he found, assimilate new material better by working on conceptual problems in class and debating their conclusions with peers. But they tend to pair up with the same friends, which can be unproductive. Mr. Mazur and his colleagues came up with a novel solution: take students out of the matchmaking. Professors can use their software, called Learning Catalytics and now used at various campuses, to force students to defend their ideas by matching them with classroom partners who have different opinions.
FISHMAN--Anna Mae. July 20, 2000. We miss you. Take good care of our baby. Children, Grandchildren

SONDHEIM in the Park sounds like a lovely idea, particularly a revival of ''INTO THE WOODS,'' whose title is argument enough. This 1987 deconstruction of fairy tales, which includes such megastars as Rapunzel, Little Red Riding Hood and Jack the Giant Killer, has long been considered by critics something of a problem musical. They have taken issue with the overpacked plot and a wavering tone but usually not before raving about its songs and mighty ambition. Much of the creative team (including the director Timothy Sheider) for the new version comes from an acclaimed English production at Regent's Park Open Air Theater. In his 2010 review in The New York Times, Matt Wolf hinted that New York has a comparable address in the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. Maybe someone was listening, since that's where this impressive new cast performing the show will be, starting Monday. The ensemble includes Amy Adams, Denis O'Hare, Donna Murphy, Chip Zien (who was the Baker in the original Broadway production) and Glenn Close, in the voice of the giant, a role played by Judi Dench in the previous New York production. Through Aug. 25, shakespeareinthepark.org.

AN overture is, by definition, an introduction or proposal, something before the main event. So it's with a little wink that Judith Leiber, the black-tie-bag enterprise of 49 years, named its new contemporary offshoot Overture by Judith Leiber. ''They are evening bags,'' says Jana Matheson, its creative director, ''but they are far more versatile than the standard satin and rhinestone pouches that you carry to the opera.''

KANE--Sonja Rand. Born on December 10, 1935 in Polch, Germany, and raised in East Pittsburgh, PA, this incredible woman touched the lives of all who knew her. Her years as a grade school teacher in the Brooklyn school system, as well as her charitable endeavors, enriched so many lives. As it is said, to know her was to love her! Royal Lytham & St. Annes is a long way from Oklahoma. But at least a few dozen fans along the ropes during the third round of the 141st British Open were wearing Rickie Fowler's signature all-orange outfit - a tribute to the colors of his alma mater, Oklahoma State. They were not all from the United States; indeed, most seemed to have English or Scottish accents. It's just a popular, and eye-catching, outfit, and the fans, most of them in their teens or early 20s, seemed to be paying tribute to the stylish Fowler.

An article last Sunday about the possible ways the N.C.A.A. could penalize Penn State in light of the child sexual abuse scandal there misidentified the charge cited against Ohio State last year, when it received a one-year postseason ban after football players traded jerseys, bowl rings and team memorabilia for cash and tattoos. The N.C.A.A. penalized Ohio State for failure to monitor, not for lack of institutional control.

LONDON - With the Summer Games less than one week away, Jacques Rogge, president of the International Olympic Committee, said once again on Saturday that there will be no moment of silence at the Opening Ceremony to commemorate the Israeli athletes killed 40 years ago at the 1972 Munich Games. ''We feel that the Opening Ceremony is an atmosphere that is not fit to remember such a tragic incident,'' Rogge said at a news conference inside the Olympic Park.
'Honestly, I preferred New York.' JEREMY LIN,

Daniel J. Wakin's article last Sunday about being one of 104 amateur musicians at the Baltimore Symphony's BSO Academy elicited a healthy response from readers. Many praised the interaction between professional and amateur. Elaine S. of Pennsylvania wrote, ''As an amateur violinist and public school orchestra director, a former community orchestra concertmaster and a current assistant, I have wished for years for this type of commingling between professionals and amateurs.'' The package with the article includes a video and a slide show: nytimes.com/music

IN South London, the Brixton neighborhood continues to be the city's leading culinary cradle. Especially in Brixton Village, the area's historic produce, meat and staples market, where abandoned shops are being reclaimed and converted into tiny cafes, boutiques and eateries hawking what seems like every ethnic street food under the sun. Some of the new faces laying down roots here include Honest Burgers (below, 12 Brixton Village), a no-frills burger joint supplied by one of London's finest butchers, Ginger Pig. Highlights here are the crunchy golden rosemary salt fries and creamy fennel, parsley, carrot and cabbage slaw. Across the road in Market Row, bulbous pitchers of red sangria and toothsome tapas like crostate topped with Roquefort cheese and ripe figs are served at the recently opened Seven at Brixton (7 Market Row). Nearby is Wild Caper (13 Market Row), a quiet cafe and bakery with an eye on the provenance of whatever finds its way into its salads and sandwiches.

TUPANJANIN--Vukosav, 89, beloved husband, father and grandfather, died July 12, 2012. A retired mutual fund manager from Glen Rock, NJ, he was born on November 28, 1922, in Sarajevo, in Bosnia-Herzegovina. He was the son of Milos Tupanjanin, a member of Parliament in pre-war Yugoslavia and vice chairman of the Agrarian Party, and Madeleine Salmon of Grenoble, France. During World War II, Vic made a harrowing escape from Yugoslavia as Germans invaded the country. He then joined the British Army and served in South Africa and Egypt. After the war, he went to England and graduated from the University of Exeter and the London School of Economics. In the 1950's, he immigrated to the U.S., and joined Calvin Bullock, Ltd. He is survived by a daughter, Madeleine Barry; a son, Michael; his former wife Else; two sisters, Mirjana Jovanovitch and Solange Avakumovic; and five grandchildren. Vic's lifelong passions included painting, reading and a love of nature. A Memorial Service was held on July 19th.

REUTER--Stewart, M.D.,J.D., Professor Emeritus, Department of Radiology, The University of Texas Health Science Center (UTHSCSA), died in his home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, July 8, 2012. Dr. Reuter has had a distinguished career as a radiologist, legal scholar, and educator. He spent his entire career in academics. Dr. Reuter's training was unique. He earned a B.S. from Ohio Wesleyan University, a M.D. from Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine, and a J.D. from the University of San Francisco. He was a pioneer in the field of cardiovascular radiology. He was the first to describe the angiographic abnormalities in several disease processes in the abdomen. He is one of the founders of the Society of Cardiovascular and Interventional Radiology. He was a member of the Texas Bar. His law review articles are considered authoritative resources in appellate decisions. Dr. Reuter accepted the Chair in the Department of Radiology at UTHSCSA in 1980 and remained its Chair for 20 years. He built a first class research laboratory, where the technique of percutaneous transhepatic portocaval shunting was developed, in which Dr. Julio Palmaz invented the arterial stent. While serving as Chair, Dr. Reuter also helped develop the UTHSCSA Center for Medical Ethics and Humanities. He is one of its founders. In retirement, Dr. Reuter worked as an artist. His art was shown at the Gallery Nord in San Antonio and the MADI Museum of Art in Dallas. Dr. Reuter was a renaissance man, a great friend to many, and a beautiful husband and partner for his beloved wife Marianne. Dr. Reuter is the son of Grace McCaig and Carl Reuter, M.D. of Springfield, Ohio. He is survived by his wife Marianne, his sister Ann Dove (Michael) and her family of Shelbyville, Illinois, his sister-in-law Marga Sarkis (Riad) and her family of Jdeidet Ghazir, Lebanon, and the family of his deceased brother-in-law Erik Ahfeldt of Stockholm, Sweden. A memorial will be held at the Gallery Nord, San Antonio, Texas on August 28 at 4pm. In his memory, contributions can be made to the Stewart R. and Marianne C. Reuter Fund at the San Antonio Area Foundation.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the beginning of the World Team Tennis season misspelled the surname of one of the tennis stars who played in the league in the 1970s. He was Vitas Gerulaitis, not Guerlaitis. Also because of an editing error, the article misspelled the name of the autoimmune disorder from which Venus Williams suffers. It is Sjogren's syndrome, not Sjorgren's.

Rory McIlroyshot a three-over-par 73 Saturday, another disappointing round in the British Open for a player who would sorely like to win the event. Since his victory at the 2011 United States Open, McIlroy has increasingly seemed out of sorts in his British Open appearances. Last year, after he finished tied for 25th at Royal St. George's, he said links golf might not suit his game. He took back those comments this year, but he was unable to play any better through the first three rounds.

A news analysis article last Sunday, by reporters from the investigative news organization ProPublica, described imprecisely T-Mobile's release of information about law enforcement requests for call data. On July 9, Representative Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat, reported that cellphone carriers responded to 1.3 million demands for subscriber information last year from law enforcement agencies. That figure did not include data from T-Mobile, because it had asked Mr. Markey's office to keep the figure confidential; it was not the case that T-Mobile had refused to release the information. (On the day of Mr. Markey's announcement, T-Mobile disclosed the number: 191,000 requests in 2011. A T-Mobile spokesman said that because the carriers had different ways of tallying requests for call data, T-Mobile was ''initially concerned the comparison could lead to an inaccurate portrayal.'')

THE latest addition to J. Crew's curated In Good Company collection comes from Goldsign, the Los Angeles jeans brand founded by the denim industry's designer-guru Adriano Goldschmied. The item: a classic five-pocket called Jenny made of selvage denim that is ''in between a sexy jean and a boyfriend jean,'' Mr. Goldschmied said. Available in two washes -- a dark vintage and a lighter shade with a green cast -- the one-year-old style was originally inspired by a pair worn by Norma Jeane Baker in photographs taken by André de Dienes in the 1940s. Just like those jeans, the Jenny has a straight side seam, a high waist and a cuff (that's easy to undo, as shown here). ''Back then women were buying men's jeans and rolling them up,'' Mr. Goldschmied said. ''I was in some way a little bit tired of the skinny that was born in L.A. and that's been very successful. I was looking for what's next. My way of designing is about starting from something that's part of a tradition and not just replicating it but innovating through fabric, fit and wash.''

GARR--Michael, died on May 17, 2012, ten weeks after he was diagnosed with liver cancer. He was surrounded by his dear friends and family at Haven Hospice in Manhattan. Michael was born and raised in Atlanta, GA and although a Manhattanite for most of 30 years, he retained a southern gentility while facing the challenges of living in New York. He nourished his southern roots in recent years by visiting family in Pawley's Island, SC. Michael came to New York in 1980 to attend Circle in the Square School of Performing Arts. He also attended Parsons School of Design. He worked as an actor in New York and Washington, DC, where he lived for seven years. He appeared in commercials, corporate films, TV shows, off Broadway plays and regional theater. While in Washington, his priorities shifted significantly and he found a new primary purpose. At about this time, he began working in the real estate business and discovered he had a real knack for it. Missing Manhattan, he returned to New York where his charm, creativity, insight into people, and negotiating skills were the recipe for his considerable success as a broker, investor and developer. Michael was well known for his integrity and kindness. Michael is survived by many dear friends and, his beloved family, Sally Garr Brodhead, Andy Garr of Henderson, TX. He was predeceased by his parents M. A. Garr, Jr. and Lorraine Sarah Mullaney. A memorial service will be held at Church of the Ascension on July 26, 2012 at 6:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donations should go to the Church of the Ascension Outreach where he was on the Board of the Food Pantry or to the Ryan White Program in Charleston SC.
Shaheen Lavie-Rouse, economics, Tufts; music, New England Conservatory

BRAVO--Veronica, long-time resident of Ossining, N.Y., died in London on July 13 at the age of 75 after a brief and courageous battle with sarcoma. Veronica is deeply missed by her husband Robert Sherman, mother Hilda Bramson, sister Shirley, children No'A (Antony), Adam and Juliet, daughters in law Jacqueline and Sang, grandchildren, Toshi and Jackson Leroi, and step-children Steve J. and Peter Sherman. Following her early career as a stage dancer in London's West End, Veronica moved to the U.S. where she was a regular performer on the "Sing Along with Mitch" TV series. She later went on to a career in classical music arts management and publicity. A warm, elegant, gracious and dynamic woman with an irreverent sense of humor, she filled her home with plants and artworks, was a passionate animal lover, and a strong advocate for personal freedom of choice and human dignity. She was also the best cook ever to come out of England.

In sunshine and little wind early in the third round, Bubba Watson, this year's Masters champion, was on quite a roll: making six birdies in the first 13 holes and climbing the leader board. But that momentum came to a halt on Lytham's tough stretch of finishing holes. Watson bogeyed the 14th and missed a 10-foot putt for a bogey on the par-4 15th, ending with a 6.

We are nearing the end of the season of the Great Mentioning, with murmurs of a vice presidential pick by Mitt Romney in the next few weeks, and possibly sooner. Will it be Tim Pawlenty, Bobby Jindal or Rob Portman? Or maybe Condoleezza Rice, despite her consistent declarations that she has no interest? The media, and to some extent the public, are focused on who Romney will choose. A better question is: what is Romney's vision for the office of the vice president, and how does his running mate plan to exercise the enormous powers of that office? If you watched the recent HBO comedy series ''Veep,'' you might conclude that vision and expectations don't matter because the vice president is an irrelevant player in the governing game, or relevant only for comedic purposes. Indeed, Vice President Biden has contributed from time to time to the image of the vice presidency as a source of entertainment.

What is the most burdensome disease in the world today? According to the World Health Organization, the disease that robs the most adults of the most years of productive life is not AIDS, not heart disease, not cancer. It is depression. The disease is not merely a bourgeois problem. It is especially prevalent in places that have experienced war, disaster or crushing deprivation. Yes, in many poor countries the bonds between people are much stronger than they are in wealthier, more individualistic societies, and this is a good thing for mental health. But it can hardly counteract the fact that a lot of people have an awful lot to be depressed about. Violence - whether war or high rates of crime - produces widespread post-traumatic stress. The constant worry that a crop failure or serious illness will throw a family into poverty is a source of extreme anxiety. Seeing your children go hungry creates paralyzing guilt.

HOTELS for adventure travelers don't tend toward the stylish. Enter Basecamp, a new property in South Lake Tahoe, Calif. The concept: embody the spirit of a traditional base camp (where mountaineers swap equipment, advice and war stories before expeditions) with a modern eco-chic touch. ''There's an amazing sense of community and exploration in these camps,'' said the hotel's owner, Christian Strobel, an avid hiker and mountain biker, and the former chief development officer at Joie de Vivre hotels. Then there's the design, a riff on the idea of roughing it. Each of the 50 rooms has tarp headboards, kerosene desk lamps and reclaimed-barnwood furnishings. Some rooms offer bunk beds with bright-orange frames; one, the Great Indoors, has green carpet that looks like grass, an electric log fire and a tented king bed. As for the actual great outdoors? Activities include rock-climbing, mountain biking and paddle boarding on Lake Tahoe -- or taking in the Sierra Nevadas from Basecamp's rooftop hot tub.

Running back Franco Harris helped the Pittsburgh Steelers win four Super Bowls during his 13-year Hall of Fame career. As a rookie 40 years ago, he caught a deflected touchdown pass from Terry Bradshaw that instantly became known as the Immaculate Reception; it gave the Steelers their first playoff victory, against Oakland. Harris, 62, appeared at a fund-raiser last month for the Franciscan Sisters of the Poor Foundation at Yankee Stadium. Q.

An article last Sunday about the latest Batman movie, ''The Dark Knight Rises,'' and how it features 72 minutes of high-resolution Imax footage, misstated the horizontal resolution of standard home HD television screens. It is 1,920 pixels -- not 1,080, which is the vertical resolution of such screens.

A POTENT mix of street savvy and aching vulnerability characterizes the portraits of city teenagers that the photographer Amy Touchette took for her series New York Young. Today's youngsters grow up primed to pose for the insatiable lenses of smartphones, but Ms. Touchette tapped a richer vein. The teenagers in her photos look tough, soft, wary, scared, confident and sometimes, somehow, all those things at once. ''I did want to reach some place genuine and deep,'' said Ms. Touchette, who lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. ''I feel they're in this distinct tenuous time, where they feel like they know it all, they have this overconfidence, but there's no sidestepping the utter ignorance that's implicit in adolescence.''

THE great designer shoe wars of Manhattan retailing have escalated at an astonishing pace since 2007, back when Saks Fifth Avenue, in a clever marketing gambit, announced that its expanded footwear department was so large that it deserved its own vanity ZIP code, 10022-SHOE. Rivals have responded with incremental upgrades and exclusives to their shoe departments, setting the stage for a Battle of the Blahniks that could carry on well into the next decade. In 2018, Nordstrom, well known for the breadth of its footwear offerings, is set to open an attack on the Western Front, or at least on West 57th Street. Down in Herald Square, meanwhile, Macy's is fortifying its flagship during a $400 million overhaul with a shoe department that will reportedly hold more than 300,000 pairs. But the latest salvo came this week from Barneys New York, which opened a shoe department that sprawls across an adjoining floor of its men's and women's store on Madison Avenue. A civilian might have thought that the new look was designed to equate shoe shopping with entering heaven, as the elevators open onto a gleamingly bright and white space, covering 22,000 square feet on the fifth floor. (It was created with the interior design firm Yabu Pushelberg.)

BALONON--Adoracion, MD (Morales) "Cion," Rochester, NY. Formerly of Manahawkin, NJ and New York City, on July 17, 2012 in NYC following a brief illness, at 86. Born in Manila, beloved wife of late Pedro S. Balonon, loving mother of Alma Balonon-Rosen, dear mother-in-law to Mitchell Rosen, cherished Lola of Marissa and Peter, Ninang to many. Predeceased by brothers. Rogelio and Romulo and sister Areceli. Univ of Santo Thomas Medical School, Philippines, 1952. Spent career at Creedmoor Children's Hospital, Queens and New Lisbon State School, New Jersey. Enjoyed recent months at River's Run, Rochester. Services will be in NYC. In lieu of flowers, family requests donation in honor of Adoracion M. Balonon, Eastman Pathways Program, c/o Development Office, Eastman Community School, 26 Gibbs St, Rochester NY 14604.

HONDA announced on Wednesday that it would join, however belatedly, the connected-car race, pledging a new HondaLink telematics system for the Honda Accord. The upgraded system will be offered in the sedan this fall. Like systems offered by nearly every major automaker, the more robust HondaLink relies on the Android and iPhone handsets of owners to feed information from the Web to an in-dash display. Honda said drivers would be able to stream Internet radio stations, download audiobooks, view aggregated ratings for nearby restaurants and have Facebook feeds read aloud.

Last week's heat wave did not faze the stylish. For many younger men, the trend to abandon socks has only grown stronger. Men who embrace a '30s and '40s image from the days before air-conditioning rely on airy, light mohair suits and the occasional dapper straw hat. Perfectionists greet 90-degree heat with a fresh lapel flower. In stylish Southampton, N.Y., a Lilly Pulitzer suit stood out among white linen and navy blazers. In tony Rumson, N.J., cotton seersucker remains a signature.

HOMER--William Innes, Ph.D. A nationally recognized scholar, teacher and connoisseur of the Arts, Dr. Homer died peacefully at his home in Greenville, DE on July 8, 2012 at the age of 82. A Memorial Service and celebration of his life will be held at Christ Church Christiana Hundred, Greenville, DE on October 26, 2012 at 11:30am. For additional information, please go to: www.chandlerfuneralhome. com

9 P.M. (13, 49) INSPECTOR LEWIS, SERIES V: FEARFUL SYMMETRY A new season of this ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' stalwart continues as Inspector Lewis, the long-suffering detective played by Kevin Whately, and his erudite sidekick, Detective Sgt. James Hathaway (Laurence Fox, above left with Mr. Whately), are drawn into the underbelly of Oxford while investigating the murder of Jessica Lake (Abigail Hardingham), a substitute baby sitter who was found bound by her wrists to the bed of her employers, Honey and Nick Addams (Georgia Taylor and Ciaran McMenamin). But when this unusual death pose exposes Jessica's secret life as a model for Marion Hammond (Lucy Cohu), a fetish photographer exploring the nature of passion, the men find themselves searching for answers in a residence for abandoned children, a primate lab and the home of a venture capitalist (Gary Kemp), who just happens to be Nick's boss, adorned with Marion's photographs. 8:30 A.M. (IFC) CURSE OF THE GOLDEN FLOWER (2006) A cruel emperor (Chow Yun-Fat) and his secretive wife (Gong Li) plot each other's annihilation: he by destroying her sanity with a rare fungus; she by planning a bloody coup during a festival. Writing in The New York Times, Jeannette Catsoulis said that this martial-arts drama from the director Zhang Yimou, set in A.D. 928, ''achieves a kind of operatic delirium, opening the floodgates of image and melodrama until the line between tragedy and black comedy is all but erased.''

BAUER--Emily Jane, on July 19, 2012. Beloved wife of Peter Bauer and daughter of Elizabeth Flesch. Loving mother of Victoria Nadler (Mark) and David Bauer (Alison). Cherished grandmother of Audrey, Stephen, Benjamin, Matthew, and Daniel. We love you and miss you. Contributions can be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, P.O. Box 27106, New York, NY 10087-7106.

CITING a fire hazard, Ford is recalling about 11,500 of its new 2013 Escape crossovers in North America and telling drivers to immediately stop driving them. In a media release issued on Thursday, the automaker said the problem was traced to the fuel line on the turbocharged 1.6-liter EcoBoost 4-cylinder engine. The line, Ford said, could split.

SILVERMAN--Robin Amy, 58, of New York City, loving daughter, sister, niece, cousin and trusted friend, after enjoying life to the fullest, and facing death with courage, perseverance and dignity, died on July 20, 2011, surrounded by her mother and close friends. Robin was born on July 13, 1953 in New York City to Sam and Beverly Silverman, and was raised on Long Island. Having lived in Boston, New York City, and Providence, she returned to New York City after grad- uating from The Rhode Island School of Design with professional degrees in both Architecture and Fine Arts. Robin also received a degree in Interior Design from Fashion Institute of Technology. She was a gifted artist and designer, who possessed a strong work ethic, and had a distinguished career as an architect, most recently as an Associate within the partnership group at Skidmore Owings & Merrill in New York. As a recipient of a prestigious Stewardson Keefe LeBrun Travel Grant from the American Institute of Architects, Robin conducted extensive architectural research in northern Italy in 1997, where her self-directed study focused on modernist interventions to architecturally historic significant buildings, including the work of Carlo Scarpa, as an alternative approach to historic building additions. A generous teacher and professional advisor, Robin shared information and knowledge while training younger designers and architects. Robin was a creative, fiercely determined yet reflective and sensitive person, generous with her loyalty, support and compassion. She radiated warmth, passion and humor and was especially inspired by travel, cultures, spirituality, the mystery and beauty of the natural world, color, and all of the Arts. She is survived by her mother, Beverly Silverman of Sun City Center, Florida, her sister, Susan of New York City, many cousins, as well as cherished friends and colleagues from New York City, throughout the United States and abroad. She is predeceased by her beloved father, Sam Silverman. Donations may be made to TNBC Foundation, P.O. Box 204, Norwood, NJ 07648 or www.tnbcfoundation.org/ donate.htm

Johan Santana, the ace of the Mets' pitching rotation, was placed on the 15-day disabled list Saturday because of soreness in his right ankle. The team said that the ankle, which Santana hurt on July 6 against Chicago, was the primary source of his recent struggles. ''We sat for quite a while this morning in discussion with Johan and the training staff, and pretty much determined that the ankle issue was bigger than anybody had realized,'' Manager Terry Collins said. ''Ever since he had the ankle injury, his command has not been there, due to the fact that he can't land properly, that he's using all arm to pitch, causing some fatigue in his shoulder.''
BOERUM HILL TRIPLEX $1,225,000

IF heritage work wear was the biggest story of the last couple of years, then urban surf is its successor. Thanks to stores like Saturdays in SoHo, and the now-closed but once-revered Mollusk and its mastermind Chris Gentile's latest venture, Pilgrim Surf and Supply in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, there's a huge resurgence in 1950s Californiana on the East Coast. Pilgrim Surf and Supply, which opened in February, is a one-stop shop for all your Brooklyn-based surfing needs. In store you'll find pieces from M.Nii Makaha, a Californian brand that claims to have made the very first pair of board shorts in the late 1950s. You know that clever shoelace waistband system you find on most swim shorts? That's their invention. The T-shirts, all sun faded and shlubby, look as if they've already been worn on countless trips to the beach; the Vans tees are cut in the softest washed-out cottons and feature the company's original '50s and '60s graphics. The Best in Store award has to go to swimwear made by Bantu, an African surf brand that digitally screen-prints traditional local designs on water-ready fabric. Each print is used for one season only, and the cutting technique ensures that no two pairs are the same. M.Nii T-shirt, $72; Bantu shorts, $125; Auntie Oti towel, $48; available at Pilgrim Surf and Supply, 68 North Third Street, Brooklyn, (718) 218-7456. ISAAC HINDIN-MILLER

To the Sports Editor: Re ''I Got Next,'' July 12: On many visits to New York over the years, I've enjoyed watching pickup games from the other side of the fence as an outsider. Those games captivate me as no N.B.A. game can, but I've never really been able to figure out the how they work, or what they mean.

KONLANDE--James E.,in Hayward, CA, 78. Survived by wife, Anny, daughter, Carol, step-son, Chenghua, and siblings, Ken, Tom, and John Konlande and Cathy Wellikoff. He was a college professor and co-authored Encyclopedia of Foods & Nutrition. He will be greatly missed.

Some may shrug and say that the undisclosed high-altitude tracking of U.S. vehicles for training purposes is harmless, but the line between civilian privacy and an increasingly Orwellian capacity of the federal government to track its own citizens is blurred just a bit more by this practice. There are already serious concerns about U.S. military drones -- designed for warfare abroad -- being repurposed for civilian purposes. . . . The problem with an ever powerful national government with more and more tools to control and track its citizenry is that these powers, legal and technical, are often abused and used in ways not originally intended. STEVE CLEMONS, posted on theatlantic.com

FEDERICO--Helen Lesser, died July 19 at home in Pound Ridge, NY, age 90. Helen had a long career as a graphic designer, painter and illustrator. Born September 15, 1921, to Donald and Augusta Brand Lesser. A talented and directed young artist, she graduated from Washington Irving High and Parsons School of Design. She worked for the Abbott Kimball advertising co., where she met her future husband, art director Gene Federico. They were married June 26, 1942. Helen worked at I. Miller shoes, assisting Alexey Brodovich, known for introducing modern graphic design to the U.S., and was associate art director under Paul Rand at William H. Weintraub Co. Moved to Pound Ridge in 1951, where Helen worked as an independent illustrator, painter and graphic designer. Clients included MOMA, IBM, Doubleday, Glamour, Fortune. Specializing in gouache and acryllics, she created scores of beautiful paintings. She wrote and illustrated children's books and illustrated cookbooks. She was a former trustee of Hiram Halle Memorial Library (Pound Ridge). Survived by daughters Lisa Federico (Hillsdale, NY) and Gina Federico (Pound Ridge); grandchildren Rio and Deco Goodman, and Elie and Kaare Andersen. Lovingly attended in recent years by caregivers Steven Hunt and Paula Forbes. There will be a memorial in September. Donations may be made to Cary Library, Rochester Institute of Technology, Rochester, to support the Helen Federico Collection.

''Yahoo finally has someone who has both business acumen and geek cred at the helm.'' Chris Sacca, a venture capitalist and former Google employee, on Yahoo's decision to hire Marissa Mayer, one of the top executives at Google, as its chief executive.

ROSNER--Harold, loved by so many, passed away peacefully on July 18th. He was in his 96th year and continued to enjoy his life immensely. He had no interest in dying. Predeceased by Anne, his beloved wife of 54 years, he is survived by his daughter Susan Rosner Ragusa and his son Jeff Rosner who are left to cherish his memory as a terrific dad and good buddy! Graveside Services - private.

IN 2010 LE'ANDRIA JOHNSON came in first on ''Sunday Best,'' BET's gospel answer to ''American Idol.'' She won on the strength of her extraordinary, flexible, battling voice. And the controversial data about her daily life, as a financially struggling, twice-divorced single mother of three who at first had defended her desire to go to clubs, drink and smoke -- then later announced she'd forsworn it all -- didn't hurt. In April she revealed to an audience in Philadelphia that she was pregnant with her fourth child, which would be fine in any other segment of American music, but not in gospel, because she's still single. Since then, online and on the radio, the gospel audience has debated whether she should be ''sat down,'' or take a break from ministry. Meanwhile the caravan rolls on. She performs in a free SummerStage gospel concert Wednesday at 7 p.m. at Springfield Park in Queens, along with the rising, Donny Hathaway-influenced Brian Courtney Wilson; Trin-I-Tee 5:7; and the most recent ''Sunday Best'' winner, Amber Bullock. Information: nycgovparks.org.

RESIDENTS of Barrio Logan, a predominately Mexican-American neighborhood near the waterfront in downtown San Diego, have long fought to preserve the area's Latino cultural heritage. In the 1960s, when a bridge linking downtown to the wealthy Coronado enclave bisected the neighborhood, displacing many homes and businesses, local artists responded by turning the bridge pylons into soaring murals depicting Chicano heroes and historical events. Recent years have seen a new wave of artists' collectives, performance spaces and galleries occupying repurposed warehouses, and many of the newcomers maintain ties to Barrio Logan's Latino roots. BRENDAN SPIEGEL

It's unclear whether the slew of seating fees that have touched off a backlash by families, who fear that they will be separated, has increased airlines' revenue. But the fees have prompted action. Representative Jerrold Nadler, a New York Democrat, introduced a bill this month requiring the transportation secretary to issue regulations to ensure that families sit together ''to the extent practicable.'' ''Families should not be stuck paying hidden fees, or buying 'premium' seats, simply because they wish to be seated together on crowded flights,'' Mr. Nadler said in a statement. The bill comes after Allegiant Air and Spirit began charging for advance seating assignments and after several carriers, including American and Delta, increased the percentage of coach seats offered at a premium fare.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Scandal at Penn State Leaves the N.C.A.A. With Difficult Decisions,'' July 15: The Sandusky cover-up is directly linked to gaining an unfair advantage on the football field because Coach Joe Paterno knew the bad publicity would hurt recruiting. Therefore, the so-called death penalty for Penn State's football program is inevitable and appropriate.

I met Albrecht Muth and Viola Drath at a small party in the late '90s or early 2000s. I actually didn't think they were a pair and asked Viola who she was with. She said, ''Albrecht!'' I said, ''What does Albrecht do?'' She said, ''Nothing!'' How I wish that were true. She was a tragic figure indeed. MICHAEL J. ORTIZ, Potomac, Md., posted on nytimes.com

Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County, Arizona, whose trial in a class-action civil-rights lawsuit continues this week in Phoenix, didn't get to be America's most notorious anti-immigrant lawman by being shy. The camera and microphone are blood and oxygen to him. Where he goes, he trails TV crews, a gallery of rabid followers, posse volunteers and, every four years, supplicating Republican presidential candidates. The tent-city jail he calls his ''concentration camp'' is meant to signify brash, unchallenged power. In the blistering landscape of Phoenix, he blots out the sun. The people he abuses and humiliates, by contrast, are not Fox News regulars. The men and women hustled into custody by his immigration sweeps are generally undocumented and unknown. The neighborhoods he targets can seem like traumatized places, silent and cowed by the dread Sheriff Joe.

SCHICK--George, On July 16th, 83, of Westwood, NJ. Devoted father of Jeanette Waldman and Ron Schick. Loving grandfather of Nichole, Michele, Dylan, Mason and Ruby. George was born in Budapest, Hungary and was a survivor of the Holocaust. He excelled at school and was a water polo captain. He escaped Hungary in 1956 and learned French at a collegiate level to finish his undergraduate studies at the University of Grenoble, in France. He moved to New York, learned English at a graduate studies level and received a scholarship to MIT where he earned his Masters of Science in Metallurgy in 1961. During his time at MIT he formed a water polo team and was recruited by Bell Labs who paid for his PhD studies. While at NYU he earned a Doctor of Philosophy degree from the School of Engineering and Science, as well as membership with the International Metallurgical Honor Society in 1971. In 1972, NYU awarded him a Founders Day Certificate. His primary research identified that 'Hydrogen Producing Bacteria was the cause of appreciable signal attenuation in optical fibers and that they could be suppressed by sulfate-reducing bacteria." This research led to advancements in a number of applied sciences including the corrosive protection coating all automobiles and all fiber optic cabling to this day. In 1994 he received the Francis L. LaQue Memorial Award from the American Society for Testing and Materials for outstanding contributions to the field of corrosion testing and evaluation and became a Fellow of the ASTM in 1997. He was NACE chairman from 1983-1993 and served the National Association of Corrosion Engineers for over 25 years and received its technical achievement award in 1998. In 1985 he was named Distinguished Member of the Professional Staff by BELCORE. Throughout his career, during summer months, he was a professor at the University of West Virginia. He was a great man in every way and the world has lost a national treasure.

IN China modern dance is still relatively young, which is understandable. The political atmosphere hasn't exactly made it easy for an art form known to challenge the status quo to flourish. But this season's Lincoln Center Festival provides a closer look at one of the country's freshest choreographic voices. TAO YE, who formed TAO Dance Theater in 2008, presents his company in ''2,'' a male duet, and ''4,'' a work for four women that explores constant synchronicity. Clearly Mr. Tao cares little for complicated titles. As he sees it, words weigh a dance down, and he prefers that audiences view his works with as little expectation -- and as much imagination -- as possible. Both pieces exemplify Mr. Tao's approach, which is rooted in contemporary concerns about the body. His minimalist aesthetic strips movement and the human figure to their essence. In the spellbinding ''2,'' set to a score by the Chinese composer Xiao He, the dancers are first seen as deflated forms facedown on the floor. As they start to move, sliding their thighs and flinging their arms against the stage's surface, they possess the loopy grace of fish out of water. Prepare to be hypnotized. 7:30 p.m., Wednesday and Friday, Starr Theater, Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center; (212) 721-6500, lincolncenterfestival.org. $30 to $55.

It's the fate of being in the middle: a good student but not Ivy caliber, strapped by college costs but not eligible for enough need-based aid. The New York Times analyzed College Board data of colleges that award merit aid and compiled a list of larger schools (2,000-plus undergraduates) that give at least $5,000 to 10 percent or more of first-time freshmen. All monetary figures are in 2012 dollars. A fuller list of colleges is at nytimes.com/edlife.

An article last Sunday about the changing risks of mountaineering misstated the cause of death of two people in Great Smoky Mountains National Park in Tennessee this month. They died from falling trees or tree limbs in a violent thunderstorm that struck the area, not from flooding during the storm.

MANY longtime opera buffs miss the METROPOLITAN OPERA'S summer tours of New York parks, presenting concert performances of complete operas. In recent years the Met has substituted a series of free recitals in the parks in all five boroughs, programs that have proved popular. The first of this summer's six recitals (which run through Aug. 9) is on Wednesday at SummerStage in Central Park, featuring the exquisite soprano Danielle de Niese, the exciting tenor Dimitri Pittas and the robust bass-baritone John Del Carlo, with the pianist Dan Saunders, performing arias, ensembles and songs. 8 p.m., Rumsey Playfield, midpark at 70th Street; (212) 362-6000, metopera.org. On Friday those artists head to Brooklyn Bridge Park. 7 p.m., Pier 1, Harbor View Lawn, Brooklyn. Those looking for free outdoor music of another type might head to the Museum of Modern Art sculpture garden on Sunday night for the third Summergarden concert. Musicians from the NEW JUILLIARD ENSEMBLE will perform new works for string quartet. Despite occasional traffic noise, not to mention lively birds who like to sing along, this is an inviting place to hear contemporary music. Gates open at 7 p.m., concert starts at 8, enter on West 54th Street; (212) 708-9400; moma.org.

WARREN--Lucie Bedford Cunningham Warren, of Greens Farms, CT, passed away peacefully at her home on July 16, 2012. Mrs. Warren was 104 years old. She is survived by her three children, Briggs S. Cunningham, III, and his wife, Elizabeth, of Lancaster, Kentucky, Lucie C. McKinney, of Greens Farms, CT, and Cythlen C. Maddock, and her husband, Paul "Jay" Maddock, of Palm Beach, FL. She was predeceased by her first husband, Briggs S. Cunningham, II, and her second husband, Lynne A. Warren. In addition to her children, Mrs. Warren was survived by her grandchildren, Paige Cunningham Garland, Brian Cunningham, Robert Cunningham, Blair Cunningham Newsome, Stewart B. McKinney, Jr., Lucie B. McKinney, Jean McKinney, Elizabeth McKinney Tritschler, John P. McKinney, John Dewing, Cythlen Dewing Moss, and Zachary Read. She was also survived by 25 great-grandchildren. She is survived by her sister, Ruth Bedford, and predeceased by her sisters, Helen McCashin and Mary Bedford. Mrs. Warren was also survived by her goddaughter, Lesley Cowenhoven, her good friend, Kathryn Ann Rabesa, and her loyal companions and sailing master, Walter and Lorraine Billings. Mrs. Warren was a woman who was ahead of her time well educated, well travelled, graceful and athletic. She was dignified, competitive and independent. She had vision, energy and a strong work ethic. Most of all, Mrs. Warren believed in helping others. She was known as the "working donor" and was a leader in her philanthropic pursuits. She was an extremely private person and always believed that her philanthropy did not need fanfare or notoriety. Mrs. Warren was a generous giver of time and philanthropy to many charitable worthwhile causes for over 75 years. She was deeply concerned about education and children. She supported Norwalk Hospital, especially the Lucie Bedford Warren Department of Pediatrics. She volunteered two days each week at Norwalk Hospital until she was 96 years old. She also supported the Wakeman Boys and Girls Club, Greens Farms Academy, the Chapin School in New York City, the Westport YMCA, the Connecticut Audubon Society, the Garden Club of America, the Mystic Aquarium Seaport for the Brilliant and many other worthwhile causes. She also volunteered at the Pequot Library Book Sale each year until she was 97 years old. In addition, she helped hundreds of individuals in supporting their personal education. When it came to education, Mrs. Warren never said no. Mrs. Warren was involved in many other activities and was exceptional in all she did including golf, tennis, basketball, and field hockey. She attended Smith College in Northhampton, MA. She was the golf club champion at the Country Club of Fairfield, many times. She was the only woman champion of the Star Atlantic Coast Sailing Championship. She enjoyed being a part of the support team when her husband, Briggs Cunningham, won the America's Cup in 1958 and when he raced in Le Mans in the 1950s. Lucie and Briggs also won numerous sailing championships in Europe. Mrs. Warren had tremendous care in her final years and the family is extremely grateful to all of the dedicated individuals who provided such exceptional care and who became a part of her life. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to any of the charities that Mrs. Warren was involved. She improved countless lives and we are better people because of her. She will be greatly missed. Services will be private.

In honor of Nora Ephron, who died last month, the Big City Book Club will revisit her early work as a journalist and essayist. In the 1960s and '70s, she wrote for magazines like Rolling Stone, New York and The New Yorker -- pieces collected in the anthologies ''Crazy Salad'' and ''Wallflower at the Orgy.'' We're going to read ''Wallflower'' because it's more readily available, but if you're lucky enough to have an old copy of ''Crazy Salad,'' reread it, too, and weigh in!

An article on July 8 about Charles Dickens's travels in Switzerland, and an accompanying map, misspelled the name of a town on Lake Geneva. It is Montreux, not Montreaux.

GAY characters are common on television and in films now, but there was another period when the movies contained a fair amount of homosexuality as well, or at least allusions to it. Vito Russo, who rediscovered those precode films and explored what happened to gay characters later in the century in a lecture series and book called ''The Celluloid Closet,'' is the subject of ''VITO,'' a documentary Monday night on HBO that recounts his eventful life not just as a scholar but also as an activist at the center of the gay-rights scene in New York. Mr. Russo, who died of AIDS in 1990, seemed to be everywhere in the tumultuous years when the gay liberation movement was defining itself and, it's now easy to see, changing American society. A revolution of a different sort is hinted at in ''THE LIGHT IN HER EYES,'' a timely documentary on PBS's ''POV'' that is being broadcast Sunday on WNET in New York (check local listings). It chronicles a school for girls in Damascus that emphasizes the study of Islam and a woman's place in it. The film was made just before the current uprising in Syria.
