ANDERSON--Vance J. Dearly loved husband, father, grandfather, brother, brother-in-law, and friend died on July 16th at home in Lakeville, CT more than five years after his diagnosis of lung cancer. He was 70. Vance grew up in Alexandria, VA where his lifelong fascination with history and government began. Although he was a nominee for a Woodrow Wilson Fellowship he instead chose a career in law. After graduating from the Georgetown University Law Center he joined the Employee Benefits Division of the American National Bank & Trust Co. in Chicago. He returned to Washington, DC to join the United States House of Representatives Committee on Education & Labor. He was its Chief Counsel and Staff Director-Pension Task Force. The work of this committee led to the passage of the Employee Retirement Security Act of 1974 (ERISA). Subsequently he held positions with the American Bankers Association and then rejoined the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Education & Labor to focus on the passage of the Multi-employer Pension Plan Act of 1980. His work in employment law continued after joining Mobil Oil Corporation as Employee Relations Counsel and Assistant Secretary. He then served as Associate General Counsel and Assistant Secretary of Allied Signal Inc. He joined Merrill Lynch's Office of the General Counsel in 1998 initially acting as an advisor to its Retirement Group. Despite his diagnosis of cancer in 2007, he continued to work virtually uninterrupted until early 2012. His most recent position was Managing Director and Associate General Counsel of Bank of America/Merrill Lynch. He is survived by his wife, Margaret Monaco; his son James Anderson, daughter-in-law Virginia Grandison, their children Emma and James, Jr.; his daughter Emily Anderson, son-in-law David Natt, their children Sydney, Sam, and Sophie; his daughter Heather (Anderson) Donnelly, son-in-law Brian Donnelly, their children George and Abigail; his daughter Meaghan Anderson; his sister Jane (Anderson) Cram; nieces, nephews, grand nephews, sisters and brothers-in-law. He was predeceased by his brother, Cyrus T. Anderson, Jr. and his parents Cyrus T. and Marna Lucille Anderson. Vance's work was always important to him; he found a true home and work family when he joined Merrill Lynch but nothing was more important to him than his own family he was the constant in his children's lives. He took such joy in watching them blossom and mature. He was so proud of the adults they became. And then there were the grandchildren; he loved being their "Hot Shot" although it was for far too short a time. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church in Greenwich, CT on Friday, July 27, 2012 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Memorial Sloane-Kettering Cancer Center, Attn: Mark G. Kris, MD or the Salisbury Visiting Nurse Association Hospice.

Leonard Cohen's ''Book of Longing'' must be the most discussed book in Silicon Valley since Walter Isaacson's life of Steve Jobs. The Canadian songwriter's collection of verse and drawings, first published in 2006, plays a highly visible role in the suit Ellen Pao has filed against her employer, the venture firm of Kleiner Perkins. That case will again be in the news on Friday, when Kleiner goes to court to argue that it should go to arbitration. When thinking about the case, ''Book of Longing'' offers a useful prism. Are these poems and sketches offensive, as the plaintiff charges, or benign, as the defense would have it?

Dear Diary: On my morning No. 2 train ride, crowded as usual, the oblivious man standing next to me could do no right. As he knelt to find something in his bag, he blocked off half a carriage of free space. When he stood and someone tried to walk by, he raised an elbow and whacked the unfortunate commuter in the chest. Another rider, having left the seat next to him to alight from the train, was forced to navigate his armpit.

THE UNITED STATES SENT more than 300 athletes to the last Olympics in London, the 1948 Summer Games. Despite a food rationing program in effect after World War II and accommodations in barracks, veterans of '48 consider the experience some of the best days of their lives. Archival photographs and audio clips from more than a dozen United States Olympians who competed in London, including their memories of winning and losing, of meeting royalty and celebrities, and of visiting a city much different from the one that will welcome the world this week, are at nytimes.com/olympics. 2012 LONDON

''La Douleur,'' a French theater piece based on the diaries of the writer Marguerite Duras and directed by Patrice Chereau, will come to the United States as part of the fall season at the Baryshnikov Arts Center, the organization announced. The play stars the prominent French actress Dominique Blanc and includes the collaboration of the choreographer Thierry Thieû Niang. It will be staged in French with projected titles in English. The season, which will run from Sept. 20 to Dec. 15, includes an appearance by the Bolshoi Puppet Theater in its United States debut, performing an adaptation of ''Kholstomer: The Story of a Horse,'' a short story by Tolstoy. The center also will have musical and dance performances. The choreographer Doug Elkins will bring his dance company for performances of his work based on Shakespeare's ''Othello'' set to Motown music. Other choreographers featured at the center will include Raimund Hoghe and Malavika Sarukkai. The St. Luke's and International Contemporary ensembles will perform musical programs. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

8:36 p.m. | Updated NRG Energy said Sunday that it had agreed to buy GenOn Energy for about $1.7 billion in stock, creating one of the biggest independent power generation companies in the country. The deal is the latest example of consolidation within the power industry, as companies seek to deal with falling electricity prices. NRG has pursued several transactions over the past decade, and GenOn was formed from the 2010 union of RRI Energy and Mirant.

An obituary on Wednesday about the producer, director and screenwriter William Asher included several errors. Mr. Asher was about 3 years old when his parents moved from New York to California, not about 10. He worked in the mailroom at Universal Studios before joining the Army, not after being discharged. He and his second wife, the actress Elizabeth Montgomery, had not had children before they both worked on the series ''Bewitched''; Ms. Montgomery was pregnant with their first child when the show began. And Ms. Montgomery died at age 62, not 57. (Many accounts of her death in 1995, including a Times obituary, gave her age as 57, but it was later established that she had been born in 1933.)

Because of editing errors, an article on Thursday about the soprano Elizabeth Futral misidentified the composers of two works in which she has appeared at the Metropolitan Opera. ''Juive'' is by Fromental Halévy, not Giacomo Meyerbeer; ''I Puritani'' is by Vincenzo Bellini, not Gaetano Donizetti. The article also referred incompletely to the distance between Cooperstown, N.Y., where Ms. Futral has been performing in ''The Music Man,'' and Manhattan, where she is performing in ''Émilie'' in the Lincoln Center Festival. While it is about 139 miles as the crow flies, for the wingless who must make the trip by car, it is about 195 miles.

There were 10 of us, including our hosts, Jacqueline and Aristotle; Ari's Greek godson and his wife; Jackie's cousin Nina Steers; Gianni Agnelli and his sister Susanna Rattazzi; and my date, David Frost.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau cited Capital One Bank for deceptive practices last week. The bank, which will pay $210 million in fines and refunds to customers, is one of several that offer products like so-called credit card payment insurance. Capital One, which features celebrities like Alec Baldwin and Jerry Stiller, above, in its commercials, ranked third most favorable among 29 banks tracked by YouGov in the first half of 2012. As a group, consumer banks scored dead last behind several industries, including retailers, carmakers tech companies and airlines. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Voice recognition technology is critically important, not just for mobile phones, but potentially for control of lots of other devices, particularly televisions. It is still early days, but if you're thinking about which side will win in the battle between Apple's Siri and Google Voice Search, consider the lesson of spell check. When Eric Schmidt was still chief executive of Google, I asked him what the company owned that would make it particularly hard for any emerging search contender to wipe Google out. Spell check, he said. Google had observed the spelling mistakes and corrections typed into billions of queries, and had a vast understanding of what people really meant when they typed like thsi. Google was able to use this knowledge to offer a ''did you mean'' function in search, eventually completing queries before people were finished typing.

Not everyone thinks of Austin as a city for winter sports. There is the decided lack of snow, for one thing. And the average December-January temperatures range from 41 to 62. But, why not? If we set American ingenuity to the task, we can certainly come up with a polymer that would do the job, some petroleum-based product that would be powdery and slick, so that people can Ski the Hill Country. If the powder is black instead of pearly white, well, skiers can adjust. And black is slimming.

Amid all the talk of American cities hosting the Olympics, there is no doubt that New Orleans is the clear choice for the 2024 Summer Games. The Winter Games would be my preference, but the United States is already out of the 2022 bidding, and things here don't always get done right on the old nose, so 2022 would have been pushing it anyway. So Summer 2024 it is. This is a very sports-oriented city, though it may not be obvious at first glance. There are the Saints, the Hornets and a succession of major sporting events in the Superdome. There is also the athletic endurance of the citizens themselves, who can sit and watch these sports -- often while drinking -- for hours at a time.

59E59 Theaters has announced that it will present the New York premiere of a revival of Stephen Schwartz's musical ''Working'' beginning Dec. 1 as part of its fall season. Based on the 1974 nonfiction book of the same name by the oral historian Studs Terkel, this version of ''Working,'' which had a run last year at the Broadway Playhouse in Chicago, includes two new songs written by Lin-Manuel Miranda (''In the Heights''). Casting has not been announced. The season will start on Sept. 5 with ''Fly Me to the Moon,'' a new comedy written and directed by Marie Jones (''A Night in November'') about two social workers who face a moral dilemma when a man in their care dies after winning a horse racing bet. That is to be followed by, among others, ''A Twist of Water,'' written by Caitlin Montanye Parrish (''The View From Tall''), from Nov. 1 through Nov. 25, and ''The Outgoing Tide,'' written by Bruce Graham (''Any Given Monday''), from Nov. 7 to Dec. 16.

Lasker Rink is close by, for hockey, if we can get the rabid youth league parents to clear out.

She is survived by her nephew, Mark Johnston, his wife Alice, their son, Travis and her longtime friend and travel companion, Betty Deming. She was employed at Jacobi Medical Center in New York for over 30 years, concluding her career as Associate Director of Nursing. One of the first murals that Franco Gaskin noticed missing was of a weeping Martin Luther King Jr. He had painted the work about 18 years ago on the dreary metal front gate of an abandoned store where Dr. King was said to have had a book signing. Then his painting of a bountiful harvest outside a store called Family Fair Fruit that is now a Starbucks disappeared. Also gone was his vision of a phoenix flying near the sun outside a mom-and-pop store that became a Rite Aid. Back when Harlem's 125th Street was a far drearier commercial stretch, Mr. Gaskin, an artist who has gained global acclaim as Franco the Great, painted mural after mural on the storefront security gates. He ultimately painted about 200 of them.

Updated 8:59 p.m. | Five people, including two children, died Sunday morning when a sport utility vehicle they were riding in hit a concrete support, rolled over and burst into flames near the Van Wyck Expressway in Queens, the authorities said. Shortly before the accident, the driver and seven passengers had left a nearby banquet hall, where an association of Nigerian immigrants had gathered from across the United States for a celebration that featured dancing and discussions about improvement projects they were sponsoring in their homeland.

''Jackie,'' a play by the Nobel laureate Elfriede Jelinek that dissects the life and legend of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, will have its North American premiere this winter at the new Off Broadway home of the Women's Project, the producing artistic director, Julie Crosby, said. The theater company, now 35 years old, which produces plays written and directed by women, will mount ''Jackie'' and two other shows for its 2012-13 season at City Center Stage II, which the Pearl Theater Company vacated this year to move to the old home of Signature Theater Company. The first show will be ''Bethany,'' written by Laura Mark and directed by Gaye Taylor Upchurch, a dark comedy about morality set in an American exurb where home foreclosures are spreading. The production, a world premiere, is scheduled to run Jan. 11 to Feb. 17.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. -- Barry Larkin, half of the Baseball Hall of Fame's class of 2012, puffed his chest, clenched his fists and held his head high, full of pride. Larkin, a Cincinnati native, had played 19 seasons for the team he grew up adoring, had played for Pete Rose, a legend and a mentor, and had won a World Series for the city in 1990. And this was his chance to reflect.

A variety of contenders faltered during Sunday's final round of the 141st British Open, but no one seemed to find himself in more peculiar situations than Tiger Woods. That included a bunker shot on the sixth hole when he nearly hit himself with his ball and then had to drop to both knees to hit it sideways. He ended up with a three-over-par seven on the hole.

BURKE--Brian M.,aged 58, died peacefully at home on Shelter Island on July 19, 2012. After a long battle, Brian died from cancer. All remember Brian for his kind spirit, mirthful smile and witty intelligence. He is survived by his five siblings- Kathy, Joan, Richard, Helen and Nancy. A memorial will be held in Manhattan in January, 2013. Brian will be missed by all who knew him. Donations, in lieu of flowers, can be made to East End Hospice, Colgate University or Regis High School.

Jerry was the husband of Carol Gertz, our esteemed board member and one of the founders of CPFA. He was the father of the late Ali Gertz. Our heartfelt sympathy to Carol and her mother Elise. The Board of CPFA

8 P.M. (TCM) SPOTLIGHT: CLASSIC ADVENTURE The first part of a daylong pirate fest starts at 5:45 a.m. with ''Captain Kidd'' (1945), starring Charles Laughton in the title role, and ends at 6:30 p.m. with ''China Seas'' (1935), featuring Clark Gable (above, with Jean Harlow) as the hard-living captain of an ocean steamer. That is followed by the Spotlight series, with the blockbusters ''Mutiny on the Bounty'' (1935), with Laughton as the sadistic Captain Bligh and Gable as his lieutenant, Fletcher Christian, at 8; ''Captain Horatio Hornblower'' (1951), with Gregory Peck as the heroic British sailor during the Napoleonic Wars, at 10:30; ''Treasure Island'' (1934), Robert Louis Stevenson's tale about a boy (Jackie Cooper) out to foil pirates (including Wallace Beery, as Long John Silver) and find a buried treasure, at 12:30 a.m.; and ''Captain Blood'' (1935), with the swashbuckling Errol Flynn as a doctor who, unjustly sent to prison, escapes to become a notorious pirate, at 2:30. Ioan Gruffudd does a stint as Hornblower, this time commanding a transport schooner along the North African coast, in ''Horatio Hornblower: The Fire Ship,'' at 8 p.m. on Ovation. 8 P.M. (Sundance) THE FIRST WIVES CLUB (1996) After their college friend (Stockard Channing, in a cameo) dives off a Fifth Avenue terrace, drink in hand, three middle-aged friends (Bette Midler, Diane Keaton and Goldie Hawn) take revenge on the husbands who have abandoned them (Dan Hedaya, Stephen Collins and Victor Garber) for younger women (Sarah Jessica Parker, Marcia Gay Harden and Elizabeth Berkley) in this comedy directed by Hugh Wilson and based on the novel by Olivia Goldsmith. ''The film is played as witchy, all-star vamping with a lethal sting,'' Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. ''What makes its premise especially funny is that, at heart, it's no laughing matter.''

OAKLAND, Calif. -- It had been nine years since the Yankees were swept in a four-game series, and more than 40 years since they allowed the Oakland Athletics to do it. That four-game sweep by Oakland occurred at Yankee Stadium in July 1972, the year the Swingin' A's won their first World Series with Reggie Jackson, Catfish Hunter and Vida Blue. But since the Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum opened in 1968, no Athletics team could take four games from the Yankees here, not until this feisty version did it over the weekend.

Ernie Els was watching cricket in his Lytham hotel Sunday morning when he suddenly realized what he needed to do if he managed to win the British Open. He should make mention of Nelson Mandela, the former president of South Africa. Els did just that as he held up the claret jug after his stunning come-from-behind victory.

Combine athletic excellence, your spoiled niece's wedding and your midlife crisis into one inspiring event! Instead of gold, silver and bronze medals, winners receive silver pendants for first place, turquoise bracelets for second and, for third, kitschy amethyst-and-pewter pendants made by former Long Islanders who took community college extension classes in Navajo art. Watch as the setting sun casts dramatic shadows over eternal landscape features like the Red Rocks and Bob Costas. Special event: the cognitive dissonance balance beam, in which aging flower children try to shift in midsentence from ''this ethereal landscape has allowed me to transcend material needs'' to ''that Hope Solo petrified wood sculpture costs $600'' without falling over sideways.

The Cygnus Ensemble has announced that it will perform new musical compositions based on the works of Samuel Beckett, to be paired with three of his one-act plays in a new production, ''Sounding Beckett.'' The plays, ''Footfalls,'' ''Ohio Impromptu'' and ''Catastrophe,'' are to be directed by Joy Zinoman with a cast including Ted Van Griethuysen, Philip Goodwin and Holly Twyford. Each play will be followed by new musical pieces inspired by the plays and written by the composers Chester Biscardi, Laura Schwendinger, David Glaser, Laura Kaminsky, John Halle and Scott Johnson.

Why pump iron when you can pump irony? America's most self-consciously hip city is too cool for athletic competition -- Trail Blazers history makes more sense once you realize this -- but people in Portland will happily fit some sports between trips from the organic grocery to the feminist bookshop, so long as we acknowledge that they are appreciating the events on a different level. Special event: the individualist freestyle, in which everyone does his own thing and no one is judged. For an alternate site in the Pacific Northwest, consider Forks, Wash., the setting of the ''Twilight'' series. The city has made a business model out of busing around moody, emaciated teenagers, giving it the perfect infrastructure for supporting gymnastics teams.

WARREN--Lucie Bedford Cunningham Warren, of Greens Farms, CT, passed away peacefully at her home on July 16, 2012. Mrs. Warren was 104 years old. She is survived by her three children, Briggs S. Cunningham, III, and his wife, Elizabeth, of Lancaster, Kentucky, Lucie C. McKinney, of Greens Farms, CT, and Cythlen C. Maddock, and her husband, Paul "Jay" Maddock, of Palm Beach, FL. She was predeceased by her first husband, Briggs S. Cunningham, II, and her second husband, Lynne A. Warren. In addition to her children, Mrs. Warren was survived by her grandchildren, Paige Cunningham Garland, Brian Cunningham, Robert Cunningham, Blair Cunningham Newsome, Stewart B. McKinney, Jr., Lucie B. McKinney, Jean McKinney, Elizabeth McKinney Tritschler, John P. McKinney, John Dewing, Cythlen Dewing Moss, and Zachary Read. She was also survived by 25 great-grandchildren. She is survived by her sister, Ruth Bedford, and predeceased by her sisters, Helen McCashin and Mary Bedford. Mrs. Warren was also survived by her goddaughter, Lesley Cowenhoven, her good friend, Kathryn Ann Rabesa, and her loyal companions and sailing master, Walter and Lorraine Billings. Mrs. Warren was a woman who was ahead of her time well educated, well travelled, graceful and athletic. She was dignified, competitive and independent. She had vision, energy and a strong work ethic. Most of all, Mrs. Warren believed in helping others. She was known as the "working donor" and was a leader in her philanthropic pursuits. She was an extremely private person and always believed that her philanthropy did not need fanfare or notoriety. Mrs. Warren was a generous giver of time and philanthropy to many charitable worthwhile causes for over 75 years. She was deeply concerned about education and children. She supported Norwalk Hospital, especially the Lucie Bedford Warren Department of Pediatrics. She volunteered two days each week at Norwalk Hospital until she was 96 years old. She also supported the Wakeman Boys and Girls Club, Greens Farms Academy, the Chapin School in New York City, the Westport YMCA, the Connecticut Audubon Society, the Garden Club of America, the Mystic Aquarium Seaport for the Brilliant and many other worthwhile causes. She also volunteered at the Pequot Library Book Sale each year until she was 97 years old. In addition, she helped hundreds of individuals in supporting their personal education. When it came to education, Mrs. Warren never said no. Mrs. Warren was involved in many other activities and was exceptional in all she did including golf, tennis, basketball, and field hockey. She attended Smith College in Northhampton, MA. She was the golf club champion at the Country Club of Fairfield, many times. She was the only woman champion of the Star Atlantic Coast Sailing Championship. She enjoyed being a part of the support team when her husband, Briggs Cunningham, won the America's Cup in 1958 and when he raced in Le Mans in the 1950s. Lucie and Briggs also won numerous sailing championships in Europe. Mrs. Warren had tremendous care in her final years and the family is extremely grateful to all of the dedicated individuals who provided such exceptional care and who became a part of her life. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to any of the charities that Mrs. Warren was involved. She improved countless lives and we are better people because of her. She will be greatly missed. Services will be private.

THE LAST OLYMPICS IN LONDON were the 1948 Summer Games, the first after a 12-year hiatus caused by World War II. The United States sent more than 300 athletes, most of them arriving in England after a weeklong voyage on the S.S. America. In London, they found a city still devastated by years of bombings preparing for what became known as the Austerity Games. A food-rationing program was in effect, and many athletes were encouraged to pack food alongside their uniforms, sneakers, swimsuits or canoe paddles. The organizers could not afford to build an Olympic Village to house the competitors, so a large group stayed in barracks at an air base outside the city. With the Games set to return to London this week, veterans of '48 recalled some of the best days of their lives.

I am by nature a bookish sort of person, and most of what I know about almost anything at all I picked up from books. But last summer, as readers of this column may recall, I forswore reading any more books or articles of golf instruction. I had been rendered a basket case of self-consciousness, so crippled by swing thoughts that I could barely take a club back. This summer I have backslid. Not completely. I will no longer go near Ben Hogan's ''Five Lessons: The Modern Fundamentals of Golf,'' a book that I believe would have screwed up even Hogan had he bothered to read it instead of just write it.
SHAPIRO--Joseph S.,91, of Verona, retired owner of Panache, died July 20th. Services are today at 1pm at Temple Sholom, 760 Pompton Ave, Cedar Grove, NJ 07009.

TISCHLER--Richard. The finest man we've known passed away on July 22, 2012 at the age of 92. Loving son (James, Sarah) and husband (Elsie), he was beloved by his children Steven (Barbara) and Janet (Ed) and by his grandchildren (Ben, Dan, Owen, and Josh). He taught us common decency, self-sacrifice, and baseball. A Marine Corps veteran of World War II (Guam, Iwo Jima), he was a generous and admired friend to all who knew him. He will be deeply mourned, missed, and never forgotten. Contributions in his memory should be sent to the Wounded Warrior Project.

Marion--Samuel. What a life! Sam Marion passed away in Bethesda, MD on July 22, 2012 at age 91 with his loving family at his side. Born in Poland, he came to America in 1937 at age 16 with little more than the clothes on his back. He got a job in a factory, learned English, and worked as hard as he could. Within 25 years, he had married Anna, who predeceased him, and became owner of the factory, Bilt-Rite Juvenile Products. Sam was proud of his two sons, Dr. Lester (Vivien) and Dr. Robert (Beth), five grandchildren, Sara (Udi), Michael, Dori (Nate), Davida and Jonah, and two great-grandchildren, Benjamin and Ari. He lived a wonderful and joyous life: he was loved by his family and many friends, and admired for his strength, his wisdom, and his deep caring for others. He will be missed. Graveside service will be held on Tuesday, July 24 at 1pm at the Steinberg Family Plot in Beth El Cemetery, Westwood, NJ. Shiva will be observed at the home of Robert Marion in Mamaroneck, NY from Tuesday evening through Friday morning, July 27, and at the home of Lester Marion in Bethesda, MD on Wednesday and Thursday evenings, July 25 and 26, from 7 until 9pm.

SIEGEL-BAUM--Judith E. Died peacefully at home on July 22, 2012 after a valiant battle with pancreatic cancer. Beloved daughter of the late Miriam and Sherman Siegel of Washington, PA. Adored sister of the late Joel Siegel of Washington, DC. Cherished cousin of Jim and Eileen Kopelman, Pam Siegel, Mike Siegel, Mark Siegel, Erica Sulkowski and Sarah Sulkowski. Much loved by her closest friends and former college roommates Nancy Stillpass, Margi Booth, Sheri Cohen, and Hope Geller. Private funeral service. Memorial service to be announced. Donations may be made to Dr. Joseph Ruggiero, Pancreatic Cancer Research Fund, Weil Cornell Medical College.

LIBOR INQUIRY Congress widened its inquiry into the interest-rate manipulation scandal, pressing the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to further disclose its knowledge of the multiyear scheme. On Monday, Representative Randy Neugebauer, left, the chairman of the oversight panel of the House Financial Services Committee, sent a letter to the New York Fed, demanding details of its communication with employees of all 16 banks that help set the London interbank offered rate, or Libor, which affects the trillions of dollars in mortgages and other loans. BEN PROTESS

Scientists have long known that increasing age is the strongest risk for a diagnosis of late-stage cervical cancer. Now a new study suggests that the next strongest risk is the patient's insurance status. Survival is strongly related to the stage at which cervical cancer is diagnosed. Women with early, localized lesions have five-year survival rates of 91.2 percent; just 17 percent of those with advanced, distant disease survive that long.

An article on July 15 about the American marathon runner Ryan Hall misstated the number of Olympic medals won by Joe Bottom, who attends the same church as Hall. He won one, a silver medal in swimming for the United States at the 1976 Montreal Games; he did not also win a gold medal from those Games. (Bottom swam in the qualifying round of the 4x100-meter medley relay, which the United States went on to win. At the time, only the swimmers who competed in the final were awarded medals. The rule was changed before the 1980 Summer Olympics.)

BASS--Franklin L. Born May 26, 1926, passed away peacefully on July 22, after a long illness, surrounded by his family. A retired partner at Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, one-time resident of Great Neck, NY, and longtime Manhattanite, he was 86. He is survived by his beloved wife and soul mate of 60 years, Phyllis (nee Feldman), three children, Claudia, Andrea (Jim) and Jonathan (Tatiana), and four grandchildren, Thomas, Elizabeth, Francesca, and Nicolas. Raised in Bedford-Stuyvesant, he was a member of the last graduating class of the original Townsend Harris H.S. He continued his education at Brooklyn College, which he left for a time to serve in the Army Air Corps. Thanks to the G.I. Bill, he went to Harvard Law School, graduating in 1951. In 1949 Frank met his wife Phyllis at Camp Milford, CT, where he also made many life-long friends. In 1951 he joined a small law firm. The firm and Frank grew together. In 1960 he became a partner in the firm today known as Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson. As head of the real estate department, member of the executive committee and chairman of its finance committee, his brilliance and integrity helped guide Fried, Frank as it expanded into a large international firm. He was also a founding member of the American College of Real Estate Lawyers. Frank retired from active practice in 1993, and served as a Pro Bono Assistant District Attorney with the Brooklyn DAs office. Frank loved to cook for friends and family, perfecting an arsenal of recipes over the years, most notably an annual Thanksgiving Day feast. Frank lived the American Dream, finding personal fulfillment and professional success. He had a passion for living as well as a great capacity for self-discipline and sacrifice. To his family, he was a man of tremendous love, strength, knowledge, curiosity and humor. His spirit will live on in our hearts. Funeral service will be held Tuesday at 12 noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street.
CARRICK--George. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of George Carrick associated with The New York Times from March 1, 1966 until retiring on February 1, 1993.

TISCHLER--Richard. The finest man we've known passed away on July 22, 2012 at the age of 92. Loving son (James, Sarah) and husband (Elsie), he was beloved by his children Steven (Barbara) and Janet (Ed) and by his grandchildren (Ben, Dan, Owen, and Josh). He taught us common decency, self-sacrifice, and baseball. A Marine Corps veteran of World War II (Guam, Iwo Jima), he was a generous and admired friend to all who knew him. He will be deeply mourned, missed, and never forgotten. Contributions in his memory should be sent to the Wounded Warrior Project.

WOOD--Rawson Lyman, born in 1908, died July 4. A New York industrialist, was a lifelong activist in social and racial justice as well as in conservation in an era when those were separate constituencies. Mr. Wood, Harvard 1930, joined the family jewelry business ArtCarved Company. During World War II he adapted the investment casting process to manufacture precision parts for arms t founding the Arwood Corporation. President of ArtCarved 1960-1970, then Director of Lenox, 1970-1980, he was also President then Chairman of Arwood 1946-76, continuing as Director of Interlake after a merger. In his business, Mr Wood promoted social and racial justice, serving as President of Council of Profit Sharing Industries; Chairman of the National Conference for Interracial Justice; Nassau County Commissioner on Human Rights and the Board of the New York Urban League. To assist UN diplomats in NYC, he founded the Africa Service Institute. As a liberal Catholic, he was a founder of the Catholic Interracial Councils of New York and of Long Island and a delegate to Vatican II World Congress of Lay. St John's, Xavier, and Seton Hall Universities awarded him honorary degrees. Long dedicated to conservation, he served on Boards of Linnaean Society, the AOU, and as a Director of the National Audubon Society. Retiring in 1978, he retired to Boston, close to summer home on Squam Lake, NH. Serving on Boards of several environmental, civic and social justice organizations, he founded the Loon Preservation Committee and the North American Loon Fund. In support of the arts, he served on Boards of the Boston Ballet, the Boston Symphony, Handel and Haydn Society, and both the NH and the Marlboro Musical Festivals He was a long-time member of the Boston and New York Harvard Clubs. He married Elizabeth Ford of Cambridge, MA in 1931. Married 70 years, they had five children, 13 grandchildren and 15 great-grandchildren. In 2002 he married Marcia Kimball and was step-father to her daughter. Donations to your special charity in his name.

Pity Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo. Three weeks ago, Consolidated Edison, one of this state's gold-plated utilities, decided it didn't care for its pension costs and took the extraordinary step of locking out more than 8,000 unionized line workers in the midst of a baking-hot summer.

GREENBERG--Anita. May 16, 1936 - July 23, 2012. Absolutely the best wife, mother, grandmother, daughter, aunt, sister, cousin and friend that anybody could ever have. Funeral services Wednesday, July 25, 11:30am, Riverside Nassau Chapel, Great Neck, NY. For directions, 516-487-9600.

REYNA--Jack, Age 13, Beloved friend who passed too soon after a brave fight against cancer. Jack was the best: An amazing athlete, friend, brother, son, person, and student. Always dedicated and interested in all that life gave and positive through all of the wrenches life threw. Some of my greatest memories were with you, from going undefeated in soccer three seasons in a row, to hitting homeruns on the baseball field. You were always happy and cheerful, even when you were sick. You always had a contagious smile on your face and made everyone around feel happy inside. You always looked at things in the most positive ways, living life to the fullest extent. I love you like a brother, and even though you aren't here with me, you will always be remembered in my thoughts and in my heart every day of my life. I will always remember and love you, Rest In Peace. With Love and Sincerity, Harrison Mack

''You can take the band out of the bar, but you can't take the bar out of the band,'' Steven Van Zandt told David Remnick of The New Yorker this week. That said, Mr. Van Zandt, the ''Sopranos'' star and guitarist in Bruce Springsteen's E Street Band, is not so set in his ways that he can't say he's sorry from time to time. Over the weekend, Mr. Van Zandt apologized for messages he posted to his Twitter account after a performance in London's Hyde Park by Mr. Springsteen, his band and guest star Paul McCartney was halted due to a curfew. At that time, Mr. Van Zandt wrote, ''We break curfews in every country but only English cops needs [sic] to 'punish us' by not letting us leave until the entire crowd goes.'' He added, ''But seriously, when did England become a police state?''

MEXICO CITY -- Oswaldo Payá, an eloquent Cuban activist who spent decades trying to build a grass-roots movement that would compel the government of Fidel and Raúl Castro to allow more freedom and human rights, died on Sunday in a car crash in eastern Cuba. He was 60. The circumstances of his death were in dispute. Cuban officials said the crash, near the eastern city of Bayamo, occurred when the driver lost control and hit a tree, killing Mr. Payá and another Cuban and injuring two passengers, one from Spain, the other from Sweden.

The ad, which his campaign says will run in nine battleground states, is different in tone from many of the previous commercials from Mr. Obama and his rival, Mitt Romney.

SCHALL--Edward. The NYU Wagner faculty and staff mourn the loss of Edward Schall, father of our beloved Dean, Ellen Schall. We extend our hearts and our deepest sympathy to Dean Schall; her brothers, Richard, Lawrence, and Steven; her husband, Steven Kelban; and all her family.

Updated, 6:48 p.m. | It was a moment that divided a mother's life into before and after. One minute, Shianne Norman's 4-year-old boy gleefully whirled around a Bronx playground among a group of other children. The next, he lay in a heap on the ground as blood seeped from a gunshot wound to his head, and a life of promise drained away amid screams and chaos.

When Eddie Carrillo, a Los Angeles contractor, was found to have prostate cancer at the age of 52, his primary care doctor and his urologist both urged him to have his prostate removed. But after hearing about a ''watchful waiting'' program on talk radio, Mr. Carrillo decided to simply monitor his disease rather than treat it. That was 15 years ago, and Mr. Carrillo, still hale at 67, is glad he did not succumb to pressure to undergo surgery.

LANE--Mark L. It is with profound sadness that we mourn the loss of Mark L. Lane. Mark passed away on July 22 at the age of 60. Mark is survived by his dear wife Robyn. He is also survived by his loving daughters Tina and Erika; sons-in-law Jason and Michael; grandson Ethan; mother Estelle, and sister Faye-Ellen. Mark was a graduate of Nottingham High School in Syracuse, NY. He attended Alfred University, and he received an M.B.A. and M.P.H. from Columbia University. Mark was committed to serving people through his work at Fidelis Care New York, the New York State Catholic Health Plan that provides health coverage to children and adults in 59 counties throughout New York State. As one of the founders of Fidelis, Mark provided the leadership to advocate for a health policy that accords true dignity and respect for all human persons, especially the poor and underserved. Mark exemplified the finest qualities in both his personal and professional endeavors. He touched the lives of many and will be sorely missed. The family requests that contributions be made to Fidelis Healthy Kids Fund, care of Fidelis Care New York, 95-25 Queens Boulevard, Rego Park, NY 11374.

An obituary on Saturday about the Japanese actress Isuzu Yamada misstated the number of her marriages. She was married four times, not six.

In the middle of an attempted turnaround, Newsweek and The Daily Beast now face a future without the financing of the billionaire Sidney Harman, whose family said on Monday that it would no longer invest in the newsmagazine and Web site. Newsweek and The Daily Beast had been owned jointly by IAC/InterActiveCorp and the estate of Mr. Harman, a stereo mogul. In April 2011, when Mr. Harman died at 92, his family pledged to continue his investment in the news organization. A family lawyer said then that the Harman family was ''totally committed to active participation and enthusiastic support.''

Claims of tyranny. Calls for more freedom. And a banner with a Statue of Liberty-like figure triumphantly holding aloft a large soda cup, complete with straw. BENENSON--Edward. Always in our thoughts, forever in our hearts. With much love, Gladys, Lisa and Amy

The Bayreuth Festival has a new Dutchman, this one presumably minus a swastika tattooed on his chest. The bass-baritone Samuel Youn will take over the title role in Wagner's ''Flying Dutchman,'' which opens on Wednesday, news reports said. Mr. Youn is replacing Evgeny Nikitin, who withdrew from the performances over the weekend after German news media reported that he had acquired a swastika tattoo in his youth, when he played in a Russian heavy metal band. Images show another tattoo partially covering the swastika. ''It was a major mistake in my life, and I wish I had never done it,'' Mr. Nikitin, 38, said of the swastika tattoo, in a statement released by the festival. ''I was not aware of the extent of the confusion and hurt that these symbols would cause, particularly in Bayreuth and in the context of the festival's history.''
12:37 p.m. | Updated China is making its biggest and boldest grab for overseas energy resources yet in a $15 billion deal for a Canadian oil producer.

Sean Parker, the 32-year-old billionaire and former president of Facebook -- played by Justin Timberlake in ''The Social Network'' -- was sitting on the top floor of his town house in the West Village of Manhattan last month, lamenting that too few entrepreneurs continue taking big risks after their first great success. LOS ANGELES - The Fox network has reached a deal with Mariah Carey that will bring her to television as a judge on the next season of ''American Idol,'' the president of Fox Entertainment, Kevin Reilly, announced Monday. Ms. Carey, the multiplatinum pop singer, spoke briefly by telephone to reporters at the annual press tour here, saying she was looking forward to joining the show. Mr. Reilly, who said the deal had been completed just hours earlier, also confirmed that Jennifer Lopez has left the show, saying, ''I think I can say 100 percent Jennifer is not coming back.''

LONDON -- Inside a gigantic, blindingly bright gym with Bubblicious-colored floors and a soaring white ceiling, the atmosphere had the potential to be cheery, but the Olympic gymnasts training there on Monday weren't buying it. With the Olympics less than a week away, there was no time for fun.

REITER--Shirley, 92, died peacefully at her home in Manhattan, July 23, 2012. Beloved wife to the late Louis Reiter, adored mother of Jonathan and Fran and grandmother of Mariel and Sophie. Services July 25, 2012, 12 noon, at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleeker St., NYC.

The Jets' new offensive line coach, Dave DeGuglielmo, recently offered a spirited defense of the maligned right tackle Wayne Hunter. ''If you find one out there better than that playing at that position,'' DeGuglielmo said, ''bring him to me.'' The Jets searched and they searched and, on the eve of training camp, they found a potential upgrade. If healthy, Jeff Otah, obtained Monday from the Carolina Panthers for a conditional draft pick, is all but certain to spell the end of Hunter's tumultuous one-year tenure as a starter. A first-round selection by Carolina in 2008, Otah, 26, is a run-blocking force whose prospect of unseating Hunter could hinge on the stability of his balky left knee, which restricted him to four games over the last two seasons. At the very least, his arrival creates what should be the most intriguing position competition at Jets training camp, which begins Thursday in Cortland, N.Y.

An article on Monday about the Oakland Athletics' 5-4 victory over the Yankees on Sunday misstated, in some editions, the year Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum opened. It was 1966, not 1968. (The A's began playing there in 1968 after moving to Oakland from Kansas City.)

CROSIER--Norma J.,died July 21 at home after a short illness. Much loved by her family and many friends, Norma was known for her humor, passion and compassion. Norma was born in Adams, MA but was soon drawn to the adventures, arts and culture of Manhattan. Reflecting her decades of volunteerism and devotion to the Fountain House mission, the family requests that donations in her name be sent to Fountain House, 425 W. 47th St., New York, NY 10036.

As the East Village home of Performance Space 122 continues to undergo renovations, the theater is expected to announce on Tuesday that it will join with two organizations -- the French Institute Alliance Française and the Chocolate Factory in Long Island City -- to host its fall season. The performer David Levine (''Venice Saved: A Seminar'') and the playwright Jason Grote (''Civilization: All You Can Eat'') will open the season in September with ''Habit,'' in which three actors perform a 90-minute drama on a continuous loop for eight hours a day. Part of the French Institute Alliance Française's Crossing the Line festival, the piece is to be staged inside a house designed by Marsha Ginsberg and built inside an unused space in the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side.

An article on Saturday about Matthew Robinson and Martinus Osendarp, who finished behind Jesse Owens in the 200-meter dash at the 1936 Summer Olympics, misidentified the flag that Robinson helped carry into the opening ceremony of the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles. It was an Olympic flag, not an American flag.
BERLINER--Robert. Loving husband, father and grandfather. He will be deeply mourned and greatly missed. Our heartfelt sympathy to Terri, Brian and David. Love, Ian, Michele, Samantha and Sabrina

The Drama League, a fixture on and around Broadway for nearly a century, is moving to a home of its own in TriBeCa, the group announced on Monday. The new Drama League Theater Center will be located at 32 Avenue of the Americas, on the lobby level of the former AT&T building, and is scheduled to open toward the end of this year. Gabriel Shanks, the executive director of the Drama League, described the move as the primary element in a ''wholesale transformation'' of the group, founded in 1916. The new space will allow the league to beef up existing programs, like its long-established program for young directors, as well as expand into new undertakings.

The High & Low Finance column on July 6, about commercial mortgage securitizations, misidentified the owners of a group of apartment buildings in Manhattan. The buildings were principally owned by the Praedium Group -- not by Joel Wiener and his company, the Pinnacle Group, which managed the buildings and held a 5 percent stake. The column also described incorrectly part of a prospectus for the securitization of a mortgage loan on the buildings. The prospectus did in fact disclose that Mr. Wiener's company was under investigation for its practices as landlord; it is not the case that the prospectus did not make that point.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about the severe drought settling over more than half of the continental United States misstated the surname of the two men shown on a farm in El Dorado, Kan. They are David and Arlan Stackley, not Tackley.

LONDON - In the United States, mention a swimming rivalry and images of Michael Phelps and Ryan Lochte dance in people's heads. Outside the United States, it's a different story. That was made plain Monday during a news conference featuring select members of the Australian Olympic swim team, including the sprinter James Magnussen, who owns the fastest time recorded in a nonbuoyant suit in the 100-meter freestyle. One of the first questions came from a journalist from Brazil, home of Cesar Cielo, the reigning Olympic champion in the 50 freestyle. After describing in flowery fashion the fabulousness of Cielo, a two-time Olympian, she asked, ''So, are you afraid about Cielo?''

A capsule summary on Saturday listing Friday's closing market numbers misstated, in some editions, the close of the Dow Jones industrial average. The Dow closed at 12,822.57 on Friday, not at 13,822.57.

In a recent survey of the performance-enhancing claims made for dozens of fitness products, researchers found not a single one that could be supported by rigorous scientific research. Moreover, the few fitness products that have been thoroughly evaluated appear to have no effect on strength, endurance, speed or reduced muscle fatigue. ''All the companies say they've got a scientific basis for these products,'' said the senior author, Dr. Matthew Thompson, a senior clinical scientist at the University of Oxford. ''That sounds good until you look at it with an objective scientific point of view.''

THE UNITED STATES SENT more than 300 athletes to the last Olympics in London, the 1948 Summer Games. Despite a food rationing program in effect after World War II and accommodations in barracks, veterans of '48 consider the experience some of the best days of their lives. Archival photographs and audio clips from more than a dozen United States Olympians who competed in London, including their memories of winning and losing, of meeting royalty and celebrities, and of visiting a city much different from the one that will welcome the world this week, are at nytimes.com/olympics. 2012 LONDON
MAILANDER--Frank. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Frank Mailander associated with The New York Times from December 1, 1956 until retiring on August 1, 1993.
MILLER--George K. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of George K. Miller associated with The New York Times from September 1, 1960 until retiring on April 30, 1997.

THE LAST OLYMPICS IN LONDON were the 1948 Summer Games, the first after a 12-year hiatus caused by World War II. The United States sent more than 300 athletes, most of them arriving in England after a weeklong voyage on the S.S. America. In London, they found a city still devastated by years of bombings preparing for what became known as the Austerity Games. A food-rationing program was in effect, so many athletes were encouraged to pack food alongside their uniforms, sneakers, swimsuits or canoe paddles. The organizers could not afford to build an Olympic Village to house the competitors, so a large group stayed in barracks at an air base outside the city. With the Games set to return to London this week, veterans of '48 recalled some of the best days of their lives.

The City of New York has dealt with legal challenges, and its mayor has endured some ridicule, but the new regulations on trans fats in restaurant foods appear to be having the intended effect. The law, in full effect as of July 2008, restricts restaurants from using food that contains partially hydrogenated vegetable oil and has a total of 0.5 grams or more of trans fat per serving.

We all have to remember that we can't let our love of the games get ahead of the core values, and we know that happens often. This is a painful, painful reminder that awful things can happen when that occurs. MARK EMMERT,

8 P.M. (Ovation) E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL (1982) An alien from a distant planet befriends a 10-year-old boy, Elliott (Henry Thomas, above), in suburban California after being left behind by his spaceship in this enchanted fantasy from Steven Spielberg. Soon enough, government agents are after them both, prompting creature and child to devise a way for E. T. to ''phone home.'' This film won Oscars for best sound effects editing, visual effects, sound and original score (for John Williams), and received five more nominations, including for best director and best picture. Although Vincent Canby, who reviewed the movie for The New York Times, made it a Critics' Pick, he wrote that ''at the end of the film, there is an all-out assault on the emotions that depends, it seems, more on the rising volume of this music than on the events portrayed. He added, '' 'E. T.' is good enough not to have to resort to such tricks.'' 8 A.M. (CUNY) SCIENCE & U! This newsmagazine explores urban farming in Greenpoint, Brooklyn; the addictive properties of chocolate with the confectioner Jacques Torres; foraging in Central Park with the naturalist Steve Brill; and molecular gastronomy in the home kitchen. (Repeated at 2 and 8 p.m.)

PERROTTA--Fioravante (Fred) G. Mutual of America and its Board of Directors, together with its officers and employees, mourn the passing of Fred G. Perrotta, who was a member of Mutual of America's Board of Directors from March 1998 to March 2004. Prior to serving on the Board, he was a partner at Rogers & Wells, where he served as outside counsel to Mutual of America for nearly 25 years. Mr. Perrotta also served as the executive assistant to John V. Lindsay, former mayor of New York City, and as finance administrator for the City of New York. During his many years of loyal service, Mr. Perrotta maintained a strong commitment to the mission of Mutual of America and freely shared his vast knowledge of the insurance industry. His wisdom, experience and commitment to professional excellence as a member of the Mutual of America Board of Directors, most notably on the Law Committee and the Technology Committee, profoundly influenced the Company. Those who were privileged to have known him will long remember his strength of character, high ethical standards and sound advice during the most critical periods of our Company's growth. William J. Flynn Chairman Emeritus Thomas J. Moran Chairman, President and CEO Mutual of America Life Insurance Company
Sally Ride, the first American woman to fly in space, died on Monday at her home in San Diego. She was 61. The cause was pancreatic cancer, her company, Sally Ride Science, announced on its Web site.

REYNA--Jack Egan. Born April 9, 1999 in Wolfsburg, Germany. Beloved son of Danielle and Claudio Reyna. He is survived by his parents and his brothers, Gio, Joah-Mikel and sister Carolina. Jack died peacefully in his sleep after a heroic fight against cancer. Remarkable in every way he was one of the greatest soccer players of his young generation. Sweet, handsome, smart, intellectually curious and above all a good and fiercely loyal friend dedicated son and doting older brother. Jack will be sorely missed by his family, friends and every single person on whom his brief but incredibly bright light shined upon.
GREENBERG--Anita. A loving and devoted friend, we sure did have fun. Barbara

Concern is mounting that the ''breast is best'' dogma is creating undeserved guilt and serious hardships for a growing number of new mothers, many of whom work full time and cannot afford, professionally or financially, the prolonged maternity leaves needed to breast-feed their infants for the time now recommended. Forty-three years ago, when my twin sons were born, the pressure to breast-feed exclusively for six months was not as strong as it is today. I nonetheless felt I had let them - and myself - down when this proved impossible. I had looked forward to feeding only breast milk for the six months of maternity leave my job allowed. But nature had a different plan.

SCHALL--Edward William. June 15, 1918 July 23, 2012, died peacefully in his sleep at his home, surrounded by his loving family. Married for 64 years to Rhoda Lee Miller Schall, who passed away in October 2009. They retired to NYC after successful careers in Wilmington, Delaware. Ed graduated from Princeton in 1939 and Harvard Law in 1942. He served in the Army at Fort Dix from 1942 to 1945. He began his legal career with Cleary Gottlieb in NYC and then was counsel at DuPont for 28 years. Ed was devoted to many things, most especially his family, along with his roles as President of the Jewish Federation of Delaware, President of the Human Rights Commission of Delaware, The New York Times and the Chicago Cubs. Ed is survived by his four children Ellen (Kelly), Richard (Marie), Lawrence (Betty) and Steven (Alyce), his grandchildren Benjamin (Jeannie), Michael, Jaime, Lindsay, Tyler, Lulu, Nathaniel, and one very special great-grandson, Miller. Memorial services Riverside Chapel Wednesday 11:45am. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to NYU Cancer Center Supportive Services, 160 East 34th Street, New York, NY 10016. Shiva at 70 East 10th St. Thursday and Friday 48pm.

Two food trucks sat outside a subway station on a recent weekday evening, generators humming as patrons wandered up to the vehicles to place their orders. Cannoli were the popular item being offered by La Bella Torte, a black truck selling Italian desserts, while the fire-engine-red Eddie's Pizza Truck dished out artisanal pies with toppings like arugula, pulled pork and caramelized onions.

O'KEEFE--Vincent, T.,S.J. The Fordham University community mourns the death of Vincent T. O'Keefe, S.J., who served as the 27th president of the University. Father O'Keefe died on July 22 after a long illness. He was 92. Today Fordham lost one of its heroes, Said Joseph M. McShane, S.J., president of the University. "Father O'Keefe was a man of vision, integrity, and humor: though his tenure as president was relatively short, Fordham would not be the University it is today without his influence. I know the Fordham community joins with me in holding Father O'Keefe's family, friends, and colleagues in their thoughts and prayers." Father O'Keefe served as Fordham's president from 1963 until 1965, when he participated in General Congregation XXXI of the Society of Jesus in Rome. At the Congregation he was elected Assistant ad providentiam to the newly-elected Superior General Pedro Arrupe, S.J. In 1975, during General Congregation XXXII, Father O'Keefe became general assistant and general counselor to Father Arrupe. He later served in Father Arrupe's place as vicar general during the superior general's illness. "He had a long career and he and Father Arrupe worked very closely together," said former Fordham President Joseph A. O'Hare, S.J., about Father O'Keefe's 18 years of leadership in the General Governance of the Society. "He was a very genial person and a great teller of stories, and had a great fondness for jokes," Father O'Hare said. "He was always a great companion." At the conclusion of General Congregation XXXIII, in 1983, Father O'Keefe returned to New York and became rector of Fordham's Jesuit Community. Father O'Keefe's time as Fordham's president, though brief, was significant. During his tenure, Father O'Keefe - after whom O'Keefe Commons is named - worked to incorporate women into the then all-male student body. "At that time, only men were allowed at Fordham," Father O'Keefe said in a 2009 interview with The Ram. "We wanted them to see that women were first-class citizens and had great minds, too." Prior to becoming president, Father O'Keefe served as academic vice president from 1960 until 1963. Father O'Keefe entered the Society of Jesus in 1937, was ordained in 1950 in Louvain, Belgium and took his final vows in 1954 in Woodstock. After his formation, Father O'Keefe was professor of fundamental theology at the Woodstock theologate.

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- Syrian officials warned Monday that they would deploy chemical weapons against any foreign intervention, a threat that appeared intended to ward off an attack by Western nations while also offering what officials in Washington called the most ''direct confirmation'' ever that Syria possesses a stockpile of unconventional armaments. The warning came out of Damascus, veiled behind an assurance that the Syrian leadership would never use such weapons against its own citizens, describing chemical and biological arms as outside the bounds of the kind of guerrilla warfare being fought internally.

Last month the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, announced that it had received a major gift of centuries-old Benin artifacts from what is now Nigeria, including 28 bronzes and six ivories, from the collector Robert Owen Lehman. On Friday, the Huffington Post reported that the National Commission for Museums and Monuments in Nigeria is demanding the return of 32 artifacts from the gift that it says were looted during the Benin Massacre of 1897 and said to have been illegally taken by the British Expedition as spoils of war.

WASHINGTON -- Scott Lilly was a young member of Senator George McGovern's presidential campaign staff in the summer of 1972, and he remembers the satisfaction he felt when Mr. McGovern chose Mr. Lilly's home-state senator to be the Democratic Party's vice-presidential candidate. But a few days after the convention that nominated Mr. McGovern and his running mate, Senator Thomas F. Eagleton of Missouri, Mr. Lilly said, he came to a realization. ''It suddenly struck me out of the blue that they didn't know,'' he said, that the decision to pick Mr. Eagleton had been made without some crucial facts.

HABER--Beverly, at age 86. On Sunday, July 22, 2012. Born Beverly Paley in Bronx, New York on October 5, 1925. Beloved wife of the last Dr. Stanley Haber. Proud and dearest mother of Nancy (Len) Foster, California, and the late Donn (Cindy) Haber, of New York. Grandmother of Evan Furman and Emily (Victor) Erikson, of California; Steven Haber, of Washington, D.C., and Jeffrey Haber, of New York; Stacy (Jay) Hetz, of Kansas; and Joshua (Jennifer) Foster, of Florida. Sister of the late Louise Janpel and Adely Kraman. Dear friend to many. Services pending.

SIEGEL-BAUM--Judith E. The lawyers and staff of Cozen O'Connor mourn the untimely death of our partner and friend, Judith E. Siegel-Baum. Judy fought tirelessly on behalf of her clients, gained the respect of her peers and the judiciary, and gave generously to charities that helped those less fortunate. To those of us who had the privilege of practicing with Judy, she was more than a law partner. She was a friend, a confidant, a mentor and a leader. Judy's brilliant counseling, advocacy and litigation skills were surpassed only by her compassion, wit and kindness. Judy will be deeply missed by all of us. Our thoughts and prayers are with Judy's family and friends.

The News Corporation said on Monday that its education division would operate under a newly formed brand called Amplify. After MaryAnn and Drew Szilagyi, a Houston couple in their early 30s, saw their physician for routine physicals a few years ago, they didn't have to wait for his call about the blood work. Just two days later, Mr. Szilagyi, a banker, logged onto a Web site, perused his lab results and sighed with relief. All normal. But when Mrs. Szilagyi, who sells luxury kitchen equipment, followed suit, no results were displayed. Instead, a message flashed: Contact Doctor's Office.

An article on Monday about the induction of Barry Larkin and Ron Santo into the Baseball Hall of Fame rendered incorrectly part of the last line inscribed on Santo's Hall of Fame plaque. It says, ''His courageous fight with diabetes during and after his career served as an inspiration to millions.'' It does not say that Santo ''served as an inspiration to millions through a courageous fight with diabetes.''

An article in some editions on Saturday about Second Saturday, a monthly assortment of art shows, free wine and cheese, and street music in Beacon, N.Y., gave an incomplete name for a gallery that participates in the event. It is Fovea Exhibitions, not Fovea photography gallery.

LANE--Mark. The Board of Trustees and the Administration of Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center are deeply saddened by the untimely passing of our dedicated Board Member, Mark Lane. Mr. Lane joined Kingsbrook's Board of Trustees in 2006, and passionately committed himself to assisting us in advancing the health and well-being of our community in Central Brooklyn. We extend our sincere condolences to his family and the many that he touched and transformed through his generosity of spirit and intellectual depth. Henna White, Chairman, Board of Trustees Linda Brady, MD, President and CEO Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center

LANE--Mark. With great sadness, we mourn the loss of Mark Lane, Fidelis Care President and CEO, who passed away unexpectedly on July 22. The tradition of the Catholic health care ministry found a new expression in Fidelis Care, and Mr. Lane guided the health plan to become an advocate, a resource, and an answer for uninsured children and adults of all ages. From the beginning, he expressed and instilled in each of us an uncommon passion for excellence, the highest attention to detail, and a steadfast commitment to the company's mission of serving the poor and most vulnerable with compassion, dignity, and respect. His vision for what Fidelis Care could be was realized not only in the company's growth and success over the years, but also in the lives that were changed by having access to quality, affordable health insurance. He cared about people from all walks of life - children, parents, college students, jobless adults who recently lost health insurance, the low-income elderly, residents of rural areas, and those in New York's largest cities - there was no population too small, no story too insignificant for his focus and attention. With one set of values, Mr. Lane lived life seamlessly. Whether as steward of a successful company, or as loving and devoted husband, father, and grandfather, the same uncompromised principles prevailed. We are grateful for his vision and the standards and expectations he established, giving each of us a foundation upon which to build as we go forward, day by day. This is how we will honor him; he will never be forgotten. - The Board and Staff of Fidelis Care New York

SEATTLE - The Mariners' team store downtown was doing a brisk business Monday and Tuesday as people bought up jerseys and T-shirts with Ichiro Suzuki's name on them. Fans were eager to get one last Mariners memento of Suzuki's nearly 12 seasons here, and they gathered at Safeco Field on Tuesday eager to soak in their last looks at their longtime star outfielder. For a team that has provided a stage for high-profile stars like Ken Griffey Jr., Alex Rodriguez and Randy Johnson, Suzuki carved out his own spot in that pantheon. He lived up to his billing from his first year as the first position player to move from Japan to Major League Baseball (he beat out Tsuyoshi Shinjo of the Mets by a day). He has also been the most successful, even more than the former Yankees slugger Hideki Matsui.

A staging of ''Hamlet'' by Shakespeare's Globe theater will be among the attractions in the 2012-13 season at Pace University's Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts, which announced its line-up on Tuesday. ''Hamlet,'' which is directed by Dominic Dromgoole and will run Oct. 2-7, will be the Shakespeare's Globe's third appearance at the center in lower Manhattan, following ''Love's Labour's Lost'' in 2009 and ''The Merry Wives of Windsor'' in 2010. The more than 30-event season, which begins on Sept. 22, will also include an appearance by the Romanian gypsy brass band Fanfare Ciocarlia; a banjo summit featuring Béla Fleck; and a tribute to Woody Guthrie by Justin Townes Earle and guests.

ZANONI--Ronald A.,a former managing director at Kidder, Peabody &Co., Incorporated, died in Akron, OH on Saturday, July 21st. He was 70 years old. Mr. Zanoni graduated from Brooklyn Prep, was a member of ROTC and graduated Phi Beta Kappa with a B.A. in History from Fordham University. He earned his JD with honors from Columbia University Law School. After completing his education, Mr. Zanoni served as a Captain in the United States Army. After being honorably discharged, he returned to New York City where he worked as an attorney for Simpson Thacher & Bartlett LLP. He joined Kidder, Peabody & Co., Incorporated and became a managing director where he was group head of project and lease finance and then Latin American corporate finance. Following that, Mr. Zanoni was a managing director of the asset management division of the Export-Import Bank of the United States. He also actively consulted in his area of expertise, international and corporate project finance. He was a member of the Harding Township Historic Preservation Commission and a former Trustee of Marymount Manhattan College. Mr. Zanoni was born in Brooklyn, NY and resided in New Vernon, NJ. He is survived by his loving wife, Clarissa (Risa), brother Richard Zanoni, SJ, daughters Sharon (Cortright) McMeel of Denver and Clarice (Thurston) Smith of Greenwich, and grandchildren Connor and Marlowe McMeel and Tanner and Avery Smith.

BUYOUT TALKS Ancestry.com, the genealogy Web site, is in discussions with TPG Capital and Providence Equity Partners and Permira about taking the company private, according to people with knowledge of the matter. Though final bids are not due until August, these people said, recent discussions have centered on a price of $35 to $39 a share. At that range, the company will be valued at north of $1.5 billion, roughly triple its market value in 2009, the year it went public.

Marion--Samuel. What a life! Sam Marion passed away in Bethesda, MD on July 22, 2012 at age 91 with his loving family at his side. Born in Poland, he came to America in 1937 at age 16 with little more than the clothes on his back. He got a job in a factory, learned English, and worked as hard as he could. Within 25 years, he had married Anna, who predeceased him, and became owner of the factory, Bilt-Rite Juvenile Products. Sam was proud of his two sons, Dr. Lester (Vivien) and Dr. Robert (Beth), five grandchildren, Sara (Udi), Michael, Dori (Nate), Davida and Jonah, and two great-grandchildren, Benjamin and Ari. He lived a wonderful and joyous life: he was loved by his family and many friends, and admired for his strength, his wisdom, and his deep caring for others. He will be missed. Graveside service will be held on Tuesday, July 24 at 1pm at the Steinberg Family Plot in Beth El Cemetery, Westwood, NJ. Shiva will be observed at the home of Robert Marion in Mamaroneck, NY from Tuesday evening through Friday morning, July 27, and at the home of Lester Marion in Bethesda, MD on Wednesday and Thursday evenings, July 25 and 26, from 7 until 9pm.

BROCK--Constance Starr, passed away on July 20, 2012 in New York City in her home at Peter Cooper Village. Constance was born in New York on March 30, 1925. Her mother was Helen Starr Brock. Her father, Louis Brock, produced many feature films in Hollywood in the 1930s, including the Astaire-Rogers hit Flying Down to Rio which received an Oscar. Constance graduated from Brown University in 1946 and went on to further studies at the University of Geneva. She was married to then divorced George Robert Numrich Jr. She had a successful career as a advertising and fashion copywriter in New York City, working with a variety of top fashion brands. She was also a poet, painter and author; several of her poems were published in The New York Times. Upon her retirement, Constance became a very active member of The National Arts Club where in 1993 she founded Le Cocktail Francais, an ongoing monthly program devoted to the promotion of French art, culture and language. For creating Le Cocktail Francais, Ms. Brock was honored by the French Government and inducted as a Chevalier dans l'Ordre des Palmes Academiques. The ceremony took place at the NAC with Education Attache Charles Barrier presenting the medal. She is survived by several cousins, including Sarah Rosenbaum, Michael Kantrow Jr. and Jonathan Starr Upshaw. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting that donations be made out to the National Arts Club in the name of Constance Brock and Le Cocktail Francais. Burial was held on Tuesday, July 24th, at Woodlawn Cemetery.

The producers of ''Ghost the Musical,'' an adaptation of the hit film, announced on Tuesday that the Broadway show will close on Aug. 18 after 39 previews and 136 regular performances at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater. The closing represents a commercial failure for ''Ghost,'' which has never come close to cracking $1 million a week in ticket sales. The show's capitalization is believed to be in the low-to-mid eight figures, and the production will close at a financial loss. (A spokeswoman for the production declined to confirm the capitalization for the show.)

An article on Saturday about the football media days for the Southeastern Conference described incorrectly one of the objects handed to Alabama Coach Nick Saban to sign during an autograph session. It was a movie poster for ''The Gamechanger,'' a documentary about Saban; it was not ''a faux movie poster featuring him as a character called 'The Gamechanger.' ''

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Monday about new plays for the new Off Broadway home of the Women's Project, using information from a publicist, misstated the surname of the writer for one of those plays, ''Bethany.'' She is Laura Marks, not Mark.

For all of Square's challenges, raising money has not been one. Square, the mobile payments start-up best known for its pint-size credit card reader, is close to raising roughly $200 million, which would give the company an implied valuation of $3.25 billion, people briefed on the matter said. This financing round is expected to be led by Suhail Rizvi, the head of Rizvi Traverse Management, a small private equity firm that has made investments in Twitter and Playboy, these people added.

The past, the future and several stars will align in the opening night selection at this year's Toronto International Film Festival. ''Looper,'' Rian Johnson's time-travel thriller, will open the festival on Sept. 6. Starring Joseph Gordon-Levitt as a hired gun named Joe, with Bruce Willis as a future version of the same character, the film is Mr. Johnson's third feature. His previous film, the caper comedy ''Brothers Bloom,'' played the festival in 2008, and his first movie, ''Brick'' (starring Mr. Gordon-Levitt), received a special jury prize at the Sundance Film Festival in 2005. Also appearing in the new movie are Emily Blunt, Paul Dano and Jeff Daniels. The festival announced over 60 other features on Tuesday, with 38 world premieres, including David O. Russell'snew family drama, ''Silver Linings Playbook''; Joss Whedon's take on ''Much Ado About Nothing''; Joe Wright's adaptation of ''Anna Karenina''; and a return to the big screen for Andy and LanaWachowski, who, with Tom Tykwer, directed the film adaptation of the David Mitchell novel ''Cloud Atlas.'' Films from actors-turned-directors are part of the lineup, including the directorial debut of Dustin Hoffman, ''Quartet,'' and new films from Ben Affleck (''Argo'') and Billy Bob Thornton (''Jayne Mansfield's Car''). The festival will also include a new work from Terrence Malick, ''To the Wonder,'' starring Mr. Affleck, Javier Bardem and Rachel McAdams. And Robert Redford returns both behind and in front of the camera for ''The Company You Keep.'' This year's festival runs from Sept. 6-16.

BASS--Franklin L. Born May 26, 1926, passed away peacefully on July 22, after a long illness, surrounded by his family. A retired partner at Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, one-time resident of Great Neck, NY, and longtime Manhattanite, he was 86. He is survived by his beloved wife and soul mate of 60 years, Phyllis (nee Feldman), three children, Claudia, Andrea (Jim) and Jonathan (Tatiana), and four grandchildren, Thomas, Elizabeth, Francesca, and Nicolas. Raised in Bedford-Stuyvesant, he was a member of the last graduating class of the original Townsend Harris H.S. He continued his education at Brooklyn College, which he left for a time to serve in the Army Air Corps. Thanks to the G.I. Bill, he went to Harvard Law School, graduating in 1951. In 1949 Frank met his wife Phyllis at Camp Milford, CT, where he also made many life-long friends. In 1951 he joined a small law firm. The firm and Frank grew together. In 1960 he became a partner in the firm today known as Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson. As head of the real estate department, member of the executive committee and chairman of its finance committee, his brilliance and integrity helped guide Fried, Frank as it expanded into a large international firm. He was also a founding member of the American College of Real Estate Lawyers. Frank retired from active practice in 1993, and served as a Pro Bono Assistant District Attorney with the Brooklyn DAs office. Frank loved to cook for friends and family, perfecting an arsenal of recipes over the years, most notably an annual Thanksgiving Day feast. Frank lived the American Dream, finding personal fulfillment and professional success. He had a passion for living as well as a great capacity for self-discipline and sacrifice. To his family, he was a man of tremendous love, strength, knowledge, curiosity and humor. His spirit will live on in our hearts.

Sherman Hemsley, the bantamweight comic actor who portrayed the scrappy, nouveau riche George Jefferson on the hit CBS sitcom ''The Jeffersons,'' died on Tuesday at his home in El Paso. He was 74. His death was confirmed by his agent, Todd Frank. He did not specify a cause.

BLYE--Marilyn "Mitzi", 90, adored mother of Iris and Karl Mollin, Pamela and Jay Cohen, John and Shelley Blye and Jeffrey Blye. Mitzi was pre-deceased by her devoted husband, Arnold. In addition to her children, she is survived by her sister, Renee Gross and her brother and sister-in-law, Herbert "Buddy" and Sue Albert. She also leaves nine grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. A private family service will be held.

TURKEL--Dr. Herbert, 89, of Croton-on-Hudson and Sleepy Hollow, NY on July 22, 2012. Psychologist, potter, photographer, world traveler, WWII vet and most of all beloved husband of Dorothea. In addition to Dorothea, his wife of 67 years he is survived by daughter Judith Turkel and her partner Jennifer Costley of New York City. Son Eric died in 2001. Please call family for memorial gathering information.

The past, the future and several stars will come into alignment in the opening night film at this year's Toronto International Film Festival. ''Looper,'' Rian Johnson's time-travel thriller, will open the festival on Sept. 6. Starring Joseph Gordon-Levitt as a hired gun named Joe, with Bruce Willis as a future version of the same character, the film is Mr. Johnson's third feature. His previous film, the caper comedy ''Brothers Bloom,'' played the festival in 2008, and his first film, ''Brick,'' received a special jury prize at the Sundance Film Festival in 2005 (and starred Mr. Gordon-Levitt). Also appearing in ''Looper'' are Emily Blunt, Paul Dano and Jeff Daniels. The festival also announced on Tuesday a lineup of more than 60 features, with 38 world premieres, including the new family drama from David O. Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about threats by Syria to deploy chemical weapons against any foreign intervention erroneously included one type of unconventional weapon among those that Western authorities believe to be in Syria's arsenal. It is not thought to have biological weapons.

Six minutes into overtime during the eastern regional championships for boys' youth soccer in Pennsylvania, Amara Sesay, 15, a refugee from Liberia who has lived in the United States for less than two years, turned, trapped the ball with his foot and sent it soaring into the net. His game-winning goal was the difference between last year, when the Manhattan Paris Saint-Germain boys' team from New York lost its regional final match, and this year, when it will compete against five other teams at the national youth championships in South Carolina, which start Wednesday. In his age group, Amara was the regional's leading scorer - and this is just his first year playing organized soccer.
