After college he earned two Master's degrees and a Ph.D. He was a teacher, then a counselor; his last job was Director of Guidance at Garden City Long Island. A veteran of World War II, he served in Patton's Army with units that liberated concentration camps. Later he served with the occupation forces in Japan. His sole survivor is his wife of 55 years, Jean Satterthwaite Faust. Much beloved by many friends and professional associates, he will be greatly missed.

WEST--Franz. 19472012. It is with tremendous sadness that the Franz West Foundation, Gagosian Gallery, Galerie Meyer Kainer and Galerie Eva Presenhuber announce the death of Franz West, which occurred on July 25. He died peacefully in Vienna, Austria after a long illness. Franz West was one of the most innovative and progressive artists of his generation, who charmed, influenced and inspired his contemporaries, students and followers and all those who encountered him. His sculptural sensibilty culminated in the physical engagement of the onlooker with his sculpture, making the onlooker become part of the work. The world has lost a great artist who changed the way people looked at art and themselves. His great sense of originality and his generosity with other artists, writers and musicians will be missed by us all. Our thoughts are with his family, colleagues and friends on this very sad day.

A picture caption on Wednesday with the continuation of an article about an agreement between the Department of Justice and the New Orleans Police Department to overhaul the city's police force overstated what is known about the circumstances surrounding the controversial arrest in 2005 of Lance Madison, and the caption also omitted the resolution of the arrest. Mr. Madison, who was shown handcuffed on the Danziger Bridge, was later cleared of wrongdoing. And whether there was ''a confrontation'' preceding his arrest has been a matter of dispute over the years.

An article on Wednesday about a crackdown on drunken violence and abuse of police officers in Seoul, South Korea, misspelled the name of the district where a jaywalking man recently blocked a police car, kicked the bumper and pulled the antennae, then used derogatory Korean slang for officers in challenging them to a fistfight. It is the Sinchon district, not Sinshon.

LONDON -- The problems continue to mount for Barclays, as the British bank disclosed that it was facing lawsuits related to a rate-rigging scandal and that regulators were investigating the company's financial director on a different matter. The bank's legal and regulatory burdens have been a continued source of financial pain for Barclays.

Fireworks erupting Friday night in London during the opening ceremony for the Olympics. The evening started with a streamof red, white and blue smoke from fighter jets over the stadium and ended with a performance by Paul McCartney. 2012 LONDON

HAGENDORF--Sam. Has entered the universe on a cloud of love, surrounded by his loving family, on July 24, 2012, after a short illness, at nearly 89 years old. He was predeceased by his wife of 50 years, Sylvia (Starr), and son Scott. He is survived by his soul mate of 16 years, Bernice Salenger and his children, Sheryl Schwartz and son-in-law Barry, Sonny (Harry) Hagendorf and daughter-in-law Kathy, daughter-in-law Karena Wienands, his loving grandchildren, Stephanie Ferdman (Michael), Jonathan Schwartz, Colin Hagendorf, Emma Hagendorf, two great- grandchildren Jordan and Cooper, as well as Bernice's children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, and a large number of loving nieces and nephews. Sam was born in Williamsburg, Brooklyn on September 21, 1923 to Harry and Esther Hagendorf. He was predeceased by his sisters, Minnie, Lee, brothers, Ted, Louie, and Irwin. Sam served as a signalman in the US Navy in WWII in the pacific theater. A man ahead of his time, he owned a bar, the Havagrand Cafe, on Havemeyer and Grand Sts.-60 years too early, but the right idea! Sam's heart was as big as a bear's, and so was his appetite. We will love him, we will miss him and we will honor him. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The American Cancer Society. Funeral will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY 10023, on Sunday July 29, 1pm. Shiva will be observed on Sunday immediately following the service at the home of Sonny and Kathy Hagendorf in New Rochelle until 9pm, and on Monday and Tuesday at the home of Sheryl and Barry Schwartz in Granite Springs, NY from 2-9pm. "Now Let's Eat!"

With the summer travel season in full swing, you may be looking for credit cards that don't charge foreign transaction fees. The Web site CardRatings.com has identified three dozen cards that don't charge these fees. The annoying fees, also known as currency exchange fees, can be as much as 3 percent for purchases made abroad. But it's getting easier to avoid paying them, because more cards are dropping the fees, according to CardRatings.com.

An obituary on July 14 about Else Holmelund Minarik, a writer for children, misstated the original name of the publisher of her first book, ''Little Bear,'' in 1957. It was Harper & Bros. -- not Harper & Row, a name it adopted five years later after a merger.

When the Universal Music Group agreed last year to pay $1.9 billion for EMI Music, the deal was supposed to represent a kind of salvation for EMI, the venerable British record label that was weakened by a bad private equity deal. Universal, already the dominant music company, promised to revitalize EMI, the home of the Beatles, Pink Floyd and current acts like Norah Jones. Even Mick Jagger, one of many stars to leave EMI in recent years, signaled his approval, saying the label would ''once again be owned by people who really do have music in their blood.''

A former chief executive of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles has called for the removal of its current director, Jeffrey Deitch, a month into a roiling controversy over the direction of the museum, The Los Angeles Times reported. Charles E. Young, who ran the museum from 2008 to 2010, made his argument to Eli Broad, the museum's largest donor and most influential board member, in an e-mail which was obtained by the paper. The museum's round of troubles began in June with the resignation of its longtime chief curator, Paul Schimmel, who was known to have a difficult relationship with Mr. Deitch, a former New York gallery owner. Mr. Schimmel's departure was followed by the resignation of four prominent artists from the board: John Baldessari, Catherine Opie, Barbara Kruger and Ed Ruscha. In his e-mail to Mr. Broad, as quoted in The Times, Mr. Young wrote of Mr. Deitch, ''I hope that the four-alarm fire now enveloping MOCA has at least given you pause for thought about his appointment and your continued attempts to try to save him for a job for which many (including myself) believe he is unqualified.'' He added, ''The resignation of dedicated, long-term trustees, and especially four highly respected artists of international acclaim should bother you, David [Johnson], Maria [Bell] and the other continuing members of the Board. The question is 'What is now to be done?'''

LONDON -- Amber Charles still remembers the wasteland behind Stratford station, the hooded youths lingering across the street by the McDonald's and her mother's instruction not to walk the dirt track leading to their housing development after dark. Today, a sparkling new Olympic stadium and state-of-the art shopping mall have replaced the once-bleak expanse and the hooded youths are nowhere to be seen. What was once a dirt track has become a paved street complete with a road sign.

SILVERSTEIN--David Bruce, of Corona, California, and formerly Tappan, NY died on July 25, 2012 after a heroic struggle with cancer. Devoted husband of Maggie Cabrera. Beloved son of Sara-Fay and Sheldon Silverstein. Loving brother of Mark Silverstein. Caring father of Jason, Helen and Whitney. An amazing man, he will never be forgotten.

Apple has found one way to shrink its huge pile of cash. The iPhone maker has agreed to acquire AuthenTec, a mobile security company, for $356 million in cash, according to a filing. Apple will pay AuthenTec's shareholders $8 per share, a 60 percent premium above Thursday's closing price.

LOS ANGELES - After a promising start that was undermined by a polarizing decision that alienated fans, the AMC drama ''The Killing'' was canceled by AMC on Friday after two seasons. The studio that produces the moody murder-mystery drama, Fox Television Studios, announced that it will look to other networks to try to find a new home for the series. Viewership for ''The Killing,'' which was based on a Danish original series, dropped precipitously, from an average of nearly 2.2 million in its first season to just under 1.6 million in the second, as the show couldn't recover from the creative decision to not solve the ''who killed Rosie Larsen'' mystery in the Season 1 finale.
BERKOW--Arthur L.,died on July 27, 2012 in Tamarac, FL. Beloved husband of Joan, father of Ken (Birgit), grandfather of Emily and Daniel. Brother of the late Joan Katz, uncle of Andy and Jill.

SCHULKIND--Gladys, on July 25, 2012. Lifelong political activist and vocational counselor. Beloved daughter, sister, mother, aunt and grandmother. Service Sunday, July 29, 11:30am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Adjusting to a shifting banking landscape, JPMorgan Chase broadly reshuffled its management ranks on Friday and united some of its business operations. The moves, coming months after the bank announced a multibillion-dollar loss on a soured trade, are intended to strengthen JPMorgan's focus on its clients, especially as profits in other areas are threatened by regulatory changes and the gloom in Europe.

An article on Friday about a fund-raising event in London for Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, misstated, in some editions, the amount of money the reception for 250 people was expected to raise. It was at least $2 million -- not $250 million.

Now don't start chopping shallots, but we thought you'd be interested to know that an artificial mussel bed - believed to be the first of its kind along the city shoreline - is under construction on the East River. The habitat, two submerged V-shaped concrete troughs studded with about 340 rocks, is part of a new ''eco-park'' in the East River Waterfront Esplanade. The $165 million esplanade project, by the New York City Economic Development Corporation, extends about a mile and a half from Pier 35 down to the Battery Maritime Building. The corporation would not break out the cost of the mussel bed, whose home will be at Pier 35, near Rutgers Slip.

VOLPE--Domenick A.,95, in Sandwich, MA, July 16, 2012. Born in Brooklyn NY, the devoted husband of the late Jean Mackenzie Volpe and survived by their daughters: Ann, Janet, and Denise, three grandchildren and five great- grandchildren. A patriot, Dom served the Veterans of Foreign Wars achieving the rank of New York State All-American Commander, 1977-8.

Because of an editing error, a report in the Weekend Miser column on Friday about a production of ''Richard III'' presented by the Mobile Shakespeare Unit of the Public Theater, which is touring New York City and will have a limited run at the Public Theater starting Aug. 6, misstated its closing date there. It is Aug. 25, not Aug. 26. The column also referred incorrectly to today's performance on the grounds of St. Peter's Episcopal Church in the Bronx. The production started touring New York on July 16; today's performance is not a ''preview'' of it.

LONDON -- Michelle Obama, visiting the Olympics as part of her campaign against childhood obesity, met with members of the United States Olympic team Friday morning, telling them that she remembered watching the Games on television with her family growing up in Chicago and ''cheering at the top of our lungs.'' As part of a tour that includes meetings with dignitaries and appearances at Olympic events, the first lady was at the U.S.O.C.'s training center based at the University of East London's Docklands campus. Basketball, fencing, taekwondo, badminton, wrestling and weigh lifting athletes are training there and made up most of the crowd at the breakfast.

Dick Cheney, who has been slowly re-entering political life since undergoing heart transplant surgery in March, will sit down Friday for his first network television interview this year. Jonathan Karl of ABC News will conduct the interview from Jackson Hole, Wyo., where Mr. Cheney, the former vice president, has a home. Portions of the interview will be broadcast first on Sunday on ABC's public affairs program ''This Week with George Stephanopoulos.'' And ABC will use other segments from the exclusive sit-down with Mr. Cheney on Monday during their three major news broadcasts, ''Good Morning America,'' ''World News with Diane Sawyer'' and ''Nightline.''

KAY--Judith, nee Kawer, 65, of Brooklyn, New York passed away on July 25, 2012. Judith was born in Paris and graduated from Georgetown University and Brooklyn Law School. All those who knew her understood her deep devotion to her son and husband, her loyalty to friends, her great love of life, her keen intellect, her enchantment with words, and the wonderful pleasure she took in all things French. She was indeed one-of-a-kind. A career lawyer for the New York City Board of Education who served as acting counsel to the chancellor, Judy is survived by her mother Lilli Kawer, her husband Judge Jerome M. Kay, her son Jonathan Kay, and her brothers Joel Kawer (Roz) and Philippe Kawer. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Beth Elohim, 274 Garfield Place, Brooklyn on Sunday at 10:00am. The family requests that donations be made to the American Cancer Society.

CIÑERA, Spain -- This village in northern Spain has lived on mining for generations, its gritty labors passed from father to son as long as anyone can remember. But these days, its 1,300 inhabitants are less occupied with scratching coal from the earth than with combating government security forces as part of a struggle over the future of Spain's economy. In recent clashes, the miners blocked roads and railroad lines, used slings to hurl rocks at the police and fired golf balls from homemade bazookas. The police answered with tear gas and rubber bullets. Along the entrance to the village, rocks are still piled up in preparation for renewed battle.

Time Warner said on Friday that Jim Walton, the embattled president of CNN Worldwide, would hand the news giant over to a new chief at the end of the year. The announcement came in the middle of a year of widespread scrutiny, both of CNN's performance and, by extension, that of Mr. Walton. CNN, while highly profitable, has been plagued by an identity crisis, particularly at its flagship cable news channel CNN/U.S., where ratings have sagged.

LOS ANGELES - Bristol Palin, who attracted a lot of attention and some controversy in her first appearance on ''Dancing With the Stars,'' will return this fall on a special all-star edition of the longtime ABC hit, the network announced on Friday at the Television Critics Association presentations here. Though billed as a showdown to see which star is the best dancer, the cast of the all-star edition does not include just previous winners, but several who did not finish on top. Besides Ms. Palin, who was a finalist in the fall 2010 edition, that list includes the actress Kirstie Alley, the celebrity Pamela Anderson, the former 'N SYNC singer Joey Fatone, the actor Gilles Marini and Melissa Rycroft, a former contestant on ''The Bachelor.''

The Securities and Exchange Commission has moved to freeze the assets of traders accused of illegally trading in shares in advance of the announced $15 billion acquisition of a Canadian oil producer by the state-owned Chinese oil company, China National Offshore Oil Corporation, or Cnooc. The action comes just days after the deal was announced, as the regulator seeks to prevent the proceeds from alleged insider trading from flowing back overseas and outside of its jurisdiction.

Seven gold medals will be handed out on the first full day of competition at the London Games. Here are some of the athletes and teams in the spotlight. (All times Eastern.) SWIMMING All eyes will be on the latest duel between Michael Phelps and Ryan Lochte in the 400-meter individual medley. Phelps is the reigning Olympic champion, and Lochte is the reigning world champion. Their rivalry is such a draw that their heats will be broadcast live on NBC around 5 a.m. But another set of swimming rivals will also face off: Sun Yang and Park Tae-hwan in the men's 400-meter freestyle. Sun is trying to become the first Chinese man to win an Olympic swimming gold. But he will have to dethrone Park, who won South Korea's first swimming gold four years ago. The other finals are the women's 400 I.M. and the women's 4x100-meter freestyle relay. nbcolympics.com, 2:30 p.m.; NBC, 8 p.m. (taped)

Margaret Mahy, an award-winning children's author who tested the limits of her readers' whimsy and courage with fantastical tales of witches, hauntings, infinite fog, and robbers brought to account by peppery grown-ups wielding chocolate cake and balloons, died on Monday at her home in Christchurch, New Zealand. She was 76. The cause was cancer, a cousin, Ron Mahy, told the BBC. Ms. Mahy wrote more than 150 books, including illustrated stories for small children like ''A Lion in the Meadow'' (1969), ''Beaten by a Balloon'' (1998) and the best-selling ''Bubble Trouble'' (2009), as well as young-adult novels, including ''The Haunting'' (1982), about a clairvoyant boy, and ''The Tricksters''(1987), in which a writer's characters come to life and play havoc with her family.

DRESSLER--Kenneth, MD, 52, the best husband, father, doctor and friend one could hope to know. Loved and respected by all who knew him. We were so lucky to have you in our lives for as long as we did. We will honor you throughout the rest of our days. Loved always and forever remembered, Nancy, Andrew, Danielle, Jillian and Max.

DRESSLER--Kenneth, MD. Dr. Dressler has served as Chief of Hematology and Medical Oncology at St. Vincent's Medical Center since 2007. At St. Vincent's and at Medical Specialists of Fairfield since 1998, he brought research trials of novel agents and treatment strategies to the community, as well as a multi-disciplinary approach to cancer care. Dr. Dressler also taught medical residents the complexities of cutting edge cancer care. Dr. Dressler graduated summa cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa from Brandeis and received his medical degree from Harvard. He performed his residency at Mount Sinai, followed by a Fellowship at Cornell and a Fellowship in Medical Oncology and Hematology at Memorial Sloan-Kettering. Dr. Dressler has won numerous awards including the Charles A. Dana Research Fellow Award, the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Clinical Scholars Award and the National Institute of General Medical Sciences Fellowship Award. His clinical and academic posts included Memorial Sloan-Kettering, Yale University Department of Medical Oncology, and the Columbia University School of Physicians and Surgeons. His clinical research has been published in his field. Most recently, he was named St. Vincent's Physician of the year.

PAHUJA--Gargi, MPH, JD, advocate for the thalassemia community, passed away on July 21 in New York City, age 37. A member of the National Advisory Committee for Blood Safety and Availability, the Boards of Cooley's Anemia Foundation and Thalassaemia International Federation and past President of Thalassemia Action Group, she worked tirelessly to build an international community of thalassemia patients, parents, doctors and researchers. A loving daughter, sister and aunt, she is survived by her mother, Kamini Pahuja; brother, Rishi Pahuja; sister, Meera Pahuja; brother-in-law, Kedar Mate; and nephew, Zubin Mate. Donations can be sent to 5P Foundation, 3310 Deepwater Terminal Road, Richmond VA 23234.

Because of an editing error, a caption last Sunday with a picture essay about United States Olympians who competed in the 1948 London Games erroneously attributed a distinction to the high jumper Alice Coachman. She was the only female American athlete to win gold in track and field in 1948. She was not the only female American athlete to win a gold medal in those Games; six American women did so. (Ms. Coachman also held the distinction of being the first black woman to win Olympic gold.)

Competition begins on Sunday in men's basketball, women's gymnastics, diving, canoe, field hockey, sailing and waterpolo. Here are some of the athletes and teams in the spotlight. (All times Eastern.) MEN'S BASKETBALL The United States opens against France, which features six N.B.A. players, including Tony Parker, Boris Diaw and Nicolas Batum. Parker, right, the Spurs' star guard, is recovering from an eye injury sustained when he was a bystander in a brawl in a New York nightclub (NBCSN, 9:30 a.m.). But the United States-France game is not the only matchup between possible medal contenders. Later in the day, Argentina takes on Lithuania. Argentina, with stars like Manu Ginobili aging, is seeking to win a medal for the third consecutive Games. Lithuania was the bronze medalist in 1992, '96 and '00, and the fourthplace team the past two Olympics. NBCSN, 5:15 p.m.

THE Wade Thompson Drill Hall at the Park Avenue Armory, a major site for artistic spectacles of the indoor kind, has recently brought us a multistage Merce Cunningham celebration, a Mars-bound art installation by the sculptor Tom Sachs and an adventuresome surround-sound concert by the New York Philharmonic. Its latest offering, opening Friday, is ''The Murder of Crows,'' an elaborate sound installation by the Canadians JANET CARDIFF and GEORGE BURES MILLER. Something like a spatially dispersed radio play or an invisible film, the work is their largest yet. Its 98 speakers -- placed on stands, chairs and walls throughout the 55,000-square-foot hall -- will alternate enveloping aural effects with ambiguous narratives. The scene will be set by three dreams (recited by Ms. Cardiff) emanating from a vintage gramophone at the center of the space. The surrounding speakers will introduce other characters and vignettes as well as the sounds of everything from a bustling factory floor to crashing waves to a Russian marching band. The meaning of the sinister, noirish title will be for visitors to piece together. Luckily the chairs are also for sitting, as the work is unlikely to reveal itself fully with just one listening. Through Sept. 9, 643 Park Avenue, at 66th Street, (212) 744-8180, armoryonpark.org; $12.

I was thrilled to see my Rap Genius persona, SameOldShawn, appear in your article on misheard song lyrics. But Rap Genius does not, as you claim, assume that ''every rap lyric has a meaning'' that ''should be unearthed.'' The site strives only to annotate lyrics that would not be obvious to the casual listener. Our explanations include anecdotes of the tune's creation, relationships to other songs, pop-culture or literary references, etc. This is why the site has attracted artists like Nas, RZA, A.G. and Jean Grae to annotate their own lyrics. Thanks for the mention -- and don't worry, we're always here to correct the lyrics to ''Ghetto Qu'ran'' as well. SHAWN SETARO, A K A SAMEOLDSHAWN Brooklyn

Motel 6 is following airlines, cruise lines and motor clubs by turning contest winners into social-media reps. In celebration of its 50th anniversary, the budget motel chain chose three ''Open Road Correspondents'' who this summer will document the road trips they have won on its Facebook and Twitter pages. Winners will drive hybrid or fuel-efficient rentals and use iPads instead of guidebooks, which the company intends as ways to promote its new environmentally friendly features.

WEST--Franz. 19472012. It is with tremendous sadness that the Franz West Foundation, Gagosian Gallery, Galerie Meyer Kainer and Galerie Eva Presenhuber announce the death of Franz West, which occurred on July 25. He died peacefully in Vienna, Austria after a long illness. Franz West was one of the most innovative and progressive artists of his generation, who charmed, influenced and inspired his contemporaries, students and followers and all those who encountered him. His sculptural sensibilty culminated in the physical engagement of the onlooker with his sculpture, making the onlooker become part of the work. The world has lost a great artist who changed the way people looked at art and themselves. His great sense of originality and his generosity with other artists, writers and musicians will be missed by us all. Our thoughts are with his family, colleagues and friends on this very sad day.

THEY were the trailblazers -- the women who legitimized a questionable occupation and transformed human clothes hangers into Personalities. In ''ABOUT FACE: SUPERMODELS THEN AND NOW,'' Monday at 9 p.m. on HBO, the director Timothy Greenfield-Sanders talks with some great 20th-century beauties like Carmen Dell'Orefice, still working at 81, about the relationship between fashion and physical appearance, and the inevitable: growing old. They've come a long way, baby. Modeling was once so disreputable that Bethann Hardison's mother thought she was a prostitute until she saw her in a television commercial. And though China Machado, with her Asian and Portuguese lineage, claims to have been the highest-paid model in Europe in the 1950s at $100 a month, it wasn't until Beverly Johnson, an African-American, landed the cover of Vogue in 1974 that the high-fashion color barrier in this country was broken.

Extremely portable high-definition cameras and operators who know how to use them have made stunning images of the natural world commonplace on the big screen and on television since Ron Fricke's ''BARAKA'' came out two decades ago. Fans of this type of lavish work will get a chance to see how that film holds up when it opens the Rural Route Film Festival on Friday night at the Museum of the Moving Image. Mr. Fricke's wordless 70-millimeter film was shot on six continents and features not just the wonders of nature but also the achievements and degradations of humans. Stephen Holden, reviewing it in 1993 in The New York Times, called it ''an aggressively spectacular exercise in planetary consciousness raising.''

The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the soaring 1956 ticket counter created by Lester Tichy at Pennsylvania Station in New York City a few years before the station was torn down, misstated the airport for which Eero Saarinen designed his swooping terminal for T.W.A. in 1962. It was John F. Kennedy International, not La Guardia.
An entry on the ''On the Market'' page last Sunday, for a triplex at 183 Dean Street in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, misstated its price. It is listed for $1.215 million, not $1.225 million.

An ''In the Region'' article in some copies last Sunday, about the increasing use of feng shui principles in the design stages of new developments, misstated part of the name of the company that partnered with Roseland Property Company on 99 Hudson, a complex in Jersey City. It is Hartz Mountain Industries, not Hartz Mountain Associates. The article also referred incorrectly to the start of the Port Imperial project. It was 1997 -- not ''five years ago,'' which was when Port Imperial developers began applying feng shui principles in construction and design. And the article misstated the significance of RiversEdge to the Imperial project. It was the first completed building to incorporate feng shui features, not the first completed building in the project.

LONDON - The United States men's archery team experienced both ends of the Olympics' emotional spectrum Saturday. First, the Americans were euphoric after scoring a convincing upset of world power South Korea in the semifinals at Lord's Cricket Ground. About an hour later, they were crushed in the gold medal match when Italy beat them by a single point on the final arrow of the competition. While a silver medal is hardly disappointing, the manner in which the United States lost was brutal. After scoring 27 points in their final end to cut their deficit to 1, the Americans watched as Italy scored 17 points on the first two arrows of its last series. If the final Italian archer, Michele Frangilli, scored 8 points, the United States would win outright; if he scored 9, the match would be tied; and if he scored 10, the Italians would win the gold medal after losing it four years ago on a similar last-arrow shot.

As the music biz adjusts for the downturn, that's the average price for a pop concert ticket in North America in the first half of 2012, according to a midyear report from Pollstar, a concert industry trade magazine and Web site. The average price dropped a whopping 9.4 percent -- $6.34 -- during that period, for the lowest midyear average since 2007. Drake (at right), for instance, who had the sixth biggest North American tour, charged an average of $58.66 per ticket. But other stars charged far more: Roger Waters's average price was $107.58; Van Halen's was $100.11.

ENDER--Marvin J.,95, of Rancho Mirage, CA passed away July 5, 2012 in Rancho Mirage. He was born January 25,1917 to Louis and Hannah Ender in Brooklyn, NY. He married Leslie Levy on November 11, 1939 in Brooklyn, NY. They had a wonderful and loving life together, and travelled all over the world. Their love of good food and wine was shared with their children and friends. He was President of Louis Ender, Inc, a food service company. He was President of United International Distributors; a board member of Fenway Country Club; and a member of Tamarisk Country Club in Ranch Mirage for 38 years. His passion was the game of golf. He is survived by his wife of 72 years, Leslie; daughter, Donna Lewis of New York City; son Neil and daughter-in-law, Sylvia of Rancho Mirage, CA; and sister, Shirley Kaslow of New York City. Private services were held at Forest Lawn Memorial Park, Cathedral City, CA.

TUROK--Paul Harris. Composer, Critic. December 3, 1929 July 10, 2012. Died peacefully at home, after a long illness. Paul Turok studied composition with Karol Rathaus at Queens College, with Roger Sessions at both the University of California (Berkeley) and at Princeton prior to studying with Wagenaar and Mennin at Juilliard from 1951-1953. Subsequently he served in the U.S. Army during the Korean War. He lectured at CUNY and was a Visiting Professor of Composition at Williams College. His orchestral works have been performed worldwide including premieres by The Cleveland and Philadelphia Orchestras. "Threnody" was recorded on Modern Masters by the City of London Sinfonia .(David Amos) "Aspects of Lincoln and Liberty" (2007), with the Nashville Symphony conducted by Leonard Slatkin, celebrated the bicentennial of Abraham Lincoln's birth. Recent piano recordings include "Passacaglia" and "Tango for James Adler" performed by James Adler and "Ragtime Caprice" played by Joshua Pierce. Paul Turok's chamber music was premiered at Lincoln Center and the Library of Congress as well as at Notre-Dame in Paris and in Japan, Taiwan and South America. Quoting Baker's Biographical Dictionary, edited by Nicolas Slonimsky, Paul Turok "as a composer, follows the principles of stylistic freedom and technical precision, without doctrinaire adherence to any circumscribed modernistic modus operandi." Among his 150 compositions are several sets of songs and "Richard The Third" opera in four acts. A regular contributor of classical music feature articles in the Sunday New York Times Arts Section, he was also a frequent guest critic on WQXR's nationally-syndicated program "First Hearing." He wrote for The Herald Tribune, Ovation, Music Journal and Fanfare before founding Turok's Choice: the Insider's Review of New Classical Recordings which he published from 1990-2011. He is survived by his wife Susan. A memorial concert of his music is being planned.

''What we should probably do is go and split up investment banking from banking.'' Sanford I. Weill, the former chief executive of Citigroup, during an interview on CNBC. He called for a wall between a bank's deposit taking operations and its risky trading businesses, a reversal of his previous stance.

DREAMING of being a June bride in 2013? There's little less than a year left to plan the affair if you get engaged right now, so for those considering a proposal piece (or needing a hint to hand to your beloved), here is a selection of dazzling and enchanting engagement rings from some of the genre's most distinguished designers. ''We are noticing more women looking for new interpretations of the solitaire,'' said Keeley Smith Cabot, the boutique director of Cartier Fifth Avenue. The brand's popular d'Amour ring features a stone and a circular pavé motif symbolizing eternal love . Harry Winston, which introduced the made-for-engagements Belle by Harry Winston collection last year, is seeing a similar trend: its new solitaire is simply dizzying (in the best way), flanked by pavé diamonds in a modernized quatrefoil setting.

STOTT--Michael A.,75, of Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ, died July 26, 2012. Beloved husband of Alison (NEE: Walker) Stott. Loving father of Timothy Stott, Amy Tominovich and husband Rod, David Stott, Gregory and wife Dana Stott, Thomas John TJ Stott , and the late Michael Jr., who passed away in 1997. Adoring grandfather Carly and Max Tominovich, Cole, Emma, Lillian, Quinn, Preston, and Madison. Devoted brother of Betsy Kimmerle, and William R. Stott Jr. and the late Susan Stott, who passed in June. Funeral Mass Tuesday 11am at St. Gabriel RC Church, Saddle River, NJ, interment Valleau Cemetery, Ridgewood, NJ. Services at Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood NJ 201-444-7650, feeneyfuneralhome.com

LONDON -- Alexander Dale Oen was not forgotten Saturday during the first day of the Olympic swimming competition. His name was there in small print at the end of the heat sheet for the men's 100-meter breaststroke, under the list of the event's top 10 performers. Dale Oen became a Norwegian hero last summer when he clocked the fourth-fastest time in a 100 breaststroke, winning at the world championships in Shanghai three days after 77 were killed in the worst massacre in his homeland's history. Nine months later, during a training camp in Flagstaff, Ariz., Dale Oen died of heart disease.
GREENWICH VILLAGE CO-OP $1,490,000

BOWER--Betty B.,of Southbury, CT died July 19 at 92. She is survived by her son Stephen and his family. Formerly of Washington, D.C., Betty was a dedicated alumna of Sarah Lawrence College, a longtime resident of South Hero, VT, and an avid sailor on Lake Champlain.

SCHULDER--Patricia Mary, nee O'Driscoll, born February 2, 1934, passed away on July 24th, in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. She is survived by her husband of 53 years, Daniel Schulder; her children Joseph, Rachel, David, Zoe (with son-in-law Carlo Elia) and Malcolm; her grandchildren Julian, Katherine and Ethan. Warm, loving Mother, Grandmother and Wife. She was a lifelong activist in social justice causes. Born in the Bronx, NY, she graduated from the College of New Rochelle and was a teaching assistant at the Department of Sociology, Columbia University. She was also on the national board of the Young People's Socialist League (YPSL). She met Daniel at the Association of Catholic Trade Unionists (ACTU). Both were arrested supporting workers fighting sweetheart contracts in their shops. She also supported the work of the Catholic Worker (founder Dorothy Day) in the Lower East Side of New York City. As a special education teacher in public schools, she was an active member of the New York Teacher's Union and the United Federation of Teachers. While raising her children in Washington D.C., she was active in PTA and other public school support programs. Also during this period, she and Daniel were committed to the anti-war, civil rights and trade union movements. In 1973 the family moved to Harrisburg, PA. There, she was Executive Director for many years of the Dauphin County Pretrial Services Agency, an organization devoted to gaining freedom for poor people while they awaited trial. She was also on the boards of the Pennsylvania Prison Society and Central Pennsylvanians Against the Death Penalty. She was a mediator in the Harrisburg Neighborhood Dispute Settlement Center and was an alumna of Leadership Harrisburg. All through her later years, she participated in Harrisburg's own peace and social justice groups, including Pax Christi. Her friends, neighbors, and family will never forget her love of music, diverse cultures, chocolate, wine, weaving, birds, butterflies, Cape May, NJ, and The New York Times crossword puzzle, and her gracious lady-like demeanor. She was a font of family lore and a devotee of letter writing and reading. She was also beloved as the Hostess of the Annual Bastille Day and Boxing Day Celebrations. She will be remembered always as someone who did not fear standing up, even in the face of arrest, for justice, peace and the rights of citizens, in and out of prisons. Memorial contributions can be made to the Catholic Worker, 36 East First Street, New York, NY 10003.
2012 London

JOHNSON--Douglas Bedford. 62, passed on July 23, 2012. He was born in New York City to C. Bedford Johnson, originally from Amarillo, Texas and Sally Barber Johnson, from Brighton, Colorado and was raised in Bedford and Mt. Kisco, New York. He is survived by his younger brothers Scott W. Johnson of Houston, Texas and Blair M. Johnson of Billings, Montana, by his nieces Claire I. Johnson, Camille I. Johnson and Sara Johnson, and by a great-niece Kiara Johnson. Doug graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy in 1968, from Stanford University in 1973 and from the New York University School of Law in 1978. He started his professional career at the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meager & Flom as a merger and acquisition attorney, and later worked in the investment banking division of Prudential Bache in the bankruptcy and workout group. Doug was passionate, opinionated, and outspoken. He inquired, researched, and thought deeply about things that grabbed his interest. In his younger years he loved hiking, camping, skiing and sailing. He always strove to be the best he could be at whatever was his focus. His family will miss him and fondly recall his passion and intellect. A memorial service is planned during the week of September 17, 2012 in New York City. Contact Scott Johnson at slalom--75@yahoo.com for details.

MALONE--Mary E. Mary E. Malone was reunited with her husband Kevin E. Malone in Heaven on July 24, 2012. Mary was born on February 12, 1941 in New York City. She was the oldest daughter of J. Robert and Catherine Pierson who predeceased her. Mary is survived by her siblings Robert Pierson (Pat) of Novi, Michigan and Kathy Pidgeon (Steve) of Paradise Valley. Mary was the proud and devoted aunt of Tyler, Greg and Austin Pidgeon and Dawn Thomas. She was the loving God Mother of Tyler Pidgeon and Danny Lawlor. Mary graduated Bryant High School and attended Queens College in NY. She was the office manager of the Watson Wyatt Company in NYC for more than 30 years and moved to Phoenix from Queens, NY in 2001 to be closer to her sister Kathy and her nephews. Mary volunteered at Ss. Simon & Jude School where she loved working in the library and assisting the Loreto Sisters and especially Sister Raphael whom Mary deeply admired. She loved all sports and cheered for the Giants and Mets and Knicks until she became a devoted Phoenix Suns fan. Mary stared down her cancer diagnosis with courage and dignity. She was so thankful to Hospice of the Valley for their love and care and especially the staff of The Coronado House where she lived out her final days. Mary's faithful puppy Nicky remained by her side throughout her final days. Mary's Funeral Mass was held at Brophy Chapel on Friday July 27th. She will be buried in Farmingdale, NY beside her beloved husband Kevin and her parents. In lieu of flowers, Mary's wish was that donations be made to the Help A Student fund at Ss. Simon & Jude School, 6351 N. 27th Ave., Phoenix, AZ 85017 or Hospice of the Valley, 1510 East Flower Street, Phoenix, AZ 85014.
KENSINGTON HOUSE $750,000

BRAVERMAN--Lori Goldman, 74, passed away on July 17, 2012. The cause was complications from acute myeloid leukemia. Lori was, first and foremost, about her family. She was the devoted wife of Monte Braverman for over fifty years and is survived by her children, Andrea Gross, Harvey Braverman and Janice Kaplan; her son-in-law Cliff Kaplan and daughter-in-law Kiki Braverman; her grandchildren, Corey, Drew and Jordan Gross, Carly, Alex and Jillian Kaplan, and Oliver Braverman; and her brother Mitchell Goldman. Lori was predeceased by her parents Bernard and Ree Goldman of Philadelphia, PA, and her sister Paula Goldman. Lori, a watercolorist, grew up in Bala Cynwyd, PA and was a long-time resident of Tenafly, NJ and Snowmass Village, CO.

KOEGEL--Christina Williams, 90, of Armonk, NY, and formerly Granite Springs, NY, passed away peacefully July 22, 2012, at her home in Armonk. She was born on November 18, 1921, the youngest of four daughters born to the late Edgar I. Williams and the late Hulda Gustafva Olson Williams. The girls grew up in Rutherford, NJ. Christina attended Smith College and graduated in the class of 1943. While at Smith on traditional "Mountain Day" she traveled from Northampton to Williamstown, MA, the site of Williams College, where she met her future husband, James Erwin Koegel. Following college, she was working at Gibbs & Cox, ship architects, in Manhattan, while Jim Koegel was an attorney in the same city at Dwight, Harris, Koegel & Caskey (now Clifford Chance). When she was called upon to fill in a bridge foursome at the apartment of Jim Koegel's parents, the friendship rekindled. Eventually, on September 20, 1946, they were married in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. Three children were born of this marriage, all three at Presbyterian Hospital. The first child was Christina Rae Koegel, who is now Christina Granrud in Kalispell, Montana, and the mother of two grandchildren, Philip and Jennifer Granrud. The second child was Sarah Nilsson Koegel, who lives in the Armonk home. The third child was James Arnold Koegel, who resides with his wife, May in the town of Bedford. The evening of November 19, 1954 was expected to be a festive occasion. The Koegel family planned to have dinner out and then attend a premier showing of the 20th Century Fox film Desiree at the old Roxy theatre. Unfortunately, Christina began to feel ill and her back ached badly. As a result she was taken to Columbia Presbyterian Hospital and was diagnosed with polio and spent three months in the Harkness Pavilion. Ironically, during her time at the hospital the announcement was made that Dr. Jonas Salk had developed the vaccine that would put an end to the scourge of polio. But this beautiful woman was determined to resist the disease and she fought mightily to regain strength in her legs and back. With great fortitude and spirit, and Sarah's good care, she was able to serve in many activities, including the Board and Executive Committee of Northern Westchester Hospital and active member of the Board of the VNA of Husdon Valley for many years. Jim predeceased Christina three years ago. A private service will be held for her at the Amawalk Cemetery, next to Jim.

A TREE-LINED city sprawling out from the base of the snow-capped Tian Shan mountain range, Almaty is Kazakhstan's former capital, the largest urban center in the country and the most important cultural hub in Central Asia. Fueled by the country's mushrooming petrol dollars, the city comes alive in the spring and summer as residents enjoy atmospheric restaurants, cafe patios, yoga classes and art galleries. A new metro system that opened in December has interiors combining elements of the Stalin-era aesthetic with a modernist sheen. GABRIELA MAJ

Retired teacher, co-owner of Lorraine Bake Shop in Inwood, Manhattan 1965-1985. Kakia touched many lives and will be missed. She is survived by daughters, Georgia Tavlarios (Michael) and Stephanie Mouzakis Smith (Bob), grandchildren James and Sophia. Service at St Spyridon G.O. Church, New York City, July 31st at 9:30am.

To the Editor: Re ''Maternity Leave? It's More Like a Pause'' (Sunday Styles, July 22). Much has been made of Marissa Mayer's comments that she will work through her short maternity leave. Sadly, much of it has been criticism from all ends: that she's putting work before family, that she is doing a disservice to women who do take time off or that she's naïve to think that postpartum will be that easy. But clearly, she is a very smart and talented woman who is capable of making the choices that are best for her own life, and that's nobody else's business.

CHICAGO - Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr., who has been absent from Congress since early June, is receiving treatment at the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota for depression and gastrointestinal issues, a statement issued by the clinic said on Friday night. The statement offered few details about Mr. Jackson's ailment, but said that he had arrived at the clinic, based in Rochester, Minn., and was to receive ''extensive inpatient evaluation.'' The statement, which the clinic said it was distributing on behalf of Mr. Jackson, added: ''Further information will be released as Congressman Jackson's evaluation proceeds.''

RADIN--Caroline, born October 2, 1919, passed away at age 92. She earned her BA from Hunter College. Caroline was an original life member of Old Westbury G & CC. She is survived by her children Alice, Michael and Howard, grandchildren Cynthia, Alan, Daniel, Sara and Mark, great-grandson Andrew, and sister Norma Spector. She is pre-deceased by her husband Arthur and brother Paul Lerner. She will be greatly missed by all. Donations in her memory may be made to The JCC Senior Center 760 Northfield Ave., West Orange, NJ 07052 Attention: Gina Goldman.

PACKER--Eleanor Gerb, age 86, passed away in Palm Beach, FL on July 2, 2012. The only child of Anna (nee Zuckerbraun) and Louis Gerb of Poughkeepsie and Peekskill, NY. Eleanor graduated from Peekskill High School in 1943 with highest honors, attended Mary Washington College of the University of Virginia and graduated from New York University with degrees in Finance and Spanish. An accomplished pianist who performed in Carnegie Hall, Eleanor was an avid reader, often reading three books simultaneously. After marrying Sidney in 1947, Eleanor moved to Huntington, NY, where she and her husband established Packer's Wholesale Distributors, a business which grew over 30 years to become one of Long Island's largest distributors of candy, paper goods and fountain syrups. She later became a real estate broker, working in both commercial and residential real estate on Long Island with her husband for the next 11 years until retiring to Palm Beach, FL in 1988, where they were involved in Magen David Adom and other philanthropic Jewish organizations. Eleanor was an active member of Hadassah, ORT, and National Council of Jewish Women. She leaves her beloved husband of almost 65 years, Sidney; two daughters, Aileen (Al) Cwanger of Cherry Hill, NJ, and Marcia (Rabbi Bill/Zev) Schechter of Delray Beach, FL; and two sons, Jeffrey (Jane Sandhaus) Packer M.D. of Lancaster, PA, and Gregory Packer of Huntington, NY, seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Donations in Eleanor's memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Assoc., S.E. Florida Chapter, P.O. Box 22594, W. Palm Beach, FL 33416.

IT'S something of a paradox when a woman best known for taking off her clothes in public hopes to be famous for what she has on. All the more so when that woman is Dita Von Teese, fetish queen, stripper and sultry fashion idol, and the inspiration to at least one generation of would-be calendar girls. Now she is about to capitalize on her notoriety by turning herself into a fashion brand.

HYMAN--Charles. Our hearts go out to our dear friends Larry, Anne, Gail and Dan on the loss of their father/grandfather. He was a true Fire Islander, world traveler and businessman. May he rest in peace. Steve, Linda, Michael and Nicole Breskin and Jeremy Vandel

Birds of a feather often caucus at an impromptu fashion convention on Fifth Avenue in the mid-50s. I have been photographing several of them for decades, but they don't necessarily know one another. Last week, free-spirited dressers created an amazing sight at 8:45 a.m. while on their way to work: top right, from left, Marjorie Stern, Timothy John, Andrew Mukamal, Tziporah Salamon and David Don D Sealey. Ms. Stern is a grandmother and a retailer; her signature is multiple scarves and necklaces. Mr. John, an artist, has this philosophy: ''I refuse to be defined by other people's limitations.'' He wears clothes upside down and inside out, often demonstrating on the spot. Mr. Mukamal, 24, who works in fashion media, is the Beau Brummell of the future, mixing avant-garde designers with bravado. Ms. Salamon bikes to work in antique Asian and Matisse-inspired textiles. Mr. Sealey, in his 20s, dresses in hip-hop style and creates jewelry. Delroy Smith, right, drawn in by the spectacle, stopped in his tracks; he works in fashion and makes his own clothes.

''WHAT is the city but its people?'' a lowly plebeian asks in ''CORIOLANUS,'' suddenly feeling the power of being part of the multitudes. So it seems appropriate that Shakespeare's tragedy of war, politics and mass appeal in ancient Rome is being taken to the streets in this summer of a presidential election year. Or specifically, to a parking lot on the Lower East Side. That's where the Drilling Company is presenting ''Coriolanus'' as part of its city-conscious Shakespeare in the Park(ing) Lot series. (It once spun ''Julius Caesar'' into a power struggle within an urban school system.) Directed by Hamilton Clancy, who says he sees parallels between Shakespeare's angry Roman commoners and the Occupy movements, this open-air ''Coriolanus'' must expect to vie with not only the elements but also cars in search of a berth, giving special resonance to the idea of ''traffic of the stage.'' Arash Mokhtar plays the title role of a charismatic leader widely perceived as too aloof to hold onto popular support. Not that there's anyone like that in our line of vision these days. Thursday to Aug 18, municipal parking lot at the corner of Ludlow and Broome Streets, (212) 873-9050, shakespeareintheparkinglot.com.

FOR a company trying to put wireless charging devices on electric cars, road trips can be interesting. WiTricity is the company, based near Boston, that has partnerships with Audi, Mitsubishi and Toyota to put wireless charging on electric cars, possibly as early as the 2015 model year. WiTricity licenses technology, developed at M.I.T., to transfer power between a pair of copper coils resonating at the same electromagnetic frequency.

RUTMAN--Sherry (Berg), passed away on July 27, 2012 at the age of 83. She was the loving and devoted wife of the late Henry Rutman for nearly 60 years. She will be deeply missed by her adoring children, Howard Rutman and Lori Fife, and their spouses Shereen Gertel Rutman and Mark Fife, as well as her grandchildren, Elizabeth Fife and Melissa and Stephen Rutman. She is survived by her sisters, Gizella Perl and Bella Pollack and their families. After living through the Holocaust, she immigrated to New York City where she raised her family. Always elegant in her appearance, she was lovingly by her husband's side as they traveled throughout the world for business and pleasure. Shiva will be at the Fife home. Contributions in memory of Sherry Rutman can be made to The Museum of Jewish Heritage - A Living Memorial to the Holocaust.

If Disney is where everyone's a kid again, KidZania is where every kid is an adult. And these educational theme parks, pint-size indoor cities where children pretend to work in professions at places like hospitals, banks and fire stations, got a new addition in Mexico City last month. The latest park is one of 11 in cities including Tokyo, Dubai and Lisbon; the company is scouting locations for a KidZania in the United States.

AN urban version of the traditional rambling family compound, a seven-bedroom nine-and-a-half-bath apartment that occupies all 8,360 square feet of the 16th floor at 995 Fifth Avenue, a condop building formerly known as the Stanhope Hotel, was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records. With a recorded price of $27,376,940.03, it was arguably the most fiscally exacting transaction of the week as well. But people familiar with the deal said the unit actually sold for more than what was noted in the city records, quite close to its $30 million asking price.

KEMPNER--Shirlee, beloved aunt and sister, died June 29, 2012. Vivacious, generous, beautiful, loving, devoted, the best friend ever; a real mensch...that was Shirlee. A memorial will be held Thursday, August 2, 2012 at 2pm, Sutton Place Synagogue, E. 51st Street, New York City. Contributions may be made to the Brooklyn College Foundation Scholarship Fund in Memory of Shirlee.

My first impression of a story entitled ''Why Can't the Bronx Be Like Brooklyn?'' is that it's always worth thinking about people in the Bronx who don't want it to be Brooklyn, and even people in Brooklyn who don't like what they think Brooklyn is becoming. Beyond that, I think this is a problem of form. In journalism, if your neighborhood isn't being populated with cool shops and young, single people, it's a ghetto suffering from decades of societal neglect. If it actually is being populated by all the pretty people, it's an enclave that we worry is losing its sense of identity. . . . The question of how different areas of a city develop or don't is an interesting one. I just don't like the assumption that everyone wants areas to develop the same way. A lot of us just want things like safety and decent schools not to be considered luxury goods. TA-NEHISI COATES, posted on theatlantic.com
A report on July 8 about the marriage of Ashley Prewitt and Victor Wu referred incompletely to the bride's career. Besides being a marketing consultant, she also works in public relations.

Eckstein IV and Andrew Eckstein, his daughter Jacquelyn Eckstein, and step-daughters Schuyler Clemente and Blair Clemente, and daughters-in-law Sylvia Eckstein and Lisa Eckstein. The cover article on July 15 about travel advice from frequent travelers in Silicon Valley referred incorrectly to the chemical composition of GoToob travel bottles. They are BPA free, not PBA free.

LONDON -- High above the cotton-candy-colored floor of the Olympic gymnastics arena, the scoreboard Saturday showed the United States men's team in the lead after qualifying was done. But the five Americans who have said for weeks they would win gold here dared not celebrate. Instead, they huddled together after besting teams from Japan and China -- favorites to win medals here -- and reminded themselves that first place at that point meant nothing. None of the qualifying scores carryover to Monday's team final, in which eight teams will square off for the first gymnastics gold medal of the London Games. A new day will give some teams, including the defending Olympic champion Chinese, a chance to redeem themselves after struggling during qualifying. And the Americans, careful lest they become complacent, are keenly aware of that.

THE real star of the 1983 film ''Risky Business,'' as every car fan knows, isn't Tom Cruise or Rebecca De Mornay. It is the shimmering Porsche 928. On Tuesday, fans will have a chance to buy Mr. Cruise's old ride at an auction just north of Los Angeles. In the movies, nothing is what is seems, and that applies to the 928, of which there were four used in the movie, according to Profiles in History, the auction house in Calabasas Hills, Calif., that is selling the car.

In honor of Nora Ephron, who died last month, the Big City Book Club will revisit her early work as a journalist and essayist. In the 1960s and '70s, she wrote for magazines like Rolling Stone, New York and The New Yorker -- pieces collected in the anthologies ''Crazy Salad'' and ''Wallflower at the Orgy.'' We're going to read ''Wallflower'' because it's more readily available, but if you're lucky enough to have an old copy of ''Crazy Salad,'' reread it, too, and weigh in!

FLASTER--Stanley Rock. WWII Veteran and Hero. Born August 4, 1927 at Rockaway Beach Hospital In New York City, died Sunday July 15, 2012 in Santa Barbra, California. He deactivated mines on Omaha Beach Normandy, fought with 104 Infantry Division (Timber Wolves), involved in two night bayonet attacks against German troops, fought German Tiger Tanks in Holland, fought in Belgium; was wounded in the Battle of the Bulge, he received a Silver Star, two Bronze Stars and Purple Hearts. He is survived by his Wife Dorothy, Son Neil, Daughter Karen, Brother Alvin, Sister-In-Law Norma, Sister Roberta Mahler, Niece Lynn, Nephew Richard plus five Grandchildren and a Great-Grandchild. He was a supporter and contributor to Israel.

MACARI--Michael, MD, of Bronxville, NY on July 27, 2012 at the age of 47. Beloved husband of Kimberley (nee Terry), loving father of Miles, devoted son of Thomas and Maryann Macari, brother of William and Thomas. Dr. Macari served as Professor of Radiology and Surgery at the NYU Langone Medical Center. A memorial mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Patrick's Cathedral on Wednesday, August 1st at 6:15pm.

KAY--Judith, nee Kawer, 65, of Brooklyn, New York passed away on July 25, 2012. Judith was born in Paris and graduated from Georgetown University and Brooklyn Law School. All those who knew her understood her deep devotion to her son and husband, her loyalty to friends, her great love of life, her keen intellect, her enchantment with words, and the wonderful pleasure she took in all things French. She was indeed one-of-a-kind. A career lawyer for the New York City Board of Education who served as acting counsel to the chancellor, Judy is survived by her mother Lilli Kawer, her husband Judge Jerome M. Kay, her son Jonathan Kay, and her brothers Joel Kawer (Roz) and Philippe Kawer. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Beth Elohim, 274 Garfield Place, Brooklyn on Sunday at 10:00am. The family requests that donations be made to the American Cancer Society.

An article on July 15 about Olympic National Park, in Washington State, erroneously attributed a distinction to Cape Alava. It is the westernmost point in the contiguous United States, not in the Continental United States. (Much of Alaska is farther west.)

IT'S easy to dismiss the ''Step Up'' movie franchise as simply another sugary confection aimed at teenagers. And make no mistake, it is, first and foremost, just that. The four films, which began in 2006, follow the same basic plotline: an attractive underdog uses dance to fit in and achieve. The first three installments -- ''Step Up,'' ''Step Up 2: The Streets'' and ''Step Up 3D'' -- were increasingly over the top in tricky moves, use of flying hair and shots of impossibly toned abs. The latest version, ''Step Up Revolution,'' released on July 27, follows the template. Set in Miami and starring Kathryn McCormick and Ryan Guzman, and directed by a first-timer, Scott Speer, it makes use of one of the latest dance trends: the flash mob. The movie also nods gently at the Occupy movement, as the young dancers take on a not-so-scary hotel developer (Peter Gallagher) representing corporate America. (At one point Ms. McCormick's character says, ''Enough performance art, time for protest art.'') But beyond the fluff the ''Step Up'' movies have grossed more than $424 million worldwide, according to Box Office Mojo, and spawned many careers. Melissa Rosenberg went on to write the ''Twilight'' films on the strength of her ''Step Up'' screenplay. The director Jon M. Chu was handed the reins of the Justin Bieber movie while Channing Tatum, a star at the box office this year, was introduced in ''Step Up.'' Julie Bloom spoke with some of them about their experiences; here are excerpts.

FAUST--Irvin, 88, of New York city, died on July 24 succumbing to pneumonia after a long illness. After college he earned two Master's degrees and a Ph.D. He was a teacher, then a counselor; his last job was Director of Guidance at Garden City Long Island. A veteran of World War II, he served in Patton's Army with units that liberated concentration camps. Later he served with the occupation forces in Japan. His sole survivor is his wife of 55 years, Jean Satterthwaite Faust. Much beloved by many friends and professional associates, he will be greatly missed.

The TV Sports column last Sunday, about NBC's plan to provide live video streaming on its Olympics Web site of all the events at the London Games, misidentified, in some editions, one of the sports that the network streamed live during the 2010 Vancouver Games. Besides hockey, NBC also streamed curling -- not lacrosse, which is no longer an Olympic sport.

For the first time in the 50-year history of the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, visitors can now venture almost a quarter-mile inside the security fence and have a close look at Launch Pad 39-A, the starting point for most of the space shuttle flights and all six Apollo missions that landed on the moon. ''Visitors will travel the same route as astronauts to the launch pad,'' said Bill Moore, the chief operating officer of Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex, in a statement.

The Strategies column last Sunday, about reasons that the Dow Jones industrial average may eventually reach 20,000, misstated the assessment of current stock prices by Bernstein Global Wealth Management. In the firm's view, they are relatively low, not high.

To the Editor: Re ''I Do, I Do, I Do, I Do, I Do...'' (Sunday Styles, July 22), by Brooks Barnes: For those of us who attended far too many funerals of gay friends who died of AIDS, too many weddings are a welcomed and long-awaited pleasure.

CONWAY--Paul Emmanuel. Born February 24th, 1923 in Cologne, Germany. Paul Conway passed away July 27th at Waveny Care Center in New Canaan, Connecticut surrounded by his family. He was 89 years old. He was born on February 24th, 1923 in Cologne Germany. He was the son of the late Hedwig and Albert Conway of New York City. He is survived by his three children; Andrew J. Conway of Edgemont, NY, his wife Jill Conway. Victoria C. Newman of Greenwich, CT and her husband Peter Newman; Alexandra C. Marks of Riverside, CT and her husband Steven Marks; seven grandchildren who kept him young ranging in age from 1-17. Jonathan and Steven Conway, Talia and Kylie Newman, and William, Sophie and Charlie Marks; He was the husband of Madeleine Adler Conway and brother of Vernon Conway of Cheltenham, England. At a young age Mr. Conway his family moved to Berlin and in 1936 they fled Berlin for the safety of London. Shortly thereafter Mr. Conway enlisted in the British Army and served as a member of the Royal Fusiliers. He was stationed in India and Burma during WW2 and was recruited to the Prisoner of War Interrogation Section under the command of Lt. Col Alexander Scotland which later became the War Crimes Investigation Unit. Mr. Conway interrogated German War Criminals under the command of Mr. Scotland. After the war, Mr. Conway immigrated to the United States. He had a successful career in the Textile Industry, most recently co-owning C&L Sales. He was a founding shareholder in Carlton Woolen Mills and as President of Carltex, he became a major producer and seller of fabrics to retail stores. Mr. Conway was President of the Retail Associates Group, a major trade organization in the 1960's. He also led the Lincoln Square Neighborhood Center in New York City. Mr. Conway was an avid art collector, a lover of German Expressionist Art, classical music, travel and the United States. Mr. Conway was given the keys to the City of Cologne, Germany in 1986. A Memorial Service will be held on Monday, July 30th at 10am at Temple Sholom, 300 East Putnam Avenue in Greenwich, Connecticut. Memorial Contributions may be made to Waveny Care Center c/o Donna Sammarino, or the Norwalk Hospital Foundation, c/o Residents' Fund.

HAGENDORF--Sam. Has entered the universe on a cloud of love, surrounded by his loving family, on July 24, 2012, after a short illness, at nearly 89 years old. He was predeceased by his wife of 50 years, Sylvia (Starr), and son Scott. He is survived by his soul mate of 16 years, Bernice Salenger and his children, Sheryl Schwartz and son-in-law Barry, Sonny (Harry) Hagendorf and daughter-in-law Kathy, daughter-in-law Karena Wienands, his loving grandchildren, Stephanie Ferdman (Michael), Jonathan Schwartz, Colin Hagendorf, Emma Hagendorf, two great- grandchildren Jordan and Cooper, as well as Bernice's children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, and a large number of loving nieces and nephews. Sam was born in Williamsburg, Brooklyn on September 21, 1923 to Harry and Esther Hagendorf. He was predeceased by his sisters, Minnie, Lee, brothers, Ted, Louie, and Irwin. Sam served as a signalman in the US Navy in WWII in the pacific theater. A man ahead of his time, he owned a bar, the Havagrand Cafe, on Havemeyer and Grand Sts.-60 years too early, but the right idea! Sam's heart was as big as a bear's, and so was his appetite. We will love him, we will miss him and we will honor him. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The American Cancer Society. Funeral will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY 10023, on Sunday July 29, 1pm. Shiva will be observed on Sunday immediately following the service at the home of Sonny and Kathy Hagendorf in New Rochelle until 9pm, and on Monday and Tuesday at the home of Sheryl and Barry Schwartz in Granite Springs, NY from 2-9pm. "Now Let's Eat!"

VOLPE--Domenick A.,95, in Sandwich, MA, July 16, 2012. Born in Brooklyn NY, the devoted husband of the late Jean Mackenzie Volpe and survived by their daughters: Ann, Janet, and Denise, three grandchildren and five great- grandchildren. A patriot, Dom served the Veterans of Foreign Wars achieving the rank of New York State All-American Commander, 1977-8.

An article about Hillary Rodham Clinton misspelled the surname of a foreign-service of cer who wrote an article mentioned by Clinton. He is Aaron D. Snipe, not Snipes. It also misstated which round of the United States-China Strategic and Economic Dialogue Clinton attended this year. It was the fourth round, not the third. A correction in this space on July 15 misstated the date the article was published. It was July 1, not June 17.

Gathered now in London, they are out to make the fun and games of the Olympics into something more, to take you beyond yourself, to lift you with a performance that is graceful or muscular or gymnastic or maybe even -- for here the bar is highest -- unforgettable. We are talking about sportswriters, a famously shopworn and bibulous lot whose calling the novelist Richard Ford, himself a former sportswriter, lamented in his novel ''The Sportswriter,'' as ''more like being a businessman, or an old-fashioned traveling salesman with a line of novelty household items, than being a genuine writer ... there is very little that is ever genuinely creative to it at all.'' Yet so often, the greatest spur to the imagination is limitation. What Mr. Ford's sportswriter overlooked is that for really good writers, sports offers an opportunity to express all the pleasure and passion of life. I spent four and half years as a young reporter at Sports Illustrated, in the company of many fine writers and editors. All of them knew that the world considered sports to be of modest significance. And yet they also observed how much time and emotion people invested in sports and saw that sports mattered in ways that transcended the games. They took some credit for this. When I left to write books, the first one about sports, I continued to think about my privileged apprenticeship -- about what sportswriters do to make the unimportant feel absolutely urgent.

THE pairing of two current dance stars -- the choreographer and performer JONAH BOKAER and ballet's ''it'' boy, David Hallberg -- seemed almost too good to be true when it was first announced for this year's Jacob's Pillow festival. And it turns out that it was. Mr. Hallberg is injured, and Mr. Bokaer's ''Curtain,'' a collaboration with the visual artist Daniel Arsham, will take a different shape at its Pillow premiere on Wednesday. It's no less worth seeing, though. Mr. Bokaer's latest works have been striking for both their originality and their aesthetic impact, and the collaboration with Mr. Arsham promises a dramatic visual setting, with cast fiberglass molds that will melt during the performance, offering changing shapes as a living sculptural counterpoint to the dance. For the last-minute changes to the work obliged by Mr. Hallberg's injury, Mr. Bokaer has turned to Adam Weinert and James McGinn, dancers who have worked with him frequently, using them in the work's second half, ''Les Innocents,'' while performing alone in the opening section. 8:15 p.m. Wednesday to Saturday, Doris Duke Theater, Becket, Mass., (413) 243-0745, jacobspillow.org; $35 to 38.

7 P.M. (NBC) 2012 LONDON OLYMPICS The United States female gymnasts, including Jordyn Wieber, above, and Gabby Douglas, make their debuts at the Summer Games in a qualification round. Swimming finals include the women's 100-meter butterfly and 400-meter freestyle as well as the men's 100-meter breaststroke and 4x100-meter free relay. The first gold medal in women's diving will be awarded in the synchronized springboard final. Earlier in the day the men's basketball team, whose roster includes Kobe Bryant, LeBron James and Kevin Durant, faces off against France, for whom the N.B.A. star Tony Parker will play, at 9:30 a.m. on NBC Sports. The men's water polo team will take on Montenegro at 2:40 p.m. on NBC. And the women's field hockey team will meet Germany at 4:15 on NBC Sports. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, and Senator Kelly Ayotte, Republican of New Hampshire, discuss Mitt Romney's trip abroad.

The Check In/Check Out column on July 1, about the Inn at the Presidio in San Francisco, misidentified the entity that manages the land on which the inn is located. It is managed by the Presidio Trust, a federal agency created to preserve the Presidio; it is not overseen by the National Park Service. (The park service administers some other parts of the Presidio.)

An article last Sunday about the gentrification of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, misstated the location of the Well, a bar and performance space. It is on Meserole Street in East Williamsburg, not on Meserole Avenue in Greenpoint.
AWAD--Dewey John. July 25, 1979. Loved, missed, respected, resting with his sweet Rose. Jimmy

WHEN the guitarist and composer Pat Metheny last revved up for a full-scale tour, he had literally tons of equipment in tow, and no one to play it but himself. Those were the parameters behind ''Orchestrion,'' his outlandish, ingenious 2010 album on Nonesuch, and he fulfilled them with wizardly brio. But one suspects that conditions will be slightly breezier for the PAT METHENY UNITY BAND, which kicks off a cross-country tour with concerts at the Caramoor Jazz Festival on Sunday afternoon and the Bergen Performing Arts Center on Monday night. On its self-titled Nonesuch debut, the band -- with Chris Potter on saxophones, Ben Williams on bass and Antonio Sanchez on drums -- brings cohesive warmth as well as imposing fluency to a batch of concise new tunes by Mr. Metheny, whose gift for springlike melody is undiminished. Later in the tour there will be stops in Westhampton Beach, Rochester, Syracuse and the Catskills, but nothing has yet been announced for New York City, so make your plans accordingly. 4 p.m. Sunday, Caramoor Jazz Festival, Katonah, N.Y., (914) 232-1252, caramoor.org; $15 to $52.50. 8 p.m. Monday, Bergen Performing Arts Center, Englewood, N.J., (201) 227-1030, bergenpac.org; $29 to $89.

KLUTZNICK--Samuel John, Passed away peacefully on July 17th in a room filled with family and friends in Jackson Hole, WY. Born on August 4, 1948 in Chicago, he was the youngest son of Philip and Ethel Klutznick. Sam graduated from New York University. He had a life-long interest and involvement theater. He was active with the Actor's Studio and a member of the Dramatists Guild of America. Sam had an incredible intellect and was an entrepreneur. He was a writer, a real estate partner with his family and did private investment and finance. Sam lived in Paris and Jackson Hole, Wyoming, and he spent significant time in New York and London. He leaves behind his many friends and family members in Jackson Hole, Paris, Chicago, New York and around the world. He is survived by his siblings, Bettylu (Paul) Saltzman, Thomas Klutznick, James (Judy) Klutznick, Robert (Dodi) Klutznick and his nieces and nephews, Amy, David, Peter, and Jane Saltzman, Karen, John, Daniel and Katherine Klutznick, Barri, Marc and Kimberly Klutznick, Jennifer Beard, Lauren Hassan and Nathan Klutznick. A private graveside service was held in Chicago.

FLYNN--Rev. D. Michael, S.J.,on July 27. Cherished brother of Charles (Marilyn) Flynn. He is also survived by his loving nieces. Reposing at St. Mary of the Assumption Church, 2230 Richmond Terrace, Staten Island on Monday and Tuesday from 2-5 and 7-8:30pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be held Wednesday at 7:00pm at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel and St. Benedicta Church, 1265 Castleton Ave., Staten Island. Internment will take place at the Jesuit Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to the HAP Program at St. Mary of the Assumption Church would be appreciated. For information call Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors 718-654-0500.
'Losing is one thing; the way that we're going about it is unacceptable right now.' DAVID WRIGHT,

QUARANTA--Honorable Kevin J.,Town Justice, Bedford, New York, died July 27, 2012, peacefully at home surrounded by his loving family. He was the devoted husband of Judith Peterson; loving father of Christina, Kevin and William; dear brother of Mary Beth Morrissey and son of the late Dr. Mary Ann Quaranta and Dr. John V. Quaranta. Visitation on Sunday, July 29 and Monday, July 30 from 2-4 and 7-9pm at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY. The Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10:00am on Tuesday, July 31 at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Route 22, Bedford Village, NY.

NASH--Michael, Head of Tamiment Library -- NYU Libraries mourns the passing of our colleague; innovative archivist of left politics, labor, and human rights; scholar; teacher; dear friend. He transformed his library, his profession, and our understanding of the historical record. Our hearts are with his family. Memorial gifts may be sent for Tamiment to the Michael Nash Memorial Fund, Dean's Office, 70 Washington Square S, New York, NY 10012, or to organizations fostering social justice.
