I am the mother of two young boys. My nannies do the work that I know I could not do, since I work outside the home. What is important is the love and care my nannies give to my boys, as do the women in your article. If children cry and tug when their nannies leave (as mine do), that is exactly what a parent should want to see. I want my children to want their caregivers to stay. That is the only way I can leave. I could not imagine cutting my nannies from family pictures; they are as much members of our family as anyone related by blood. NANCY RODRIGUES, Mendham, N.J.
FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel reports back on a trip suggested by a New York Times reader, in the southern Swedish city of Kalmar and the nearby island of Oland (above).

BMW anticipates the road to ownership will be paved through short-term car rentals. The automaker is inviting customers in select markets in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to rent its 328i sedan by the hour, day or week, starting on Aug. 13, through a pilot program called BMW on Demand.

In last Sunday's Big City column, Ginia Bellafante wrote about the city's high unemployment rate and the difficulty of making ends meet with a job near the minimum wage. Readers responded on NYTimes.com. They also commented on an article by Sarah Maslin Nir about New York City airport mix-ups -- heading to, for example, La Guardia when one's flight leaves from Kennedy. A selection of responses is below.

SCHULMAN--Jerome Morris, 73, Chemistry Professor at Queens College died July 24, 2012 in Manhattan. He earned a B.S. from RPI and his Ph.D. in organic chemistry from Columbia University. A full professor by 1973, he published more than 100 papers. Jerry is survived by his wife of 30 years, Karen; his sister Linda Schulman (Sheldon Metz) of Tucson, AZ; his stepdaughter Diana Corless (James), of Washington, DC, and grandchildren, Viva, Harry and Wade Corless. A memorial service to be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to VNSNY Hospice Care, 1250 Broadway, 7th floor, NY, NY 10001.

A pop quiz last Sunday about the alma maters of presidents misidentified the location of Leiden University, which John Quincy Adams attended. It is in Leiden, the Netherlands -- not in Amsterdam. (Mr. Adams graduated from Harvard, in 1787.)

An article last Sunday about the Baltimore Symphony's BSO Academy, which brings together amateur and professional musicians (some of them doctors and government workers) for a weeklong program, misstated the date on which the Supreme Court recently made its ruling on health care. It was June 28, not June 26.

Declutter. Bathe the walls in neutral paint. Banish all traces of pets. These are the better-known steps to take before selling an apartment. Following are some more obscure home staging tips, courtesy of the professionals:

An article on July 8 about Ben Shaoul, a developer of luxury real estate in Manhattan, referred incorrectly to Department of Buildings violations for 118 and 120 East Fourth Street, which Mr. Shaoul owns. While Mr. Shaoul indicated that he had never received a Department of Buildings violation for either building, violations were in fact issued. The article also misstated the ownership of the Norwood Club, a members-only establishment on West 14th Street. While Mr. Shaoul owns the building that houses the club, the club itself is a nonprofit organization. He does not own the club.

''Lawless'' opens Aug. 29 and could also be called ''How to Succeed in Bootlegging While Really Trying.'' Set during Prohibition, it focuses on the moonshining Bondurant brothers. To some it's an outlaw story, but others might take it as Harvard Business Review case study. Shia LaBeouf and Mia Wasikowska are above.

The Big Ticket column last Sunday about the sale of Apartment 9W at 907 Fifth Avenue for $25.5 million erroneously attributed a distinction to the building. It was not the first multifamily dwelling on the avenue.

LET the cool kids have the Rockaways and the tourists Coney Island. Wayne Lawrence will stick to Orchard Beach, in the Bronx, even if it takes him three trains and a bus to get there. He has been shooting portraits of Orchard Beach's summertime regulars since 2005. If Weegee's iconic photographs of beachgoers focused on the crowds -- in his shots, 1950s sunbathers outnumbered grains of sand on Coney Island -- Mr. Lawrence seeks out individuals who catch his eye along the ''Bronx Riviera.''

LYNCH--Richard Hugh. February 12, 1940 - June 19, 2012. Richard died peacefully at home of a heart attack. In 1970, he became a life member of the Actors' Studio. He later joined a theater group with Al Pacino, playing in many productions in New York and Boston. He made his film debut in the 1973 classic "Scarecrow" - winner of the 1973 grand Prix at the Cannes Film Festival - opposite Pacino and Gene Hackman. Some of his other memorable roles were in "Invasion U.S.A.," "The Seven Ups," and "The Formula." Richard was the recipient of the Lifetime Achievement Award at the Madrid Film festival for his distinguished career. For more information on his career, please visit the online memorial at: http://youtube.com/watch? v=zlaTDCOLhfo. He was an honorary member of the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences. In addition to being an accomplished actor, Richard served his country proudly as a United States Marine. He is survived by his sisters, Carole J. Taylor and Cathy L. Jones, his brother Barry J. Lynch and many other loving relatives. He is predeceased by his beloved son, Christopher L. Lynch. He will be deeply missed by his family, friends, and loyal fans. A memorial service was held at Hollywood Forever Funeral Home on June 24, 2012.

Podcast Scheduled to appear this week: Nicholas Confessore on ''The Candidate: What It Takes to Win -- and Hold -- the White House,'' by Samuel L. Popkin; Henry Alford on two recent books about the ''manly arts'' -- Joel Stein's ''Man Made'' and James May's ''How to Land an A330 Airbus''; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles with best-/seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. By the BookAn expanded version of our interview with Alison Bechdel, the cartoonist and author of the memoirs ''Fun Home'' and ''Are You My Mother?''

BORIE--David Boyd. 83, died in Greenwich, CT July 14 surrounded by his loving family. Born in Philadelphia, Mr Borie was a graduate of Yale, class of '51, varsity football, Chi Psi fraternity. Mr. Borie served as officer in the U.S. Marine Corps during the Korean War, received medals including Bronze Star (Combat V) and Purple Heart. 30 year career at Time-Life, he retired as European Marketing Director in London. Mr. Borie was an active community member and enjoyed shooting sports and fishing. Survived by his beloved wife, Mary Washington Borie and four children, Mary W. Zara of New Canaan, CT, David B. Borie Jr. of Denver, CO, J. Stewart Borie of San Diego, CA and Lyssa B. Righi of Phoenix, AZ, 11 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Memorial services will be held at St. Barnabas Church in Greenwich, CT September 22, 11:30 am. Donations in lieu of flowers to Nantucket Conservation Foundation (508) 228-2884 or Marine Corps Scholarship Foundation (866) 496-5462 Ref: Service #

MAHTA--Peter. Born in Oxford, UK on March 11, 1922 and died peacefully at his home in New York on July 21, 2012. He studied in England at Willingdon College. At the outbreak of WWII Peter Mahta was in India where he enlisted in the Royal Indian Artillery and served in Burma from 1940 to 1945 ending his army career with the rank of major. Peter Mahta played a significant role in the success of Air India which he joined in London in 1948. Peter Mahta started the airline's transatlantic service in New York in 1960 as Director for the North American Region and retired in 1980. He then joined Oberoi Hotels as Vice President Sales North America until 1994. He enjoyed running and ran 15 consecutive marathons in New York. Peter Mahta is survived by his wife of 45 years, Karola Marlene and his sister Sheila Leggett living in the UK. A memorial gathering to celebrate his life will be announced at a later date.

HYMAN--Charles B.,of New York City and Ocean Beach, Fire Island, on July 26, 2012. Born in El Paso, Texas, proud WWII veteran, prominent exporter and owner of Harry Hyman & Son, Inc. He traveled extensively all over the world. Beloved husband of the late Ruth, devoted father of Laurence and the late Roger. Dear father-in-law of Ann and Susan. Cherished grandfather of Kevin, Douglas, Daniel and Gail. Great-grandfather of Roger, Nathaniel, Julia, Zachary and Marc. Brother of the late Julie Berns. He will be missed by his extended family and wide circle of friends. Service Sunday, July 29th, 11am at Westchester Hills Cemetery. Shiva Sunday afternoon at his home. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Central Park Conservancy or The New York Council of Jewish Women.

Hanna Adams joined PJA Advertising and Marketing as an account supervisor. She had been an account supervisor at Hill Holliday, Boston, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

The Afghanistan Infrastructure Project was intended to bring soldiers and civilians together to buttress the counterinsurgency strategy, but delays could end up undercutting it, according to a new report.

Deep in thought about the day or work or whatever, I failed to notice the little yellow caution signs the window-washers had placed on Park Avenue outside one of the huge buildings there. I suddenly felt water hitting my head.

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- As the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad's government grinds on with no resolution in sight, Syrians involved in the armed struggle say it is becoming more radicalized: homegrown Muslim jihadists, as well as small groups of fighters from Al Qaeda, are taking a more prominent role and demanding a say in running the resistance. The past few months have witnessed the emergence of larger, more organized and better armed Syrian militant organizations pushing an agenda based on jihad, the concept that they have a divine mandate to fight. Even less-zealous resistance groups are adopting a pronounced Islamic aura because it attracts more financing.

FAUST--Irvin, 88, of New York city, died on July 24 succumbing to pneumonia after a long illness. After college he earned two Master's degrees and a Ph.D. He was a teacher, then a counselor; his last job was Director of Guidance at Garden City Long Island. A veteran of World War II, he served in Patton's Army with units that liberated concentration camps. Later he served with the occupation forces in Japan. His sole survivor is his wife of 55 years, Jean Satterthwaite Faust. Much beloved by many friends and professional associates, he will be greatly missed.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Saturday with an article about James Robert Williams, a major political benefactor who lives in a humble section of Queens, misstated, in some copies, the date Mr. Williams was shown outside his apartment. It was Saturday, June 30 -- not Saturday, July 28.

RASHBAUM--Harold (Buddy), beloved husband of Charlotte and devoted father to Dory and Jody and grandfather to Zoe, Eileen and Alex passed away July 27th, 2012. Buddy was a WWII veteran and bombardier. He worked in the textile industry and then co owned a company with his brother-n-law for many years. He passed away peacefully in his home. He will be deeply missed by his family and friends.

LONDON -- The two other swimmers had already finished, leaving Jennet Saryyeva to complete the final 75 meters of her 400-meter freestyle by herself. But she was not alone. The crowd at the London Aquatics Centre on Sunday threw its collective voice behind her, clapping and cheering as if she were one of them. When Saryyeva, an 18-year-old student from Turkmenistan, stopped the clock in 5 minutes 40.29 seconds, almost a minute after her nearest competitor, the applause was deafening. Only the British swimmers were received more royally.

A few weeks after becoming press secretary to the mayor of New York City in 2006, Stu Loeser walked into his City Hall office, opened a refrigerator and was stunned to see a small white box with the name of a Daily News reporter scrawled across the top. The box held a cake, which the reporter wanted to keep cool for the day. But Mr. Loeser was suspicious. ''What if there is a tape recorder in here?'' he asked, according to several people who recounted the episode.

LOS ANGELES -- After what amounted to a routine holdout by the six adult stars of television's top comedy, ''Modern Family,'' deals were concluded Friday night that will have the show's premiere episode begin production Monday, as scheduled. The president of ABC Entertainment, Paul Lee, said here Friday night that all cast members had agreed to new deals. They will receive significant, though undisclosed, salary raises.

JERUSALEM -- Mitt Romney said Sunday that preventing Iran from obtaining nuclear capability should be America's ''highest national security priority,'' stressing that ''no option should be excluded'' in the effort. ''We have a solemn duty and a moral imperative to deny Iran's leaders the means to follow through on their malevolent intentions,'' Mr. Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, told an audience of about 300, including a large contingent of American donors who flew here to accompany him. ''We must not delude ourselves into thinking that containment is an option.''

JERUSALEM -- Miriam Ben-Porat, the first woman to serve as a justice on Israel's Supreme Court and to hold the post of state comptroller, the government's watchdog, died on Thursday at her home in Jerusalem. She was 94. Her death was confirmed by a spokeswoman for the Israeli courts administration.

The movie has been a Christmas favorite for almost 30 years now, and a stage musical version was a big hit when it played in five cities late last year. Now ''A Christmas Story, The Musical!'' is headed to Broadway, just in time for the 2012 holiday season. ''A Christmas Story, The Musical!'' will play at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, with opening night scheduled for Nov. 19, and is scheduled to run through Dec. 30. The creative team includes veterans like the director John Rando (''Urinetown'') and the choreographer Warren Carlyle (''Hugh Jackman: Back on Broadway''), with songs by two young newcomers, Benj Pasek and Justin Paul.

The jazz legend Charlie Parker was born on Aug. 29, 1920 - a Sunday. The saxophonist Lester Young was born on Aug. 27, 1909, a Friday. The trumpeter Jabbo Smith died on Wednesday, Jan. 16, 1991. These may seem like petty pieces of jazz trivia to some people, but they are nearly articles of faith to Phil Schaap, the loquaciously edifying elder statesman of WKCR-FM (89.9), the Columbia University radio station, who during his 42 years on the air has emerged as one of the planet's more knowledgeable jazz historians.
2012 LONDON

Going into the weekend, the research firm NRG told film studios that about 20 percent of moviegoers remained hesitant to go to the movies following the July 20 mass shooting in Colorado during ''The Dark Knight Rises.'' Studios also worried about competition from the London Olympics and poor weather in parts of the country. Something sure dragged down box office results: North American theaters sold about $135 million in tickets over the weekend, a 25 percent decline from the same period last year, according to studio distribution executives. ''The Dark Knight Rises'' (Warner Brothers) was No. 1, taking in an estimated $64 million -- a 60 percent drop from last weekend, when the movie benefited from strong advance ticket sales. ''The Dark Knight Rises'' has now taken in about $289.1 million in the United States and Canada, or 14 percent less than its franchise predecessor grossed over the same period in 2008, after adjusting for inflation.

In ''How to Get Into the Twin Palms,'' Karolina Waclawiak's first novel, a young Polish woman named Anya struggles with her isolated existence in Los Angeles. Her dreams revolve around gaining entrance to the private club of the title, a place exclusively reserved for the city's Russian residents. Anya tries to pass herself off as Russian and cozies up to a possibly dangerous man named Lev. In a recent interview via e-mail, Ms. Waclawiak discussed her resemblance to Anya, her favorite writers on Los Angeles, how she would cast a movie version of her novel and more. Below are excerpts from the conversation. Q.

FX announced that it had renewed its Emmy-nominated comedy series, ''Louie,'' for a fourth season, according to the Web site Hitfix.com. Created, directed and written by Louis C. K. (left), who also stars as a single father in New York City, the program has averaged 1.9 million total viewers, including DVR use, so far in its third season. But the low ratings are offset by the work of the multitalented Louis C. K., who received three Emmy nominations this month and runs the show on a shoestring budget in exchange for creative control. The network also announced that it had ordered an additional seven episodes of ''Brand X,'' its late-night talk show hosted by the comedian Russell Brand.

BUITEKANT--Allan. At 78, in Asheville, NC, July 14. One of a small group of art directors at the Doyle Dane Bernbach agency in the '60's and 70's who transformed advertising, infusing it with wit, style, and elegance. In his studio in Union Mills, he continued the pursuit of his true vocation, ceramics. Much influenced by the Mashiko tradition, his work was widely collected (visit buitekantpottery.com). He was also a student and disciple of the great bonsai master, Yuji Yoshimura. Devastated by the death of Jane, his beloved wife of 40 years, he had the great good luck to meet and fall in love with Joyce Cunningham, his life partner, who survives him. His renowned collection of bonsai, donated to The Bronx Botanical Garden, also lives on after him.

In 1995, a good-hearted programmer named Craig Newmark thought of a way to make newspaper classified ad listings simple, and in turn, people's lives easier. His free Web site, called Craigslist, quickly gained millions of users. Eye-popping offers to buy the company outright came in, all of which Mr. Newmark turned down, saying Craigslist was a ''public good.'' Despite its success, Craigslist has become stagnant. Today, it feels stuck in the 1990s, where links are electric blue and everything is underlined. As a result, the site is now crammed with listings and is extremely difficult to use.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- Two years ago, as the final pieces of the Obama administration's troop surge were moving into place in southern Afghanistan, American officials identified a handful of infrastructure projects that they hoped would build popular support for the Afghan government in the Taliban's heartland. The Pentagon and State Department secured $400 million from Congress for what was christened the Afghanistan Infrastructure Fund and drew up plans for seven projects, five of them aimed at increasing the electricity supply in southern Afghanistan to light shops and power factories. The projects were to be completed by mid-2013, just as the NATO combat mission was to wind down.

Not familiar with characters named Alpha Pig, Princess Presto, Super Why, Woofster and Wonder Red? Advertising and promotional campaigns worth several million dollars may soon be filling you in. The characters are the stars of an animated series for children, ''Super Why,'' that has appeared since 2007 on PBS Kids and PBS Kids Sprout. The series is intended to help youngsters ages 3 to 6 learn to read.

An obituary on July 20 about the comedian and former ''Saturday Night Live'' writer Tom Davis included several errors. Mr. Davis was born in St. Paul, not in Minneapolis. He created the Coneheads for ''Saturday Night Live'' with Dan Aykroyd, not with Al Franken. And a ''Saturday Night Live'' sketch in which Mr. Aykroyd played Julia Child was written by Mr. Davis and Mr. Franken, not by Mr. Davis and Mr. Aykroyd.

Ginny Tyler, a Head Mouseketeer in the syndicated version of the ''The Mickey Mouse Club'' of the 1960s and a voice actor who shifted from Snow White to Cinderella to Bambi on recordings as a Disneyland Storyteller, died on July 13 at a nursing home in Issaquah, Wash. She was 86. Her death was confirmed by her son, Ty Fenton.

The Smithsonian announced that Kirk Johnson had been appointed the next director of the National Museum of Natural History in Washington. Mr. Johnson, who is currently the chief curator and vice president of research at the Denver Museum of Nature & Science, will assume his new post on Oct. 29. He has also served as the curator of paleontology at that museum since 1991 and recently led an excavation near Snowmass Village, Colo., where more than 5,400 bones of mammoths, mastodons and other ice age animals were discovered. His paleontology background dovetails with the Smithsonian's recently announced plans to build a new dinosaur hall on the National Mall over the next several years. The natural history museum holds more than 126 million specimens and artifacts and hosts an average of seven million visitors a year.

Miller--Judith Martin, 93, died on July 28. A brilliant actress, director modern dancer, and a founder of The Paper Bag Players. She gave delight to children everywhere, but mostly to her daughter Daisy and her late husband Sol. She is survived by Daisy Miller, Seth Armus and her grand- children Benjamin and Lilah.

An article on Wednesday about a New York City Board of Health hearing on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposal to restrict sales of big sugary drinks referred incorrectly to a prop that a speaker brought. One speaker brought a 64-ounce fountain drink cup; a bowl of fruits and vegetables was not the only prop brought by any of the speakers.

In the world of search engines, Google's dominance has propelled it to a permanent place as a verb in dictionaries. But another Web site named after a verb wants to own the business of answering questions. On Friday, Ask.com began an advertising campaign with the hope of getting more people to visit the site when they have questions like ''What's the best way to make a potato salad?'' or ''Who killed J.F.K.?'' ''People aren't looking for a new search engine,'' said Doug Leeds, the chief executive of Ask.com. ''They are satisfied with Google.'' Mr. Leeds said Google is a place to do research ''where you just want a whole bunch of sites that point you in the right direction.''

BORIE--David Boyd. 83, died in Greenwich, CT July 14 surrounded by his loving family. Born in Philadelphia, Mr Borie was a graduate of Yale, class of '51, varsity football, Chi Psi fraternity. Mr. Borie served as officer in the U.S. Marine Corps during the Korean War, received medals including Bronze Star (Combat V) and Purple Heart. 30 year career at Time-Life, he retired as European Marketing Director in London. Mr. Borie was an active community member and enjoyed shooting sports and fishing. Survived by his beloved wife, Mary Washington Borie and four children, Mary W. Zara of New Canaan, CT, David B. Borie Jr. of Denver, CO, J. Stewart Borie of San Diego, CA and Lyssa B. Righi of Phoenix, AZ, 11 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Memorial services will be held at St. Barnabas Church in Greenwich, CT September 22, 11:30 am. Donations in lieu of flowers to Nantucket Conservation Foundation (508) 228-2884 or Marine Corps Scholarship Foundation (866) 496-5462 Ref: Service #

HANCOCK FIELD AIR NATIONAL GUARD BASE, N.Y. -- From his computer console here in the Syracuse suburbs, Col. D. Scott Brenton remotely flies a Reaper drone that beams back hundreds of hours of live video of insurgents, his intended targets, going about their daily lives 7,000 miles away in Afghanistan . Sometimes he and his team watch the same family compound for weeks.''I see mothers with children, I see fathers with children, I see fathers with mothers, I see kids playing soccer,'' Colonel Brenton said.

So far, viewers are flocking to the London Olympics. After an average of 40.7 million viewers watched Friday's opening ceremony -- the most on record in the United States for a Summer Games -- 28.7 million tuned in Saturday night, the most to have watched a first night of competition.
If it looks like a duck, quacks like a duck and walks like a duck, then it's a duck - right? One question many seem to be wondering about Twitter: is this duck a media or technology company?

Walker Evans's photographic study of New York subway riders during the late 1930s and early '40s nudged me to try the same. His candid portraits, shot without obviously aiming his camera, captured the unguarded and revealing face of urbanity. Among the masses, he found singular souls. Mr. Evans's technique made him, by one description, the ''first to use the subway as a lens on society.'' His collected images were not published until 1966, as the book ''Many Are Called,'' with an introduction by James Agee. Three years later, as a young photographer fresh to New York, I, too, heard the call. I did not try to hide my 35-millimeter camera, but because there was no flash, most people didn't seem to notice me. Of the ones who did, few seemed to care. The subway, I discovered, was the best studio in town.

CONWAY--Paul Emmanuel. Born February 24th, 1923 in Cologne, Germany. Paul Conway passed away July 27th at Waveny Care Center in New Canaan, Connecticut surrounded by his family. He was 89 years old. He was born on February 24th, 1923 in Cologne Germany. He was the son of the late Hedwig and Albert Conway of New York City. He is survived by his three children; Andrew J. Conway of Edgemont, NY, his wife Jill Conway. Victoria C. Newman of Greenwich, CT and her husband Peter Newman; Alexandra C. Marks of Riverside, CT and her husband Steven Marks; seven grandchildren who kept him young ranging in age from 1-17. Jonathan and Steven Conway, Talia and Kylie Newman, and William, Sophie and Charlie Marks; He was the husband of Madeleine Adler Conway and brother of Vernon Conway of Cheltenham, England. At a young age Mr. Conway his family moved to Berlin and in 1936 they fled Berlin for the safety of London. Shortly thereafter Mr. Conway enlisted in the British Army and served as a member of the Royal Fusiliers. He was stationed in India and Burma during WW2 and was recruited to the Prisoner of War Interrogation Section under the command of Lt. Col Alexander Scotland which later became the War Crimes Investigation Unit. Mr. Conway interrogated German War Criminals under the command of Mr. Scotland. After the war, Mr. Conway immigrated to the United States. He had a successful career in the Textile Industry, most recently co-owning C&L Sales. He was a founding shareholder in Carlton Woolen Mills and as President of Carltex, he became a major producer and seller of fabrics to retail stores. Mr. Conway was President of the Retail Associates Group, a major trade organization in the 1960's. He also led the Lincoln Square Neighborhood Center in New York City. Mr. Conway was an avid art collector, a lover of German Expressionist Art, classical music, travel and the United States. Mr. Conway was given the keys to the City of Cologne, Germany in 1986. A Memorial Service will be held on Monday, July 30th at 10am at Temple Sholom, 300 East Putnam Avenue in Greenwich, Connecticut. Memorial Contributions may be made to Waveny Care Center c/o Donna Sammarino, or the Norwalk Hospital Foundation, c/o Residents' Fund.

LONDON -- The medals were silver, but the smiles of Abby Johnston and Kelci Bryant showed that they meant much, much more than that. Johnston and Bryant finished second in the women's synchronized 3-meter competition Sunday, claiming the United States' first diving medal since 2000. Their final dive, a backward two-and-a-half somersault, might have been their best.
DOUGHERTY--Edward. God's gift to us. Love everlasting. Annie and Family
Hanna Adams joined PJA Advertising and Marketing as an account supervisor. She had been an account supervisor at Hill Holliday, Boston, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

Periodically throughout the Olympics, The Times will check in with Dennis Spurr, owner of the Fantastic Sausage Factory in Weymouth, a pretty town on the English coast where the sailing events are taking place. Spurr's sausage business was targeted by the Olympic branding authorities in 2007 after he put up a sign featuring the Olympic five-ring logo fashioned out of sausage links. He took it down on their demands, but he replaced it with a sign featuring five squares made out of sausage links. Q.

The top two digital songs through June 2012 were built around guest turns by female vocalists. ''Somebody That I Used to Know'' by Gotye, above, paired the Australian singer-songwriter with Kimbra, a singer-songwriter from New Zealand. ''We Are Young'' by Fun., an indie group from New York, featured the Atlanta artist Janelle Monáe. These hit songs helped propel album sales: ''Making Mirrors'' by Gotye sold 309,000 digital albums, and Fun.'s ''Some Nights,'' 250,000. The top digital albums were ''21'' by Adele (876,000) and One Direction's ''Up All Night'' (367,000). SHELLY FREIERMAN

Here are some of the athletes and teams in Monday's spotlight. (All times Eastern.) WOMEN'S VOLLEYBALL When the United States and Brazil met in the final at the Beijing Games, Brazil took home the gold. But the United States took over the No. 1 ranking from Brazil late last year. The two heavyweights are in the same pool in London, offering an early tournament showdown. Coached by Hugh McCutcheon, who led the American men to a gold medal in Beijing, the American women are looking for their first gold in the sport. NBC, 11:30 a.m.

Two weeks after its takeover by an online media company, Spin magazine's future as a print publication was cast further into doubt on Friday when 11 employees - a third of the staff - were laid off and publication plans for the bimonthly magazine were suspended. Whether Spin, an alternative music magazine founded in 1985, will disappear in printed form altogether is unclear.

CARMEN--Captain Marvin, DDS, born September 10, 1919, died July 28, 2012. He was a graduate of Marquette University and served 43 years in the USN Dental Corps, from World War II through Vietnam, where he was Chief of Dental Service on the hospital ship Sanctuary. He retired from the Navy in 1981 and embarked on a second career as a Professor of Dentistry at New York University, where he taught for over 25 years. He passed away peacefully at home surrounded by loved ones. He is survived by wife Claire, two stepchildren, five grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. The funeral is Monday, July 30, 2012 at 9:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, New York City; interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery, Long Island. Memorial contributions may be made to Central Synagogue in Dr. Carmen's name.

CORTLAND, N.Y. - Darrelle Revis missed most of the Jets' first full-pads workout Sunday with tightness in his right hamstring, but he said that the injury was neither serious nor a reflection of any dissatisfaction with his contract. After sensing discomfort Saturday, Revis was shut down after participating in positional drills. He said he expected to practice Monday. Revis bristled when asked whether he sat out seven-on-seven and team workouts in protest of his contract, as he did during a June 2010 minicamp, when he exaggerated a hamstring pull and complained of feeling light-headed. That summer, he staged a 36-day holdout. Revis, who acknowledged last week that he came close to holding out again, said he had been adjusting to the faster pace at practice favored by the new offensive coordinator, Tony Sparano.
DEAR DIARY: The Chelsea post office on 23rd Street and 10th Avenue is so full of dysfunction, I couldn't possibly write down every quip I overhear there.

Some remember St. Nick's Pub as simply magical. Perhaps the jazz greats who played there, blowing, singing and sweating into the early hours of the morning, left something in the tattered walls and creaky floors of the little Harlem nightspot on St. Nicholas Avenue at 149th Street. That magic went on, like a saxophone riff, until March 4, 2011. That night, the place was jumping, dark, smoky and loud. Beer and liquor flowed and platters of soul food were eaten. A band called the Skillet Show performed to a packed house. But though few patrons were aware of it, St. Nick's, one of the few remaining jazz clubs in Harlem, had been teetering for some time. The police shut it down during a raid before another act, the Donald Smith Ensemble, could finish its set. Since then the magic has existed only in memory.

WASHINGTON -- The best aircraft to fight the growing number of Western wildfires would be dozens of modern ''scooper'' planes that fill their bellies with water skimmed in seconds from a lake or river, and not the slower helicopters and tankers now in use, according to a study released on Monday by the RAND Corporation. But the chief of the federal Forest Service, which commissioned the study, has rejected its central finding. The problem is urgent because destructive fires are increasingly frequent, and the existing fleet of planes, leased from private operators, is old and accident prone. Firefighting crashes have killed seven crew members this year.

These days, if you want to stand out among the hundreds of mobile-social-local-global applications and services competing for users' attention, it is no longer enough to get tech types to champion your service. You need someone with star power - someone like Justin Bieber. On Thursday, Stamped, a mobile application and Web site that lets people share reviews of anything they like - songs, books, places, movies, television shows, even other applications - plans to announce a revamped version of its service, along with a roster of new celebrity investors (and users) that includes Mr. Bieber, Ryan Seacrest and Ellen DeGeneres.

An obituary on July 20 about the sportswriter Robert Creamer misidentified the publication in which Roger Angell said that Babe Ruth had ''at last found the biographer he deserves in Robert Creamer.'' It was The New York Times Book Review, not The New Yorker.

BRAVERMAN--Lori Goldman, 74, passed away on July 17, 2012. The cause was complications from acute myeloid leukemia. Lori was, first and foremost, about her family. She was the devoted wife of Monte Braverman for over fifty years and is survived by her children, Andrea Gross, Harvey Braverman and Janice Kaplan; her son-in-law Cliff Kaplan and daughter-in-law Kiki Braverman; her grandchildren, Corey, Drew and Jordan Gross, Carly, Alex and Jillian Kaplan, and Oliver Braverman; and her brother Mitchell Goldman. Lori was predeceased by her parents Bernard and Ree Goldman of Philadelphia, PA, and her sister Paula Goldman. Lori, a watercolorist, grew up in Bala Cynwyd, PA and was a long-time resident of Tenafly, NJ and Snowmass Village, CO.

MANCHESTER, England - With two victories and a place in the Olympics quarterfinals already in hand for the United States women's soccer team, the story line generating the most attention here is a modern-day version of the schoolyard spat. Coach Pia Sundhage said Sunday that she and the team's captains, Abby Wambach and Christie Rampone, met with the goalkeeper Hope Solo following Solo's posting of bitter Twitter messages directed at an NBC broadcaster who Solo felt was unreasonably evaluating the team.
A film review on Friday about ''Sacrifice'' referred incorrectly to the director, Chen Kaige, at one point. Chen is his family name; thus he is Mr. Chen, not Mr. Kaige.

''My heart goes pitter-patter every time I walk into this closet-size store; I've never seen so many handbags that I couldn't live without,'' Suzy Gershman wrote of one of the hidden gems she discovered in her research for ''Born to Shop Hong Kong.'' ''These bags are not copies, they just coincidentally look a lot like the handbags in fashion magazines.''Of another find, revealed in ''Born to Shop New York,'' she wrote, ''This is the kind of small Madison Avenue boutique that you might pass without ever knowing that it is the 'in' place for Upper East Side ladies who like the Euro-Asian-artsy-hippie-boho look.''

Bobby Valentine, the animated and ever-scheming manager of the Boston Red Sox, tossed his gum in disgust. He stomped back to the dugout, face flushed, having been ejected over a controversial call on a bunt foul tip by Will Middlebrooks in the 10th inning of a tie game with the Yankees. In the clubhouse, though, Valentine may have winked. He certainly smiled when, two batters later, shortstop Pedro Ciriaco blooped a single into right field for the go-ahead run to help Boston sneak out of Yankee Stadium with a 3-2 win Sunday night.

WASHINGTON -- ''Why believe me? I'm a noted fabulist,'' says Mike Daisey, his honeyed voice all but dripping with sarcasm, eyes glinting with challenge. The audience at the Woolly Mammoth Theater here, where Mr. Daisey is performing an encore run of his solo show ''The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs,'' chuckles in sympathy. Mr. Daisey is, of course, referring to the controversy that erupted last spring over his popular, polemical solo show, in which he exposed the dire conditions workers were subjected to at the factories in China where Apple products - and much of the rest of the world's electronics - are manufactured.

While the onscreen versions of the Marvel Comics superheroes are racking up dollars at the box office, their printed incarnations are commanding premium prices at the auction block, too. An illustration of Spider-Man that ran on the cover of one of the wall-crawler's comic book adventures from 1990 was sold on Thursday for more than $650,000, while 1960s comics containing the first appearances of that publisher's Avengers and X-Men teams each sold for six-figure prices. The auction house Heritage Auctions said that the original cover artwork from Amazing Spider-Man No. 328, drawn by Todd McFarlane and depicting Spidey as he lifts the Hulk over his head (and smashes him into his logo) had been sold for $657,250. The company said this was the highest auction price ever paid for a piece of comic-book art; another illustration by Mr. McFarlane drawn for the cover of Spider-Man No. 1, a series published in the 1990s, was sold at this same auction for $358,500.

A critic's notebook article on Tuesday about the Festival International d'Art Lyrique d'Aix-en-Provence, and picture captions with it, misstated the name of the ensemble that played the music for two Mozart operas, ''Le Nozze di Figaro'' and ''La Finta Giardiniera.'' It is Le Cercle de l'Harmonie, not Le Cercle d'Harmonie. And because of an editing error, a caption referred incorrectly to ''La Finta Giardiniera.'' It was a production of several organizations, not Le Cercle de l'Harmonie.

8 P.M. (MSG) DOG DAY AFTERNOON (1975) A double bill celebrates the collaboration between the actor Al Pacino and the director Sidney Lumet, starting with this crime drama about a first-time crook whose plan to rob a Brooklyn bank to pay for the sex-change operation of his lover (Chris Sarandon) goes awry. The film won an Oscar for best original screenplay and was nominated for best picture. Also nominated, among others, were Mr. Pacino (above, with Penny Allen), Mr. Sarandon and Mr. Lumet. The film is Mr. Lumet's ''most accurate, most flamboyant New York movie -- that consistently vital and energetic Lumet genre that includes 'The Pawnbroker' and 'Serpico' and exists entirely surrounded by (but always separate from) the rest of his work,'' Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. ''Mr. Lumet's New York movies are as much aspects of the city's life as they are stories of the city's life.'' In ''Serpico'' (1973), at 10:30, Mr. Pacino, in another Oscar-nominated role, plays the real New York City police detective Frank Serpico, who put his life on the line in the early 1970s to reveal graft and corruption within the department to David Burnham, a reporter for The New York Times. 9 A.M. (MTV) DARIA The network's Retro Mania programming block wraps up with three hours of this 1997 ''Beavis and Butt-Head'' spinoff centered on the sharp-tongued intellectual Daria Morgendorffer (voiced by Tracy Grandstaff). The comedians Nikki Glaser and Sara Schaefer provide commentary.

WASHINGTON -- President Obama's biography -- son of a black father from Kenya and a white mother from Kansas -- has long suggested that unlike most African-Americans, his roots did not include slavery. Now a team of genealogists is upending that thinking, saying that Mr. Obama's mother had, in addition to her European ancestors, at least one African forebear and that the president is most likely descended from one of the first documented African slaves in the United States.

Sometimes the only way to get a straight answer from a company on a thorny topic is through its government filings. In an annual report that it submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday afternoon, Microsoft finally conceded something that has been rather obvious to anyone with a rudimentary understanding of the personal computer industry and Microsoft's historical role in it. On page 14 of the document, Microsoft acknowledges that its Surface family of tablet computers could weaken support for Windows among Microsoft's partners in the PC industry, known as original equipment manufacturers, or OEMs for short.

Dear Diary: As I was driving uptown on Third Avenue, I suddenly heard sirens blaring and saw red and blue lights flashing, right behind me. ''Oh, oh - here comes a ticket. Did I inadvertently run a red light? Or did I commit some other moving violation?'' I rolled down my window.

Irvin Faust, who as a high school guidance counselor found time to write novels and short stories that critics likened to the magic realist fiction of South America, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 88. The cause was pneumonia following a series of strokes, his wife, Jean, said.

Dear Diary: The heat the other week drove me out of my blazing hot apartment in search of a ''cooling'' center. Day 1: 88 degrees. I visited the New York Main Library. I floated around a funny, even appetizing archival tour of lunchtime eating in New York City. The cool air whirled gently around me as I listened to the Horn and Hardart theme song, ''Less Work for Mothers.''

The Cuidad Nezahualcóyotl Journal article on Feb. 17, about one of the world's largest garbage dumps, at the edge of Mexico City, misidentified the type of waste that is used as an alternative fuel for cement kilns operated by Cemex, the giant Mexican cement maker. It is organic waste, not inorganic. A reader pointed out the error last week in an e-mail.

OASIS, Calif. -- Signs of once grandiose dreams dot the shoreline of the Salton Sea, dried up like the dead fish that bob ashore from time to time. This lake, the largest in California, was once supposed to be the Riviera of the West, a playground for stars like Frank Sinatra, Jerry Lewis and Desi Arnaz. But the Salton Sea, created by accident 40 miles south of Palm Springs, has been shrinking for decades now, while the saline content continues to rise -- it is roughly 50 percent saltier than the Pacific Ocean. Waterfront homes built more than a generation ago sit abandoned and boarded up, on a labyrinth of streets where only a couple of houses on each block are occupied.

GIULIANO--Samuel J.,of South Orange, NJ entered into eternal life on Thursday, July 26, 2012 surrounded by loving family, friends and clergy. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Sorrows Church, 217 Prospect St., So. Orange, on Tuesday, July 31, 2012 at 10:30am. Interment is in Gate of Heaven Cemetery, E. Hanover, NJ. Sam was the retired President and CEO of Title USA Insurance Co. He graduated from Seton Hall University in 1950 after serving in the US Army, and received his MBA from New York University in 1954. Sam was very active with NYU, Seton Hall University, the Archdiocese of Newark, Our Lady of Sorrows Parish, and the Village of South Orange. Sam was predeceased by his wife, Rosetta Iodice Giuliano, and his daughter Elizabeth. He is survived by three daughters, eight grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.

Drunken actors are not unknown in the theater world, but a lack of sobriety is not generally planned. The experimental Chocolate Factory excels in breaking with tradition, however, and so it is kicking off its fall season, which runs Sept. 13 through Jan. 12, with ''Hot Box,'' a project that requires its creator, the theater's founding artistic director, Brian Rogers, below, to become inebriated. ''A considerably drunk Mr. Rogers is slated to project real-time images of himself and another performer via a live video feed during the piece,'' a description says, ''creating a violently noisy and chaotic sense of disorder.'' The theater, which is in Long Island City, Queens, and which supports ''work that defies easy categorization,'' is also presenting ''Play By Ear,'' by the mime Rob List; ''There There'' by Kristen Kosmas, which is loosely about Chekhov and the actor Christopher Walken; and ''Ich, Kürbisgeist,'' by Big Dance Theater and Sibyl Kempson, which is described as ''an olde tyme agricultural revenge play for Halloween.'' The theater will also present projects by the dance and video artist Jillian Peña and the performance artist Aki Sasamoto. Most tickets are $15.

3:18 p.m. | Updated After a months-long stalemate over a bill to protect women from crimes of domestic violence, Speaker John A. Boehner on Monday named eight House negotiators to serve on a nonexistent conference committee, one that would be charged with bridging the divide between House Republicans and the Senate. In April, the Senate voted to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act, and it urged the House to move on the legislation.

Here are some of the athletes and teams in Tuesday's spotlight.(All times Eastern.) WOMEN'S GYMNASTICS The United States will look to Jordyn Wieber, left, to get past her disappointment in not making the all-around final as the Americans pursue their first Olympic team gold since 1996. The team's depth cost Wieber a spot in the allaround competition, but it will be the Americans' greatest asset in the team competition. Wieber led the United States to a dominant performance at the world championships last year, and Gabby Douglas and Aly Raisman add more versatile talent that few teams can match. Russia -- with Victoria Komova, who scored the most points in qualification, and the former world champion Aliya Mustafina -- is the most formidable threat. nbcolympics.com, 11:30 a.m.; NBC, 8 p.m. (taped)

An art review on Friday about an exhibition at the George Adams Gallery in Manhattan referred incorrectly to some of the portraits by Alfred Leslie on display. They are graphite pencil on paper, not charcoal on paper.

HOUSTON -- It may be the armadillo days of summer in Texas, but a runoff vote on Tuesday for the Republican Senate nomination has jolted the party establishment here and around the country as a magnetic Tea-Party conservative with no elective experience gains momentum against the chosen candidate of Gov. Rick Perry. Only a few months ago the longtime lieutenant governor, David Dewhurst, 66, seemed all but certain to win the nomination, which in Republican-dominated Texas is tantamount to winning the seat being vacated in November by Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison.

HSBC'S WOES Profit at HSBC Holdings dropped nearly 9 percent in the first half of the year, as the big bank dealt with the fallout from a money-laundering investigation and a settlement over selling inappropriate financial products. ''I very much regret HSBC's past failures and I apologize for them. Our controls should have been stronger and more effective,'' the British bank's chief executive, Stuart Gulliver, above, said. On Monday, HSBC said that it had set aside $700 million to cover the potential fines, settlements and other expenses related to a money-laundering inquiry in the United States. NEIL GOUGH

India's electrical grid suffered a major systemic failure early Monday morning, affecting at least six northern states and the capital, and an estimated 360 million people. By late afternoon, service was about 75 percent restored across the region. Power failures are common in India, but officials said Monday's blackout was the worst in a decade. The Ministry of Power was investigating the cause, but officials suggested that part of the problem was probably excessive demand during the torrid summer. ''This is a one-off situation,'' said Ajai Nirula, the chief operating officer of North Delhi Power Limited, which distributes power to nearly 1.2 million people in the region. ''Everyone was surprised.''

8:30 P.M. (TV5Monde) LA FLEUR DU MAL (THE FLOWER OF EVIL) (2003) A privileged provincial French family deals with murder, sexual complications, betrayal and guilt in this drama from Claude Chabrol. Nathalie Baye stars as Anne, a would-be politician whose stepson, François (Benoît Magimel), returns home from Chicago at a critical point in her mayoral run. Mélanie Doutey plays his beautiful stepsister, to whom he is oddly drawn. Bernard Le Coq, above with Ms. Baye, is Anne's philandering second husband (and first cousin), into whose arms she was thrown when their first spouses were killed in a car crash. Mr. Chabrol's son Thomas plays Anne's soft-spoken, ambitious and sinister assistant. And Suzanne Flon is Tante Line, the gentle and generous aunt acquitted of the murder of her father, a collaborator during the German occupation, several decades earlier -- information that surfaces in an anonymous smear campaign against Anne. ''The movie inevitably drops what the director may think of as a pearl: 'The Flower of Evil' draws off all that is good in the earth, leaving nothing behind but remorse,'' Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. ''The film often seems trapped in barren soil, too, though Ms. Flon's delicately nuanced misery blooms in the dust.'' 5 P.M. (Fox Movie Channel) JARHEAD (2005) Jake Gyllenhaal, right, portrays Swoff, the alter ego of Anthony Swofford, whose memoir about his time in the Marines inspired this drama from Sam Mendes about the terror and thrill of serving in the Persian Gulf war of 1991 -- not to mention the tedium and boredom. ''Are we ever going to kill anyone?'' a young Marine asks toward the movie's end. Peter Sarsgaard plays Troy, a tightly wound Midwesterner who becomes Swoff's shooting partner and closest friend. ''It is a movie that walks up to some of the most urgent and painful issues of our present circumstance, clears its throat loudly and, with occasional flourishes of impressive rhetoric, says nothing,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times.

FAUST--Irvin, 88, of New York city, died on July 24 succumbing to pneumonia after a long illness. After college he earned two Master's degrees and a Ph.D. He was a teacher, then a counselor; his last job was Director of Guidance at Garden City Long Island. A veteran of World War II, he served in Patton's Army with units that liberated concentration camps. Later he served with the occupation forces in Japan. His sole survivor is his wife of 55 years, Jean Satterthwaite Faust. Much beloved by many friends and professional associates, he will be greatly missed.

Physicists are rarely wealthy or famous, but a new prize rewarding research at the field's cutting edges has made nine of them instant multimillionaires. The nine are recipients of the Fundamental Physics Prize, established by Yuri Milner, a Russian physics student who dropped out of graduate school in 1989 and later earned billions investing in Internet companies like Facebook and Groupon.

A publishing industry that is notoriously ill-equipped to root out fraud. A magazine whose famed fact-checking department is geared toward print, not the Web. And a lucrative lecture circuit that rewards snappy, semi-scientific pronouncements, smoothly delivered to a corporate audience. All contributed to the rise of Jonah Lehrer, the 31-year-old author, speaker and staff writer for The New Yorker, who then executed one of the most bewildering recent journalistic frauds, one that on Monday cost him his prestigious post at the magazine and his status as one of the most promising, visible and well-paid writers in the business.

CUNNEEN--Joseph, died Sunday July 29, age 89. With his wife, Sally, he co-founded Cross Currents magazine, serving as Coeditor for 48 years. Long a film critic for the National Catholic Reporter he wrote studies of filmmakers Bresson and Rohmer, and translations of the novels of Jean Sulivan. A graduate of Xavier High School and Holy Cross College, he served in the 101st Combat Engineers in WW II. After graduate studies at Catholic U., he taught for decades at Mercy College. He lost his beloved wife of 60 years, Sally McDevitt Cunneen in 2009 and his son John in 1969 but is survived by sons, Michael, Peter, and Paul and grandson, Sean. A wake will be held at Hannemann Funeral Home, Nyack, on Wednesday 2-4:00 and 7-9:00pm. Mass will be held Thursday at 10:00am, St. Ann's Church, Nyack.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority gave Apple an unfair advantage to place one of its retail stores in Grand Central Terminal by creating a bidding process that made it nearly impossible for anyone but Apple to be awarded the space, according to a report the New York State comptroller's office released on Monday. The report said the authority began discussions with Apple about the space more than two years before issuing a request for proposals, and agreed to specific terms with the previous tenant that afforded Apple an unfair advantage.

CARMEN--Captain Marvin, DDS, born September 10, 1919, died July 28, 2012. He was a graduate of Marquette University and served 43 years in the USN Dental Corps, from World War II through Vietnam, where he was Chief of Dental Service on the hospital ship Sanctuary. He retired from the Navy in 1981 and embarked on a second career as a Professor of Dentistry at New York University, where he taught for over 25 years. He passed away peacefully at home surrounded by loved ones. He is survived by wife Claire, two stepchildren, five grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. The funeral is Monday, July 30, 2012 at 9:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, New York City; interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery, Long Island. Memorial contributions may be made to Central Synagogue in Dr. Carmen's name.

''Every four years, the summer Olympics get people excited to exercise,'' says Glenn Gaesser, a professor and director of the Healthy Lifestyles Research Center at Arizona State University, who oversaw a new study about exercise and high blood pressure that was inspired in part by the coming games in London. The streets and gyms fill with people who, fueled by stories of Olympic success, ''run or work out for an hour or more,'' Dr. Gaesser says. But ''within a few weeks, most people have quit'' and resumed their sedentary lives. ''We wanted to see if there were approaches to exercise that would fit more easily into people's lifestyles, but still be effective'' in terms of improving health, he says.
THE FACTS In the world of alternative medicine, milk thistle is the treatment of choice for liver disease, particularly chronic infection with hepatitis C.

Every year, hundreds of thousands of older Americans get on a treadmill in a doctor's office and walk or jog as an electrocardiogram monitors their heart function. But a growing number of medical authorities would like to make routine screening using the procedure, known as the treadmill or exercise stress test, largely a thing of the past. On Monday, an expert government panel, the United States Preventive Services Task Force, joined the call by recommending against routine testing with electrocardiograms, or EKGs, in people who have no known risk factors or symptoms of heart disease, like shortness of breath or chest pains.

A news analysis article on Thursday about the history of violent films from Warner Brothers, the maker of the new Batman movie, ''The Dark Knight Rises,'' referred incompletely to the studio's series of ''Lethal Weapon'' films. The fifth in the series has not been released; it is in development with a projected release date in 2015.

BUCHHEIT--Helen M. Wheeler. Died on July 27, 2012 in Reno, Nevada. Born on August 4, 1919 in Moingona, Iowa, Helen graduated from the Mercy Hospital School of Nursing in Des Moines and received her RN. A veteran of WWII, she enlisted in the Army Nurse Corps and served from 1942 to 1946 in the Pacific theater in New Guinea and the Philippines, as well as on the Hospital Ship U.S.S. Mercy. After the war, she received her B.S. Degree from Dusquesne University and her M.S. Degree from the University of Pittsburgh. Education was a passion and, for 32 years, Helen served in public school systems as a teacher and as a children's librarian. She was predeceased by her husband of 58 years, Charles R. Buchheit, Jr. and is survived by her sons, Carl and Lee. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Fisher House Foundation, www.fisherhouse.org.

Despite its many delights, summer also brings its fair share of pestilence. One, called babesiosis, has only recently been widely recognized as a potentially serious outdoor hazard. According to a very detailed study conducted on Block Island, R.I., it could eventually rival Lyme disease as the most common tick-borne ailment in the United States. But with reasonable precautions, neither babesiosis nor Lyme should keep you from enjoying a romp in the grass or hike in the woods.

LONDON -- Practically every sport ever played has at one point been compared to chess, and the more violent the sport -- football, boxing -- the more insistent the comparisons. In the strictest sense, this is absurd. If you're playing chess and somebody ends up lying on the floor unconscious, you're doing it very wrong. But in the most general sense, boxing and other fighting sports are like chess in that all of the strategizing or maneuvering is directed toward solving a simple and straightforward problem, to wit, this person in front of me is not lying flat on his back; how shall I go about fixing that?

An article on June 5 about the first mention of leukemia in The New York Times described the disease's discovery imprecisely. Rudolf Virchow, who described the condition in 1845, was among the first to do so, and he gave it its name, in 1847 -- but he was not the first to describe it. (John Hughes Bennett, a Scottish doctor, and Alfred Francois Donne, a French doctor, published studies of the condition earlier, but did not identify it as a new pathological entity, rather than a symptom of another.) This correction was delayed because an e-mail from a reader pointing out the error went astray at The Times.

SAN FRANCISCO - Jason Bay will readily tell you that his professional struggles have eaten at his spirit, that his near-perpetual slump has eroded his pride. But, as far as he is concerned, it is his job to ensure this does not affect his teammates. As Bay has further descended into what has amounted to a multiyear blackout - he entered the Mets' four-game series against the San Francisco Giants batting .159 and mired in a 0 for 22 skid - the way he is perceived by his colleagues, many of them young players, has become all the more important to him.

Hans Zimmer, who composed the score for ''The Dark Knight Rises,'' has written another song -- this one dedicated to the victims of the movie theater shooting in Aurora, Colo., The Associated Press reported. Mr. Zimmer, who announced that he recorded the song in London in the days after the killings, posted the song, ''Aurora,'' on his Facebook page on Friday, saying it ''is dedicated to those who lost their lives and were affected by the tragedy.'' The eight-and-a-half-minute song is selling for donations from 10 cents to $2,500 on iTunes and Moontoast. All the proceeds, Mr. Zimmer said, are being donated to the Aurora Victim Relief organization.

Advice to New York City employees who wish to stay employed: Do not ask a welfare recipient to watch your beloved pet ferret. A caseworker at the city's Human Resources Administration was fired after doing just that, the city's Conflict of Interest Board said on Tuesday, the latest episode in a long line of municipal controversy wrought by the musky yet misunderstood mammal.

LONDON -- ''Sorry, mate,'' Peter Waterfield said to Tom Daley after they had hoisted themselves out of the pool on Monday with the home-crowd roars already turning into murmurs. It was the soundtrack of an Olympic moment turning sour, and the scores that flashed on the electronic scoreboard at Aquatics Center soon provided confirmation.

LONDON -- Another athlete has been thrown out of the Olympics for making disparaging remarks on Twitter. On Monday, the Swiss Olympic delegation said it had sent home Michel Morganella, a soccer player, for making insulting remarks about South Koreans after the South Korean soccer team beat the Swiss, 2-1, on Sunday. In a statement, Gian Gilli, the head of the Swiss Olympic delegation, said that Morganella, 23, ''said something insulting and discriminatory'' about the South Korean team. ''We condemn these remarks,'' which, he said, ''contradict the Olympic Charter.''

There's ''Brooklyn's Finest,'' ''Brooklyn Rules'' and ''Brooklyn Lobster,'' and later this week there is the Art of Brooklyn Film Festival, which runs Aug. 4 to 12 at St. Francis College in Brooklyn Heights and features 45 premieres that all have links to that borough, New York City's most populous. The independent movies include a Turkish film about Brooklyn's diversity, a documentary about a Hasidic rapper from Brooklyn and a short by a Brooklyn-born animator. ''Major events mostly cluster around only a few north Brooklyn neighborhoods,'' said Joseph Shahidi, the festival's executive director. ''Our innovation is simple: We include everyone, from Boerum Hill to Bergen Beach, Fort Greene to Flatlands.'' The festival begins with a free screening of ''Out for Justice,'' a 1991 film with Steven Seagal, above -- set in Brooklyn, of course -- and a Seagal look-alike contest at Founders Hall Theater.

The Public Theater has added a family-friendly performance of ''Into the Woods,'' James Lapine and Stephen Sondheim's musical take on classic fairy tales, on Aug. 22 at the Delacorte Theater. The free one-act matinee, part of Shakespeare in the Park, is intended ''to engage younger audiences and to serve families unable to attend evening performances,'' the Public said. Most of the tickets will be distributed through an online lottery, starting Aug. 15 at 4 p.m. A limited number of standby tickets will be given out the day of the performance. ''The Public wants to make great theater accessible to all, and young people, with their parents, deserve an invitation to be a part of the story,'' said the theater's artistic director, Oskar Eustis. ''This will be a great and rare opportunity. One we hope is just a beginning.'' The regular two-act evening performance of Aug. 22 will take place as scheduled, though ticket distribution will begin that day at noon instead of 1 p.m.

O'NEIL--C. Roderick. A former banker, investment manager, and co-founder of Riverfront Recapture in Hartford, CT, died July 28 at Greenwich Hospital in Greenwich, CT. He was 81 and lived in Mt. Kisco, NY. Mr. O'Neil died of complications related to ALS. In business, Mr. O'Neil led the trust department for the Manufacturers Hanover Bank before moving to Hartford to serve as Chairman of the Finance Committee and Board Member of The Travelers Companies. He left that position in 1984 to launch a private investment firm in partnership with Alan Greenspan, Greenspan O'Neil Inc. In 1986, he became chairman of the financial consulting company, O'Neil Associates. Rory O'Neil served on a wide range of corporate and nonprofit boards, including Beckman Coulter, AMBAC, Colt Manufacturing, Fort Dearborn Income Securities, Brinson Trust Co., Memorial Drive Trust, and the California Institute of the Arts. He was a Chartered Financial Analyst and was trustee and past president of the Institute of Chartered Financial Analysts. He chaired the State of Connecticut Investment Advisory Committee from 1988-91 and he served for two decades on the Investment Committee of the Hartford Foundation for Public Giving. He was a director of the Corporation for Independent Living in Hartford and director (1982-93) and past chairman of the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation. But, in many ways, his proudest achievement was the role he played in the restoration of the Connecticut River waterfront in Hartford. Now, more than three-quarter of a million people each year visit the chain of parks, walkways and boathouses created by Riverfront Recapture, which The Hartford Courant called "one of the state's most successful non-profits." Mr. O'Neil maintained his family home in Mt. Kisco, NY, with his wife, Nancy. However, when he joined Travelers in 1977, he and his wife became pioneers in the revitalization of downtown Hartford and were active in the restoration of a number of historic properties, including 20 Charter Oak Place. In 1985 the O'Neils restored Simsbury 1820 House in Simsbury, CT, and were owners until 1997. Mr. O'Neil was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. He married Nancy Galante in 1950. Together, they had six children: Brian, Sarah, Tim, Kevin, John and Anne. In addition to his wife and children, he is survived by 13 grandchildren and his brothers, Terry and Tom. Mr. O'Neil was born on January 26, 1931 in Amityville, Long Island, NY. He graduated from Princeton University in 1953 and received his MBA from the University of Chicago GSB in 1957. Among his hobbies, he was an avid tennis player and also a licensed pilot. Visitation will be at Beecher Funeral Home, 418 Bedford Road, Pleasantville, NY on Tuesday, July 31 from 5pm until 9pm and a Memorial Service will take place at 11:30am on Wednesday, August 1, at the Bedford Historical Hall at 608 Old Post Road, Bedford, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Riverfront Recapture in Hartford, CT, or to The Eleanor and Lou Gehrig MDA/ALS Multidisciplinary Care Center at Columbia University in New York City.

MEREL--Frances, at 89. Died on July 27, in Delray Beach, Florida. She will be greatly missed by her loving husband, children, grandchildren, nieces, nephews and the many relatives, friends and clients that got to know her over her long and successful career as an interior designer. Funeral service will be at 11am on Wednesday, August 1 at The "Parkside" 98-60 Queens Blvd, Rego Park, NY.
Question: What would you do if you had $117 billion? That's the challenge facing Tim Cook, Apple's chief, whose company's cash hoard keeps growing - by about $1 billion a week.

Some American Internet companies may be unpopular with investors these days, but a Chinese one is finding plenty of takers. The Alibaba Group, a Chinese e-commerce giant, is close to completing a more than $8 billion round of financing that will value it at as much as $43 billion in equity, according to two people briefed on the matter. Alibaba plans to use the bulk of that new money to buy back a 20 percent stake in itself from Yahoo for $7.1 billion. Yahoo owns 40 percent of Alibaba.

The two Hobbit movies will become three -- so said Peter Jackson, their director, Monday morning in a posting on his Facebook page. ''It has been an unexpected journey indeed, and in the words of Professor Tolkien himself, 'a tale that grew in the telling,' '' wrote Mr. Jackson, right, who said he would use the three-movie format to ''tell more of the tale.'' ''The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey,'' the first of what will now be three films based on ''The Hobbit,'' by J. R. R. Tolkien, remains set for release by Warner Brothers and its New Line Cinema unit, along with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, on Dec. 14. The second film is scheduled for release in December 2013. The third can be expected in the summer of 2014, Warner said in a statement. In an appearance this month at the Comic-Con International fan convention Mr. Jackson explained that some material from the related ''Lord of the Rings'' cycle, and a small bit of invention that added a stronger feminine presence to Tolkien's Hobbit story, had expanded its cinematic potential.

The older a woman is when she gives birth, the lower her risk for endometrial cancer, a new study reports. A large team of researchers, led by V. Wendy Setiawan, an assistant professor of preventive medicine at the University of Southern California, pooled data from 17 studies that included 8,671 cases of endometrial cancer and 16,562 controls. After adjusting for known risks, the researchers found that women who had their last babies after age 40 had a 44 percent reduced risk of endometrial cancer, compared with women who had their babies before age 25.

GROSSMAN--Arlene Petroff. It is with the most profound sense of loss that I must report the passing of my wife, my absolute love, and my dearest friend, on July 28, 2012 in Gt. Barrington, MA. Arlene succumbed to the ravages of metastasized breast cancer despite the determined and extraordinary medical care she received at Memorial Sloan Kettering. She is survived by her loving husband, Ed, her brother Martin and his wife Marsha, numerous cousins and many devoted friends. Born in New York City, February 2, 1940 to Max and Lillian Petroff. Attended PS 6, Calhoun, and earned a BA from NYU. Arlene worked in magazine editorial, then at JC Penney as Director of Home Fashion and as President of In Detail, before joining her husband's wholesale business. Loved by all who knew you, you were my life and my shining light. My world is now much darker. Thank you Arlene for over 43 years of love and devotion. Please know that you are my love for all eternity. Services will be Thursday, August 2nd, at 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue followed by entombment at the Sanctuary of Abraham & Sarah at Cedar Park Cemetery, NJ. Donations to honor Arlene can be made to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation. Edmund A. Grossman

An article on Monday about Stu Loeser, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's press secretary, who is stepping down to form his own communications company, quoted incorrectly in some copies from comments by the mayor. The mayor said, ''I'm convinced that Stu Loeser has kept me out of more trouble than his gotten me out of,'' not ''than he's gotten me into.''

Soldiers in World War II stuck the pinups on their lockers while female fans swooned over the photos of Frank Sinatra and Gary Cooper. Now Movie Star News, the company that sold classic prints of celebrities, has sold its entire collection of Hollywood photographs, The Associated Press reported. It will be auctioned off later. Today pictures of stars can be downloaded in a heartbeat but in 1939, when Irving Klaw started the business from his Manhattan bookstore, he discovered a huge market for studio photographs. Mr. Klaw essentially invented the pinup and turned the model Bettie Page into the genre's queen with images of her acting out bondage and sadomasochistic themes. ''He noticed that kids were tearing out the pictures of the movie stars, so he decided to sell their pictures rather than the books,'' said Ira Kramer, above, who took over the business from his mother and his uncle, Mr. Klaw. Stuart Scheinman, co-owner of Entertainment Collectibles in Las Vegas, bought the collection, which consists primarily of images made between 1939 and '79. There are original prints and negatives of Marlon Brando, Bette Davis and the Three Stooges as well as scenes from ''The Godfather,'' ''Citizen Kane'' and ''Gone With the Wind.'' He said that the lot, which is being handled by Guernsey's auction house, could be worth as much as $150 million.

MUNK--Harriet. Until that final second, Mrs. Harriet Zimmerman Munk never stopped loving life and the wonderful and caring people in her life. Predeceased by her cherished Parents, Nathan and Bertha Zimmerman, brothers, Sidney and Samuel Zimmerman and her devoted late-husband, Melvin Munk. She leaves in life, her sons, Norman, Gary and Jeffrey daughters-in-law, Marilyn and Susan, grandchildren, David and Marissa Munk and their partners, Jessica and Justin and her, great-granddaughter, Kiera Lee Munk. May her memory be for a blessing. Service will be on Wednesday, August 1, 10am at Riverside Memorial Chapel 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY 10552. Interment to follow at Beth Israel Cemetery in Woodbridge, NJ.

Taking aspirin may reduce the chances of developing Barrett's esophagus, the leading risk factor for esophageal cancer, researchers say. In Barrett's esophagus, tissue that lines the esophagus is replaced with tissue similar to the lining of the intestines. The condition, commonly found in people with acid reflux, affects about 1 percent of American adults.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Thursday about an online petition demanding curatorial changes at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles referred incompletely to the position of senior curator there. While the report noted that one senior curator, Philipp Kaiser, who has now left the museum, will become director of the Museum Ludwig in Cologne, Germany, Alma Ruiz remains as a senior curator.

There are good reasons for college athletes to get in shape before the season, but a study suggests that injury prevention is not one of them. Canadian researchers evaluated 86 male and female hockey, volleyball and basketball players for endurance, body strength and flexibility. The scientists also measured the time each participant spent in practice and competition, and they collected information on the athletes' injuries.

GUTTMAN--Abraham, Beloved Father of Robert (Joan) Guttman, Deborah Davis and Ann (Eric Ratner) Guttman and the late Peter Guttman. Cherished grand- father of Isabelle, Marisol, Sandy, Martin, Lillian, Michael and Benjamin. Devoted brother of the late Harry and Louis Guttman. Dear uncle, cousin and friend to many. Services Wednesday 2PM at Emanuel Congregation, 5959 N. Sheridan Rd., Chicago, IL 60660. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, remembrances to the Jewish United Fund would be appreciated. Service by Mitzvah Memorial Funerals, (630) Mitzvah (648-9824) or www.MITZVAHFUNERALS. com

Miller--Judith Martin, 93, died on July 28. A brilliant actress, director modern dancer, and a founder of The Paper Bag Players. She gave delight to children everywhere, but mostly to her daughter Daisy and her late husband Sol. She is survived by Daisy Miller, Seth Armus and her grand- children Benjamin and Lilah.

An article on July 18 about Gloria Steinem's campaign to urge the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, to allow a vote on a bill that would require businesses to give their employees paid sick leave referred incompletely to the legislation. While the proposed bill would require most businesses with five or more employees to provide up to five days of paid sick leave a year, it would also require that those with 20 or more workers provide each with up to nine paid sick days. (Businesses with fewer than five workers would have to allow up to five days of unpaid sick leave.)

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about changes in New York City over the past several years that have made it more difficult for blind pedestrians to negotiate its streets misstated the portion of Second Avenue where subway construction in taking place. It is on the Upper East Side, not in Lower Manhattan.

GROSSMAN--Arlene Petroff. The Rockefeller University notes with sadness the passing of our dear friend Arlene Grossman. With her beloved husband, Ed, Arlene championed and supported pioneering biomedical research initiatives, with the goal of improving opportunities for the prevention and treatment of cancer and other diseases. At Rockefeller, we are especially grateful to Arlene and Ed for their outstanding commitment to cancer research under the direction of Dr. Sohail Tavazoie and for establishing the Edmund A. and Arlene Grossman Clinical Scholarship at the University. Arlene was a woman of great charm, warmth, and generosity, whose visionary philanthropy and humanitarianism will live on through her many acts of kindness. Our hearts go out to Ed and to everyone whose life she touched. Russell L. Carson, Chair David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Sohail Tavazoie, Leon Hess Assistant Professor

RASHBAUM--Harold (Buddy), beloved husband of Charlotte and devoted father to Dory and Jody and grandfather to Zoe, Eileen and Alex passed away July 27th, 2012. Buddy was a WWII veteran and bombardier. He worked in the textile industry and then co owned a company with his brother-n-law for many years. He passed away peacefully in his home. He will be deeply missed by his family and friends.
