Older people who have eye surgery to remove cataracts and improve their vision also significantly reduce their risk of breaking a hip in a fall, with the sickest among them and those in their early 80s experiencing nearly 30 percent fewer hip fractures in the first year, a large study reports. The study adds to findings from earlier papers indicating that the benefits of cataract surgery, a relatively safe outpatient procedure with a high success rate, may significantly enhance the quality of life for the elderly, improving sleep, enabling them to be more engaged and mentally alert and curbing depression.

NAMROW--James Arnold, 60, died peacefully at home after a long, brave fight with cancer. Jim graduated from Beloit College and from Columbia University where he received his doctorate in American History. Jim taught at Columbia University and John Jay College. He is the beloved husband of Linda and brother of Andy, Tony and Laurel. Services will be held on August 1 at noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel in Manhattan at 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

MARTIN--Judith. We will miss Judy but her creativity, intelligence, and her child-like sense of fun and adventure will inspire us as we continue her work of bringing theater to the children of New York City and the world. Ted, Laura, Amy, Kevin, John, Jon, and Jim, The Paper Bag Players

Julián Castro, the Democratic mayor of San Antonio, will deliver the keynote speech at his party's national convention in September, taking the role that vaulted Barack Obama to national prominence eight years ago. Mr. Castro will become the first Hispanic American chosen for the high-profile speaking slot at a time when President Obama is counting on Latinos to help him win a second term in the White House.

What? A new cola in a 24-ounce bottle? Does Mayor Bloomberg know about this?Q Kola, the latest in a Brooklyn-made line of soft drinks that includes a nicely bitter tonic water and a spicy ginger ale, comes in a giant bottle and eight-ounce single servings. It lacks the sweetness and metallic taste of mass-market brands.

MUMBAI, India -- A leading Indian television network has sued the Nielsen Company, accusing its Indian joint venture of providing ''false, fabricated and manipulated data'' on TV ratings for almost a decade. The Indian network, New Delhi Television, or NDTV, says the manipulated data cost it nearly a billion dollars in advertising revenue, and the suit is seeking several billion dollars in damages.

An article on Friday about an autopsy report that revealed that Ray Easterling, the former Atlanta Falcons safety who committed suicide in April, had a degenerative brain disease misstated, in some editions, the connection his wife, Mary Ann, has to a lawsuit against the National Football League. She is among the more than 3,000 plaintiffs; she is not a defendant.

KLUTZNICK--Samuel John, Passed away peacefully on July 17th in a room filled with family and friends in Jackson Hole, WY. Born on August 4, 1948 in Chicago, he was the youngest son of Philip and Ethel Klutznick. Sam graduated from New York University. He had a life-long interest and involvement theater. He was active with the Actor's Studio and a member of the Dramatists Guild of America. Sam had an incredible intellect and was an entrepreneur. He was a writer, a real estate partner with his family and did private investment and finance. Sam lived in Paris and Jackson Hole, Wyoming, and he spent significant time in New York and London. He leaves behind his many friends and family members in Jackson Hole, Paris, Chicago, New York and around the world. He is survived by his siblings, Bettylu (Paul) Saltzman, Thomas Klutznick, James (Judy) Klutznick, Robert (Dodi) Klutznick and his nieces and nephews, Amy, David, Peter, and Jane Saltzman, Karen, John, Daniel and Katherine Klutznick, Barri, Marc and Kimberly Klutznick, Jennifer Beard, Lauren Hassan and Nathan Klutznick. A private graveside service was held in Chicago.

Two weeks after the actor and comedian Fred Willard was arrested in Hollywood on a charge of lewd conduct at an adult movie theater, ABC is pulling the last two new episodes of his improv series ''Trust Us With Your Life.'' Reruns of ''Wipeout'' will replace the Tuesday show hosted by Mr. Willard. The 72-year-old actor previously lost his job as narrator of a new PBS series, ''Market Warriors,'' which pits professional antiques pickers in a competition to spot the best bargain.

A federal jury on Tuesday cleared a Citigroup executive of wrongdoing in connection with the bank's sale of risky mortgage-related investments at the peak of the housing boom, dealing a blow to the government's effort to hold Wall Street executives accountable for their conduct during the financial crisis. The Securities and Exchange Commission had accused Brian Stoker, a former midlevel Citigroup executive, with negligence related to his role in creating exotic mortgage securities known as collateralized debt obligations, or C.D.O.'s. In a lawsuit filed last October, the government said that Mr. Stoker, who prepared sales materials for C.D.O.'s, knew or should have known that he was misleading investors by not disclosing that Citigroup helped select the underlying mortgage securities in the C.D.O. and then placed a large bet against it.

SAN FRANCISCO -- As baseball's nonwaiver trade deadline approached Tuesday afternoon, Sandy Alderson took stock of his options, probably took one more glance at the standings and decided that the Mets' best course of action was to do nothing. For Alderson, who in his two seasons as the Mets' general manager has always had one foot in the future, acquiring a player at the expense of a valued prospect in the farm system had been out of the question all along.

STEPHENSON--Dr Hugh E. Jr. MD, 90, of Columbia, Missouri, passed away July 26, 2012. Pioneering heart surgeon, higher education supporter and civic leader, Stephenson was a founding father of the University of Missouri School of Medicine. He was chief surgery resident at New York University's Bellevue Hospital from 1950-1953 and is credited with developing the first mobile cardiac resuscitation unit. See http://medicine.missouri.edu/stephenson/ Leave online tributes at wwwmemorialfuneral homeandcemetery.com

The City Room column on Tuesday, about the excitement among Malaysian immigrants at the CP Badminton Club at College Point, Queens, about an Olympic competitor, Lee Chong Wei of Malaysia, referred incorrectly to him at several points. Lee is his surname, and therefore he is Mr. Lee, not Mr. Chong Wei.

LONDON - A female judo athlete from Saudi Arabia will be allowed to compete wearing a head scarf after an agreement was reached between the sport's governing body and Saudi Arabia's Olympic officials, according to the International Olympic Committee. Saudi Arabia has women competing at the Olympic Games for the first time - Sarah Attar, who will run the 800 meters, and Wodjan Ali Seraj Abdulrahim Shahrkhani, the judoka. The athletes are expected to follow Saudi Arabia's strict Islamic traditions, which include head coverings for women.

The Philadelphia Orchestra has stepped into the sunlight, announcing on Tuesday that it formally emerged from operating under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code. The development, which happened according to schedule, comes after a little more than a year of operating under the cloud of bankruptcy protection. No major American orchestra, amid periodic waves of economic hardship in the symphonic world, had taken the measure before. Orchestra officials said the filing, on April 16, 2011, was necessary to deal with a high pension burden and mounting losses from a drop in donations and ticket sales. ''There is much critical diligence and fiscal capitalization to be achieved for the orchestra,'' its president and chief executive, Allison Vulgamore said in a prepared statement, adding, ''and we embrace this new era - and our audiences - with gratitude and dedication.'' The orchestra is now playing at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center and opens its main season at Verizon Hall on Oct. 18.

The Romney campaign said Tuesday that it would reveal its vice-presidential pick not by e-mail, text message or online video, but through a first-of-its kind mobile phone app called ''Mitt's VP.'' All anyone has to do is download the app and make sure the smartphone accepts incoming third-party messages. Whenever the Romney campaign decides to push the button, phones across the United States should buzz with the news. Already, tens of thousands of people had downloaded it on Tuesday, the campaign said.

KALINER--Howard. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member and Past President, Howard Kaliner. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved family. Stuart Albrecht, President H. Lawrence Fein, Secretary

We extend our heartfelt condolences to Seymour's son, Robert, and the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

HUTCHINGS--Christine H.,of Juno Beach, FL. died on July 29, 2012 at Glen Cove, NY. Wife of Robert, mother of Robert Jr., William and Christine, grandmother of four. Sister of Winston Hagen and Audrey Patterson. A Memorial Sevice at St. John's Episcopal Church, Lattingtown, NY at 11am on Monday, August 6th. Contributions may be made to the charity of one's choice.

The health club chain 24 Hour Fitness is for sale, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday. Forstmann Little, the private equity firm that owns 24 Hour Fitness, has hired Goldman Sachs to run the auction process, these people said. Goldman will soon begin soliciting interest from potential buyers, a group that includes other fitness chains and private equity firms.

SILVER SPRING, Md. -- Faced with diminishing membership and revenues, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is selling the site of its accredited institution of higher learning, the National Labor College, on 47 prime acres ripe for development just off the Capital Beltway here. The campus, which has been owned by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. for about 40 years, is 10 miles from the White House and a mile from the Food and Drug Administration, which recently consolidated its offices from 27 separate buildings elsewhere in Montgomery County.

LONDON -- When Tunisia mounted a challenge, however brief, to the United States national team on Tuesday, it registered as breaking news. While no international basketball experts expected Tunisia to contend with the Americans, most expected that it would never lead.

FAUST--Irvin, 88, of New York city, died on July 24 succumbing to pneumonia after a long illness. After college he earned two Master's degrees and a Ph.D. He was a teacher, then a counselor; his last job was Director of Guidance at Garden City Long Island. A veteran of World War II, he served in Patton's Army with units that liberated concentration camps. Later he served with the occupation forces in Japan. His sole survivor is his wife of 55 years, Jean Satterthwaite Faust. Much beloved by many friends and professional associates, he will be greatly missed.

VILLANI--Frank J.,85 of River Vale, NJ passed away on July 31, 2012. He was the owner of Columbus Circle Liquors, New York City, NY until he retired in 2007 and was a member of the NY Liquor Retailer's Alliance. A complete obituary and all service information can be obtained at the Becker Funeral Home website, www.becker-funeralhome.com. Becker Funeral Home, Westwood, NJ is in charges of the services.
WEISMAN--Hermine, on July 29th. Beloved mother of Bradley and Annie Schreiber. Loving and devoted grandmother of Louis and Jared.

Jeff Otah, the Jets' presumptive solution at right tackle who was acquired in a trade last week, was returned to the Carolina Panthers after failing a second physical exam. Although General Manager Mike Tannenbaum said the incumbent Wayne Hunter had the ''inside track'' on the starting job, he was not as effusive about Hunter as some members of the coaching staff. More coverage at nytimes.com/fifthdown. The N.F.L. suspended Giants safety Tyler Sash for four games for violating its policy on performance-enhancing substances. Sash, a sixth-round draft pick last year, said he took Adderall in March, under a doctor's care, to help with anxiety. More coverage at nytimes.com/fifthdown. TIM ROHAN

Leave the barbecuing on Fridays and Saturdays to James Mallios and his executive chef, Nilton Borges Jr., at Amali, a Mediterranean restaurant a few blocks from Central Park on the East Side. On an outdoor recessed terrace area in front of the restaurant, they have started grilling whole lambs, pigs and other large cuts of meat like pork shoulder, all of it locally raised, on spits over hardwood charcoal.

6:30 P.M. (HBO2) STARDUST MEMORIES (1980) In this Fellini-esque comedy from Woody Allen, a director (Mr. Allen, above with Jessica Harper) faces an existential crisis when he attends a festival of his films and recounts his life and the loves (Charlotte Rampling, Ms. Harper and Marie-Christine Barrault) who inspired his work. ''As photographed by Gordon Willis and played by a cast of excellent though muted principals, 'Stardust Memories' is starkly handsome and imbued with a very special bravado,'' Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. ''This isn't Mr. Allen's most successful film -- 'Annie Hall' was that. It isn't his most earnest experiment -- 'Interiors' was far more so. It isn't even his first brush with fatigue or uncertainty, since there were traces of these things in 'Manhattan.' But 'Stardust Memories' is his most provocative film thus far and perhaps his most revealing.'' 8 A.M. (USA) STATE OF PLAY (2009) Cal McAffrey (Russell Crowe) is a scruffy reporter for a Washington newspaper; Della Frye (Rachel McAdams) is its fresh-faced political-gossip blogger. Together they try to get at the truth behind the death of a researcher who worked for a congressman (Ben Affleck) who is digging up dirt on a mysterious securities contractor. The congressman happens to be Cal's college roommate and best friend. Was it really an accident? Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said this thriller, adapted from the 2003 television series on BBC, ''is both shallower and muddier than its cleareyed source.'' In ''The Interpreter'' (2005), at 10:30, Nicole Kidman portrays an idealistic United Nations interpreter who believes she has overheard a plot to assassinate a dictator (Earl Cameron). Sean Penn is a federal agent sent to protect her and to investigate. ''This kind of movie, stuffed with intimations of faraway strife and people in suits talking frantically on cellphones and walkie-talkies, is conventionally described as a political thriller, but 'The Interpreter' is as apolitical as it is unthrilling,'' Mr. Scott wrote about this film from Sydney Pollack. Still, he said, the United Nations building in Manhattan ''is beautifully shot, both from without and within.''

James D. Watkins, a Navy admiral during the cold war who was later enlisted in battles far from the sea and submarines he knew best to be energy secretary under the elder President George Bush and the chairman of a presidential commission on AIDS, died on Thursday at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 85. His death was confirmed by his wife, Janet McDonough Watkins.

An article on Friday about strip clubs in Tampa, Fla., that are gearing up for increased business during the Republican National Convention misstated the estimated number of such businesses in the Tampa Bay area. There are about 30 such clubs, not 50. The article also included an invalid comparison between the number of strip clubs per capita in Tampa and Cincinnati. The Ohio city said it does not have strip clubs.

An article on Monday about countries across Latin America that are considering proposals to legalize various drugs, ranging from marijuana to cocaine to heroin, misstated the given name of the secretary general of Uruguay's National Committee on Drugs in some editions. He is Julio Calzada, not Jorge.

An article on July 23 about the Mets' 8-3 loss to the Dodgers the previous day misstated the length of the Mets' losing streak at the time. It was three games, not five. (The losing streak, which lasted six games, ended on Thursday.)

LONDON -- North of Olympic Park, an arena looms in the distance, its roof curved in an odd and yet unmistakable slope. The roof reaches its highest point at either end and sags in the middle, until it forms what architects call a truncated hyperbolic paraboloid. Translated into less technical terms, the arena, the Olympic Velodrome, is shaped like a Pringles potato chip.

HOME IMPROVEMENT BATTLE The American home improvement chain Lowe's said on Tuesday that it would continue to pursue a deal for Rona, a Canadian rival, after its $1.8 billion takeover offer was rejected. But the province of Quebec, where Rona has its headquarters, said that it would try to prevent any takeover. In a statement, Rona, which is led by Robert Dutton, above, said that it was approached by Lowe's on July 8 and that it formally rejected the offer on Thursday. IAN AUSTEN

MARTIN--Judith. We are saddened by the loss of Judith Martin. She was a visionary leader and pioneer in the field of children's theater. We are proud to have worked so closely with her as she brought joy to millions of children in New York City and around the world. Her legacy will shine on in the current Paper Bag Player ensemble as well as the influence she had on many others who saw her work. We will miss her vibrant, charming presence. The Board of The Paper Bag Players

Forty-eight years is almost enough time to hold a record. LARISA LATYNINA, a gymnast whose career record of 18 Olympic medals was surpassed by Michael Phelps, who won gold in swimming the anchor leg in the 4x200 freestyle relay. [A1]

An article on July 24 about one of the most coordinated and baldly sectarian series of attacks by Al Qaeda in Iraq in years, which left at least 100 people dead in a third of the country's 18 provinces, described incorrectly the location of Tuz Khurmato within Salahuddin Province, one of several locations across the country where car bombs had exploded in steady succession. It is in the northeastern -- not western -- portion of the province.

Cherished great-grandmother of Zack and Max Steinbaum, Eli and Benjamin Young and Zoe Anderman. Graveside Service 12:30 Thursday, August 2, 2012 at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Services by Gutterman and Musicant, Hackensack, NJ.

The architects Peter Samton and Diana Goldstein can tell you exactly where they were a half century ago, at 5 p.m. on Aug. 2, 1962: out on Seventh Avenue, tilting at windmills. Pennsylvania Station, the McKim, Mead & White masterpiece, was doomed. They knew it. But they weren't going to let it go down undefended. With Norval White, Jordan Gruzen, Elliott Willensky and others, they assembled an impromptu resistance brigade known as Agbany, for Action Group for Better Architecture in New York.

SANGIOVANNI--Lena. It is with deep sadness that we announce the passing of Lena Sangiovanni on July 26. A retired NYC teacher, alumni of Brooklyn College, steeped in Greek and Roman Classics and a lover of Classical Music and Opera. Survived by loving niece Louise and nephew Robert. Preceded in death by her parents, her brother Louis and sister Louise.

SCOTT--Thomas. It is with great sadness that Flintlock Construction Services LLC marks the passing of its Senior Director of Construction and Estimating, Thomas Scott, on July 16, 2012. Tom was beloved and respected by everyone at our company. His depth and breadth of knowledge was well known throughout the New York construction industry. Tom's ability to evaluate a project using legal pad and pencil, beating any computer, was legendary. Farewell Tom, there will not be another like you.

CHERRY--Ruth Spitalnick, born June 15, 1926 in Brooklyn, NY to Usher and Eva Spitalnick, passed away July 30, 2012, in Boca Raton, FL at the age of 86. Married George A. Cherry in 1948, remaining with him until his death in 1994. Survived by siblings, Florence Silfen and Irving Spitalnick; three children, Sue Ellen Schwam (married to Eric Schwam), Amy Cherry Lowenstein, and Rodger Cherry (married to Debra Cherry). Beloved grandmother of six grandchildren. Spent last years with partner, Howard Werchadlo. Graduated from Tilden High School, City College of New York (BA), and Hofstra University (Master of Special Ed). Dedicated her life to helping children with learning disabilities and their families. Helped establish the Association for Children with Learning Disabilities of Nassau County, serving as President from 1969-71. Mrs. Cherry's greatest joy in life was her family. Memorial service will take place at 10am Thursday, August 2nd, at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, NY 11797. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Learning Disabilities Association, 27 West 20th St., Ste 304, NYC, NY 10011

SCHWARTZ--Richard Leonhart, died on July 26, 2012, in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, where he had lived for many years. Born on April 25, 1951 in San Diego, Richard graduated in 1973 from Loyola University in Los Angeles, where he majored in History. He then fulfilled his dream of studying philosophy in Germany and was granted the degree of Doctor of Philosophy by the University of Dusseldorf. During this period, Richard met and developed several deep and enduring friendships with his colleagues and their families. In 1978, Richard enrolled at the Columbia University School of Law, from which he received his J.D. degree. After five years as an associate in the Litigation Department of Kelley Drye and Warren, Richard joined the Office of the Attorney General of the State of New York, where he specialized in the prosecution of antitrust suits brought by the State of New York, often in cooperation with the enforcement agencies of other States. At the time of his death, Richard was Acting Bureau Chief of the Antitrust Bureau, Office of the Attorney General, and Assistant Attorney General. Richard is survived by his daughter Julia Marie Boylan Schwartz and his former wife, Geraldine M. Boylan, as well as his brothers, David F. Schwartz and Frederick Schwartz of San Diego. A funeral Mass for Richard will be held in Brooklyn at 10:00am on Thursday, August 2, 2012, at The Oratory Church of St. Boniface on Duffield Street, and will be followed by a memorial service in San Diego at a future date.

LEVIN--Edith Gerstenzang, born November 23, 1912, died peacefully at the age of 99 * in the comfort of her home on July 29th. She was an Artist who lived a long, joyous and glamorous life in New York City. She is survived by her loving children William J. Diamond and Joan D. Steinberg, her six devoted grandchildren, Jonathan Diamond, Alison Diamond, Alexandra Fuisz, Eric M. Yamin, Priscilla Yamin Lowndes, Deborah Yamin Manocchia, and 13 great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Friday August 3, 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. (81st Street).

Rihanna and Drake lead the field of nominees for this year's MTV Video Music Awards, with five nominations apiece, while Katy Perry got four nods for her videos, the MTV announced on Tuesday. The awards ceremony will be broadcast live from the Staples Center in Los Angeles on Sept. 6 at 8 p.m. The performers will include One Direction, the British boy band whose hit ''What Makes You Beautiful'' has been high on the American pop charts since it was released last spring.

Since the implosion of the dot-com bubble in 2000, retail investors have been rightfully wary of the stock market. Facebook was going to change it all, bringing the ordinary investor back. Instead, Facebook was a massacre for retail investors, highlighting yet again why stock picking is a loser's game. The hype around Facebook was enormous as retail investors salivated at the chance to buy what they hoped would be the next Apple. Yet, after initially trading above $40 a share, the stock is now down nearly 43 percent from the initial offering price.

YOUNG--Mary. After a long struggle with C.O.P.D.,Mary died in her own bed during the night of 30-31 July. Mary's great loves were for books and France. She received the rare honor of being made an Honorary Member of the Grolier Club in 2008. She collected children's illustrations including Beatrix Potter, E.H. Shepard, de Brunhoff and James Marshall. She received several honors from the French government and earlier this year was advanced to the position of Officier in the French Legion of Honor. Mary was an officer and director of the Florence Gould Foundation and the Geoffrey C. Hughes Foundation. Mary was also active in local Greenwich affairs and was past President of the Garden Education Center and the Old Greenwich Association. She also served for many years on the Town of Greenwich's Conservation Commission. Her husband John, her daughters Anne and Mary, and Mary's husband George survive her. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street, New York City.

LEVENSON--Richard L.,88, on June 30. Enlisted and served in World War II in the 104th U.S. Infantry Division "The Timberwolves" as a Military Policeman in Belgium, Holland and Germany. His Unit liberated the Nordhausen Concentration Camp on April 12, 1945. He was graduated from New York University Law School in 1950. As an Attorney, he was at the forefront of the tenants' rights movement in the late 1950's and 60's in New York City and maintained a practice defending tenants until his death. He was active in the Metropolitan Council on Housing and the Tenants' Union of the West Side. He is survived by his loving wife, Betty Cohen; a son from his first marriage, Richard L. Levenson, Jr.; a sister Brina Zwicker; a sister-in-law Ellen Beener; nephews Andrew Zwicker, Kosta Nomikos and Alexander Nomikos; nieces Carolyn Zwicker and Katherine Elrod. A Memorial Gathering to be held at a future date.

ROEMER--Harold S.,passed away peacefully July 30, 2012 in Weston, Florida, surrounded by his daughter Marta and niece Phyllis. Harold was born, June 20, 1914 in Paterson, New Jersey, to Samuel and Dora Roemer. He was very proud of the time he spent as a naval officer, enlisting at the beginning of WWII. He was very active in the Masons, serving as Master of Fortitude Lodge and also holding a position in Grand Lodge. He is survived by children Marta and Steve Pieraldi, and Irwin and Carol Young, grandchildren Matthew, Stephen, Claudia, Christopher, Brian, Jason, Lisa and Steve and great- grandchildren Justin, Lauren and Michael. He is also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Services will be held on Sunday, August 5, 2012 at 11:30am at Boulevard Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY 11557. Phone (516) 295-3100.

A 17-year-old man who told the British Olympic diver Tom Daley on Twitter that he disappointed his late father by failing to win an Olympic medal on Monday was arrested by the police on "suspicion of malicious communications." Regarding tweets to @TomDaley1994 - 17-year-old man arrested this morning at a guest house in the Weymouth area. Enquiries continue.

WASHINGTON -- Two of the world's largest poker companies agreed to pay hundreds of millions of dollars, some of it to be reimbursed to online gamblers, to settle federal money laundering and fraud charges, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York said Tuesday. The deal, announced by Preet Bharara in a case filed in April 2011 against the two companies, PokerStars and Full Tilt Poker, was approved by Judge Leonard B. Sand of United States District Court for the Southern District.

ROSENCRANS--Leslie. The Officers, Board of Governors, Members and Staff of The Muttontown Club mourn the passing of our beloved member, Mr. Leslie Rosencrans, and extend our deepest sympathy to his children Charles & JoEllen and their families. Robert Anton, President

A headline last week on the Saturday Profile article, about Michael Sfard, the left's leading lawyer in Israel, who has brought scores of cases challenging Israel's occupation of the Palestinian territories, referred imprecisely in some editions to Mr. Sfard's relationship to the country. While his parents, Polish dissidents, moved there in the 1960s, Mr. Sfard was born and raised in Israel; therefore it is not his ''adopted land.''

Here are some of the events, athletes and teams to watch Wednesday at the Olympics. (All times Eastern.) CYCLING Still in search of its first gold medal of the Games, Britain once again turns to the cyclist Bradley Wiggins (pictured), the winner of the Tour de France. Wiggins spent most of Saturday's road race in a supporting role for his teammate Mark Cavendish, but Wiggins is a master of time trials like Wednesday's 44-kilometer race. His main competition figures to be the reigning Olympic time trial champion, Fabian Cancellara of Switzerland, who is recovering from a shoulder injury sustained in a crash during Saturday's road race. If Wiggins wins a medal, it will be his seventh, making him Britain's most decorated Olympian. In the women's race, Kristin Armstrong of the United States, who won gold in Beijing, is also coming off a crash in the road race. Armstrong, 39, came out of retirement two years ago after giving birth to her son. Women's race, NBCSN, 7:30 a.m.; men's race, NBC, 10 a.m.

TRAVELING in the United States, one often encounters food proudly touted as authentically ''New York,'' including pizza, hot dogs, cheesecake, Manhattan clam chowder, pastrami and loaves of rye. Sadly, such honorifics almost always prompt invidious comparison, resulting in a good laugh if not a few homesick tears.I still recall biting into a bialy about 15 years ago at the Broadway Deli, a favorite in Santa Monica, Calif., that closed in 2010. I was doing research on that scrunchy, savory Jewish-Polish onion roll. Identified as a ''New York bialy,'' its rubbery, pale appearance was fair warning. It came as no surprise that what looked like a white Rubbermaid sink stopper would taste like one, too.

Twitter has become the default forum for people when they have a complaint. Even when that complaint is about Twitter. The company found itself at the center of a firestorm when on Sunday it suspended the account of Guy Adams, a British newspaper reporter for The Independent, after he posted complaints about NBC's tape-delayed Olympics coverage. His posts included the e-mail address of Gary Zenkel, the head of NBC Olympics.

An article on Tuesday about the new Fundamental Physics Prize misattributed a quotation by a winner about how he would spend the $3 million in prize money. It was Alexei Kitaev, a professor of physics at the California Institute of Technology -- not Maxim Kontsevich, a mathematician at the Institute of Advanced Scientific Studies outside Paris who is among the eight other prizewinners -- who said, in part, ''There are some rather mundane things, like paying out the mortgage.'' The article also gave an outdated amount for the monetary award to winners of the Nobel Prize. The prize was reduced this year to about $1.2 million, from about $1.5 million.

LONDON - Two of Europe's largest financial institutions reported on Tuesday that profit plunged in the second quarter as the banking industry continues to struggle with the debt crisis. Deutsche Bank of Germany and UBS of Switzerland both were hit by drops in trading activity, which weighed on the firms' investment banking units. The banks warned that continued market volatility related to the crisis would most likely affect future growth.

ROME - The Vatican Museums have one of the greatest collections in the world, and the overlap of masterpieces by Michelangelo, Raphael, Giotto, Caravaggio and scores of other artists (not to mention the rooms packed with classical sculpture) can be quite overwhelming. So starting in August the Vatican is making two priests available to museum visitors, whether they are looking for spiritual advice or more basic iconographic information about the subject matter of a work of art. The priests will be in ''two strategic points'' of the museums, according to an article last week in L'Osservatore Romano, the Vatican newspaper, which presented the project devised by Bishop Giuseppe Sciacca, secretary general of the Governorate of Vatican City. Presumably, the priests will not be inside the Sistine Chapel, where recorded announcements shush chatty visitors on a regular basis (though the Osservatore Romano article implied that Michelangelo's ''Last Judgment'' was wont to thrust spectators into existential crises, requiring the services of a pastor).

With a blast at the toxic partisanship in Washington, Representative Steven C. LaTourette, Republican of Ohio, announced his retirement Tuesday, ending a nine-term career in the House marked by bipartisanship and a pro-labor voting record. ''The time has come not only for good politics but good policy,'' he said at a news conference in his Northeast Ohio district. ''The atmosphere today no longer encourages the finding of common ground.''

BUTLER--Helen Zax, 93, died peacefully in her South Hempstead New York home surrounded by her family, on July 29, 2012. She was born in Paterson, NJ. She will be greatly missed by her loving sons, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, nieces, nephews, cousins and a whole boatload of friends. She was predeceased by her loving husband I. Daniel Butler
$9/SQUARE FOOT $126,000 approximate annual rent

Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has announced its 2012 New York City Center season with the world premiere of ''Another Night,'' by the choreographer Kyle Abraham as well as the premiere of ''Strange Humors,'' a duet from Robert Battle, the company's artistic director. For the first time in the company's history, a work by the Czech choreographer Jiri Kylian, ''Petite Mort,'' is also on the bill. The five-week run will also feature Garth Fagan's ''From Before,'' the first staging of his work outside his own company, Garth Fagan Dance and a new production of Ronald K. Brown's ''Grace.'' The City Center season,which runs from Nov. 28-Dec. 30, is the company's 41st consecutive year there. Mo'Nique, the actress and comedienne, will serve as honorary chair and the honored guest for the opening night gala benefit on Nov. 28, which is a fundraiser to support the company's educational and training programs for young people. Nineteen premieres, repertory favorites and classic Ailey works will be performed for the season.

The producers of ''Memphis,'' the winner of the 2010 Tony Award for best musical, announced that the production would recoup its $12 million investment by its final performance on Sunday. Memphis officially opened Oct. 19, 2009, at the Shubert Theater and at its closing will have played 30 previews and 1,166 regular performances.
An article on Monday about Mitt Romney's trip to Israel misidentified, in some editions, the city from which David E. Sanger contributed reporting. He was in Dallas, not in Washington.

Neatly slice that blushing peach or that ripe tomato bursting with juice. Cut thin rounds of firm, peppery salami. Gently quarter sea scallops. Whack wedges of lime for drinks. These and many more everyday kitchen jobs will not daunt the new French paring knives by Nogent, with handles in bathing-suit colors. What makes these knives unusual is that the stainless steel blades have serrations so fine as to be almost microscopic. They do not give hacksaw treatment to delicate fruits; they can handle tougher jobs, and, for those whose sharpening steels and stones simply gather dust, they require no sharpening.
2012 LONDON

Periodically throughout the Olympics we will check in with Dennis Spurr, proprietor of the Fantastic Sausage Factory in Weymouth, a pretty town on the English coast where the sailing events are taking place. Spurr's sausage business was a target of the Olympic branding authorities in 2007 after he put up a sign featuring the Olympic five-ring logo fashioned out of sausage links. He took it down on their demands but replaced it with a sign featuring five squares made out of sausage links. Q.

KLEIN--Dolores Linda, 69, of City Island New York a gifted educator and successful business woman succumbed on July 30th, 2012 from pancreatic cancer, which she fought fiercely and bravely. Dolores will be remembered as a loving wife, mother and grandmother. She will be missed by her many friends for her intelligence, dedication, charisma, generosity and beauty. She is survived by her husband Arthur Klein, her son Marc Klein, her daughter Charisse Brossard, her son-in-law Mario Brossard, and her grandchilden Chase and Chandler Brossard. We love you. You were a super nova! Services Friday 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.
A documentary examines the popularity of sushi and questions its sustainability.
Three childhood friends brush with the history of Taiwan in “Girlfriend Boyfriend.”
The pains of adolescence are exposed in the third film based on the “Diary of a Wimpy Kid” books.
A former F.B.I. field agent (Christian Slater) is enticed back to his old duties in “Assassin’s Bullet.”

Fernando Meirelles’s “360,” with Anthony Hopkins and Jude Law, is a multistrand narrative that follows an ensemble cast from Vienna to Phoenix, exploring the cause-and-effect nature in a string of affairs.
“Celeste and Jesse Forever” explores a relationship between a man and a woman that’s no longer predicated by mutual desire.
“Mosquita y Mari,” written and directed by Aurora Guerrero, is the story of the fraught friendship between two 15-year-old girls in Los Angeles.
Tyler Clary, who won gold in the 200-meter backstroke, and Ryan Lochte, who won bronze, spoke to the media after the race.
In “Free Radicals: A History of Experimental Film,” Pip Chodorov offers an enthusiastic, accessible look at the genre’s big names.
The documentary “Dreams of a Life” explores the life and death, at 38, of the singer Joyce Vincent.
He might own the record for most Olympic medals, but Michael Phelps is not the greatest Olympian ever, says William C. Rhoden.

ROBERTS--Gerald L. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-LIJ Health System mourn the loss of Honorary Trustee Gerald L. Roberts. Gerald was a dedicated supporter of North Shore University Hospital and the health system. His generosity and many years of service on the board of trustees has helped North Shore-LIJ to grow and advance patient care to meet the healthcare needs of area residents. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Michael Dowling, President & CEO Richard Goldstein, Chair North Shore-LIJ Health System

YOUNG--Mary. After a long struggle with C.O.P.D.,Mary died in her own bed during the night of 30-31 July. Mary's great loves were for books and France. She received the rare honor of being made an Honorary Member of the Grolier Club in 2008. She collected children's illustrations including Beatrix Potter, E.H. Shepard, de Brunhoff and James Marshall. She received several honors from the French government and earlier this year was advanced to the position of Officier in the French Legion of Honor. Mary was an officer and director of the Florence Gould Foundation and the Geoffrey C. Hughes Foundation. Mary was also active in local Greenwich affairs and was past President of the Garden Education Center and the Old Greenwich Association. She also served for many years on the Town of Greenwich's Conservation Commission. Her husband John, her daughters Anne and Mary, and Mary's husband George survive her. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street, New York City.

1:37 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES - Howard W. Koch Jr., known widely as ''Hawk,'' was named president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences at a Tuesday night meeting of its board of governors. He succeeds Tom Sherak, who stepped down on reaching a term limit after three years as president of the Academy, which presents the Oscars and oversees programs that promote film education and awareness. Mr. Koch, a film producer of long experience, had been widely viewed as a likely successor to Mr. Sherak. He had served recently as the group's first vice president, and is entering his ninth year on the board of governors. Because the president must be a governor and governors only serve for nine years, Mr. Koch will be limited to one year as president.

Just call him Snoop Lion. Snoop Dogg, the veteran West Coast rapper, says he underwent a spiritual and artistic rebirth while making a new album in Jamaica last February. He abandoned rap as his preferred mode of expression, wrote more than a dozen songs in a traditional reggae style and opened up to a documentary film crew about his long and sometimes violent journey from teenage gang member to a middle-aged hip-hop superstar. Along the way, he says, he shed the name and persona of Snoop Dogg and was rechristened Snoop Lion by Rastafarian priests.

The Idapt i4 is a charger that lets you trade four blocky ''wall wart'' chargers for one desktop wart - but an attractive desktop wart. The trick to the i4 charger is that it has interchangeable plug-in tips that adapt it for - by the company's count - 4,500 devices.

LONDON -- Bucking the industry trend of weak earnings, the British bank Standard Chartered reported on Wednesday that its net income rose 11.3 percent in the first half of the year on strength in Asia and other emerging markets. The bank, whose activities are primarily based in developing economies, said net income for the six months through June 30 was $2.86 billion, compared with $2.57 billion for the period last year.

A music review on Wednesday about a production of Richard Strauss's opera ''Arabella'' by the Santa Fe Opera referred incorrectly to the son of the librettist Hugo von Hofmannsthal who committed suicide while Hofmannsthal, who himself died two days later, was working on the libretto. He was one of two sons, not Hofmannsthal's only son.

Cornerback Antonio Cromartie's proclamation that he was the Jets' second-best receiver annoyed Coach Rex Ryan, who is refusing to tolerate comments that could produce the sort of dysfunction that derailed the team's 2011 season. Ryan bridled when asked about Cromartie's statements on ESPN's ''First Take,'' in which Cromartie, who will be used at receiver sometimes this season, called himself ''one of the best receivers on the football team, next to Santonio Holmes.'' The Jets' receiving corps has been pummeled by hamstring and groin injuries. Of the 12 receivers in camp, only four were healthy enough to finish practice Wednesday. More coverage at nytimes.com/fifthdown.

Q. I'm wondering what data my installed Android apps can see and use on my phone. Is there a way to tell? A. When you install a new app on your Android smartphone, the program presents you with a list of permissions, and it is up to you to decide if you want to continue installing the app. (You aren't allowed to pick and choose among the functions.) These permissions can include access to your contacts list, network connection, location information and so on. If you want to look before installing, the Permissions tab on the app's Google Play Web page also lists what, if any, personal information or system data the app can use.

WASHINGTON - An MF Global trustee damped hopes that customers would recover all of their missing money from the bankrupt brokerage firm, telling lawmakers on Wednesday that a $1.6 billion gap remained. In testimony before the Senate Agriculture Committee, James W. Giddens predicted that clients could recoup in the ''90 percent range'' of their cash. Mr. Giddens, the trustee tasked with plugging the gap in customer money, has so far retrieved about 80 percent of the funds.

Winston Churchill has been gone for almost half a century, but he returned for a small cameo role this week in Washington as the overheated campaign season continues. The White House was forced to apologize late Tuesday after incorrectly insisting that it still had a Churchill bust on loan from the British government that in fact was sent back during the presidential transition between George W. Bush and Barack Obama.

An article in some editions on Tuesday about New York City's granting of financial incentives for Columbia University to expand its engineering school described incorrectly a plan to add 75 faculty positions. That would be a 40 percent increase in the faculty, not a doubling of it.

An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about plans to sell the campus of the National Labor College in Silver Spring, Md. misstated the financial relationship between the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the college. The labor organization heavily subsidizes the college, but does not own it. And it is not the case that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. would receive revenue from the sale. The article also gave an outdated professional association for Patricia Earnest, a broker involved in the sale. She is an adviser to PRC, LLC; she is no longer a broker for Transwestern.

Nathan Adrian of the United States won Wednesday's 100-meter freestyle in 47.52 seconds. It's one of the fastest times in history but not as fast as that of Alain Bernard, who won the gold in Beijing. So how does Adrian measure against history? In the pool below, he is swimming against every Olympic medalist ever in the 100-meter freestyle, going all the way back to 1896 (technically, medals weren't around back then -- if you won, they gave you a silver medal, an olive branch and a diploma, but never mind).
ACHSEN--Dave, For forty years ... Treasured in our Memory. His Family

As my colleague Damien Cave reported, Syrian rebels on Tuesday said they had captured and later executed several members of a prominent Aleppo family with close ties to the government of President Bashar al-Assad. That act -- captured on video and circulated widely -- appeared to constitute a war crime, human rights activists said on Wednesday. While the details remained murky, the killings appeared to stem from the pitched battles that have raged for days in Aleppo, the largest city in Syria and the country's commercial hub. Rebels accused members of the Barri family, a large Sunni clan well known for suppressing opposition to Mr. Assad, of killing 15 antigovernment fighters.

SELL OUT Roy Halston Frowick, a k a Halston, epitomized the fashion scene in the 1970s, with his glamorous gowns worn by Bianca Jagger, Liza Minnelli and other disco icons. He was among the first to capitalize on licenses and in 1973 sold the company to Norton Simon Industries, which stamped his name on shoes, perfume and handbags. A 1982 deal with J. C. Penney cheapened the brand, and in 1984, after hostile takeovers, Halston was fired. WHAT NOW The designer never regained control of his name, and died in 1990, of complications from AIDS. The label changed owners over the decades and included Harvey Weinstein, who hired Sarah Jessica Parker in 2010 as its chief creative officer. Both departed, and a new team from BCBG is seeking to reboot the brand once again.

ROYAL AIR FORCE STATION NORTHOLT, England -- More than 70 years after squadrons of Spitfire and Hurricane fighters flew from here into an epic air battle with Hitler's Luftwaffe, pilots flying the fastest fighter interceptors in Britain's modern arsenal have been cast in a similar role. But instead of waves of German bombers in the Battle of Britain, these pilots are guarding against a more elusive enemy: terrorists who might seek to rain destruction on the Olympic Games from the air. While the pilots are loath to talk about the threat, officials acknowledge that they have prepared for a nightmare situation in which terrorists hijack an airliner or executive jet and try to fly it into the 80,000-seat Olympic Stadium or one of the other 30 or more spectator-packed sites around the capital. The specter of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks on New York and Washington hangs over the operation, and the lessons learned from those attacks are central to the planning of the mission here.

The Disruptions column on Monday, about Craigslist's litigation against other Web sites, referred incorrectly to Craigslist's financial performance. Its annual revenue was estimated at $115 million last year; it is not the case that the company has ''hundreds of millions'' of dollars in profit a year.

An article on Wednesday about an Indian television network's lawsuit against the Nielsen company described incorrectly the corporate status of TAM Media Research, the entity that the suit accused of manipulating TV ratings. TAM is a joint venture of Nielsen and Kantar Media Research; it is not a unit of Nielsen. The error was repeated in a caption.

An article on Monday about the New York Marble Cemetery in the East Village, where weddings and other social events are held to help pay for renovations, gave an imprecise location for a cemetery with which it is often confused, the New York City Marble Cemetery. While the New York City Marble Cemetery does have limited office space on First Street -- ''a little bigger than a coffin and a little smaller than a vault,'' says its director, Colleen Iverson -- its grounds are on the north side of East Second Street, between First and Second Avenues -- not on First Street. The article also referred imprecisely to the clattering of the Second Avenue El. While it possibly could have been heard along the Jewish Rialto on Second Avenue, that portion of the El ran along First Avenue -- not over the Rialto.

8:21 p.m. | Updated LONDON - The hedge fund titan Louis M. Bacon has made billions of dollars for himself and his investors over the years by placing big bets that allowed him to overcome and profit from one financial crisis after another.

The New Yorker this week is publishing a story by F. Scott Fitzgerald, ''Thank You for the Light,'' that it rejected three-quarters of a century ago. Turning the story down in 1936, the editors said that it was ''altogether out of the question'' and added, ''It seems to us so curious and so unlike the kind of thing we associate with him and really too fantastic.'' It's not hard to see why they thought so. The story, though lovely in its odd way, is a long way from ''Winter Dreams'' or ''The Diamond as Big as the Ritz.'' ''Thank You for the Light,'' which Fitzgerald's grandchildren discovered while going through his papers, is just a vignette -- only a page long -- almost fablelike and written in a pared-down style that, at the end especially, seems more Hemingway than Fitzgerald. According to Deborah Treisman, The New Yorker's fiction editor, the Fitzgerald scholar James West thought it seemed ''almost Chekhovian'' and suggested to the grandchildren that they give the magazine another crack at it.

Comcast added 156,000 high-speed Internet customers in the three months that ended June 30, helping to bolster its net income by 32 percent and underscoring the company's continuing transition from cable giant to broadband provider. The increase in Internet subscribers produced $2.38 billion in revenue, an 8.9 percent improvement from 2011, the media company said Wednesday. Revenue jumped 34 percent at the company's services business, a growing division that includes Internet, voice and other services for mostly small businesses.

Gore Vidal, who died at 86 on Tuesday, wore many hats: novelist, essayist, screenwriter, playwright. He was also a combatant, one of the last popular authors whose public persona was opinionated, political and aggressive. In 1968, arguing with William F. Buckley while the Democratic convention was raging in Chicago, Mr. Vidal called Buckley a ''crypto-Nazi.'' Buckley responded by calling Mr. Vidal a ''queer'' and threatening to ''sock'' Mr. Vidal in the face. (The video clip is on YouTube.) Even more redolent of its time was Mr. Vidal's run-in with Norman Mailer on Dick Cavett's show, which segued into a run-in between Mailer and Mr. Cavett (also available online). At one point Mr. Vidal wondered if what he said had hurt Mailer's feelings, to which Mailer responded: ''It hurts my sense of intellectual pollution.''

BUCHHEIT--Helen M. Wheeler. Died on July 27, 2012 in Reno, Nevada. Born on August 4, 1919 in Moingona, Iowa, Helen graduated from the Mercy Hospital School of Nursing in Des Moines and received her RN. A veteran of WWII, she enlisted in the Army Nurse Corps and served from 1942 to 1946 in the Pacific theater in New Guinea and the Philippines, as well as on the Hospital Ship U.S.S. Mercy. After the war, she received her B.S. Degree from Dusquesne University and her M.S. Degree from the University of Pittsburgh. Education was a passion and, for 32 years, Helen served in public school systems as a teacher and as a children's librarian. She was predeceased by her husband of 58 years, Charles R. ROME -- Italian cultural officials announced Tuesday that a 25-million-euro restoration of the Colosseum (about $31 million) sponsored by the luxury goods maker Tod's would finally begin in December. The start date of the project had been up in the air after a consumers rights association challenged in court the allocation of the sponsorship to Tod's, asserting that other potential benefactors had been shut out of the bid. On July 4 a regional court threw out the complaint, but the consumers association has vowed to appeal. The appeal will not affect the work, said Mariarosa Barbera, the culture official who oversees archaeological monuments in Rome.

You don't often - or ever - see the words ''combination lock'' and ''cool'' in the same sentence, so prepare for a first: the Master Lock 1500eDBX DialSpeed is one cool combination lock. The eye catcher is its electronic touch pad face, which takes the place of a spinning dial. It unlocks when you tap up, down, left and right arrows that correspond to letters and numbers.

Gore Vidal, the elegant, acerbic all-around man of letters who presided with a certain relish over what he declared to be the end of American civilization, died on Tuesday at his home in the Hollywood Hills section of Los Angeles, where he moved in 2003 after years of living in Ravello, Italy. He was 86. The cause was complications of pneumonia, his nephew Burr Steers said.

I've always wondered what my cat did while I was away from home. Did she devour the leaves of the plant in the living room or merely nibble them? How often did she jump up on the kitchen counter to forage for food? Did she dash out through the open window to patrol the ledge from four stories up? Plenty of video monitoring cameras offer home surveillance solutions, but they are either expensive or the video resolution is low. At $150, the Dropcam HD aims to hit the middle ground, serving as a decent child monitor or home security camera. As I was getting ready to head out of town on vacation, I was eager to try it out.

Wallace Shawn and Andre Gregory, best known for their performances in the award-winning 1981 film ''My Dinner With Andre,'' are going to be working together again, this time on a pair of plays to be presented at the Public Theater next year in co-productions with the Theater for a New Audience. Both plays are written by Mr. Shawn and will be directed by Mr. Gregory; they have also collaborated on adaptations of Chekhov's ''Uncle Vanya'' and Ibsen's ''Master Builder.'' The first production will be a revival of Mr. Shawn's ''Designated Mourner,'' which originally played in New York in 2000, and the second is the New York premiere of ''Grasses of a Thousand Colors,'' which Mr. Gregory directed when it had its debut at the Royal Court Theater in London in 2009.

Like a defecting Syrian colonel or converted climate-change denier, Sanford I. Weill has been heartily welcomed among those on the right side of history. The sheer inappropriateness of the vessel, the breathtaking audacity of the messenger, can oddly confer authority on an idea. If even the creator of Citigroup now believes that the giant banks should be broken up, who could not believe it?

A slow three months at the box office for Warner Brothers movies and continued sluggishness at Time Inc. magazines contributed to a 32.6 percent decline in net income at Time Warner. The giant media conglomerate said on Wednesday that its net income for the three months that ended June 30 was $429 million, or 44 cents a share, compared with $637 million, or 59 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Revenue decreased by 4 percent to $6.7 billion and adjusted operating income fell 5 percent to $1.2 billion.

More coverage at nytimes.com/offthedribble.

McINTOSH--Dr. James E.,DDS, a dedicated, long-time faculty member at the Columbia University College of Dental Medicine, passed away on July 27, 2012. Dr. McIntosh first joined Harlem Hospital Center in 1984 when the department of dentistry was a division under General Surgery. Under his leadership and direction, he brought dentistry to departmental status at Harlem Hospital Center, where he was Director of Dentistry for many years. The resolution has been approved to name the Harlem Hospital Center Department of Dentistry as the "Dr. James E. McIntosh Department of Dentistry" in recognition of his dedication on behalf of the Harlem community for over 40 years. In the late 1980s, in cooperation with Dean Emeritus Allan J. Formicola of the School of Dental & Oral Surgery (now the College of Dental Medicine), Dr. McIntosh started the minority specialty program, which trained over 30 minority specialists. During his career, he mentored over a hundred minority general dentists, who mostly returned to practice in underserved areas of the country. Funeral services are as follows: Funeral: Thursday, August 2, 2012 10:00am, Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 Odell Clark Pl. (138 Street), New York City (212) 862-7474. On behalf of the Faculty of Dental Medicine, we extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. A memorial scholarship fund has been established for Dr. James E. McIntosh at the College of Dental Medicine at Columbia University. The fund will be used to provide financial aid to under- represented postdoctoral dental students. If you wish to make a contribution to the fund in Dr. McIntosh's memory, please make your check payable to Columbia University College of Dental Medicine, with a notation that it is for the Dr. James E. McIntosh Scholarship Fund. It can be mailed to the address below: Office of Development Columbia University College of Dental Medicine, 630 West 168th St. Box 20, New York, NY 10032 (212) 342-5612. Ronnie Myers, D.D.S. Interim Dean Columbia University College of Dental Medicine

Our environment, we're told by climate scientists, is fragile. But are children learning that their immediate natural environment -- the trees, grass and dirt that surround us -- is fragile, too? Several educators, after observing years of kids being taught to ''look, but don't touch,'' have argued this summer that many programs and policies designed to protect the natural world are actually preventing a new generation from developing an interest in it. ''We don't play with nature,'' one blogger overheard a counselor tell a camper who had picked up a branch. The environmental educator David Sobel, who wrote ''Look, Don't Touch: The Problem with Environmental Education'' in the July-August issue of Orion magazine, says this is an attitude that's all too common. He has seen wildflower programs where the children see more PowerPoint slides than flowers, and arboretums trying to encourage a love of trees in urban children while refusing to let them climb even the biggest and sturdiest ones. But allowing children to explore the natural world is what creates children who love that world enough to take care of it. Climbing trees, digging holes, collecting rocks and catching tadpoles are time-tested childhood traditions that haven't broken nature yet, aren't likely to. Isn't a little tough love of our outdoor centers and nature trails worth it? A childhood spent climbing and hiking and wading leads to a fresh generation of parents who will encourage their children to do the same. KJ DELL'ANTONIA

8 P.M. (Cinemax) ALMOST FAMOUS (2000) The director Cameron Crowe looks back on his career as a teenage music journalist in this coming-of-age story about his fictionalized alter ego, William Miller (Patrick Fugit, above), a 15-year-old from San Diego who makes a fairy-tale ascent from nerdy schoolboy to Rolling Stone reporter. Frances McDormand portrays William's protective mother, a college professor; Zooey Deschanel plays his rebellious older sister; Philip Seymour Hoffman is the critic Lester Bangs; Billy Crudup is Russell Hammond, the lead guitarist of the band Stillwater, to whom William is especially drawn; and Kate Hudson is Penny Lane, the ringleader of a troupe of liberated groupies called the Band-Aids. ''We don't have intercourse,'' she says. ''We inspire the music.'' Mr. Crowe ''may be the least cynical director working in Hollywood today,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. He adds: ''Rock 'n' roll is not always about being nice. 'Almost Famous' overflows with sympathy for the devil but glides over the demonic power and decadent excess that remain integral to the music's allure and central to the rock star lifestyle.'' Ms. Hudson and Ms. McDormand earned Oscar nominations; Mr. Crowe won for best screenplay. 5:45 A.M. (NBC Sports) 2012 LONDON OLYMPICS The American women's field hockey team meets Australia. The beach volleyball players Jennifer Kessy and April Ross go up against Liliana Fernandez Steiner and Elsa Baquerizo McMillan of Spain at 11:30 on NBC. The men's water polo team plays Britain in a qualifying match at 1:20 p.m. on NBC. The men's basketball team faces Nigeria in a qualifying game at 5:15 on NBC Sports. And at 8, on NBC, the all-around women's gymnastics champion is named, and Michael Phelps and Ryan Lochte face off in the 200-meter individual medley.

EXCHANGE DEAL The Maple Group, a consortium of Canadian financial firms and pension funds, has acquired 91 percent of the shares in the TMX Group, securing its $3.7 billion buyout of the Canadian exchange operator. Wednesday's announcement ends a battle of more than a year for control of the company, which owns the Toronto Stock Exchange. The consortium of Canadian financial institutions fended off advances from the London Stock Exchange, which withdrew its rival offer last year after failing to get shareholder backing.

KALINER--Howard, of Purchase, NY and Palm Beach, FL, passed away July 29, 2012 at the age of 90. Howard survived his beloved wife of sixty-three years, Lee, who recently passed away. He was the loving father of Lynn and Stephan Solomon, Karen and Larry Mendelowitz, Bruce and Debbie Kaliner and the adored grandfather of Alyse and Andrew, Jay, Adam, Dana, Melissa and Mitchell. Howard was born in Chicago, Illinois to Rose and Benjamin Kaliner. He fought in WWII in Central Europe served in a Field Artillery Battalion and received three decorations and citations. After being honorably discharged in 1946, he completed his Bachelor of Science Degree in Industrial Administration at the University of Illinois in 1948. He started his career at H. Muehlstein & Co., Inc., an international marketer for plastics, rubber and chemicals. Hired initially as a stevedore, he rose to CEO, devoting thirty plus years of passion and drive to the company. As a visionary, Howard spearheaded the sale of H. Muehlstein to Mobil in 1980, leading to major changes in the industry. He continued as CEO and became Chairman of both Mobil Polymers Int'l. Ltd. and Mobil Polymers U.S. Inc. After retiring in 1986, Howard was a founding member and later President of High Ridge Country Club of Palm Beach, Florida. Howard and his wife Lee were founding members of the Kravis Center for the Performing Arts in Palm Beach, Florida. Howard's zest for life led him to be a world traveler, art collector, avid golfer and best friend to many. He will always be remembered in our hearts as an extraordinary husband, father and grandfather, and an accomplished leader. The family will hold a private funeral service on August 2, 2012. Memorial contributions can be made to the Kravis Center for the Performing Arts and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

VIDAL--Gore. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. In all his writing, he had a singular purpose -- to tell the truth. He had the gifts of a broad perspective on American history and culture, a sharp wit, an elegant scorn, and a large-hearted sense of his responsibilities as both author and citizen. Death may have stilled his voice, but not his insight and effect.

GILBERT--Jane Treman. Founder of Northshire Performing Arts, Jane Treman Gilbert died peacefully at home in Dorset, Vermont, surrounded by family. Born in Ithaca, New York, on February 3, 1931, Jane attended The Madeira School ('48) and Bennett Junior College ('50). In 1954, Jane wed Dr. David Paton and, in 1958, they had one son, David Townley Paton. Jane enjoyed a fulfilling 30-year career in real estate at Douglas Elliman and Brown Harris Stevens in Manhattan. Jane was a lifelong lover of travel and the performing arts. In 2004, true to her passion for the performing arts, Jane founded Northshire Performing Arts, which brought such renowned talent as Salvatore Licitra and Frederika von Stade to Southern Vermont. In addition, Jane introduced HD Opera to Burr and Burton Academy and endowed the Treman Music Room at Maple Street School. Along with her beloved husband of 38 years, Clinton Gilbert, Jr., she endowed the Gilbert Music Series at Phillips Exeter Academy. Jane is survived by her husband Clint; her son Townley Paton (Shannon) and granddaughter Cricket; stepdaughter Lili Harris (Gary) and grandchildren Walker and Anastasia; stepdaughter Nina Pedersen (Jess) and grandchildren Olivia and Oskar; stepdaughter Annie Gilbert; stepson Geoffrey Gilbert (Helen) and grandsons Ethan and Davis; and granddaughter Elizabeth Gilbert. Jane was predeceased by her older brother, Arthur B. Treman Jr. All who have known and loved Jane will miss her quick wit, her wry sense of humor, her generous spirit and her tremendous courage in the face of a long and arduous battle with cancer. A Gathering of Remembrance will be held on Wednesday, August 8, 2012 at 4:00pm at the Southern Vermont Arts Center. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be given to Northshire Performing Arts in Jane's memory.

She also participated in missions from Israel to America, sharing with us her many years of professional expertise. Her breath of knowledge, her ability to work successfully with all the ELEM Board and professional members, her caring and love for the children, her continuous financial support - all, over so many years, will be remembered by all of ELEM. Our sympathy to her children and grandchildren. She will be sorely missed by all of us, in ELEM/America and ELEM/ Israel and all the Israeli children that she helped so much. Lenore Ruben, President, ELEM/America Ann Bialkin, Chairman, ELEM/America Michele Carlin, Executive Director, ELEM

A campaign is under way to digitize and make available online the first collected edition of Shakespeare's plays, known as the First Folio. A cadre of celebrities - including the actors Vanessa Redgrave and Stephen Fry and the theater director Peter Hall - are championing the fund-raising effort by the Bodleian Library at the University of Oxford, ''Sprint for Shakespeare,'' which started this week. The campaign aims to raise £20,000 (about $31,000) through private contributions.

The Pop artist Roy Lichtenstein's black and white ''Electric Cord'' painting, which disappeared 42 years ago, has turned up in a New York City warehouse, The Associated Press reported. The painting was reported stolen after it was sent out to be cleaned by its owner, the art dealer Leo Castelli, in 1970 and never returned.

PARIS - Société Générale, the big French bank, reported second-quarter results on Wednesday that fell short of analysts' estimates as it struggled against a downturn in Europe. Net profit in the second quarter fell 42 percent, to 433 million euros ($530 million), compared with 747 million euros in the period a year earlier. Analysts were expecting the bank to earn 764 million euros in the latest quarter. The bank also said it was making progress in bolstering its capital cushion.

DETROIT -- Auto sales in the United States cooled off in July as the two biggest American carmakers, General Motors and the Ford Motor Company, reported declines that they attributed partly to lower sales to rental car fleets. The drop in sales at G.M. and Ford were offset by strong performances at Toyota and Honda, which a year ago were struggling to overcome inventory shortages because of the earthquake and tsunami in Japan.

LONDON -- North of Olympic Park, an arena looms in the distance, its roof curved in an odd and yet unmistakable slope. The roof reaches its highest point at either end and sags in the middle, until it forms what architects call a truncated hyperbolic paraboloid. Translated into less technical terms, the arena, the Olympic Velodrome, is shaped like a Pringles potato chip.

My 2-year-old niece has a fascination with my iPad. But I take the blame. I'm the one who introduced her to the magic of touch-screen devices. Now, whenever we are together, she asks to play with my iPad, and I'm happy to oblige. But she hasn't quite figured out how to hold it in her tiny hands. We've tried placing it on a table or in her lap, but she wants to hold it like a book, and I end up hovering close by, wincing with every slip of her grip.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a runoff for the Republican Senate nomination in Texas misstated, in some editions, the amount of personal money that Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst spent on his campaign. It was $19 million, according to his campaign, not $10 million. The article also misstated part of the name of a commission to which Tom Pauken, who commented on the power of grass roots politics, belongs. He is a commissioner of the Texas Workforce Commission, not the Texas Workplace Commission.

HAMPTON COURT, England -- For a brief time, Kristin Armstrong thought her competitive cycling days were over. She had a gold medal from the Beijing Olympics and a beautiful little boy named Lucas, and since it felt right, she retired. Six weeks after giving birth, she went for a bike ride. Twenty-two months after that, on Wednesday she found herself at a start line, defending the women's time-trial gold medal she captured in 2008. That she won again could have been expected. That she won by more than 15 seconds, after the birth and the retirement and a broken collarbone, surprised even Armstrong.

Rita Miljo, whose devotion to rescuing orphaned, injured and mostly reviled baboons earned her the sobriquet ''the Mother Teresa of Baboons,'' died on Friday in a fire in her home on her 50-acre preserve in South Africa. She was 81. Bobby, the first baboon she ever saved, in 1980, also perished in the blaze, as did two other baboons that were in her small apartment at the Center for Animal Rehabilitation and Education, a rescue operation she established in the bush of Limpopo Province about 250 miles northeast of Johannesburg.

LONDON -- One by one, the swimmers emerge poolside from behind a wall, making their way to the starting blocks at the Olympic aquatics center in a procession that combines the drama of sport, the staging of prime-time TV and the posturing of a fashion-show catwalk. This conspicuous scene, playing out many times a day at the London Games, has also become an international advertising bonanza for a product not usually associated with water sports: headphones. Some swimmers dance or showboat as they walk across the pool's deck. Most acknowledge the crowd with a wave. But many more strut out coolly toward their lanes wearing headphones. These are rather massive headgear that, when twinned with mirrored goggles and the pounding beats of artists like Lil Wayne and Cash Money Millionaires, shut out all outside stimuli in the pursuit of perfect prerace concentration.

In a slow week for music sales Zac Brown Band returned to No. 1 on Billboard's album chart, and Carly Rae Jepsen's ''Call Me Maybe'' has been certified as one of the biggest hits of the year. The country-rock Zac Brown Band's ''Uncaged'' (Southern Ground/Atlantic), which opened at No. 1 two weeks ago and then fell to No. 2, made its way back to the top slot with 48,000 sales in its third week out, according to Nielsen SoundScan. As Billboard notes, that's the lowest sales number for a No. 1 album in almost 18 months, when Nicki Minaj's ''Pink Friday'' had 45,000 in the winter doldrums of February 2011.

''I am the only princess,'' Judith Martin announced. A friend proclaimed herself a witch, another said she was a knight. And just like that, they began to act out their chosen parts. So began an unlikely but soon-to-be influential and ultimately long-lived children's theater group, the Paper Bag Players. It would become a New York City institution -- the first children's theater group to win a special Obie citation for Off Broadway excellence, as it did in 1965. It has played in 37 states and many foreign countries. Its innovative use of boxes, grocery bags and wrapping paper as props and costumes prompted the name.

An article on Wednesday about a settlement between federal prosecutors and two of the world's largest poker companies, Full Tilt Poker and PokerStars, misstated a point made in court documents about the taking of money from the accounts of bettors for distribution to owners. Adding mathematical equations to Microsoft Word can be frustrating as many of the symbols used in the notation can be hard to find on the keyboard. Thanks to the Math Input Panel in many versions of Windows 7, the mathematical expressions can be written by hand with a mouse, digitizer pen or touch screen, converted to text and easily inserted into a Microsoft Word document -- or any other program that supports Mathematical Markup Language. To find the Math Input Panel, type ''math input'' in the search box on the Windows 7 Start menu -- or, from the Start menu, go to All Programs and then to the Accessories folder and select Math Input Panel. When the program opens, write the needed math expression into the lower part of the box.

An article on Tuesday about efforts in the Intermountain West to contain cheatgrass, an invasive weed, misstated the origin of the crested wheatgrass plant. Like cheatgrass, crested wheatgrass comes from the Eurasian steppe; it is not native to North America. The article also omitted part of the name of a scientific journal that is publishing an article about cheatgrass. It is Global Change Biology, not Global Change.
2012 LONDON

The CBS Corporation reported record operating income for the second quarter of 2012, even though overall revenue declined slightly from a year ago because of shifts in television programming schedules and a decline in digital sales. The company on Thursday reported $769 million in operating income for the three months ended June 30. That was a 5 percent increase over the same period last year and the highest second quarter for CBS since it was established as a separate entity from Viacom six years ago.

Federal prosecutors have charged a Bristol-Myers Squibb executive with insider trading, saying he had profited from confidential information about pending deals by the pharmaceutical company. Robert D. Ramnarine, the executive, was accused of buying call options in ZymoGenetics, Pharmasset and Amylin Pharmaceuticals before the companies were acquired by Bristol-Myers Squibb. Call options give their buyer the right to buy a stock from their seller at a specific price and time. Mr. Ramnarine sold the options and made more than $300,000 on the illegal trades, according to the complaint filed in Federal District Court in Newark.

The Royal Air Force Station Northolt Journal article on Thursday, about Britain's air defense plans for the Olympic Games, described incorrectly the missiles deployed around the main Olympics sites in London and in Beijing and Athens during the two previous Summer Olympics. They are ground-to-air missiles, not air-to-ground.

The trading firm Knight Capital recently rushed to develop a computer program so it could take advantage of a new Wall Street venue for trading stocks. But the firm ran up against its deadline and failed to fully work out the kinks in its system, according to people briefed on the matter. In its debut Wednesday, the software went awry, swamping the stock market with errant trades and putting Knight's future in jeopardy.
