The return of the Academy Award winner Philip Seymour Hoffman to the director's chair is one of the highlights of the 2012-2013 season of the LAByrinth Theater Company, announced Wednesday. Mr. Hoffman, who won the Oscar for best actor for his performance in ''Capote,'' will direct ''A Family for All Occasions,'' a new comedy by Bob Glaudini, in the spring of 2013 for LAByrinth, with which he has been associated since the mid 1990s. Also on the schedule is a new play by Stephen Adly Guirgis, one of LAByrinth's artistic co-directors, scheduled for the summer of 2013. Mr. Guirgis's previous work includes ''The ------------------------ With the Hat,'' nominated for several Tony Awards, and ''The Last Days of Judas Iscariot.'' LAByrinth's season begins with another new play, ''Radiance,'' written by Cusi Cram and directed by Suzanne Agins. All three productions will be performed at the Bank Street Theater.

HOBOKEN, N.J. - Mumford & Sons, the British folk rockers, kicked off a monthlong American tour here on Wednesday night with an outdoor concert, providing thrills for more than 15,000 people who crowded into Pier A Park. It was the first time a major rock concert had been held in the park, which was built on an old pier near the Hoboken Terminal and has views of the Manhattan skyline, city officials said. The skyscrapers across the river were bathed in rosy light, and a rainbow appeared in the stormy sky just before the band took the stage and launched into ''Lover's Eyes,'' an anthemic song off its long-anticipated second studio album, ''Babel'' (Glassnote), slated to be released next month.

Updated, 5:56 p.m. | A urologist at Mount Sinai Medical Center was arraigned Thursday on charges of taking videos up the skirt of a woman at the Union Square subway station during the evening rush hour on Wednesday, the Manhattan district attorney's office said. The doctor, Adam W. Levinson, an expert in robotics and minimally invasive surgery, was observed by a transit police officer at 5:15 p.m. holding a newspaper under the woman's skirt with a pen containing a tiny video camera clipped onto the newspaper, according to a criminal complaint. The officer seized the device and found ''numerous clips in which the defendant recorded underneath said female's skirt,'' the complaint states.

Apollo Global Management said Thursday that its profit tumbled by 84 percent in the second quarter, as its core private equity business grappled with difficult markets. The investment firm said it earned $18.7 million for the quarter, down from $117.5 million in the same time a year ago.

DirecTV on Thursday reported its first drop in net subscribers to its service in the United States, highlighting the challenges for pay television providers in a saturated marketplace. The company said that it more than made up for the decline by adding a record number of subscribers in Latin America. Over all, DirecTV reported a 1.4 percent increase in net income, to $711 million, or $1.09 a share, in the second quarter of the year, from $701 million, or 91 cents a share, in the same quarter last year.

As the leader of one of the largest brokerage firms in the nation, Thomas M. Joyce has been an unapologetic advocate of electronic trading and one of the most vociferous critics of companies that struggled to keep up with the ever-changing stock market. Now, Mr. Joyce, a longtime trader who seized the reins of the Knight Capital Group in 2002, is fighting for his company's survival.

TOKYO -- Japan Airlines, the former flagship carrier driven to bankruptcy and a government bailout two years ago, will relist its stock in Tokyo on Sept. 19 in an initial public offering that could raise $8.5 billion. A government-backed fund that owns the airline and has led its restructuring will sell 175 million shares at a tentative price of 3,790 yen a share, recouping its investment, Japan Airlines said Friday in a filing with the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

LEWIS--Bernice L. (Bunny), 97, on August 1, 2012. Beloved wife of the late Seymour. Adored mother of Larry and Ann Elizabeth. Cherished mother-in-law of Richard Seltzer. Wonderful grandmother to Mitch, Daniel, Sarah and grandmother-in-law to Simon. Loving sister to the late Lillian, Anna, Flora and Harry. Spectacular aunt, great aunt, in-law, cousin, friend and teacher to many. A warm and inspiring presence in the lives of those she cared for and in the end the lives of those who cared for her. She could say, like Tennyson's Ulysses, "I am a part of all that I have met." Services Friday 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

KINZER--Bernard H.,passed away in his sleep July 30, 2012. The middle son of nine children, he was born August 22, 1917 to Myrtle Hess and Kenneth Kinzer in Utica, Illinois. His early education was in the Utica public schools. He graduated Wheaton College, Moody Bible Institute, and was ordained at Northern Baptist Theological Seminary in 1944. He enlisted in the U.S. Navy serving as Navy Chaplain on transports in the Pacific. After the war, he graduated from Columbia University with a Masters Degree in Labor Relations and spent 25 years in the business world, as management consultant for Columbia Engineering and Computer Sciences. In 1972 he gave up the business world to devote his energies to community service as Executive Director at Hartley House, a Community Center on West 46th Street in NYC. Active in professional associations, he was on Boards of several foundations, such as Perly Fund and Boys Scouts of America. At Hartley House, he managed to get New York City to plant trees on 46th Street between 8th and 10th Avenues, one street known as Restaurant Row, the other on which Hartley House is located. He was a member of the community organization, which helped bring about middle-income housing, Manhattan House, at West 42 Street. He retired in 1985 and became a resident of Florida, living in Key West and spending summer months in Pawling, New York. He is survived by his long time friend Joseph J (Joe) Famularo, also of Key West, Florida and Pawling, New York, and a younger sister, Mrs. John O'Farrell, of Tallahassee, Florida. As one of nine children brought up on an Illinois farm, he felt then as he did all his life, in the traditional work ethic that if you work hard you will realize the American dream. He gave his time to help immigrant people learn English, he encouraged youth to advance their educational careers, and he loved to roll up his sleeves and get his hands dirty by working hard in vegetable and flower gardens. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution, if you wish, to any of the following: Hartley House, 413 West 46th St., New York, NY, 10036; Grace Lutheran School, 2713 Flagler Ave., Key West, FL, 33040; Boy Scouts (Smith-Johnson Scout Reservation) P.O. Box 55. Pawling, NY 12564.

-A decade ago, when the Brooklyn Academy of Music restored its landmark exterior, the Brazilian photographer Vik Muniz decorated the scaffolding of the building's second, third and fourth floors with images of a giant gingerbread house. It was a colorful confection: melted sugar outlined with giant jelly beans and slithering Gummi Worms recreated the building's arched windows; giant M&M's became its frieze. -Now, to enliven its newest theater - the Richard B. Fisher Building - which was unveiled in June and officially opens Sept. 5, the academy has asked the Brooklyn artist José Parlá to create its first permanent commissioned piece of public art for an interior space.

The New York Observer said on Thursday that Elizabeth Spiers was leaving at the end of this month, becoming the fourth editor in chief in seven years to leave the newspaper. Ms. Spiers said that she was leaving to start a new company. She will be succeeded by the executive editor, Aaron Gell, who will oversee the weekly newspaper, the Web site and other related Web sites like Politicker and Velvet Roper, according to the announcement.

DANFORTH--Jed. Suddenly on July 24, 2012 in Stockholm, Sweden. Employed by the Wall Street Journal. Loving Partner of Tony Matson for 32 years. Visitation Friday, 4-9pm Redden's Funeral Home, 325 W. 14th Street, NYC.

BACHMAN--Barbara M. The Board of Directors and staff of Plaza Jewish Community Chapel wish to express their condolences to board member Rabbi Andy Bachman on the death of his mother Barbara M. Bachman. May her memory forever be a blessing. Harold Handler, Chairman

A lawsuit that aimed to block a sequel to ''Raging Bull'' has been settled, according to Entertainment Weekly, which reports that the movie will go forward under the title ''The Bronx Bull'' and will have no connection with ''Raging Bull.'' Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studios, which owns rights to the earlier film, joined Dahlia Waingort, the producer of the new movie, in announcing the settlement, Entertainment Weekly said. Jake LaMotta, whose life was portrayed in ''Raging Bull,'' has been cooperating with the second film. MGM Studios filed suit in July, claiming that Mr. LaMotta violated agreements by associating with what was then described as ''Raging Bull II.''

Responding to critics in Poland, Madonna showed a World War II-era newsreel about the Warsaw Uprising against the Nazis during her concert on Wednesday in the city on the anniversary of that 1944 revolt, Agence France-Presse reported. Thousands of fans applauded as the two-and-a-half minute film played. The city authorities had asked Madonna to screen the film after the Youth Crusade, a Roman Catholic group, started a petition to halt the concert and gathered more than 50,000 signatures. The group argued that it was inappropriate for Madonna to perform during the Polish capital's annual remembrance of the doomed 63-day uprising against Nazi occupiers, in which an estimated 200,000 civilians died.

The marquees on Broadway theaters will dim for one minute at 8 p.m. on Friday as a tribute to Gore Vidal, the novelist and playwright who died on Tuesday at 86. A revival of Mr. Vidal's political play -- ''Gore Vidal's the Best Man'' -- is playing at the Schoenfeld Theater on West 45th Street.

KALINER--Howard, of Purchase, NY and Palm Beach, FL, passed away July 29, 2012 at the age of 90. Howard survived his beloved wife of sixty-three years, Lee, who recently passed away. He was the loving father of Lynn and Stephan Solomon, Karen and Larry Mendelowitz, Bruce and Debbie Kaliner and the adored grandfather of Alyse and Andrew, Jay, Adam, Dana, Melissa and Mitchell. Howard was born in Chicago, Illinois to Rose and Benjamin Kaliner. He fought in WWII in Central Europe served in a Field Artillery Battalion and received three decorations and citations. After being honorably discharged in 1946, he completed his Bachelor of Science Degree in Industrial Administration at the University of Illinois in 1948. He started his career at H. Muehlstein & Co., Inc., an international marketer for plastics, rubber and chemicals. Hired initially as a stevedore, he rose to CEO, devoting thirty plus years of passion and drive to the company. As a visionary, Howard spearheaded the sale of H. Muehlstein to Mobil in 1980, leading to major changes in the industry. He continued as CEO and became Chairman of both Mobil Polymers Int'l. Ltd. and Mobil Polymers U.S. Inc. After retiring in 1986, Howard was a founding member and later President of High Ridge Country Club of Palm Beach, Florida. Howard and his wife Lee were founding members of the Kravis Center for the Performing Arts in Palm Beach, Florida. Howard's zest for life led him to be a world traveler, art collector, avid golfer and best friend to many. He will always be remembered in our hearts as an extraordinary husband, father and grandfather, and an accomplished leader. The family will hold a private funeral service on August 2, 2012. Memorial contributions can be made to the Kravis Center for the Performing Arts and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

WOODHOUSE--Helen Gordon MacLeod, "Gordy" died peacefully at her home in New York City July 31st. Born May 15th 1921, Berwyn, PA, daughter of Cameron MacLeod and Mary Paul Morris. Remembered fondly as a passionate and beautiful athlete, competed successfully in women's alpine events nationwide while managing the renowned Foster Place of Stowe, VT. During the 40's expanded the nascent ski lodge into a popular winter haven for a generation unsettled by war. Married James Merriman Woodhouse of Wethersfield, CT in 1958, moved to New York City. From 1970 1992 owned Glad Rags, a children's clothing store on Madison Avenue celebrated for its wide selection of merchandise, dedicated staff, loyal customers and a warm, friendly atmosphere. Survived by two daughters, Katie Woodhouse Meigs and Sandy Woodhouse Drayton, and two grandsons. A memorial service in NYC will be announced. In lieu of flowers, gifts in her honor may be made to The Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60th St., New York, NY 10022 or Common Cause, 1133 19th St. NW 9th Fl., Washington, D.C. 20036.

9 A.M. (Cinemax) THE DILEMMA (2011) Vince Vaughn stars as Ronny, and Kevin James is Nick, best buddies enthralled by beautiful women (Jennifer Connelly and Winona Ryder). (Above, from left, Ms. Ryder, Mr. James, Ms. Connelly and Mr. Vaughn.) Ronny and Nick are designing an engine that combines fuel efficiency with muscle-car brawn and noise. But what is Ronny to do when, amid planning the perfect proposal for his girlfriend, he spies Nick's wife in a lip lock with another man (Channing Tatum)? '' 'The Dilemma,' written by Allan Loeb and directed by Ron Howard -- hardly a name associated with frat-boy yukfests -- is not entirely what it appears to be,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''It is less a macho comedy than what you might call a bromantic melodrama, an unabashed weepie with enough beer, sports, fistfights and cars to reassure the snuffling he-men in the audience that their tears are not ... well, you know.'' 8 A.M. (USA) HAIRSPRAY (2007) John Travolta wears a dress to play Edna Turnblad in this version of the Broadway musical adapted from John Waters's 1988 movie. Nikki Blonsky is Tracy Turnblad, Edna's daughter, a chunky high school student who lives to dance on ''The Corny Collins Show.'' Brittany Snow is Amber Von Tussle, the show's uppity star, who isn't about to let Tracy onto the set. And Queen Latifah is Motormouth Maybelle, who longs for a future when ''every day is Negro Day.''

The Bernard and Anne Spitzer Charitable Trust, founded by the parents of the former New York governor Eliot Spitzer, have given $4 million to the Public Theater. The money will go toward the theater's free Shakespeare in the Park productions as well its capital campaign to revitalize its downtown home at Astor Place, a $40 million renovation of the building that houses five theaters and Joe's Pub and is nearing completion. The gift, which was announced on Wednesday night by the theater's executive director, Patrick Willingham, is the Spitzers' first donation to the theater. Over the years their trust has supported a variety of projects including the Bernard and Anne Spitzer School of Architecture at City College, the Hall of Human Origins at the American Museum of Natural History and a stem-cell research project at Columbia University.
SELIGMAN--Benjamin D. 7/10/04 - 8/03/07. In remembrance of your wisdom, strength and devotion. Your loving family.

WIENER--Michael A. Dearest Mikey, It's hard to know how I go on without you. You mean so much to so many. People talk about you with affection, emotion and loss even now. I thank the angels for giving me so much time with you. Of course, it's never enough. Each day I say a loving prayer for you. I will always love you and you will always be mine. Love, Zee

SPANIER--Ktziah. Our thoughts and condolences are with you at this difficult time and we mourn the loss of Ktziah, a devoted wife to Sidney, beloved mother to Etan, Noam and Talia, and an adoring grandmother. Buchbinder & Warren, Eugene Warren, Lori and Susan Buchbinder, Rosemary Paparo and Deborah Schwartz

YOUNG--Mary. After a long struggle with C.O.P.D.,Mary died in her own bed during the night of 30-31 July. Mary's great loves were for books and France. She received the rare honor of being made an Honorary Member of the Grolier Club in 2008. She collected children's illustrations including Beatrix Potter, E.H. Shepard, de Brunhoff and James Marshall. She received several honors from the French government and earlier this year was advanced to the position of Officier in the French Legion of Honor. Mary was an officer and director of the Florence Gould Foundation and the Geoffrey C. Hughes Foundation. Mary was also active in local Greenwich affairs and was past President of the Garden Education Center and the Old Greenwich Association. She also served for many years on the Town of Greenwich's Conservation Commission. Her husband John, her daughters Anne and Mary, and Mary's husband George survive her. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street, New York City.

The staggering art collection put together by William S. Paley, the television impresario who founded the Columbia Broadcasting System, first went on view at the Museum of Modern Art in 1992. Paley, a longtime trustee at MoMA, had left his paintings, drawings and sculptures to the museum upon his death in 1990. After MoMA showed the collection it then traveled to museums in Indianapolis, Seattle, Los Angeles, San Diego and Baltimore. One city that did not get the show was San Francisco. But on Sept. 15, ''The William S. Paley Collection: A Taste for Modernism,'' will open the de Young Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco before going to the Portland Museum of Art in Maine, the Fine Arts Museum of Quebec and the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark.
Aleksandr Y. Lebedev, who for years has gotten away with tweaking the Russian president in public, said police and regulatory checks on his businesses had become so intense that he was giving up.

GOLD--Gerald, of Beechhurst New York, formerly of Oceanside, Long Island, died on Wednesday August 1st at the age of 85. He spent 41 years at the New York Times until his retirement in 1991. During his years at the Times he held several positions including Deputy Foreign Editor, Deputy Culture Editor, Sunday Times Magazine editor, consumer and music editor during which time he wrote a classical music recordings column. While at the Times, he was also part of the lead team of The Pentagon Papers for which the Times won a Pulitzer Prize. He was the author of The White House Transcripts, Gandhi: A Pictorial Biography of Mahatma Gandhi and The Easy Bird Guide: Eastern Region. Early in his career, he taught journalism at Columbia's University's graduate school. In addition to over 10,000 music CDs, thousands of books, and tens of thousands of opinions on virtually every subject, he leaves his wife of 62 years, Gloria, a retired New York City school teacher, who cared for him round the clock during his last years, as well the knowledge of his infinite love and devotion to his three children and their spouses: Audrey Gueldenzopf and her husband Allen of New York CIty, Martin Gold and his wife Jacqueline Meyer of Manhattan, and Madeleine Gold and her husband Richard Swarbrick, also of Manhattan and four grandchildren to whom he was beyond devoted: Lisa, Allison, Gillian, and Ethan. Services will be held at 11:30am Friday August 3rd at Sinai Chapels in Fresh Meadows.

Gerald Gold, an editor for The New York Times who helped supervise the herculean task of combing through a secret 2.5-million-word Defense Department history of the Vietnam War, later known as the Pentagon Papers, to produce articles showing that officials had lied about the war, died on Wednesday at a hospice in Melville, N.Y. He was 85. The cause was heart failure, his daughter Madeleine Gold said.

''Marry Me a Little,'' a Stephen Sondheim musical that hasn't been performed in New York in 25 years, will begin the Keen Company's 2012-2013 season next month. The Off Broadway production, with previews beginning at the Clurman Theater Sept. 11 and an opening night set for Oct. 2, includes songs that, producers say, have never been performed on a New York stage before, most notably ''Rainbows,'' from an as yet unmade film version of ''Into the Woods.'' Last staged in New York in 1987 in a brief revival by the York Theater Company and seen more recently in regional theaters, ''Marry Me a Little'' is the story of two lonely people yearning for love, who happen to be residents of the same Brooklyn apartment building and unaware of each other. Conceived by Craig Lucas and Norman Rene, it is a revue without dialogue and draws on songs that were cut from other Sondheim works, among them ''Follies,'' ''Company'' and ''A Little Night Music.''

MANNUCCI--Elinor. Citizens' Committee for Children of New York (CCC) mourns the passing of Elinor Mannucci and extends our condolences to her family and friends and those who share our deep respect for Elinor's tireless commitment to child advocacy and, in particular, her dedication to the issues of mental health and juvenile justice. Elinor attended CCC's Community Leadership Course in 1981, was elected to membership the following year and served on the CCC Board for the last 28 years. Her intelligence, independence and determination to tackle the thorniest and most complex problems facing children made her an inspiration to her fellow Board Members and the staff of CCC. Chris Stern Hyman, Chairman Jessica Aaron, President Jennifer March-Joly, Executive Director
International VILLAGERS IN MEXICO

TOKYO - A government investigation into insider trading here has extended onto the trading floors of some of Wall Street's largest companies, including Goldman Sachs, UBS and Deutsche Bank. Regulators are scrutinizing suspicious trading activity ahead of at least 12 public offering announcements over the last three years, said Tsutomu Okubo, head of the ruling Democratic Party's financial affairs committee. The committee has been working with regulators to stiffen insider trading laws in Japan.

After the cattle show and horse-pulling contest at the Essex County Fair in Westport, N.Y., comes the demolition derby. One of the few women to take part has been Jennifer Reisigl (in the green car, next page), a 25-year-old who has been racing since 2008; at this year's fair later this month, she will drive a 1988 Chevy Caprice. The safety rules laid out by the fair's organizers are enough to remind drivers of what can go wrong. Car doors are chained shut, and hubcaps, hood ornaments and windows removed. Participants must wear full-face helmets, seat belts with shoulder harnesses and clean, long-sleeved shirts and pants to guard against burns from leaked fuel or oil. ''Some cars start on fire, some will roll,'' Reisigl said, brushing off the question of danger. ''Nothing freaks me out.''Fee to enter Essex County Fair demolition derby: $30

An obituary about the author Gore Vidal in some copies on Wednesday included several errors. Mr. Vidal called William F. Buckley Jr. a crypto-Nazi, not a crypto-fascist, in a television appearance during the 1968 Democratic National Convention. While Mr. Vidal frequently joked that Vice President Al Gore was his cousin, genealogists have been unable to confirm that they were related. And according to Mr. Vidal's memoir ''Palimpsest,'' he and his longtime live-in companion, Howard Austen, had sex the night they met, but did not sleep together after they began living together. It is not the case that they never had sex.

Former president Bill Clinton will headline a New York City event for Priorities USA Action, the ''super PAC'' founded by former aides to President Obama, in August, a person with knowledge of the plans said on Thursday. The event -- a briefing for potential donors to the pro-Obama group -- cements Mr. Clinton as one of the top rainmakers for Mr. Obama, a politician with whom he once clashed. Mr. Clinton also appeared at a high-dollar New York fund-raiser for Mr. Obama in June and will formally present him for the Democratic presidential nomination at the party's quadrennial convention a few weeks from now.

LONDON -- For the entire 2,000 meters of the Olympic women's eight final, the United States team had the best view of all. From the very first strokes to the very last, the women -- clad in their red-white-and-blue uniforms -- could see their competition pushing and straining to catch up. But the struggles of their rivals were in vain.

An exhibition review on Saturday about ''Spiders Alive!'' at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the consumption of insects by spiders in an acre of woodland. All the spiders in an acre -- not one spider -- might consume more than 80 pounds of insects in a year. The review also included an erroneous description of the brown recluse spider as being ''the size of a hairy fist.'' The main species found in the United States is typically about the size of a dime with very fine hairs on its abdomen and legs.

Narcissistic parents who let their can-do-no-wrong offspring run rampant in bars. Children-hating philistines who cannot wrap their heads around the time-honored European institution of a child-friendly beer garden. Horrendous role models. Pandering bar owners. Crybaby hipsters. Moms and dads who refuse to grow up. Filthy, smelly children. It seemed there was something or someone to hate for every reader in this week's article about Greenwood Park, a new beer hall on the fringes of Park Slope, Brooklyn, that has rolled out the welcome mat to families -- spurring a decidedly mixed reception. Here, excerpted in some cases, are a few of the more than 250 comments we received:
The new fighting was reported as diplomatic recriminations intensified over the resignation of Kofi Annan, the special peace envoy.

The State of the Art column on Thursday, about styluses for use on touch-screen devices, described incorrectly the size of the contact point necessary to register a touch on most touch screens. They require a contact area with a diameter of four millimeters, not four square millimeters.

An article on Thursday about the headphones worn by swimmers and other Olympic athletes before their events misidentified the brand of headphones often worn by the Jamaican sprinter Usain Bolt. It is Soul by Ludacris, not Beats by Dre.

Schedule information on Thursday with a music review of a concert by the violinist Caroline Chin and the cellist Brian Snow, at Spectrum in Manhattan, misstated the dates of another event at Spectrum, the NYX festival. It will be held next Friday through Sunday, Aug. 12; it does not begin today and run through this Sunday.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Thursday with an obituary about Dr. George A. Miller, a pioneer in cognitive psychology, misstated his profession. He was a psychologist, not a psychiatrist.

Here are some of the events, athletes and teams to watch Friday at the Olympics. (All times Eastern.) WOMEN'S SOCCER The tournament heads to the knockout stage, with the United States facing New Zealand in the quarterfinals at St. James' Park in Newcastle. The Americans, who would play the winner of Britain-Canada in the semifinals, have a fairly easy draw compared with those in the bottom half. The world champion, Japan, which played for a tie in its last group match in order to stay in Cardiff rather than travel to Glasgow for its quarterfinal, created a matchup against high-powered Brazil. France and Sweden meet in a rematch of the third-place game at last year's World Cup. NBCSN, 9:30 a.m.

ENGLANDER--Mary Drago, on August 1, 2012, at home. A life-long and vehement New Yorker with a passion for art and for all things Italian, for much of her life Mary and her husband, Alan Englander, lived to the hilt the City life of culture, humor, and outspoken liberal thinking, with regular excursions to Europe and beyond. An elegant, indefatigable walker, Mary (with Alan) had an extraordinary eye for contemporary art, reflected in the personal collection that gave them continuous joy. As along as was possible, Sunday mornings found them at the Met, weekdays at galleries and theater, and Sunday evenings babysitting on Riverside Drive, cooking the filet mignon and haricots verts they felt compelled to import from the Upper East Side for their grandsons. Equally capable of overwhelming empathy and of judgment, of defending and laughing at herself, Mary will be missed by her daughter Diane Englander, son-in-law Mark Underberg, and grandsons Andrew Englander Underberg and James Englander Underberg, for whom she was the world's most dedicated and delighted grandmother. Her memory will be celebrated privately, and the family asks that no flowers or contributions be sent.

When computerized stock trading runs amok, as it did this week on Wall Street, the firm responsible typically can jump in and hit a kill switch. But as a torrent of faulty trades spewed Wednesday morning from a Knight Capital Group trading program, no one at the firm managed to stop it for more than a half-hour.

A subheading on Friday with an article about Sony's fiscal first-quarter earnings characterized the results incorrectly. The biggest loss in the company's 66 years was the $5.84 billion loss for its last business year, not the loss it posted for the first quarter.

As July winds down, parents in some parts of the country (school starts in mid-August in our neck of the woods) are starting to think about back-to-school shopping. Many states are holding ''tax holidays,'' during which they drop state sales-tax collections on back-to-school goods like clothes, shoes, school supplies and even computers. (Some communities still collect local sales taxes, though.) The CCH Group, a tax and accounting firm, has compiled a list of more than a dozen states offering back-to-school tax holidays and some examples of what items are exempt.

A federal appeals court ruling has affirmed a lower court decision rejecting the claims of two protesters who were arrested when they refused to leave a no-demonstration zone opposite Madison Square Garden during the 2004 Republican National Convention in New York. Calling the challenge of providing security for the crowded area around the Garden ''altogether extraordinary,'' the court said the city had not violated the First Amendment when it restricted the protesters to a demonstration zone on Eighth Avenue.

An article on July 24 about the Senate debate over extending tax cuts to people in various income brackets cited flawed information from N. Gregory Mankiw, a former Bush White House aide and an adviser to Mitt Romney. He had stated that a typical family in the lowest fifth of the income scale receives $3 in government benefits for every $1 earned, and that even the middle fifth receive slightly more than they pay in taxes. Mr. Mankiw subsequently noted on his blog that the data he used, from the Congressional Budget Office, includes state and local benefits as well as federal benefits, but reflects only federal taxes. He said correcting this inconsistency might change his conclusions, but that the budget office does not provide the data he would need to know for sure.

Periodically throughout the Olympics, The Times will check in with Dennis Spurr, owner of the Fantastic Sausage Factory in Weymouth, England, a pretty town on the coast where the sailing events are taking place. Spurr's sausage business was targeted by the Olympic branding authorities in 2007 after he put up a sign featuring the Olympic five-ring logo fashioned out of sausage links. He took it down on their demands, but replaced it with a sign featuring five squares made out of sausage links. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON Q.It has been a little while. How are things going?

Viacom said Friday that it would develop more than a dozen new television series and movies for its struggling Nickelodeon channel. The announcement came minutes after the company said its profit fell 7 percent in the most recent quarter, driven by a decline in advertising revenue and a slower-than-usual quarter for its Paramount movie studio. The media company, which owns MTV, Comedy Central and BET, among other cable channels, said its profit in the third quarter, which ended June 30, was $534 million compared with $574 million a year earlier. Overall revenue at the company fell 14 percent to $3.2 billion, while revenue for the media networks fell 5 percent to $2.27 billion.

An article on Thursday about the sentencing of the British millionaire Hans Rausing for ''preventing the lawful and decent burial'' of the body of his wife, Eva, misstated the status of some elements of the case. The sentencing judge accepted medical evidence suggesting that Mrs. Rausing had died of heart failure coupled with drug abuse and other evidence that her husband had concealed her body; legal proceedings did not leave those questions unanswered.

CORKERY--Ann Minkel, 57, of Centerville, MA and Salisbury, CT, died peacefully on July 31. Ann was the loving wife of Matthew Corkery and the adored mother of Molly C. Garbaro (Seth), Ned Corkery and Hannah Corkery. Ann graduated from Milton Academy '72 and the College of the Holy Cross '76. She was associated with The Salisbury School for thirty years and previously was Administrative Director of the Bunting Institute at Radcliffe College. Ann was the daughter of Dr. Herbert P. and Helen S. Minkel and is survived by her brother, Herbert P. Minkel Jr. and sisters, Jean L. Minkel and Maura M. Frackleton. She was predeceased by her sister, Maize Minkel Burke. A funeral mass will be celebrated at Our Lady of Victory Church in Centerville, MA on August 6 at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations in Ann's memory may be made to The Salisbury School, 251 Canaan Rd, Salisbury, CT 06068.

SPANIER--Dr. Ktziah Ben-Dov, PhD, born December 3, 1940 in Tiberius, Israel, passed away peacefully at home on Thursday August 2nd. She valiantly fought the ravages of Alzheimer's disease for the past 10 years. She is survived by her loving husband Sidney, her three children Noam, Talia and Eitan, as well as 11 grandchildren. Also surviving are her brother and sister Zohar and Chana. She was a true academician who was well published and lectured prolifically on the central role of women in the Hebrew Bible. Dr. Spanier taught at the New School and Hunter College as well as guest lecturing at Yale University and Dartmouth College. She was an amazing women who balanced a successful career in real estate, and a full academic career while also caring for her parents and nurturing her children and her husband as well. Her accomplishments were vast including a founding role at the Corlears School where she served as the first president of its board. She was a fine photographer in her own right and studied with Lisette Model. She always kept a diary. More than 10 years ago when she first realized that she was having true memory lapses she wrote: "Time is running out. Here is a list of the things I want to accomplish before it is too late..."Number one on the list was to have her PHD thesis published as a book. Sadly, she was working on this diligently until she could no longer complete the task. Services will be held on Sunday, August 5th, 2012 at 11am at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC. The family will observe Shivah at their Tribeca home located at 466 Washington St., Apt 8W. Visitors are welcome Sunday, Monday and Tuesday from 5 to 8pm. Donations in her memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

An article last Saturday about the perils and opportunities for Mitt Romney on a campaign visit to Israel misidentified the daily newspaper there for which Nahum Barnea is a senior columnist. It is Yedioth Ahronoth, not Maariv.

A headline on Friday with the continuation of an article about General Motors' quarterly earnings misstated the results. As the article correctly noted, the company reported a net profit over all -- not a loss. (It incurred a loss in its European operations.)

TOKYO - Japan Airlines, the former flagship carrier driven to bankruptcy and a government bailout in 2010, will relist its stock here on Sept. 19 in an initial public offering that could raise $8.5 billion, the company said on Friday. A government-backed fund that owns the airline and has led its restructuring will sell 175 million shares at a tentative price of 3,790 yen ($48.38) each, recouping its investment, Japan Airlines said in a filing with the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

LONDON -- Royal Bank of Scotland on Friday reported a net loss of £1.99 billion, or $3.09 billion, in the first half of the year after it took an accounting charge on its debt and other one-off charges. The bank, which is based in Edinburgh and 82 percent owned by the British government after receiving a bailout, set aside £125 million to compensate customers for a recent technology problem and a further £135 million for the inappropriate selling of insurance to clients.

Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, ''The Behavior Gap,'' was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog. We've all heard how important it is to set and track goals.

The long battle over the fate of Fisk University's art collection is finally over. After a decision in April by the Tennessee Supreme Court upholding a lower court decision, a plan has now been completed to allow Fisk University, a historically black institution in Nashville, to sell a 50 percent stake in its101-piece collection, donated by Georgia O'Keeffe, to the Crystal Bridges Museum in Bentonville, Ark., founded by the Walmart heiress Alice Walton.
An obituary on Friday about John Keegan, a military historian, misstated the location of the Battle of Waterloo. It took place in what is now Belgium, not in the northeast corner of France.

Let's begin by acknowledging that all actors, especially stage actors, are brave. It takes guts as well as vanity to unpack your heart in front of a live audience. But within that courageous profession, there are those who stand out as particularly fearless. They're the tightrope walkers, the performers who straddle voids without nets or harnesses, who make you hold your breath in terror and release it in an ecstasy of relief.

An article on Tuesday about prospects for ending the AIDS epidemic gave outdated figures to describe the shortfall in treatment for people with H.I.V. In low- and middle-income countries, according to the United Nations AIDS organization and the World Health Organization, about 15 million people who have H.I.V. need antiretroviral drug therapy, and last year about eight million of them received the drugs they needed -- not five million, the number receiving the drugs in 2009.

The fact that women continue to earn less than men has been well documented. And while part of that pay gap can be explained away, there is still a significant piece that cannot. But new research suggests that the wage gap may potentially be attributed, at least in some part, to the way women are perceived in the workplace: When a managers know they can blame the company's financial woes for their pay decisions, they are likely to give women smaller raises than their male counterparts. And that's because women may be seen as being more readily appeased by such excuses than men.

Two new musicals bound for Broadway next spring are taking unexpected detours. ''Diner,'' based on the hit film of the same title, is postponing a San Francisco run that had been scheduled for October and November, while ''Honeymoon in Vegas,'' also based on a popular movie, has canceled performances planned for late this year in Toronto. ''Honeymoon in Vegas'' will be directed by Gary Griffin and is scheduled to star Tony Danza, top left, best known for his television roles in ''Taxi'' and ''Who's the Boss,'' though he also has Broadway and cabaret credits. ''Diner'' is written by Barry Levinson, bottom left, who directed and wrote the screenplay of the 1982 film, and has music and lyrics by Sheryl Crow; both are making their Broadway debuts with the project, which is being directed and choreographed by Kathleen Marshall, left,whosemostrecent Broadway credits are ''Nice Work if You Can Get It'' and ''Anything Goes.'' Pre-Broadway tryouts for shows are sometimes canceled because creative teams need more time to improve the production. For ''Diner,'' the producers say they are backing away from the San Francisco run to retool the show to fit better into a smaller Broadway theater, instead of one of the bigger houses. Roy Gabay, a producer of ''Honeymoon in Vegas,'' did not respond to telephone calls asking for details of the announced scheduling conflict causing the cancellation of the Toronto run.

An obituary on Friday about Gerald Gold, a New York Times editor who worked on articles about the Pentagon Papers, the Defense Department history of the Vietnam War, referred incorrectly to court rulings in the federal government's effort to block publication of the articles. While a lower court issued a stay of continued publication, its substantive ruling was in favor of The Times's ability to publish. Therefore, when the Supreme Court allowed publication to resume, it did not reverse the lower court ruling, it affirmed it.

As Beau Brendler sat in the jury box listening to the government's case against a former Citigroup midlevel executive, the same question kept entering his mind. ''I wanted to know why the bank's C.E.O. wasn't on trial,'' said Mr. Brendler, who served as the jury's foreman. ''Citigroup's behavior was appalling.''

Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly criticized the city's Law Department on Friday for its decision not to defend a police commander who is being sued in federal court for using pepper spray on Occupy Wall Street protesters last year. The commander, Deputy Inspector Anthony Bologna, was found to have violated Police Department guidelines on Sept. 24, when he squirted the chemical at penned-in protesters near Union Square, who appeared to be standing on the sidewalk. The uproar over the episode, which was captured on video, helped galvanize support for Occupy Wall Street in its early stages.
A theater review on Friday about ''Mike Tyson: Undisputed Truth,'' at the Longacre Theater, misstated Mr. Tyson's age. He is 46, not 45.

''Double Cross'' is Ben Macintyre's third book about World War II espionage, following the acclaimed ''Agent Zigzag'' and ''Operation Mincemeat.'' When MI5, Britain's domestic intelligence service, realized that it had turned all of Germany's spies into double agents, it started the Double Cross operation. The German spies fed an ornate series of lies to Berlin, helping the Allies win at Normandy by drawing the attention of the Nazis to other possible points of attack. In a recent interview via e-mail, Mr. Macintyre discussed whether he would have made a good spy, Churchill's knowledge of Double Cross, the possibility that German intelligence officers may have been sympathetic to the plan and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation: Q.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art, one of the largest spaces in the world for the public viewing of art, goes to great lengths to advertise its shows, including draping huge banners in front of its ornate facade on Fifth Avenue. But on Monday, a new show will open there that museum officials want to keep as quiet as possible. They will not discuss it much publicly, and the only people allowed to attend are museum employees and their guests.

9 P.M. (VH1) MARLEY (2012) In this documentary the director Kevin Macdonald explores the life of Bob Marley, below, from his beginnings in St. Ann, Jamaica, where he grew up in a tin-roofed shack, to his international stardom as a reggae musician and his final battle with cancer. ''Though made with the cooperation of the Marley family, the film is far from a hagiography; and while stocked with musical sequences, it is not a concert film,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this portrait, which uses archival footage and interviews with Marley's family, bandmates and former girlfriends. Mr. Holden added, '' 'Marley' is a detailed, finely edited character study whose theme -- Marley's bid to reconcile his divided racial legacy -- defined his music and his life.'' 9 A.M. (NBC) 2012 LONDON OLYMPICS The day begins with live coverage of a gold medal match in women's singles tennis. At 9:30 a.m. on NBC Sports the United States men's basketball team faces Lithuania. At 11:45 a.m. on NBC the American men's volleyball team take the court against Russia. At 3:45 p.m. the final four rowing medals will be awarded to the winners of the women's single sculls, men's four, and men's and women's lightweight double sculls.

Here are some of the events, teams and athletes to watch Saturday at the London Games. (All times Eastern.) TRACK AND FIELD The marquee event will be the women's 100 meters, which once again figures to be a showdown between the Americans and the Jamaicans (nbcolympics.com, 4:55 p.m.). Same goes for the men's 100, where heats begin Saturday, offering the first glimpse of Usain Bolt (nbcolympics.com, 7:30 a.m.). Viewers will also see Oscar Pistorius, left, the double amputee from South Africa, competing in 400-meter preliminary heats (nbcolympics.com, 5:35 a.m.). Two of Britain's top track stars are also in action, with Mo Farah in the men's 10,000 meters (NBC, 4:15 p.m.) and Jessica Ennis, who leads the heptathlon after four of seven events. Track highlights, NBC, 8 p.m. (taped)

Why just learn English when you can learn English with Ricky Gervais? The comedian and TV star announced Tuesday on his blog, www.rickgervais.com that he has a new Internet project to be called ''Learn English With Ricky Gervais.'' As he puts it: ''I also finished editing the pilot episode of our new Internet project. It will be called ''Learn English With Ricky Gervais,'' and it's turned out great. We hope to have it subtitled into as many languages as possible.''

Randy Blythe, the lead singer of the American metal band Lamb of God, was released on bail from a Czech jail on Thursday a month after he was a arrested for manslaughter, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Blythe, 41, posted $400,000 bond and left Prague for the United States on Friday, said his Czech lawyer, Martin Radvan. The police said in 2010 that Mr. Blythe pushed a fan who jumped onto stage at a concert in Prague, causing him to fall backward and hit his head. The fan later died. The singer was arrested on June 27 when the Virginia-based band returned to Prague for a show.

RASKIN--Lester. 82, a noted trial lawyer, died peacefully at home in New York City. The cause was pancreatic cancer. Born in 1929 to Morris and Sophie Raskin, Jewish immigrants who settled in the Bronx, Lester attended Morris High School, graduated from NYU and then earned a law degree from Brooklyn Law School. His high school yearbook inscription read, "From out of your ears, you'll take the wax, to hear Lester play on his sax." Upon graduating Lester formed the law firm Raskin, Rappaport and Lowe, and was an active member of numerous bar associations. He was a prominent litigator whose presence commanded attention when he walked into the courtroom. Lester was also a strong supporter of Israel from its inception as a state to the present day. Lester was proudest of his family. He encouraged his children to love learning. No dinner could be eaten without reciting current events; no allowance earned until you mastered three new dictionary words. Lester is survived by Frances Raskin, his wife of 60 years, his four children Robin, Gayle, Bruce, and Michael, and nine grandchildren. He attracted friends from all walks of life; a natural people magnet. An inspiration to all who had the privilege of knowing him, he will be deeply missed. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, on Monday August 6th at 11:45am.

Art conservation can be a rarefied field, but a new project being announced by the North American branch of the International Network for the Conservation of Contemporary Art is taking a decidedly populist approach. The group, which promotes collaboration among professional conservators, artists and collectors, has started a program in which members of the public are being asked to help locate, document and photograph outdoor sculptures made by the Minimalist artist Tony Smith, who created more than 100 such pieces. While many of the sculptures are in public spaces and are well-known, there is no complete inventory of the sites or condition of outdoor works by Mr. Smith, who died in 1980. (Sept. 23 will be the 100th anniversary of his birth.)

There are probably few bird-watchers or hikers who have not heard of Roger Tory Peterson, the author of the acclaimed pocket-size series of field guides to birds, insects, rocks, wildflowers and more. Probably the best-known ornithologist of the last century, Mr. Peterson, who died in 1996, considered himself a painter first, a writer second, and third, a naturalist. Now hundreds of pieces of his original artwork and photographs are being offered for auction on Sept. 8 at the Arader Gallery in New York. Called the ''Audubon of the 20th century'' by S. Dillon Ripley, the former head of the Smithsonian Institution, Mr. Peterson essentially invented the modern field guide, then sold millions of them. His precise and richly colored illustrations made it easy for amateurs to identify individual birds by emphasizing the shapes of beaks, wings and feathers. Online bidders will also be able to take part in the auction, which is being conducted by Guernsey's.

NEWCASTLE UPON TYNE, England -- Abby Wambach goes to sleep with her boots on. She often gets up that way, too. Strange as it might sound, the fancy footwear, which is designed to help Wambach's recovery between games, has been critical to her surge for the United States women's soccer team at these London Games. After scoring her fourth goal in four games to lead the Americans to a 2-0 quarterfinal victory over New Zealand here Friday, Wambach explained that as she is 32 and playing in her third Olympics, health is her biggest issue. ''But I'm playing pain-free for the first time in a while,'' she said. ''It means everything.''

We will miss his wise counsel, friendship and support. Glenn A. Jacobson, President Bruce N. Lederman, Chairperson of Board of Directors

Woody Harrelson and Frankie Hyman, who together wrote the play “Bullet for Adolf,” started their friendship as construction workers in Houston.

The author of “Maine” and “Commencement” regrets reading “In Cold Blood”: “I’m incapable of going anywhere remotely rural without being up all night worrying that every creaking floorboard is Dick and Perry.”
A selection of events.
At the Mostly Mozart Festival audiences for concerts featuring works inspired by bird calls can join bird-watching tours in Central Park to hear the real thing first.
The conductor Pablo Heras-Casado, 34, has only recently begun engaging with the most popular classical music, having concentrated before on both early and contemporary compositions.
In Djenne-Djenno in sub-Saharan Africa, theft and fighting have left many archaeological sites open to looting and outright destruction.
Discovering brilliant Mexican-American cuisine in — of all places — Mexico.
Lindsay Mendez talks about her role in the new Off Broadway musical “Dogfight.”
Answers to readers’ questions about giving a gift, or not, if you are not invited to the wedding and other wedding-related matters.
From an airport art walk to running-shoe room service to a “workout in a bag,” airports and hotels are trying to make it easier to exercise on the go.
The Occupy movement is still wreaking havoc in Oakland, the world capital of anticapitalism.
On his new album “God Forgives, I Don’t,” Rick Ross delivers plenty of crowing, but it’s leavened by reflection and moments of drug-dealer shame.
The saga of the subway track that New York City has been postponing, restarting, debating, financing, definancing and otherwise meaning to get in the ground since 1929.
“I’m ready to curse,” the actor and comedian said. “I’m ready to really, really be a bad boy.”
Underground lies the hidden beauty of one of the greatest public-works projects New York City has ever seen: the Second Avenue subway.

Esther Kartiganer, who as senior producer in charge of vetting content on CBS 's ''60 Minutes'' became entangled in a controversy over a program that raised questions about President George W. Bush's military service during the Vietnam War, died on Wednesday in Aspen, Colo. She was 74.The cause was a heart attack, said her brother, Joseph.

FEINSOT--Aaron, of New York, NY died August 2, 2012. Aaron is survived by his beloved wife of 55 years, Louise. He was the loving father of Paul, John, and Lauren and the adored grandfather of Max, Emily, Ally, Elana, Alec, Saul, Ethan, Isaac, and Elizabeth. Aaron was born in Elizabeth, NJ on November 25, 1923 to Philip and Ella Feinsot. He served in WWII as a French interpreter. In 1947, he completed his degree with honors at Union College in Schenectady, NY and later his Ph.D. at NYU. In the 1950's, Aaron joined New York University as director of the Office of Special Services to Business and Industry and later also became Director of the Brazilian Institute. Aaron was Dean of Graduate and Continuing Studies at Union College in Schenectady, NY, Dean in the Division of Management at Polytechnic University, and Dean of Professional and Industry Studies in the School of Continuing Education at NYU. Known as an innovator in education, Aaron was passionate about lifetime learning. He was a talented writer with a consummate wit. Burial will be private. Friends will be welcomed on Tuesday and Wednesday August 7th and 8th from 4pm to 7pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association of New York or Union College in Schenectady, New York.

SLATER--David, July 30, 2012, age 91. Joined USMC 9th Defense Battalion in WW II. Married Beulah Eisner, who died in 1981. Engineering degrees from NYU and member of Engineering Research Division. Founded Palisades Institute for Research Services in 1969. Secretary of DOD's Advisory Group on Electron Devices until 1992. Trustee of NYU (1993-1999). Survived by son Jonathan Slater, daughter-in-law Linda Caron, grand-daughter Jasmine Caron-Slater, and nieces Ruby Kaplan and Faith Rossman.

Play ball! The enduring cry is heard each summer in every corner of this country. But who remembers those days between the wars in France, when the same cri de coeur was heard in the fallow endive fields of Bilignin, where Gertrude and Alice shared their passion for baseball with their circle of femmes de lettres? They played hard, these girls of summer. The team was known for its rowdy, cerebral game. Trash talk among the women, especially Dottie and Zelda, was legendary, and often unsettled opposing players. They called their team Le Gang Stein. Why not? She ran the team the way she would later run Vichy bureaucrats off her property, with toughness and a gimlet eye. And what could be more terrifying to a batter than staring into Gertrude's eyes from only 60 feet away, knowing you were about to take a fastball under your lovely cheekbone? What we know is how much these women loved the game. Gert herself said it best in ''Girls Just Wanna Play Ball!,'' her passionate paean to the sport she so loved: a strike is a strike one is a strike two is a strike three youre out we win!

A montage of pictues on July 22 with an article about the increase in wedding invitations people are receiving because of the legalization of same-sex marriage omitted a credit. The photograph of Mark Davis and James Howe (directly below the uppermost ''I Do'' in the montage), was by Leslie J. Yerman Photography.

WILSON--Bettye, of Sedona, Arizona completed her journey in this life July 27. Originally from Tampa, Florida, and a graduate of Florida A&M University, Bettye was a corporate human resources executive. Over the years, she had a significant personal and professional impact. Bettye advocated and created opportunity for others - hiring and mentoring numerous students and professionals. She served on public and private boards and held leadership positions in many organizations, including Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Inc. and Sedona Jazz on the Rocks. Most importantly, Bettye had a grace and joy that will be loved and missed dearly by her family and friends.

An article last Sunday about a legal battle over a child whose mothers are former partners from a civil union in Vermont misidentified the organization that gave legal aid to one of the women, Janet Jenkins. It is the Gay and Lesbian Advocates and Defenders, not the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation. The article also misspelled the given name of one of the lawyers for the other woman, Lisa A. Miller. He is Mathew D. Staver, not Matthew.

PRINTZ--Edna, of New York City, passed away on August 2, 2012. She was the beloved wife of the late William. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Howard and Anne. Dearest grandmother of Philice and great-grandmother of William. Beloved sister of the late Fay Thune, the late Sally Meyers and the late Harold Fuchsman. Survived by loving nieces and nephews. Funeral service, Sunday, August 5, 2012, 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Rabbi Jonathan Stein officiating. Interment to follow, Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY. She will be remembered forever in our hearts.

All our pumpkins have died. Zucchinis? Dead. Our green beans are just sitting there turning rubbery. And my gladiolas never came up at all. VIVIAN HALLETT, on the drought that has kept her from entering any produce in the Coles County Fair in Illinois. [1]

WHO doesn't have a health care horror story? Bad diagnosis. Fifteen-hour wait in the emergency room. Nurse who seems unable to hear the call button. But even patients who have had surgical implements left inside them by inept doctors will feel as if they were only mildly inconvenienced compared with the unfortunates who find themselves at ''CHILDRENSHOSPITAL,'' the ludicrously dysfunctional medical center imagined by Rob Corddry and developed into a Web series and then a television series on Adult Swim. The TV version, which is made in 15-minute episodes, begins its fourth season at midnight on Thursday, and the situation at the hospital is grim. An airborne virus that causes amnesia has run amok in the hospital, with only Mr. Corddry's character, a lecherous clown (and doctor) named Blake, unaffected. ''Clowns can't get amnesia,'' he explains, ''though we would like to forget Cirque du Soleil.'' The series, whose cast includes Henry Winkler, Malin Akerman and Megan Mullally, has a knack for exploiting the conventions built up by decades' worth of medical dramas to cram a lot into its brief episodes. No need to burn a lot of time explaining how that virus is moving through the hospital; a quick shot of an air duct will do.

Norman Alden, a character actor who played a soda jerk in ''Back to the Future,'' a cameraman in Tim Burton's ''Ed Wood,'' and the title role in the cult director Richard C. Sarafian's first film, ''Andy,'' died Friday in Los Angeles. He was 87. His death was confirmed by Linda Thieben, his partner of more than 30 years.

THE National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating two complaints in which owners of 2013 Infiniti JX35 crossovers vehicles say the automatic braking system suddenly engaged while they were driving on a bridge, then stopped the vehicles without apparent reason. In an e-mail, Steve Yaeger, a Nissan spokesman, said engineers found ''this particular location has unique roadway construction, which caused the system to activate; it is a situation that has only replicated in this particular spot.''

Because of an editing error, a news analysis article on July 29 about variations in record-setting across Olympic events misspelled the surname of the world record holder for the long jump. He is Mike Powell, not Lowell. The article misstated the Olympic record in the women's 100-meter dash, set in 1988 by Florence Griffith Joyner. It is 10.62 seconds (10.54 seconds was her wind-aided time). It was not the case that no other woman has come within 0.2 of a second of her Olympic mark; several women have. The article also referred imprecisely to the holder of the world record in the men's swimming 1,500-meter freestyle. While Grant Hackett set the record for the short course (25-meter pool) in 2001, Sun Yang broke Hackett's 2001 record for the long course (50-meter pool) in 2011.

When Quintin Berry showed up at Detroit Tigers spring training this year, playing for his fifth organization in three years, Alex Avila knew who he was. Berry had never played in the majors, and had only four career games above Class AA. But he had made an impression at that level. ''Every time we played against him, he did great against us,'' Avila said. ''We could not get him out. He had a decent spring and he showed what you see: he has speed, he puts the ball in play and can run a ball down in the outfield for you. He's been tremendous for us and given us another dynamic.''

NORDAN--Sam. The Nordan family celebrates the 100 year life of Samuel Nordan. He lived a full, happy and complete life with family, friends, campers and students for all of whom he had the deepest affection and respect. In return, they responded with their love and loyalty. As a G(overnment)-Man he helped to establish the Department of Labor and its first minimum wage. As a high school teacher of 35 years, he educated 100's of students in their chosen subject. As a camp owner and a man of wisdom, he was a character builder, teaching so many how to live a rewarding, healthy, honorable life. With sage advice sewn in sermons called "Potatoes," "Red Ribbon," and "Quid Pro Quo" his campers were forever encouraged to reach for the stars, to have initiative, to fully complete a job, and to always remember to give whenever you receive. We hope all who knew the Silver Fox will keep him in their thoughts, appreciate his teachings and carry on his legacy. The Nordan Family, 433 Plaza Real, Suite 275, Boca Raton, Fla. 33432.

Just in time for the Democratic National Convention in Charlotte next month, the city has started offering a bicycle-sharing program that it says is the largest in the Southeast. Charlotte B-cycle, part of the Wisconsin-based B-cycle national network, comprises 200 commuter-style bicycles at 20 stations uptown (Charlotte's downtown) and nearby. Most of the stops are near bus, shuttle and light-rail stops. ''The system is a foundational amenity for a great urban place and will strengthen our transit system,'' said Michael Smith, the president and chief executive of Charlotte Center City Partners, the public and private consortium that is financing and overseeing the program.

An article last Sunday about Tavi Gevinson, a blogger popular with adolescent girls, referred incorrectly to a Love magazine cover she appeared on. It was a hoax version of the cover that circulated on the Web; although the magazine published an article about Ms. Gevinson, she was not on its real cover.

IT'S that awkward time in the shopping season when early fall pieces -- fur vests, chunky cashmere knits, velvet drainpipe pants -- start arriving in stores, while dreams and even realities of the beach still linger. Enter Reed Krakoff's large uniform satchel, an ideal transition piece developed as a limited edition on the occasion of Mr. Krakoff's recent ''One Chair'' exhibition in East Hampton, N.Y. (the show had its debut in New York earlier this year). ''The envelope in the front pocket is in felt, a nod to the chairs, and a symbolic material for the brand,'' Mr. Krakoff explained. Trimmed in four fruity shades of leather (cinnabar, citron, fuchsia and sunflower), the bag is as ideal for moms toting beach toys as for back-to-work women carrying gadgets and yoga gear. Reed Krakoff XL Uniform Satchel in canvas with leather, $990; (212) 988-0560.
The Getaway column on July 22, about buses between Manhattan and the Hamptons, misidentified the location of the Long Island MacArthur Airport. It is in Ronkonkoma, on Long Island -- not in Queens.

LOMASK--Martha, died on July 30 in Portland, OR. She grew up in Evanston, Il, and moved to New York in 1939. She wrote copy for J. Walter Thompson in the 1950s and for smaller agencies thereafter, and retired to live in London, writing cookbooks. Her husband, Milton Lomask, a violinist, died in London in 1997. Her son, Miles Turner, of Portland, survives her.

Matt Bai misrepresents the most fundamental consequence of the Citizens United ruling: that it's a new system of corruption. For the first time in more than 100 years, corporations can now legally spend unlimited funds directly from their treasuries to influence elections. The vehicles for this corruption are super PACs and their companion organizations: 501(c)(4) nonprofit corporations, or so-called social-welfare groups. These groups are now capable of accepting unlimited corporate funds and running napalm-negative television ads that advocate against the election of specific candidates, often without a scrap of disclosure. A new analysis from the Center for Public Integrity shows that companies, including some Fortune 500 corporations, have already given nearly $24 million to conservative super PACs this cycle. This is a result of Citizens United. Because of new Republican objections to disclosure laws (legislation they supported in the 1990s), we will most likely never know which corporations are participating. The article also neglects another mechanism for laundering corporate money: the Chamber of Commerce, which many predict will spend well north of $50 million dollars on this year's election, all from corporations. And while elected officials and members of a president's administration are legally restricted to soliciting a maximum of $5,000 for super PACs and 501(c)(4)s, they are free to attend lavish fund-raisers for these groups, which are often run by their own former staff members and strategists.

THEY couldn't stay together, but they couldn't stay apart. Countless bands from the 1990s indie-rock explosion poured passion, intelligence and sweat into songs that were strong enough to stir club audiences and convince a label that they were worth recording. Then they called it quits, leaving behind admiring fans. Two of those bands have reunited and perform in New York this week: BRAID, which had its first run from 1993 to 1999, and PLANES MISTAKEN FOR STARS, which persevered from 1997 to 2008. In different ways each band rerouted the churn, crash and throat-tearing vocals of hardcore toward songs that were more changeable, more vulnerable, more melodic yet even more gnarled. These aren't victory-lap reunions on the scale of Pavement or the Pixies. They're club dates for devoted audiences. Braid: Thursday, Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111; Saturday, Music Hall of Williamsburg, 66 North Sixth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718)486-5400; both shows 8 p.m., $20. Planes Mistaken for Stars: 8 p.m. Wednesday, Saint Vitus, 1120 Manhattan Avenue, Greenpoint, Brooklyn; 8:30 p.m., Thursday, Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., (201)653-1703; each show $10.

AMERICA is such a marvelously big and unruly country that to talk about ''American dance'' as any one thing is at best a deeply silly endeavor. But we can talk of tendencies and traditions, of styles and sensibilities. We can talk of choreographers who seem particularly American, knowing that there are myriad Americas in play at any one moment. For many people the dances of Trey McIntyre speak to a certain idea about this land. Talking to me a few years ago about his version of America he said, ''For me it's the heartland.'' He added, ''There's a sense of the vastness of the plains,'' and a rootedness. Both of these qualities, of space and place, are apparent in the dances he makes for the TREY McINTYRE PROJECT. His works often muse on American themes as well, though his starting points and frameworks can be deeply personal. This week his troupe, based in Boise, Idaho, is on the East Coast, performing two works: ''Leatherwing Bat'' (2008), which uses the music of Peter, Paul and Mary, and ''Ladies and Gentle Men,'' a premiere based on the 1970s television program ''Free to Be ... You and Me.'' 8 p.m. Wednesday to Saturday; 2 p.m. Saturday and Aug. 12; Jacob's Pillow, Becket, Mass., (413) 243-0745, jacobspillow.org.

PROCACCINO--Maria, wife of the well known and popular former Comptroller of the City of New York, the late Mario A. Procaccino, passed away at her home in San Juan, Puerto Rico on July 31, 2012 after a long illness. Mrs. Procaccino (Maria) was born in New York City on August 30, 1917, of Giuseppe (Joe) and Rose Piombino. She met Mario when she was 16; they married in 1941 after Mario graduated from Fordham Law School. She is survived by their only child, Dr. Marie Rose (Maria) Procaccino; and her beloved dog, Chico. Memorial Mass will be at St. Gregory the Great, Harrison, NY, October 20 at 11am. Donations to: United Hebrew of New Rochelle, New York Alzheimer's Division.

An ''In the Region'' article in some copies last Sunday, about the Knickerbocker at Manhasset Bay, an age-restricted condominium to go up in Port Washington on the site of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club, misstated the surname of a real estate developer from Sands Point and a past Knickerbocker Club commodore who is on the list to buy a unit in the new condo. He is Norman Schefer, not Schaffer.

SAN DIEGO - The quick ascension of Josh Edgin will continue with yet another unlikely upswing. When the Mets placed Tim Byrdak on the disabled list Friday, Edgin, the 902nd selection in the 2010 draft, became the solitary left-handed specialist in their bullpen. Before this season, Edgin had never pitched above Class A. Now he has become the pitcher the Mets rely on to retire left-handed sluggers in pressure-packed situations.

KARTIGANER--Esther of New York, NY, 74, died suddenly of a heart attack on August 1, 2012, in Aspen, Colorado. Esther emigrated from Berlin to New York with her family in her first year of life, and attended the Bronx High School of Science and then Brandeis College, majoring in politics. Her strong will, commitment to detail, and passion for current affairs led to a trailblazing journalism career at CBS News for 40 years, 22 of them as Producer and Senior Executive Producer at 60 Minutes, garnering multiple Emmy awards. She was an active supporter of theater and music, enjoyed skiing, tennis, and swimming, and built a strong network of friends and colleagues across the globe. Esther was passionate about enabling the next generation particularly women to learn and succeed, and served on the Brandeis College Women's Studies Board from 1992 to the present (co-chair of the Board from 2010 to 2012); in her honor, the Esther Kartiganer Prize for Excellence in Journalism was established in 2007 by faculty of the Center. After retiring from CBS, Esther served as a mediator in the New York City Civil Courts and as a member of the Institutional Review Board at Columbia University Medical Center. Her dedication to her family, friends, and causes was unwavering, and her enthusiasm and warmth will be missed dearly by all who knew her. She is survived by her brother Joseph Kartiganer (Audrey), nieces Deborah (Constantin Tanno) and Alison Kartiganer, grand-nephew Nicholas Tanno and grand-niece Christina Tanno. Donations in her memory may be made to the Brandeis College Women's Studies Program. A memorial service will be held in the fall.

BOMBACK--Florence Weinberger, the wife of the late Milton J. Bomback, lived a full life to age 94. Cherished mother of Dr. Fred Bomback and Ronnie Grossmann. Loving mother-in-law of Judy Siegel Bomback and Edward A. Grossmann. Devoted grandmother of Mark, Tema, David, Dori, Andrew, Xenia, Jamie, Alex, Richard, Jennifer, Lawrence and Coren. Beloved great-grandmother of Ariadne, Miles, Caroline, Annie, Mia, Jackson, Phoebe, Jonah, Clara, Michaela and Juno. A funeral service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St. Mount Vernon, NY. 10552 on Sunday, August 5, 2012 at 9:00am. Donations in her memory may be made to the Jackson Gabriel Silver Foundation, 1202 Lexington Avenue, Suite 202, New York N.Y. 10028. www.jgsf.org
