WHEN the Union Pacific first rolled into North Topeka, a section of the Kansas capital, in the late 1800s, the future looked bright. Businesses flourished in this district brimming with stately architectural styles, from Richardson Romanesque to High Victorian. But the devastating floods of 1951 set into motion decades of decline, and crime in the area went on the upswing. It took the birth of the North Topeka Arts District, known locally as NOTO, in 2008 -- thanks to an effort by community leaders and property owners, and fueled by an infusion of private money -- to stimulate a dramatic turnaround. This two-block stretch of North Kansas Avenue is now a mélange of art galleries and ateliers, cafes and boutique and antique emporiums all housed in historic buildings. Things are especially lively on First Fridays, when many shops and galleries are open late, and an outdoor market, open 6 to 8:30 p.m., offers antiques, crafts, live performances and noshes. JEANINE BARONE

SURE, playing a rogue teacher or a rogue soldier or a rogue politician is a challenge, and the Emmy nominations last month recognized that. But those actors at least get lines of dialogue to flesh out their characters. What about the regular ensemble players who go years without a line? Award shows may not notice, but here are a few for your consideration.

RATTNER--Milton S.,lived. For ninety-five years he loved family, music, dancing, traveling, shopping (giving away his purchases), eating (for enjoyment), and selling. He was always selling. Selling ideas, new restaurants, favorite musicians, and most of all Hansel 'n Gretel deli meats. Mr. Rattner and a buddy from WWII purchased a small meat company one day before its closure in '54. It is because of Mr. Rattner's vision, perpetual optimism, hard work and love of New York that Hansel 'n Gretel has grown, thrived, and is still producing deli meats in New York. He was the best salesman they ever had. It is with deepest regret that his daughters must post notice of the cancellation of his planned 100th Birthday Party. Due to his passing on August 2nd Milton S. Rattner will be unable to attend. Services will be held at 1:15pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City (212-362-6600). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to one of his favorite causes: Association to Benefit Children, 419 East 86th Street, New York, NY 10028.

An obsession with fame and brand names is the essence of Andy Warhol's influence, some say. On Sept. 18 the Metropolitan Museum of Art tests that assertion in ''Regarding Warhol: Sixty Artists, Fifty Years.'' It juxtaposes his work with that of contemporaries. Above, Francesco Vezzoli's 1999 portrait of Liza Minnelli (metmuseum.org).

The five most viewed articles on nytimes.com/sports from July 27 to Aug. 2. 1. JAKE LAMOTTA, AT 90, WRAPS UP ''THE LADY AND THE CHAMP'' The onetime middleweight boxing champion rolled with the punches delivered by critics for his now closed Off Broadway show.

END--Jacqueline The world has lost an amazing woman, loving sister, aunt, and friend, a multi-talented artist, published author, famous advertising writer, astoundingly gifted cook, photographer and lover of animals, particularly cats. She is survived by her devoted brother Joseph Arlotta, niece Kyra Arlotta, and her cat, Susie. Jackie enjoyed a celebrated career as an award-winning copywriter and creative director in advertising, creating famous advertising for some of the most heralded agencies which includes Doyle Dane Bernbach; Chiatay; and Wells Rich Greene. She was loved and respected by her peers and colleagues. She was known for creating the Freakies cereal and the band of animated "misfit" characters that introduced the hit cereal to America. She is also known for the Bic Banana commercials which she worked on with Mel Brooks. She created famous advertising for Volkswagen, Absolut, Nivea, and so many more. Just a few things we will remember and forever cherish about Jackie: her brilliant sense of humor, intelligence, exquisite beauty and elegance, her kindness, her wisdom, her magical and beautiful holiday gingerbread cookies, her breath-taking flower photography, her clever writings, sophisticated style and huge heart, her generous desire to help anyone in need and her sense of magic. A spirited libertarian, Jackie was a dedicated patriot and fierce defender of the constitution. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Humane Society or the ASPCA would be appreciated. Memorial service Wednesday August 22, 2012, 5pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., NYC.
STRONG--Raymond B.,Jr. Happy Birthday Again! We all miss you. Love, Ann, Ray and Ben

An interview last Sunday with the actor Clarke Peters, who stars in Spike Lee's new film, ''Red Hook Summer,'' misidentified the city Mr. Peters was in when he was interviewed by telephone. It was Baltimore, where he now lives part time -- not Englewood, N.J., where he grew up.

David Robinson played his entire 14-year N.B.A. career with San Antonio and helped the Spurs win two championships. A 10-time All-Star who was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 2009, he was also a three-time Olympian, winning two gold medals and one bronze with the United States team. Robinson, who turns 47 on Monday, was a member of the Dream Team, the Olympic squad that included Magic Johnson, Larry Bird and Michael Jordan and dominated the competition at the 1992 Barcelona Games. Robinson is featured on Canada Dry collectible cans commemorating the 20th anniversary of the Dream Team.

LAMPACK--Pauline. "They will never accuse me of dying young." Indeed, Pauline died June 23, a month shy of her 104th birthday. Born July 24, 1908 on Manhattan's Lower East Side, Pauline Denker was the eldest of four children. Her parents Max, a furrier, and Jennie (Geller), a seamstress, emigrated from Galicia, a province of the former Austro-Hungarian Empire. Pauline earned a Bachelor of Science in Education from New York University in 1921 and certification from New York Training School for Teachers in 1928. She taught with great devotion in the New York City public school system for 43 years, specializing in remedial reading. She also taught at The City College of New York by special appointment. Pauline married Irving Lampack, a law clerk, in 1932. Her teaching income sustained the couple and their first child during the Great Depression. Irving became Vice President of Public Service Mutual Casualty Insurance Company of New York and the couple retired to Sarasota Florida in 1970. Pauline was known to friends and family as "Peggy" after the song Peg O' My Heart from the musical Ziegfeld Follies. She was a voracious reader and had a life-long love of learning. In her later years she became a successful investor and used the earnings to travel the world. Her brother, the writer Henry Denker, died earlier this year. Pauline is survived by a sister, Ruth Bell of Sarasota; two children, Linda Buchsbaum of Milwaukee, a psychotherapist, and Peter Lampack of New York City, a literary agent; and three grandchildren, Jonathan Buchsbaum, Julianne Buchsbaum, and Andrew Lampack..

An article on July 22 about video montages made of the ballerina Tamara Toumanova and the choreographer George Balanchine misstated the name of an early Balanchine dance company. It was Les Ballets 1933, not Les Ballet. The article also misspelled the surname of the actor who starred with Bette Davis in the movie ''Now, Voyager'' (1942). He was Paul Henreid, not Heinreid.

BROCK--Dr. Nathan, 35, died at his home in San Diego suddenly on July 17, 2012. He leaves behind his wife, Vicky; his parents, Frances and Martin Brock; and his siblings Naomi, Nettie, and Josiah, all of Richmond, KY. Nathan graduated from the University of Louisville in 2000, with baccalaureate degrees in music, mathematics, and literature. He received his MA (2002) and PhD (2007) from the UCSD in music composition. He had been working for the past year at UCSD's CalIT2, an interdisciplinary group of musicians and engineers researching high-quality streaming media systems funded by Hollywood production companies. His co-workers regarded him as a leader in the development of visionary scenarios for next-generation media content creation. He was highly respected internationally, not only for his work in media streaming, but also for his compositions, which his memorable piece epigrammatical for guitar duet (2002) and Resonance Cycle for solo guitar (2004) along with many other works. In addition, he had adjunct teaching appointments in music at UCSD and was the executive director of San Diego New Music in La Jolla. His family requests that donations be made in his name to this group through www.sandiegonewmusic.com.

NAMROW--James Arnold, 60, died peacefully at home after a long, brave fight with cancer. Jim graduated from Beloit College and from Columbia University where he received his doctorate in American History. Jim taught at Columbia University and John Jay College. He is the beloved husband of Linda and brother of Andy, Tony and Laurel and friend to many.

FORMAN--Meryl Ann, (nee Glicksman), of Miami, formerly of Boston and Hewlett, NY, passed away after a nearly two and a half year battle with pancreatic cancer. Beloved by all who knew her, daughter of the late Ida and Clarence (Larry) Glicksman, Meryl leaves behind a husband, Michael, a brother, Howard Glicksman in Colorado and a sister Deena Frio, in Massachusetts. Meryl, a biochemist with multiple patents to her name, worked at Coulter/BCI for over twenty-six years, managing multiple reagent development projects. Meryl's significant accomplishments during her Coulter/BCI years included the design and the development of tools used in the monitoring and treatment of HIV, leukemia and lymphoma. These tools, widely used throughout the world since 2004, have significant impact today. Her extensive knowledge coupled with her desire to help others made her a frequent choice as speaker at conferences and seminars. Meryl's selfless sharing of her expertise not only made those fortunate enough to know her better scientists, but better people as well. She was passionate, kind and caring and will truly be missed by all. Meryl's degrees are from University of Buffalo and Northeastern University. Meryl was also an avid photographer, world traveler, sports fan and gourmet cook. A memorial service will be held August 19 at 11am at Rodeway Inn & Suites, Ft. Lauderdale. (www.hotelftlauderdale.net). The family has asked that memorial donations be made to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network in lieu of flowers, to advance research, support patients and create hope for all those touched by pan- creatic cancer: www.pancan.org.

THE period drama ''Chicken With Plums'' tells the story of Nasser-Ali Khan (Mathieu Amalric), an Iranian musician who, after his prized violin is damaged, loses the will to live. He takes to his bed and allows death to come for him. As he waits, viewers get a tour not only of Nasser-Ali's memories, but also of the visual imagination of the filmmakers, Marjane Satrapi and Vincent Paronnaud, best known for their Oscar-nominated adaptation of Ms. Satrapi's graphic novel ''Persepolis.'' ''Chicken With Plums,'' which opens Friday, is also adapted from one of Ms. Satrapi's graphic novels. It's the second entry in a trilogy about the trials of a family caught up in Iran's shifting politics and fortunes. A fairy tale, a love story and a political allegory in one, the film ends in the late 1950s and is informed by the 1953 coup d'état that toppled the government of Prime Minister Mohammed Mossadegh. There is even a significant character named Irâne, who symbolizes the loss of the dream of democracy.
Manhattan

SPANIER--Ktziah. Ktziah was brilliant, witty, vibrant, confident, fearless and was an inspiration to all who knew her. Ktziah left us far too early and we mourn the loss of this strong determined and beautiful woman. Our deepest condolences to her devoted husband Sidney, her beloved children Etan, Noam and Talia and their families, as well as her cherished sister and brother Chana and Zohar. Our thoughts and love are with all of you at this difficult time. Lori and Susan Buchbinder and families

A picture credit on July 15 with an essay about the unpublished Woody Guthrie novel ''House of Earth,'' using information from the Woody Guthrie Archives, misstated the medium of the painting shown. The painting, ''In El Rancho Grande,'' also by Guthrie, was done in oil on board, not oil on canvas.

An article last Sunday about the increase in television shows being filmed in Ireland misstated the name of the movie house in Dublin where the production company Element Pictures sometimes shows movies. It is Light House Cinema, not Limelight.

His division rival had just traded for the best pitcher on the trade market, but Jon Daniels, the general manager of the Texas Rangers, went ahead with a question-and-answer session with fans last weekend. Instead of criticism, though, he found support. One fan, who said he spoke for all the rest, thanked Daniels for not selling the farm. ''I appreciate it,'' Daniels said he told the fan, ''but I can only take half-credit, because we tried to sell part of it.''

The Streetscapes column on July 22, about the soaring 1956 ticket counter created by Lester Tichy at Pennsylvania Station in New York City a few years before the station was torn down, misidentified the airport for which Eero Saarinen designed a swooping terminal for T.W.A. in 1962. And a correction in this space last Sunday also misidentified the airport. It was Idlewild Airport -- not La Guardia or John F. Kennedy International. (Idlewild later became Kennedy.)

ONE perennial highlight of the Mostly Mozart Festival is the alluring LITTLE NIGHT MUSIC series in the intimate Kaplan Penthouse. Listeners cluster around small candlelit tables with complimentary glasses of wine for the one-hour concerts. On Thursday the pianist Jean-Efflam Bavouzet performs works including Haydn's Piano Sonata in C and Debussy's ''Images,'' Book 1. On Friday the pianist Shai Wosner -- who recently demonstrated his mettle as a Schubertian with an all-Schubert disc on the Onyx label -- offers a program of that composer's music, including the Sonata in A (D. 959) and several impromptus. 10:30 p.m., Kaplan Penthouse, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, mostlymozart.org; $45. There are many appealing outdoor spots to hear music in the summer, among them the NAUMBURG BANDSHELL. Twenty-five years ago Astor Piazzolla and his New Tango Quintet performed his hybrid of Argentine, classical and other South American styles in a concert at the band shell. This week, the dynamic violinist Lara St. John and musicians including the pianist Pablo Ziegler, the guitarist Claudio Ragazzi, the bandoneonist Hector del Curto, and the bassist Andrew Roitstein will celebrate the anniversary with a re-creation of the concert, presenting a selection of Piazzolla's works. 7:30 p.m., Tuesday, Central Park, (212) 501-7809, naumburgconcerts.org; free.

3 P.M. (Fox Movie Channel) RUSHMORE (1998) Max Fischer (Jason Schwartzman), a high school student and playwright with a proclivity for extracurricular activities, befriends a depressed steel tycoon (Bill Murray) until they become rivals for the affections of the same woman (Olivia Williams). (Above, from left, Mr. Schwartzman, Sara Tanaka, Mr. Murray and Ms. Williams.) Directed by Wes Anderson, who wrote the script with Owen Wilson, and complemented by an energetic British Invasion soundtrack, this comedy is ''a particular treat for its skewed, hilarious memories of a cutthroat boyhood,'' Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. She added: ''It's too smart to be maudlin. Far better to show off Max's Vietnam play, with real explosives (earplugs and safety glasses available) or let him boast derangedly (in one especially funny dinner scene) about having a hit to his credit.'' 9 A.M. (NBC) 2012 LONDON OLYMPICS The men go for the gold in singles tennis. Also at 9 a.m., the men compete in the team quarterfinals of table tennis on MSNBC. At 11:50 a.m. on NBC Sports, the winner of the men's pistol final will be determined. At 3 p.m. on NBC, the American women's volleyball team plays Turkey in a qualifying game.

Beate was a long-time volunteer at The International Center, among other charitable institutions. Celebration of her life will take place at 525 West End Ave, New York on August 15 at 4pm.

EIGHT countries are represented in the Film Society of Lincoln Center's annual LATINBEATS SERIES, which begins Friday at the Walter Reade Theater with the Mexican director Kenya Marquez's black comedy ''Expiration Date.'' It ends Aug. 23 with the second of two screenings of ''3 Million,'' a joyous soccer documentary about the Uruguayan team's journey to South Africa to compete for the World Cup. Of special interest are two music-oriented films. In ''Songs'' (''As Canções''), the 79-year-old Brazilian documentarian Eduardo Coutinho asks 18 ordinary people from Rio de Janeiro to name their favorite Brazilian song, sing a fragment, and explain its personal importance. The film underscores the centrality of music in the emotional lives of Brazilians. Andrés Wood's ''Violeta Went to Heaven'' is a fictionalized biography of the Chilean singer-songwriter, ethnomusicologist and visual artist Violeta Parra (Francisca Gavilán), who was a pioneer of Chile's folk music revival known as Nueva Canción. The movie, constructed around a 1962 television interview with Parra, who was born in poverty in 1917 and committed suicide in 1967, includes about 20 of her songs. The movie was Chile's official submission for the 2012 Oscar for a foreign-language film. filmlinc.com.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Olympic Ideal Takes Beating in Badminton,'' Aug. 2: The badminton scandal at the Olympics should come as no surprise. People respond to incentives and will act in their own self-interest when confronted with any set of rules.

Donations in Dr. Mannucci's memory can be made to Citizen's Committee for Children of NY, ELEM, & the Osborne Association.

OVER the past three decades the identical twins Stephen and Timothy Quay, better known as the QUAY BROTHERS, have created some of the strangest and most beguiling films in the history of experimental cinema. Mixing puppets, antique dolls, stop-action animation, live acting with real people and haunting classical music, their movies sacrifice narrative lucidity for the associative logic of dreaming. In a style you might call Victorian Gothic Surrealism, they create worlds that time seems to have left behind, where dust and shadows pile up over forgotten secrets that are revealed only in tantalizing glimpses. The director Terry Gilliam rated their early masterpiece ''Street of Crocodiles'' (1986) one of the 10 best animated films ever. Even though their movies look as if they might have been made by reclusive madmen in a cobweb-festooned Eastern European attic, their career has been anything but hermetic. They have created music videos, opera sets and, most recently, a gripping, nonlinear, half-hour meditation on the collection of 19th-century medical curiosities owned by the Mütter Museum in Philadelphia. ''Quay Brothers: On Deciphering the Pharmacist's Prescription for Lip-Reading Puppets'' is a full retrospective. Prepare for mind-bending magic and weirdness. Through Jan. 7, Museum of Modern Art, (212) 708-9400, moma.org.

WITH his new e-commerce site up and running, the designer Christian Louboutin is now constantly tempting the deskbound with the latest releases from his fall collection. Recently it was the Anita heel, a perfect mash-up of this season's trends: a metal-cap toe, a loaferlike shape, Western touches and tough biker buckles. The slick mirrored heel (Mr. Louboutin's fall is full of light-reflecting surfaces) takes the sturdy look to cool, new heights. Christian Louboutin shoes, $1,395. Go to christianlouboutin.com. From the Star of the East we obtain further particulars respecting the proposed revival of the Olympus Games. The startling announcement that such a measure was in contemplation may have caused some readers of The Times to brush up their school-boy recollections by a hasty glance at the Classical Dictionary, and the anachronism may have struck them as no less singular than that the celebration should take place at Athens, instead of on the grassy banks of the river Alpheus in far-famed Olympia. Yet this is to be the sober fact. . . . The games are to be celebrated every four years, and to last eight days. During the festival, the agricultural products of the country and its manufacturers are to be placed on exhibition. . . . But to the evidences of material prosperity are to be added works of painting and sculpture and poetical effusions, which are likewise to be submitted to the inspection and judgment of crowds that are expected to assemble from all quarters to view the games. Horse and foot races, and trials of bodily strength, may, we presume, be expected to form part of the entertainment, and the stadium of Athens will become vocal, as in the Panathenaea of old, to the shouts of beholding multitudes. Excerpted from ''From Greece: Athenian Journalism -- Revival of the Olympic Games,'' The New York Times, Nov. 19, 1858.

An article last Sunday about the Founder Institute, a global training program for technology entrepreneurs, misspelled the surname of the man who started chapters of the institute in Colombia. He is Alan Colmenares, not Colemenares. The article also misidentified the company started by Carlos Rozo of the Bogotá chapter. It is Thotz.net, not Thotz.com.

EVERY autumn, when the ''season'' starts, a select group of New Yorkers -- socialites, ancien régimers, dowagers from Vienna or simply those local folks with a taste for dressing up -- gathers in the great rooms of the city's grand hotels for a series of formal balls. Whether it's the Quadrille Ball or the Russian Nobility Ball, the music and the trappings are the same: waltzes, bowties, cocktails, gowns, white silk gloves and the occasional costumed horse. From 2008 to 2011, the Swedish photographer Chris Maluszynski documented these events as a participant-observer after friends of his parents invited him one evening to the Polish Assistance Ball. ''They said, 'Hey, we've got a ticket. You want it?' '' he recalled. ''I put on a tuxedo and went.''
International AS SYRIA WAR ROILS,

The Bits column last Sunday about the Nike FuelBand, a bracelet that tracks physical activity, referred incorrectly to research by B. J. Fogg, who directs the Persuasive Technology Lab at Stanford. Although he has conducted research tests on forms of wearable technology, he has not done so with the FuelBand.

EISENBERG--Yale. Born On August 21, 1923, Brooklyn, NY. The finest man who will be missed by everyone that knew him passed away on June 26, 2012 in Pompano Beach, FL. The dearest father, brother, uncle and friend. He will be deeply mourned, missed and never forgotten. Thank you for life's lessons.

THIRTEEN years ago, before department-store denim departments grew, kudzulike, into a tangled thicket of often-obscure brands (before, in fact, there were department-store denim departments), Paper Denim & Cloth sold its first pair of jeans. ''They were based on an old pair of Levis 501s -- I had been going to Cheap Jack's and buying old Levis that I would then alter -- that we had adjusted in terms of the fit,'' said Alex Gilbert Gaines, a founder of the brand. ''And we worked with a facility in Kentucky to get just the right wash.'' With a winning combination of slouch and leanness, they were one of the first high-priced jeans styles to go viral. But like a lot of denim brands that blossomed in the last years of the Clinton administration, Paper Denim faded away -- until July 25, when it made a reappearance via Instagram from a rooftop in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, where its spring look book was being shot and released to followers in real time.

Jim Furyk had the worst of his three rounds on Saturday at the W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational in Akron, Ohio, yet he enters the final round with the lead. Furyk followed his rounds of 63 and 66 on Thursday and Friday with a par 70, putting him at 11 under for the tournament with 18 holes to play. Creeping up the leader board a shot behind him was Louis Oosthuizen, who followed a 65 on Friday with a 68. More at nytimes.com David Peoples matched his career best with a 10-under 62 to take a three-stroke lead in the Champions Tour's 3M Championship in Blaine, Minn. (AP)

In her Big City column last Sunday, Ginia Bellafante wrote about the shootings that have plagued New York City this summer, resulting in the death of a 4-year-old child and the wounding of many others. On NYTimes.com, readers debated the efficacy of gun control, the nature of ''gun culture'' and what solutions there might be to the violence. A selection of responses is below. One of the alleged shooters of young Lloyd Morgan was a student I had some 10 years ago in a special education public school program in the Bronx. The teachers, the counselors, the public school administrators did all they could for this child.....this is the result i.e. he will most likely be charged with homicide. Very upsetting. Just cannot break the cycle, the inner city lifestyle deserves a good deal of blame. Social services are in place, but you have to survive a defensive, dominant street culture. Education is NOT their ticket out, as we all naively hoped. I so wish I had some answers. I took early retirement, I finally admitted it was hopeless.

GOLDSTEIN--Bernard, passed away of natural causes at 95. He enjoyed a wonderful life with his loving wife Ray for 53 years who predeceased him. For the last 21 years he was cared for and loved by his wife Carol. The world will miss an elegant and "fabulous" man who was the patriarch of the family. He is survived by his wife Carol, children Nancy, Mark and Joel (Elaine), grandchildren Alexis, Evan, and Morgan (Brian), and adored great-granddaughter Isabella, Carol's children Donna (Rick) and Linda (Don), and grandchildren Megan and Kirsten. Services at Plaza Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at W 91 St New York at 10AM Monday August 6.

WIENER--Michael A. Dearest Mikey, It's hard to know how I go on without you. You mean so much to so many. People talk about you with affection, emotion and loss even now. I thank the angels for giving me so much time with you. Of course, it's never enough. Each day I say a loving prayer for you. I will always love you and you will always be mine. Love, Zee

A picture last Sunday with an article about the arrival of wounded Syrian rebel fighters, refugees and jihadists across the border in the picturesque town of Antakya, Turkey, was published in error. The photograph showed unarmed municipal officers overseeing a construction project in Antakya -- not Turkish police officers, whose presence in the town has increased with the influx of Syrians.

CLARK--Anthony Eastburn, July 26, 2012. Dearly loved husband of Christine Semenenko, respected and beloved father of Dylan Semenenko Clark, who predeceased him on June 5, 2011. So admired for his noble soul and extensive knowledge of world history and anthropology. Known for his kindness of heart and loving ways. He took great pleasure in travel, foreign cultures and in being on the open seas. He will be profoundly missed by those who knew and loved him well. His loyalty and love will ever be remembered. A memorial will be held in the Autumn.

GROSSMAN--Arlene Petroff. It is with the most profound sense of loss that I must report the passing of my wife, my absolute love, and my dearest friend, on July 28, 2012 in Gt. Barrington, MA. Arlene succumbed to the ravages of metastasized breast cancer despite the determined and extraordinary medical care she received at Memorial Sloan Kettering. She is survived by her loving husband, Ed, her brother Martin and his wife Marsha, numerous cousins and many devoted friends. Born in New York City, February 2, 1940 to Max and Lillian Petroff. Attended PS 6, Calhoun, and earned a BA from NYU. Arlene worked in magazine editorial, then at JC Penney as Director of Home Fashion and as President of In Detail, before joining her husband's wholesale business. Loved by all who knew you, you were my life and my shining light. My world is now much darker. Thank you Arlene for over 43 years of love and devotion. LEVINE--Stanley H.,Monroe, NJ, longtime resident of Metuchen, NJ. died August 1, 2012 at age 83. Longtime developmental optometrist, inventor, entrepreneur and visionary. Husband of Suzanne Levine (d.2001), survived by sister Janice Grow, daughters Hana Levine (Tzvi), Amy Levine Samuels (Jeffrey), Dinah Harmon, companion Gloria Kowalski, seven grandchildren, three great-grandchildren, nieces, nephews, many beloved friends and thousands of grateful patients and colleagues worldwide. Contributions in Dr. Levine's memory may be made to College of Syntonic Optometry, 2052 W. Morales Dr., Pueblo West, CO 81007.

MENDEZ--Louis, 1929-2012. The exuberant artist/educator, Louis Mendez, died peacefully at the Jacob Perlow Hospice Inpatient Unit at Beth Israel Medical Center in New York City, just two weeks shy of his 83rd birthday. Louis Ernest Mendez was born on the Lower East Side of Manhattan of Puerto Rican, Spanish and Irish heritage. He spent his early years in Spanish Harlem and his teenage years in Goshen, NY, where his high school teachers recognized his unusual talent in drawing and sculpture. Louis went on to earn BFA ('52) and MFA ('54) degrees from the New York State College of Ceramics at Alfred University, where he became a protege of Professors Charles Harder and Daniel Rhodes, influential figures in the mid-century American studio ceramics movement. After college, Louis was hired by fellow Alfred alumnus, David Gil, as the first designer at Bennington Potters in Vermont. He later worked as a designer at Lenox China in Trenton, NJ, before entering the field of education, teaching first at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, then at the Philadelphia College of Art, and ultimately at the Ohio State University in Columbus, where he was an Associate Professor of Art and Chairman of the Graduate Faculty in the Ceramics Department. Aside from these professorial appointments, he taught more casually, but with no less enthusiasm, at numerous venues, including New Jersey City University and the Ceramic Education Center (NJ), Brookfield Craft Center (CT), Art+Clay (NM), Valle de Bravo (MX), Juniata College, (PA), and with special joy at the 92nd Street Y 60+ Program in New York City. From the 1960s onward his output included no only pottery, but masks, wall-reliefs, mosaics, and free-standing sculptures both large and small. Louis developed his signature "Spanish Handbuilding Technique," an approach to ceramic hand building that allowed construction and firing of large sculptural works in clay without the use of an armature, a development that helped to transform ceramics from "craft" to "art." Mendez exhibited in many important venues in the USA, including the Museum of Art and Design, the Museum of Contemporary Hispanic Art, Taller Boriqua, the Brooklyn Museum, the Everson Museum, the Columbus Gallery of Fine Arts, and the Silvermine Guild of Artists. International exhibitions include group shows at the Victoria and Albert Museum (London), the Internazionale Biennale dell' Arte Contemporanea (Florence, Italy), the Gangjin Festival (Korea), and a one person show at the Museo Regional Michoacano (Morelia, Mexico). His work is included in the collections of the Museum of Art and Design (New York), the ASU Museum at the Herberger Institute for Design + the Arts in Tempe (AZ), the Mint Museum of Craft & Design (North Carolina), the Columbia Museum of Art (SC), the Gangjin Ceramics Museum (South Korea), and the Schein-Joseph International Museum of Ceramic Art at Alfred University, among others. Louis is survived by his wife Dianne, son Aaron, daughter-in-law Mieko and two grandchildren; his sister Victoria Blanco-Alfiero; his sister and brother-in-law, Donna and David Dunning; three nephews and one niece. In lieu of flowers, the family asks friends to consider a donation to one of the following: Alfred University; send gift with a note stating that the gift is in memory of Louis Mendez to: University Relations, 1 Saxon Drive, Alfred University, Alfred NY 14802. The 92nd Street Y; make check payable to 92nd Street Y with a note indicating that the gift is "In Memory of Louis Mendez for HB Senior Program." MJHS Foundation; note that the gift is f/b/o the Jacob Perlow Hospice Inpatient Care Unit at Beth Israel Hospital in Memory of Louis Mendez.

WEINSTOCK--Jack. Founder and CEO of August Silk, Inc. He is survived by his wife, Sandra Price, sister, Harriet, his children, Richard, David and Shelley and four grandchildren. Donations in his name to The Needlers Foundation, 1410 Broadway, Ste 1902, NY 10018.

In honor of Nora Ephron, who died in June, the Big City Book Club will revisit her early work as a journalist and essayist. In the early 1960s and '70s, she wrote for magazines like Rolling Stone, New York and The New Yorker -- pieces collected in the anthologies ''Crazy Salad'' and ''Wallflower at the Orgy.'' We're going to read ''Wallflower'' because it's more readily available, but if you're lucky enough to have an old copy of ''Crazy Salad,'' reread it, too, and weigh in!

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Where Attire and Oddities Overshadow Athleticism,'' July 31: Re: The question isn't whether we will someday be celebrating the Pornolympics, with topless volleyball, bottomless dressage, full-frontal fencing and the ever-popular pornathalon (pole dancing, mud wrestling, synchronized skinny dipping), but will Viagra be a banned substance?

SCHIFFMAN--William L.,91, died July 30, 2012 at his home in Rancho Bernardo, CA, his loving wife of nearly 65 years, Barbara T. Schiffman, at his side. He was the epitome of a family man; a loyal and devoted husband, father, grandfather, son, brother and uncle. He was a warm, generous and gregarious man, and universally described as "a good guy." Billy was born and raised in New York City, son of Joe and Jennie, big brother to Claire and Helene. He was a WWII hero, returning home to join his father in the circulation department at The NY Daily News, where he worked for 40 years. In addition to his beloved wife, he is survived by his adoring children, Fredda Schiffman Ferguson of El Cajon, Mindy Schiffman of New York City, and George Schiffman of Laguna Beach, and their spouses and partner; his most-loved grandchildren, Kimberly Ferguson Walter, Joseph, Rachael and Rebecca Schiffman, and Hannah Schiffman; his sister, Claire Weber; and his nieces and nephews. Arlington National Cemetery will be a well-deserved honor and his final resting place. Dad, you are our champion...we love you. You will forever be in our hearts and minds, and your presence will be sorely missed.

I remember the tumult of being 14. I remember having unspeakable thoughts about my parents and what I wanted to do to them in the midst of an adolescent rage. I recognize that the (huge) dif erence is that the vast majority of us don't act on our thoughts. But I do feel some sympathy, or perhaps sorrow, for Greg Ousley, who was not nearly as bad of as many children are but didn't have the parental nurturing to ease the pain of being a teenager. He presented a clear story regarding the facts, leading readers to address their own morals on the issue. JOHN SCHRADER, Public Information Officer, Westville Correctional Facility, Westville, Ind.

DETAILS have been scant about ''Heartless,'' the new play by SAM SHEPARD that begins an Off Broadway run this week, but for Shepard fans it hardly matters. It's new, and it's by the man who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1979 for ''Buried Child.'' In that play he dealt with submerged secrets, and in ''Heartless'' dark secrets are at issue too, but Mr. Shepard is not simply playing in an old sandbox here. This writer known for many a testosterone-fueled battle (see ''True West,'' ''The Tooth of Crime'' and others) has -- perhaps surprisingly -- written a play predominantly populated by female characters. In ''Heartless'' Julianne Nicholson (''This'') plays Sally, an Angeleno with hidden truths that are likely to come to light, prompted by the arrival of a stranger to her family home. The cast also includes Jenny Bacon, Gary Cole, Betty Gilpin and Lois Smith, whose many credits include Halie, the hypocritical mother in the 1996 Broadway production of ''Buried Child.'' The director is the very busy Daniel Aukin (''4000 Miles,'' ''The Bad and the Better''). Previews begin Tuesday, opens Aug. 27, Irene Diamond Stage at the Pershing Square Signature Center, 480 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 244-7529, signaturetheatre.org; $25.

A STRIKING 14-room duplex at 795 Fifth Avenue, partly designed by Richard Meier and owned for decades by the wealthiest woman in Argentina, Amalia Lacroze de Fortabat, sold for $19.4 million and was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records. The co-op apartment is on the 20th and 21st floors at the Pierre hotel, where the white-glove amenities include twice-daily maid service (covered by the $20,123 monthly maintenance fee). It had been on the market barely a week in June 2011 when it attracted a bid for its original asking price of $19.5 million.

YOUNG--Mary. The Trustees and staff of The Frick Collection mourn the passing of Mary Young. As an officer and director of The Florence Gould Foundation, Mary was a great champion of French art and culture and a generous supporter of the Frick. Most important, Mary was a dear friend. She will be remembered for her love of art and for her warmth, generosity of spirit, and graciousness. We send our sincere condolences to her husband, John, and to her family. Margot Bogert, Chairman; Ian Wardropper, Director; Colin B. Bailey, Deputy Director and Peter Jay Sharp Chief Curator

KARTIGANER--Esther. Esther and Audrey met in sixth grade and together they became members of the "Sparklers." Audrey will forever treasure those Washington Heights years, including the many Broadway shows she and Esther went to see together as teenagers. Over 50 years of memories shared with Esther, and with Mr. and Mrs. K, Joe, Debbie and Alison, are in our thoughts. Esther loved being Auntie Mame to her adored nieces, Debbie and Alison, and they loved her back. She also genuinely shared in our joy of experiencing many special highlights as Eric and Mark grew up. Esther was the consummate networker among her huge circle of friends. Esther, you bonded your friends "to thy soul with hoops of steel" and in return you and all of your noble qualities will live forever in the hearts of your many friends. Audrey and Harvey Feuerstein

CRISP--Dr. William E. A leading OB/GYN surgeon, inventor, author of 100 plus publications, int'l teacher and humanitarian, passed away July 20, 2012. For full obit, tributes and service info visit: www.drwilliamecrisp.forever missed.com

SPANIER--Dr. Ktziah Ben-Dov, PhD, born December 3, 1940 in Tiberius, Israel, passed away peacefully at home on Thursday August 2nd. She valiantly fought the ravages of Alzheimer's disease for the past 10 years. She is survived by her loving husband Sidney, her three children Noam, Talia and Eitan, as well as 11 grandchildren. Also surviving are her brother and sister Zohar and Chana. She was a true academician who was well published and lectured prolifically on the central role of women in the Hebrew Bible. Dr. Spanier taught at the New School and Hunter College as well as guest lecturing at Yale University and Dartmouth College. She was an amazing women who balanced a successful career in real estate, and a full academic career while also caring for her parents and nurturing her children and her husband as well. Her accomplishments were vast including a founding role at the Corlears School where she served as the first president of its board. She was a fine photographer in her own right and studied with Lisette Model. She always kept a diary. More than 10 years ago when she first realized that she was having true memory lapses she wrote: "Time is running out. Here is a list of the things I want to accomplish before it is too late..."Number one on the list was to have her PHD thesis published as a book. Sadly, she was working on this diligently until she could no longer complete the task. Services will be held on Sunday, August 5th, 2012 at 11am at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC. The family will observe Shivah at their Tribeca home located at 466 Washington St., Apt 8W. Visitors are welcome Sunday, Monday and Tuesday from 5 to 8pm. Donations in her memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

Kayak has upgraded its iPhone app, allowing users to book flights, hotel rooms and car rentals on their mobile phones without going to third-party Web sites. The new version, which also includes an auto-fill function that prevents users from having to enter their data repeatedly, comes a month after a similar upgrade by Orbitz. Kayak's new app was partly inspired by travelers who used the mobile app to search for flights but found it so time-consuming to complete additional reservations that they switched over to desktop computers to do so. ''We wanted to let them finish their thought and not have to save it for later,'' said Bill O'Donnell, the app's chief architect.

Unlike its counterpart in the United States, the BBC is providing marathon live coverage during the Games, with 24 live feeds from different events.
As fighting continued throughout Syria, the rebels insisted that their hostages were members of Iran’s elite Revolutionary Guards, not religious pilgrims.

There were bagels. There was badminton. And, in the end, there was bitter disappointment. At the CP Badminton Club in College Point, Queens, where groups of Malaysians often gather to play the game, about 25 enthusiasts gathered over breakfast early Sunday morning to watch the Olympic men's singles final between Lee Chong Wei of Malaysia and Lin Dan of China, the world's two best players and archrivals.

An article on July 7 about children who died of preventable illnesses like diarrhea in the overcrowded Jamam refugee camp in South Sudan gave an incorrect figure from the aid group Doctors Without Borders for the average daily number of such deaths at the time. Deaths averaged about three a day, not nine. (The group said last Monday that the error was discovered during a recent standard internal review of epidemiological surveys results.)

GUYADER--Claudine, on August 3, 2012. Beloved Daughter of Cecile and the late Etienne Guyader. Loving mother of Lucas Romeo. Fond sister of Christine. To all our friends and family and Le Boeuf a la Mode, Adieu. Visiting Monday 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Hillebrand Funeral Homes 63-17 Woodhaven Blvd Rego Park NY 11374. Services Tuesday 11am at St. Sebastian RC Church 58-02 Roosevelt Ave., Woodside NY 11377. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to American Cancer Society.

Esther Kartiganer, who as senior producer in charge of vetting content on CBS's ''60 Minutes'' became entangled in a controversy over a program that raised questions about President George W. Bush's military service during the Vietnam War, died on Wednesday in Aspen, Colo. She was 74. The cause was a heart attack, said her brother, Joseph.

An article on July 24 about the Israeli government's seeking to demolish eight Palestinian hamlets in the South Hebron Hills, part of what is known as Area C, which is under full Israeli control, misstated the number of Palestinians living in the area. And because of an editing error, a correction in this space on July 27 misstated the source of the incorrect number. The Palestinian Central Bureau of Statistics puts the number at 117,000; the Israeli government estimates 92,000, and the United Nations Officer for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs says 150,000. There are not 50,000 Palestinians living in Area C, a figure provided by an advocate for Israeli settlers -- not by an advocate for the Palestinians.

Does voter fraud sometimes happen in the United States? You bet. But we are dealing with this relatively small problem in an irrational and partisan way. In a 1996 primary in Dodge County, Ga., rival camps for county commissioner set up tables at opposite ends of the county courthouse and bid for voters' absentee votes in what a county magistrate later called a ''flea market'' atmosphere.

An article last Monday about plans for a housing project near the Salton Sea in California misidentified the city where the project's developer, Federated Insurance, is based. It is Owatonna, Minn., not Milwaukee.

It just goes to show. You can unleash all the star power and venture capital in your arsenal to get a new start-up off the ground, but at the end of the day, people either love your service or they don't. Right now, people do not seem to be loving Airtime, the flashy video-chatting site introduced in June by Sean Parker and Shawn Fanning, the founding team behind the Napster music sharing service.
Barring a total surprise, the next big thing in the 2012 presidential race will be Mitt Romney's choice of a running mate. But will it be announced this week?

Job numbers for July were released on Friday, and there was plenty of presidential campaign spin, discussion about economic significance and predictions about how the Federal Reserve would react. In July, 163,000 jobs were created, up from 64,000 in June. The unemployment rate rose from 8.2 to 8.3 percent (the unemployment measure that includes part-time workers seeking full-time positions and those who have stopped looking is at 15 percent). Many seem to be job-hunting: there were 758 million visits to job sites in July, an increase of 18 percent over July 2011. SHELLY FREIERMAN
INTERACTIVE GRAPHIC Bob Beamon's performance in the long jump in the 1968 Mexico City Olympics would beat the winner in London, Greg Rutherford of Britain, by about two feet. www.nytimes.com/sports

An article on Wednesday about a number of tense and violent movies coming out this fall and winter, and possible competition among films released within a short time frame, misstated the scheduled release date for ''Parental Guidance,'' a comedy starring Bette Midler. It is scheduled to be released on Christmas Day, the same day as ''The Guilt Trip'' starring Barbra Streisand, not on Thanksgiving.

Top Republicans condemned Senator Harry Reid Sunday, accusing the Senate majority leader of fabricating an assertion that an unnamed Bain Capital investor had told him that Mitt Romney has not paid taxes over a 10-year period. ''I just cannot believe that the majority leader of the United States Senate would take the floor twice, make accusations that are absolutely unfounded, in my view, and quite frankly making things up to divert the campaign away from the real issues,'' Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, said on CNN's ''State of the Union.''

PHELANJohn J.,beloved husband, father and grandfather passed away at the age of 81 on Saturday, August 5, 2012. He was the dear husband of his wife of 57 years, Joyce C. Phelan; father of three sons, John, David and Peter; and grandfather of Grace, Campbell, David, Kate, Malcolm and Ian. He was a staff sergeant in the U.S. Marine Corps and served in combat in the Korean War during 1951-1952. He was a long time specialist on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange and rose to be chairman of the exchange from 1984 to his retirement in 1990. He achieved a long record of public service including serving as Chairman of President Reagan's Private Sector Initiative Board and helping both China and Russia to open their capital markets. He was an active and engaged board member at corporations including Merrill Lynch, MetLife, Eastman Kodak, Sonat and Avon Products He was a graduate of Adelphi University and became a leading advocate for the school serving as the chairman of the board of trustees from 1981-1986 and acting as a friend and advisor to the university throughout the following years. In addition to a wide range of charitable interest and endeavors, in recent years he enthusiastically embraced an active career as chairman of Catholic Charities, an organization which serves thousands of under-privileged New Yorkers of all faiths every year. Donations may be made in lieu of flowers to Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese, New York, 1011 1st Avenue, New York, New York 10002. The Phelan family to receive visitors at Frank E. Campbell at 1076 Madison Avenue, New York on Tuesday August 7th from 2:00-5:00pm and 7:00-9:00pm. A funeral mass in his honor will be held at St. Patrick's Cathedral on Wednesday, August 8th at 10:00am.

The percentage of the earth's land surface covered by extreme heat in the summer has soared in recent decades, from less than 1 percent in the years before 1980 to as much as 13 percent in recent years, according to a new scientific paper .The change is so drastic, the paper says, that scientists can claim with near certainty that events like the Texas heat wave last year , the Russian heat wave of 2010 and the European heat wave of 2003 would not have happened without the planetary warming caused by the human release of greenhouse gases.

WEYMOUTH, England - The bubonic plague is said to have come ashore in this coastal town, carried by fleas infected by rats. The so-called Black Death quickly spread throughout the British Isles. ''We try to play that one down, especially in light of some people's thinking about British food,'' Lorraine Morris of the county tourism office said.

DEAR DIARY: I am used to seeing people sitting in their cars until the magic time of 10:30 a.m., when parking is safe on that side of the street. But the other day in Chelsea, there was a different sight. There was a man sitting beside his car on a folding armchair, with a sun hat, comfortably reading a paper. It was after the magic hour of 10:30.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about the use of contraception to manage zoo populations misidentified the institution where the wolf shown in the photograph is housed. It is the Endangered Wolf Center in Eureka, Mo., not the St. Louis Zoo.

WURTZEL--Leo A.,87, of Palm Beach, FL. Died on August 1, 2012. Survived by wife Patricia Rubel Wurtzel, son Melvin Elliot Wurtzel, daughter Robin Wurtzel, Esq. and son-in-law Carl Varady, Esq. Grandchildren Ezra Varady and Sophia Varady. Also survived by his sisters Perle, Elaine and Dolores. Funeral Monday 10:30am, Mt. Ararat.

LEVINE--Stanley H.,Monroe, NJ, longtime resident of Metuchen, NJ. died August 1, 2012 at age 83. Longtime developmental optometrist, inventor, entrepreneur and visionary. Husband of Suzanne Levine (d.2001), survived by sister Janice Grow, daughters Hana Levine (Tzvi), Amy Levine Samuels (Jeffrey), Dinah Harmon, companion Gloria Kowalski, seven grandchildren, three great-grandchildren, nieces, nephews, many beloved friends and thousands of grateful patients and colleagues worldwide. Contributions in Dr. Levine's memory may be made to College of Syntonic Optometry, 2052 W. Morales Dr., Pueblo West, CO 81007.

Advent International said Sunday that it had agreed to buy a majority stake in the parent company of Serta and Simmons bedding, taking control of one of the country's biggest makers of mattresses. The deal for AOT Bedding Super Holdings is valued at about $3 billion, according to a person briefed on the matter. Ares Management and the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, which previously controlled AOT Bedding, will maintain sizable minority stakes in the company.

To those who thought ''Jersey Shore'' would not or could not survive for three full years, MTV is proving otherwise. The network has set a premiere date for the sixth season of this much-mocked but also much-watched reality show and has ordered a second season of the spinoff ''Snooki and JWoww,'' which features these two ''Jersey Shore'' cast members living elsewhere in New Jersey. The original ''Shore'' will return on Oct. 4 (in its usual Thursday night time slot) and is expected to wrap up in December, around the time the series had its start in 2009. MTV has not committed to a seventh season, raising the possibility that the sixth will be the last. Though its ratings have dropped (the fifth-season finale had about five million viewers, while some prior season finales had six to eight million), the franchise remains MTV's highest-rated reality show.

An article on Thursday about Chick-fil-A restaurants as a battlefield in the culture war over gay marriage misidentified the author of a Web article who said, ''It's still possible to get your fried chicken sandwich fix and keep your moral principles intact.'' The writer is Sarah Laskow of the Web site Grist -- not J. Kenji L''pez-Alt of the site Serious Eats. (Ms. Laskow was responding to a column by Mr. L''pez-Alt on how to prepare a version of the Chick-fil-A sandwich at home.)

END--Jacqueline The world has lost an amazing woman, loving sister, aunt, and friend, a multi-talented artist, published author, famous advertising writer, astoundingly gifted cook, photographer and lover of animals, particularly cats. She is survived by her devoted brother Joseph Arlotta, niece Kyra Arlotta, and her cat, Susie. Jackie enjoyed a celebrated career as an award-winning copywriter and creative director in advertising, creating famous advertising for some of the most heralded agencies which includes Doyle Dane Bernbach; Chiatay; and Wells Rich Greene. She was loved and respected by her peers and colleagues. She was known for creating the Freakies cereal and the band of animated "misfit" characters that introduced the hit cereal to America. She is also known for the Bic Banana commercials which she worked on with Mel Brooks. She created famous advertising for Volkswagen, Absolut, Nivea, and so many more. Just a few things we will remember and forever cherish about Jackie: her brilliant sense of humor, intelligence, exquisite beauty and elegance, her kindness, her wisdom, her magical and beautiful holiday gingerbread cookies, her breath-taking flower photography, her clever writings, sophisticated style and huge heart, her generous desire to help anyone in need and her sense of magic. A spirited libertarian, Jackie was a dedicated patriot and fierce defender of the constitution. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Humane Society or the ASPCA would be appreciated. Memorial service Wednesday August 22, 2012, 5pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., NYC.

LEIPER--Leslie. On August 2, 2012, aged 78, at home in Alexandria, VA. Beloved father of Karen Haffmans and loving grandfather of Olivia and Maarten Haffmans. Along with friend and business partner Dora Clarke, Leslie is one of the founding partners of Clarke Leiper PLLC in Alexandria, VA. Leslie is also survived by Helen Leiper of Sarasota, FL and Eleanor Sullivan of Watertown, NY. Services are pending for a celebration of life on September 24, 2012 in or around Alexandria, VA. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Leslie's name to the Covenant House in New York or the Central Union Mission in Washington, DC.

SUSSMAN--Iona. Died peacefully at home on August 4th, 2012 in West Palm Beach, Fla at 94. Longtime resident of Great Neck, NY. Adoring wife of the late Maurice. Devoted mother of Gordon and Ellen, Edward and Janice. Loving grandmother of Rodney, Clifford, Adam, Joshua and Jake. Estatic great grandmother of Devon. Iona was a woman of great strength, warmth and tenacity. There wasn't anything she couldn't accomplish. Young at heart she lived life her way and will be greatly missed. Interment private.

A listing of credits on Wednesday with a theater of a production of ''Love's Labour's Lost'' by the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival, in Garrison, N.Y., omitted the given name of the actor who plays Longaville. He is Charlie Francis Murphy, not Francis Murphy.

POLLOCK--Theodore, 80, an attorney of Port Washington, NY on August 3, 2012. Survived by Janet Effman, Mike Yallows, a daughter Peri Zausner, a son Wayne, a brother Barry and grandsons Eric and Alex Zausner. Funeral service Tuesday, August 7th at 10am Riverside Nassau North Chapel 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck.

Dear Diary: On a recent Saturday night, nay, Sunday morning, after a night of waiting tables in Times Square, I descended into the Times Square subway station to find a suspiciously packed platform, and, having just reached the end, heard the dreaded announcement that the 1 train was delayed because of a faulty uptown switch. Desperate to catch the 1:30 Staten Island Ferry home, I took action and weaved my way back through the crowd, to the N/R line. Standing on the foreign platform, wiping the sweat from my brow, I checked my watch, again and again, until zero hour had passed, and I knew my fate rested in the hands of a 2:30 boat.

Dear Diary: The Chelsea post office on 23rd and 10th is so full of dysfunction, I couldn't possibly write down every quip I overhear there. But one woman's recent outburst caught me completely off-guard. She went to the window and asked one of the station's trademark surly tellers what kind of stamps they had.

Prepaid phone plans, where you pay the full price for a cellphone and then pay lower monthly rates without a contract, seem to offer what most budget-conscious people want. So why haven't they really caught on? Contract-free phone plans account for only 23 percent of the wireless customers in the United States phone market, according to the research firm Ovum. The rest are subscribers locked into contracts and paying higher monthly fees.

An article last Monday about the growing role of homegrown Muslim jihadists and small groups of fighters from Al Qaeda in the armed struggle against the Syrian government of President Bashar al-Assad misstated the surname of a Syria analyst with the International Crisis Group. He is Peter Harling, not Harding.

Who will keep an eye on the eyes in the sky? Representative Edward Markey, Democrat from Massachusetts, said he planned to introduce legislation that would compel those who seek a federal license to fly drones to spell out what they will do with the information they collect and how long they will hold on it.

Before women go to the mall, they go to the shopping bible Lucky. Now the magazine wants to save them the price of gas. On Aug. 17, the magazine will introduce a shopping site called mylucky.com that will direct readers to buy clothing and accessories directly from more than a dozen retailers like Macy's and Sephora.

Dear Diary: It was my birthday and I got myself a new bike, Pinky: a small, hot pink, Ross bike. Pinky came to me by way of Craigslist for $60. While walking out of my apartment building in one of New York City's safest ZIP codes, I found Pinky absent from both spots where I usually park her: the bike rack and the old parking meter cemented into the ground.

Most people are so ignorant they don't know the difference between religions. Just because they see the turban they think you're Taliban. RAVI CHAWLA, a Sikh who moved to Wisconsin from Pakistan in the 1970s, on a shooting at a Sikh temple in Oak Creek, Wis. [A9]

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Wednesday about nominations for the MTV Video Music Awards erroneously included the singer Alicia Keys as the host of the awards ceremony on Sept. 6. She is scheduled to perform; no host has yet been announced.

Major banks, which often band together when facing government scrutiny, are now turning on one another as an international investigation into the manipulation of interest rates gains momentum. With billions of dollars and their reputations on the line, financial institutions have been spreading the blame in recent meetings with authorities, according to government and bank officials with knowledge of the matter. While acknowledging their own wrongdoing, institutions are pointing out actions at other banks that they believe are worse - and in some cases, extend to top executives.

As it strains to come up with new hit shows, Oprah Winfrey's cable network, OWN, is giving an opportunity to Michael Jackson's sister La Toya Jackson. The series, ''Life With La Toya,'' was announced on Thursday along with two other series for 2013, ''Neighborvention'' and ''The Customer Is Always Right.'' OWN said the show about Ms. Jackson, who is 56, would be a ''candid look inside the life of the outspoken Jackson sibling,'' one of Katherine and Joe Jackson's nine children.

5 P.M. (Fox Movie Channel) WAG THE DOG (1997) Robert De Niro plays Conrad Brean, a government spin doctor who recruits a Hollywood producer (Dustin Hoffman, above left, with Anne Heche and Mr. De Niro) to help him create a fake war with Albania to distract the American public from discovering a presidential sex scandal. ''Made in the witty screwball spirit of a Preston Sturges comedy, and filmed so fast (in 29 days) that none of its bright spontaneity gets lost, 'Wag the Dog' essentially amounts to a huge inside joke,'' Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. Barry Levinson directed the movie from a script by David Mamet and Hilary Henkin, based on a book by Larry Beinhart. ''It's possible that viewers indifferent to political and media chicanery will miss some of the barbs here,'' Ms. Maslin wrote. ''But those same gags will fill savvier audiences with wicked glee.'' 10 A.M. (NBC) 2012 LONDON OLYMPICS The first track-and-field events of the day include qualifying rounds for the women's 100-meter hurdles and the men's 800 meters. At 2:30 p.m. on MSNBC the Greco-Roman wrestling medal winners will be determined. At 3 p.m. on NBC the American men's volleyball team takes the court against Tunisia. At 5:15 p.m. on NBC Sports the men's basketball team faces Argentina.

Archaeologists working in Turkey have discovered a giant statue of a Neo-Hittite king that dates back 3,000 years.The partly broken sculpture of the king's head and torso stands nearly five feet tall, and the full sculpture may have been more than 10 feet, said Timothy P. Harrison , an archaeologist from the University of Toronto who was part of the team that made the discovery .

10:09 p.m. | Updated The Knight Capital Group reached a deal on Sunday to secure a financial lifeline from an investor group that included TD Ameritrade and the Blackstone Group, capping its efforts to stay alive, people with direct knowledge of the matter said. The lifeline came together days after the trading firm disclosed a $440 million trading loss tied to a glitch in its software that sent shares in 148 companies gyrating on Wednesday.

SAN JOSE, Calif. - Back in the early 1930s, a magician by the name of Horace Goldin went to court to defend his signature illusion: sawing a woman in half. Mr. Goldin filed a lawsuit against the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company for using this magic trick in an advertisement and explaining how it worked. According to an article in The New York Times from March 1933, Mr. Goldin, who had won a patent for the illusion a decade earlier, asserted that the ad had adversely affected his ability to get people to see his shows. He asked for $50,000 in damages. (That's about $865,000 in today's dollars.)

LONDON - It's not easy being a professional athlete with an auto-immune disease, but the American tennis star Venus Williams is getting by with a little help from her sister Serena. On Sunday the Williams sisters returned to the All England Club, where last month they won their fifth Wimbledon doubles title, and secured their third Olympic women's doubles title with a 6-4, 6-4 victory against Andrea Hlavackova and Lucie Hradecka of the Czech Republic. The sisters' other Olympic doubles titles came in Sydney in 2000 and Beijing in 2008. They are the first to win the same Olympic tennis event three times. With their four gold medals apiece - Venus won the singles in 2000 and Serena on Saturday - they equaled the career total of Max Decugis, a Frenchman whose heyday spanned the years from 1900 to 1920.

The Advertising column on Friday, about a new Tide detergent campaign starring the actress Betty White, misstated the date when she will appear on a live video feed on Tide's Facebook page. It is Aug. 23, not Aug. 13.

Usain Bolt repeated his win in the 100-meter dash on Sunday, with a blistering 9.63, an Olympic record. But how fast is that in the context of all sprinters ever to land on the podium? The diagram below shows where 116 years' worth of medalists would be relative to Bolt at the finish in London. Among the pack trailing Bolt: Carl Lewis, the only other person to win this event back-to-back in the modern Games, is about 10 feet back. Jesse Owens, who won four golds in Berlin in 1936? He's 20 feet back. 2012 LONDON

Add ''Total Recall'' to the list of remakes that go thud. Sony, betting in part on advancements in visual effects and fond memories of the 1990 original, spent at least $200 million to make and market a new version starring Colin Farrell in the role Arnold Schwarzenegger made famous. But moviegoers weren't feeling it: ''Total Recall'' took in about $26 million at North American theaters over the weekend, a distant second behind ''The Dark Knight Rises,'' which was No. 1 for the third weekend in a row, with about $36.4 million in ticket sales ($354.6 million total over three weeks). The continued popularity of ''The Dark Knight Rises,'' a Warner Brothers release, may have hurt ''Total Recall.'' The London Olympics and continued skittishness following last month's theater shootings in Colorado may also have taken a toll. But ''Total Recall'' was also just not considered very good: audiences gave it a C-plus grade in exit polls. ''We performed in line with tracking and industry expectations,'' a Sony spokesman said, adding that the film did well in limited release overseas in spots like Malaysia and Taiwan.

LONDON -- Nine months after the Beijing Games, Michael Phelps was in the weight room at Loyola College in Maryland when a photograph of Brett Favre flashed on a nearby television as part of an ESPN report that Favre was considering coming out of retirement a second time. Phelps turned to his coach, Bob Bowman, and said, ''That will never be me.''

The heavy-hitters in the rapidly growing comedy podcast universe are mostly located on the West Coast. Marc Maron's "WTF," and " Comedy Bang! Bang! " are both based in Los Angeles, as are the major podcast networks like Earwolf , Nerdist and Maximum Fun . But this geographic imbalance might start to change with the announcement, scheduled for Monday, that Splitsider , the popular New York comedy site under the umbrella of The Awl Web family, is starting its own podcast network.Each podcast will have a homepage on the site and be promoted as a news item. Splitsider will also help sell ads, book guests and put together live shows with talent from the podcasts. Splitsider will start a new improv-based podcast called "Make Yourself Comfy With Abra Tabak," but its slate already has six other podcasts, including "You Had to Be There," a show starring Nikki Glaser and Sara Schaefer that was recently turned into an MTV series set for 2013; "The Complete Guide to Everything," featuring Tim Daniels and Tom Reynolds challenging Wikipedia; and "The Jeff Rubin Jeff Rubin Show," about video games, comic books and other nerd fetish items.
2012 LONDON

HELFMAN--Donald J. Devoted son of Lenore and Jerry. Loving father to Brian and Dani. He cherished his brother Dennis and his wife Jane. He adored his niece Lauren and her children, Julia and Lyla and niece Lindsey. He touched and enriched the lives of his many friends. Svetlana, we thank you. Donald, we miss you already.

A new study suggests that offering paid sick leave might reduce the rate of nonfatal injury among workers and improve the bottom line at the same time.Using data on about 38,000 workers from a national survey conducted by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, researchers found that from 2005 to 2008 the injury rate per 100 workers among those with paid sick leave was 2.59, compared with 4.18 among those without.

PHELANJohn J.,Jr., beloved husband, father and grandfather passed away at the age of 81 on Saturday, August 4, 2012. He was the dear husband of his wife of 57 years, Joyce C. Phelan; father of three sons, John, David and Peter; and grandfather of Grace, Campbell, David, Kate, Malcolm and Ian. John was also a beloved and caring brother of his two sisters, Elizabeth, who survives him, and Susan, who predeceased him. He was a staff sergeant in the U.S. Marine Corps and served in combat in the Korean War during 1951-1952. He was a long time specialist on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange and rose to be chairman of the exchange from 1984 to his retirement in 1990. He achieved a long record of public service including serving as Chairman of President Reagan's Private Sector Initiative Board and helping both China and Russia to open their capital markets. He was an active and engaged board member at corporations including Merrill Lynch, MetLife, Eastman Kodak, Sonat and Avon Products. He was a graduate of Adelphi University and became a leading advocate for the school serving as the chairman of the board of trustees from 1981-1986 and acting as a friend and advisor to the university throughout the following years. In addition to a wide range of charitable interests and endeavors, in recent years he enthusiastically embraced an active career as chairman of Catholic Charities, an organization which serves thousands of under-privileged New Yorkers of all faiths every year. Donations in his name may be made in lieu of flowers to Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, 1011 1st Avenue, New York, New York 10022. The Phelan family will receive visitors at Frank E. Campbell at 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, on Tuesday, August 7th from 2:00-5:00pm and 7:00-9:00pm. A funeral mass in his honor will be held at St. Patrick's Cathedral on Wednesday, August 8th at 10:00am.

When his mother's kidneys began to fail three years ago, Ed Guillen knew what he had to do: donate one of his kidneys to her. But Mr. Guillen received a shock during a phone call with the Stanford Kidney Transplant Clinic, where his mother was being treated. He was ineligible to be a donor, even before tests to see if he was a genetic match.At 5-foot-10 and around 280 pounds, Mr. Guillen, a 39-year-old software developer in Redmond, Wash., was considered too heavy to donate an organ without potentially endangering his own health. He would need to lose more than 70 pounds, he was told, before the clinic would consider him as a candidate.

SEGAL--Martin E.,a man of great accomplishment and generosity, hero to family, friends, and colleagues, died at age 96 at home on August 5 after a very short illness, just four days after happily attending the Mostly Mozart opening. Predeceased in June 2011 by his wife of 74 years, Edith Levy Segal, he leaves his children, Susan Rai and Paul; his children-in-law, Kanti Rai and Christine Flynn; his grandchildren, Samantha and Joshua Rai, Emma Segal, and Sarah Flynn; his grandson-in-law, Jay Zaslow; his great-granddaughters, Ella and Mira Zaslow; his siblings Hylan Segal and Esther Maidenbaum; and many nieces and nephews and their children. Funeral services private. No flowers, please. Family will receive friends on Wednesday, August 8; Thursday, August 9; and Monday August 13 from 5:00 to 8:00pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. A memorial celebration will be held on Wednesday, September 12 at 5:00pm at Lincoln Center's Alice Tully Hall, Broadway at 65 Street.
