AS a child in Pennsylvania, Maggie Schaffer dreamed of working in an art gallery after watching Kristin Davis as the sweet Charlotte York in ''Sex and the City.'' But '' GALLERY GIRLS ,'' a docudrama making its premiere Monday at 10 p.m. on Bravo, is more ''The Real Housewives of New York City'' meets ''Mean Girls.''A variation on pitting pseudo-socialites against strivers, the series follows seven gallerinas who'd do almost anything to break into the city's art world -- as long as they don't have to crack their ennui. For the Upper East Side: Liz Margulies, the daughter of the art collector Martin Z. Margulies, and her fellow intern at Eli Klein Fine Art, Ms. Schaffer; and Amy Poliakoff, at Coplan Hurowitz Art Advisory, and her colleague Kerri Lisa, a Long Islander. Representing Brooklyn: Chantal Chadwick and Claudia Martinez Reardon, the owners of End of Century, a gallery cum boutique on the Lower East Side, and Angela Pham, an aspiring photographer fond of going topless.

HERSHEY--Roslyn. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Roslyn Hershey, mother and mother-in-law of Ellen and Robert Kapito. Roslyn's commitment to the Jewish community lives on through the generosity of her family. We extend our condolences to Ellen and Robert; to her other children, Helaine and Dennis; to her grandchildren; to her great-grandchildren; and to the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

To the Editor: Regarding '' Myanmar: It's Complicated '' (cover, Aug. 5), there's nothing complicated about visiting Myanmar. If you can travel low to the ground and avoid the finest hotels, very little of your money will go to the government. Kent Foster Oakhurst, Calif.

The Big Deal column last Sunday, about rising taxes in Britain and other European countries, described incorrectly the status of a plan by the French president, François Hollande, to tax the incomes of the wealthy by more than 70 percent. Parliament has yet to vote on the proposal; the taxes have not taken effect.

WELLS--David. The beloved cellist and founder of Yellow Barn, died peacefully in his home in Putney, VT on August 7, 2012. David's last wish was to express his gratitude to his students and colleagues, especially to his wife Janet, for the incredible happiness music has brought him. In remembrance of David, donations can be made to Yellow Barn.

To the Sports Editor:Re ''At Site of Heartbreak, Murray Overwhelms Federer for Gold,'' Aug. 6: The Olympic gold medal tennis match between Roger Federer of Switzerland and Andy Murray of Britain was highly disappointing.

A picture caption on July 29 with the Video column , about the French film director Jean Grémillon, misidentified the actress shown with Charles Vanel. She is Madeleine Renaud -- not Thérèse Gauthier, who is her character in the film ''Le Ciel Est à Vous.'' The caption also misspelled Vanel's surname as Venal.

PETERSON--Iver. June 30, 1942 - August 1, 2012. Iver Peterson, son of Oliver and Esther Peterson, labor and consumer rights advocates, was born on June 30th, 1942, in Brattleboro, VT, and died on Wednesday, August 1, 2012, cause of death Acute Myeloid Leukemia. He is survived by his wife Chris, his four children and five grandchildren: Heath and Angela Peterson (Chloe and Connor), Kelicia and Bob Sparano (Raquel, Robert, and Michael), Holly Peterson, and Lars Peterson, three siblings, Karen Wilken, Eric Peterson (and his wife Jani) and Lars Peterson, and dozens of nephews, nieces, and grand-nephews and grand-nieces. After graduating Harvard in 1964, Iver spent several years in Vietnam working for the US Government, and for The New York Times as a correspondent. He continued his career with The New York Times at several bureaus throughout the US. Iver was the public affairs officer at the Jordan International Police Training Center for the Iraqi Police Program where his wife was the Deputy Chief of Firearms. He loved vintage cars and the open road, and spent much of his retirement freelancing travel stories. Traveling with family and friends was his way of blending devotion of those he loved with work. He was a member of the choir at The Presbyterian Church of Lawrenceville, NJ, where a memorial service was held on August 3rd. He was also recognized at Lawrenceville's Church of St. Ann at their 75th Anniversary mass. His ministry there was mainly with the church's sister parish in San Andres, El Ciche, Guatemala. Family and friends will gather at their Vermont summer home on Saturday, August 18 to celebrate his life.

CLURMAN--Marilyn M. (Mimi), died peacefully August 7. After attending the universities of Wisconsin and Chicago, she earned a Masters of Social Work from Yeshiva University in New York City, where she practiced for over 30 years. Cherished mother of Susan Emma and Carol Clurman, adored grandmother of Anna and Michael Duning, and admired mother-in-law of Paul Duning and Richard De Rose, Mimi will always be treasured for her love, intelligence and beauty. The family plans a private memorial. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in her honor to the Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 East 77th St., New York, 10075.

HEINEMAN--Ben W.,Sr. Ben W. Heineman Sr., of Chicago, died on August 5, 2012, at age 98. He was revered as a giant of his generation--a brilliant lawyer, a far-sighted businessman, an adviser to presidents, governors and mayors, a prominent Chicago leader, a deeply committed supporter of opera and symphony, an influential trustee of the University of Chicago, and a world-class collector of contemporary glass. These and many other accomplishments reflected a person of extraordinary character, integrity and, independence, whose life truly deserved the phrases "business statesman" and "Renaissance man." He was a warm, witty, wise and caring counselor to many and, ultimately, an exemplary citizen of his city, his state, and his country. Ben was born in Wausau, Wisconsin, on February 10, 1914, six months before the start of World War I, the son of Walter Benjamin and Elsie Brunswick Heineman. After his family lost all its money in 1929, he attended the University of Michigan from 1930 to 1933 and then Northwestern Law School, graduating in 1936 at the top of his class and as the editor of the law review. His legal career spanned the next 20 years. He was a leading corporate lawyer in Chicago. Ben had deep friendships with the faculty at the University of Chicago law school (especially then-Dean Edward Levi, later University President). With professors and practitioners, he helped write the first version of the Uniform Commercial Code, a pillar of American law. During World War II, he served as assistant general counsel in the Office of Price Administration and then as assistant director of the North African Economic board. In 1951, Governor Adlai E. Stevenson appointed him special assistant attorney general to investigate Illinois' cigarette tax fraud. In 1952, he worked on the Stevenson Presidential campaign, drafting the Stevenson speech sharply criticizing Sen. Joseph McCarthy. In 1956, he was named CEO of the Chicago and Northwestern Railway after he led a successful proxy fight for dissident shareholders. He became a leading American businessman, as a dramatic innovator in a traditional industry, modernizing operating methods, reshaping labor relations, turning Chicago's commuter rail service into an acclaimed model for the nation, seeking de-regulation and greater competition. In 1968, he transformed the railway into a conglomerate, Northwest Industries, with industrial and consumer components. In 1972, he sold the railroad to its employees who benefited from the sale. Ben retired as CEO of Northwest in 1985, at age 71, having demonstrated the controversial conglomerate form of business could succeed with strong central resource allocation and decentralized responsibility. During his 30 years in business he also took on many governmental assignments. He served President Lyndon Johnson in numerous capacities, including chairman of the White House Conference on Civil Rights (1966); President's Task Force on Government Organization (1966-67); President's Commission on Income Maintenance Programs (1968). A "Man in the News" article in the New York Times called him "a can-do man with a conscience." He chaired the Illinois Board of Higher Education from 1962-69, developing master plans approved ultimately by the state legislature. In 1966, at the height of racial tension, Mayor Richard Daley appointed him chair of the Chicago Civil Rights Summit Conference on Fair Housing. But he turned down federal Cabinet positions and requests to run for public office, preferring to take on ad hoc assignments and retain his base as a private civic leader. He was a leading (and then life) trustee of the University of Chicago, of the Art Institute of Chicago, the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and the Chicago Lyric Opera. He also served on many other corporate and charitable boards. The great foundation of Ben's life was his beloved wife, Natalie Goldstein Heineman, a national leader in child welfare services. They married on April 17, 1935. She died on February 28, 2010, just shy of their 75th wedding anniversary. As a couple, they exemplified civic commitment. They were also great adventurers and world travelers, e.g. sailing alone, into their early 80s, on their 62-foot sailboat along the beautiful but desolate North shore of Lake Superior. Ben loved cars, skiing, skeet shooting, photography, woodworking, computers (he was one of the first CEOs to have a desk-top) and reading. They were deeply attached to their summer home in Door County, Wisconsin, on a 200-foot limestone cliff looking westward over Green Bay, where they often welcomed friends and family. One of their greatest adventures after Ben's retirement was assembling one of the nation's largest and finest private collections of contemporary studio glass. In 2006, Ben and Natalie gave the entire collection, valued at nearly $10 million, to the Corning Museum of Glass in Corning, New York, where all 240 objects by 87 international artists will be shown permanently on a rotating basis. Ben is survived by his daughter Dr. Martha Heineman Pieper (Dr. William Pieper) of Chicago and their children: Thalia Field (Jamie Jewett and son Benjamin), Dr. Jessica Heineman-Pieper (Dr. Param Srikantia), Johanna Heineman-Pieper, and Victoria Stein (Jotham Stein and son Gershon). He is also survived by his son, Ben W. Heineman, Jr. (Cristine Russell) of New Canaan, CT and their sons Zachary Heineman and Matthew Heineman. There will be a private family service. In lieu of flowers, donations in the name of Ben W. Heineman Sr. can be made to The Natalie G. Heineman Smart Love Pre-school, 800 W. Buena Avenue, Chicago, IL 60613 or online at www.smartlovefamily.org/ contribute.php.

WEINSTEIN--Grace W.,age 76, beloved wife of Stephen, sister of Ellis Wohlner (and Joan), mother of Lawrence Weinstein (and Carol) and Janet Mercadante (and Rick), grandmother of Lee, Rachel, Samantha, and Jared. Newspaper, magazine and newsletter journalist and syndicated columnist specializing in personal finance, author of 13 books, and corporate consultant. Donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering for Dr. Larry Norton's breast cancer research or to the American Society of Journalists and Authors, Writer's Emergency Assistance Fund.

YONEMURA--Margaret V.,age 83, of Binghamton and New York City, died on August 9, 2012. Born in Blackwood, Wales, she immigrated to the USA in 1952. Survivors include husband George, daughter Isobel and James Moir, and grandchildren Ariana Moir and Stephan Oehler, and William Moir. Her professional calling was to serve the social and educational needs of young children and their families, with a particular commitment to the vulnerable and dispossessed in society. Her career culminated as Professor of Early Childhood Education and Child Development at SUNY-Binghamton. She wrote numerous scholarly articles and books and served as a national consultant in her field. Her family will honor her presence in their lives in quiet solitude. Donations in her name may be given to The Learning Center, 90 LaSalle Street, New York, NY, 10027.

I was out of money, and no money, I knew, meant exile. I'd moved to 5 states in 10 years -- California twice. In my 30s now, I had absorbed the gypsy lessons of starting fresh. I wanted to learn the art of having a home. Besides, I had finally fallen hard for San Francisco.But what to do? How to be sustainable? (A good S.F. word!) Here in the city there was always bike repair and artisanal lattes, but I had eked out a master's degree -- I aspired to the professional class. So I looked north and south, where two valleys flowered with employment: Napa and Silicon.

If the woman answering international travelers' questions as they arrive at Newark Liberty International Airport's Terminal B seems a little repetitive, she should be forgiven. She is an airport virtual assistant, otherwise known as AVA, a hologram-like display that was installed there late last month as part of a six-month trial run. La Guardia and Kennedy Airports were scheduled to get trial avatars of their own last week.The assistant, who is actually projected onto a thin transparent screen in the shape of a woman, begins offering guidance when a traveler gets within 30 feet of her, touching on topics like how to navigate ground transportation and warning passengers away from hustlers at the taxi stand.

KAPLAN--Edith Freidus, on August 11, 2012. Beloved wife of the late William. Loving mother of Susan, Deborah and Allan. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. We will miss her. Graveside service Sunday, 11am at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

RESNIK--Sybil. CancerCare mourns the passing of longtime Board member, devoted volunteer and tireless supporter, Sybil Resnik. Our sympathy to her husband, David and family. Susan Smirnoff President, Board of Directors Helen H. Miller, Chief Executive Officer

In honor of Nora Ephron, who died in June, the Big City Book Club will revisit her early work as a journalist and essayist.In the early 1960s and '70s, she wrote for magazines like Rolling Stone, New York and The New Yorker -- pieces collected in the anthologies ''Crazy Salad'' and ''Wallflower at the Orgy.'' We're going to focus on ''Wallflower'' because it's still in print. But ''Crazy Salad'' has just been reissued as an e-book, so we'll touch on it, too.

THE MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL at Lincoln Center shows its keen ear for the contemporary on Sunday evening, when the International Contemporary Ensemble presents premieres by Marcos Balter and Suzanne Farrin, alongside works by Cage, Messiaen, Jonathan Harvey, George Lewis and Kaija Saariaho, at the spacious Park Avenue Armory. Remaining tickets are limited; call ahead to check on availability. 5 p.m., 643 Park Avenue, at 67th Street, (212) 721-6500, mostlymozart.org .Back at Lincoln Center the Emerson String Quartet and friends perform Dvorak, Barber and Schubert at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening. The exciting conductor Osmo Vanska leads the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra on Tuesday and Wednesday, offering music by Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert at Avery Fisher Hall. And on Friday and Saturday the violin superstar Joshua Bell joins the music director Louis Langrée and the festival orchestra in Brahms's Violin Concerto 7:30 p.m. Monday, 8 p.m. Tuesday to Saturday, (212) 721-6500, mostlymozart.org .
Oscar nomineesFor both acting and writing:
MOUKHTAR--Mamdouh, MD. The Council and Fellows of the New York Obstetrical Society record with profound regret the recent death of their Life Fellow, Mamdouh Moukhtar, MD.

BASS--Morton. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Morton Bass, a generous philanthropist and member of our Long Island community. Together with his wife, Sandra Atlas Bass, Morton devoted his life to serving people in need. We extend our deepest sympathies to Sandra; to their children; to their grandchildren; and to the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO
MANDELL--Roy. To my dearest friend Roy Mandell, I will miss you terribly. We had such great times for so many, many years. Lou Gilson

TWO adjoining brick buildings in the Greenwich Village Historic District that in a former incarnation served as an ice cream factory, a garage and a Steinway piano showroom, sold for $32 million, and combined are the biggest sale of the week, according to city records.The properties, at 85-89 Jane Street, carried an asking price of $35 million when first listed in 2009 and marketed as ''the last great mansion site available in Greenwich Village'' by Jim St. Andre and Peter McCuen of Peter McCuen and Associates.Ultimately, 85 Jane sold for $20 million and 89 Jane for $12 million, and they are destined to be gut-renovated and reimagined on a grandiose scale as a 12,000-plus-square-foot private residence. The low-rise buildings share 110 feet of frontage on diminutive Jane Street, the quaint, cobble-stoned, tree-lined enclave that stretches for five blocks from Greenwich Avenue to the Hudson River.

ROSE--Martin E.,M.D., a retired Staten Island thoracic surgeon, died peacefully on August 6 in Manhattan after a lengthy battle with prostate cancer. Dr. Rose was born in New York City and raised in Larchmont. He attended NYU, the University of Pennsylvania, and New York Medical College. During his nearly 40 year career, Dr. Rose was Chairman of the Board of Doctors' Hospital of Staten Island and Chief of the Medical Staff at St. Vincent's Hospital of Richmond. He is survived by Inge, his wife of 57 years, and their two children, Nancy C. Rose, M.D, of Salt Lake City, Utah, and her husband Marc Jackson, M.D., and Kenneth M. Rose, M.D. of Manhattan, and his wife Jayne S. Ressler, J.D. He is also survived by four grandchildren: Lauren, Samuel, Nate, and Benjamin.

Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday about the marriage of Kerala Cowart and Andrew Eberle misidentified the jurisdiction of Judge Roy W. McLeese III, for whom the bride will be a clerk. Mr. McLeese is an associate judge of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals, not the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

The Field Notes column on July 29, about flash-mob wedding proposals, misidentified the employer of Shawn Stephens, who proposed this way. It is Forsythe, a technology consulting business, not I.B.M.

The 36 Hours column on Aug. 5, about midcoast Maine , described the area commonly called Harpswell Peninsula incorrectly. The area is one oblong peninsula with three islands connected by bridges, plus other smaller islands; it is not three peninsulas.

STENZLER--Martin Lester, 74, on August 10, 2012 in Palm Desert, CA, formerly of Scarsdale and Bedford, NY, of ALS (Lou Gehrig's Disease). He was pre-deceased by his parents Lillian and Irving Stenzler. He is survived by his wife Barbara (Zacker), his children; Abby Mallis and Jonathan Stenzler (Celeen), his sister Carolyn Glickstein (Richard) and his granddaughters; Jordan Lily Mallis, Siena Coco and Honor Stenzler. A graduate of Bronxville High School '55 and Alfred University '59; Alfred board of trustees '81-82. Served in Navy '59-61. New York-based executive for 40 years. Retired to Indian Wells, CA. Loved the Giants, the Mets and a good party! Endearingly known as a cross between Jackie Mason, Redd Foxx and Homer Simpson, Marty was renowned for his colorful use of the English language. The world will be less intriguing without him. Certainly less fun. Private funeral service, Wednesday, August 15 with Shiva following at the Glickstein home in Scarsdale, NY. Donations in his memory to The ALS Association.

IN a widely anticipated move, Dodge has announced that it will withdraw from Nascar at the end of the 2012 race season. The action was partly prompted by Penske Racing's decision earlier this year to race Ford Fusions in 2013 rather than Dodge Chargers.Dodge earned more than 150 victories in Nascar's top series in 1953-77, years in which its cars were driven by the likes of Richard Petty, Buck Baker, David Pearson and Bobby Allison. Baker and Bobby Isaac won championships at the wheel of a Dodge, and Petty set records in the 1960s in a Plymouth, Dodge's fellow Mopar brand.

THE yearlong centennial observance of the birth of ROMARE BEARDEN (born Sept. 2, 1911) is drawing to a close and the Studio Museum in Harlem , which has been pulling out the stops to celebrate his career, has organized the third and final cycle of ''The Bearden Project,'' bringing together the works of 100 contemporary artists influenced by him. The exhibition, which opens Thursday and runs through Oct. 21, will feature more than 20 artists new to the project, including Fred Wilson, Iona Rozeal Brown, Leslie Hewitt and Clifford Owens. They will join artists like Glenn Ligon, Faith Ringgold and Wangechi Mutu, who have contributed both works and words about what Bearden meant to them.The testimonials have ranged from the succinct -- ''Romie, we love you'' (Ms. Ringgold) -- to the deeply inquiring. William Pope.L wrote: ''Maybe he was too important. I couldn't fathom it back then. And now I still cannot. How did he stomach his role as the Jackie Robinson of the American art world? And where did he put all the bits of himself that could not be accepted as part of the so-called 'African-American Experience?' '' 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500, studiomuseum.org .

KOPLEFF--Florence Florence Kopleff, whom Time magazine once called the "greatest living alto," died July 24, 2012 at Hospice Atlanta. Born in New York City in 1924, Miss Kopleff became "one of the great voices America has produced" according to Harold Schonberg. She was a mainstay and soloist with the Robert Shaw Chorale from 1941-1966, and from 1967-1997 she was Artist in Residence and Professor of Voice at Georgia State University's School of Music in Atlanta. The University honored her with its Alumni Distinguished Professor Award in 1982. Miss Kopleff performed and recorded great oratorios with famous conductors George Szell, Charles Munch, Fritz Reiner, Eugene Ormandy, Jean Martinon, Maurice Abravanel, and Robert Shaw. With the Robert Shaw Chorale, she was soloist in Grammy-winning recordings of masterworks by Handel, Bach, and Britten, among others. With the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra she gave many memorable performances and innumerable group voice classes to members of the renowned ASO Chorus. "Music is my religion," she said. "I don't have a family or a business to leave to the world, so my music, which is my life's work, will be my testament." A celebration of her life will be held on September 16, 2012 at 3:00pm in the Florence Kopleff Recital Hall at Georgia State University. Memorial gifts may be sent to the Kopleff Recital Hall Endowment Fund or the Kopleff Vocal Scholarship, GSU Foundation, P.O. Box 3963, Atlanta, GA 30302.

AUERBACH--Harvey. The Atlantic Golf Club mourns the passing of member, Harvey Auerbach. We extend our sincere condolences and heartfelt sympathy to his children, Nancy and Steven. David M. Silfen, President Susan Waterfall, Secretary

CURTIS--Huntington W. Huntington Woodman Curtis spent his 90th and final summer on Bailey Island, ME eating a bit of everything that swam, crawled or lived in the sand and mud of Casco Bay. The son of Pierson and Dr. Winifred Curtis, MD, of Stony Brook, NY, he learned to navigate by the stars with a sextant, chronometer and chart at hand when day broke. The happiest of men, he spent life asking questions and seeking solutions. He died September 13 in Newburgh, NY after a short illness. Claiming to have been an uncertain student until Mt. Hermon School, he waited tables at the College of William and Mary before being appointed a teaching assistant and graduating Phi Beta Kappa in 1942 with degrees in chemistry and physics. A grandson of Presbyterian missionaries who spent 40 years in Japan, he balanced his deep faith with a sense of national duty and enlisted in the Army Signa Corp. He spent World War II and the Korean War teaching at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point and retired years later as a lieutenant colonel in the Reserves. Known as "Hunt," his studies led to a doctorate in electrical engineering and a faculty post at Dartmouth College's Thayer School. He regularly left to romp around the arctic conducting ionosphere research and took a break during the International Geophysical Year to skinny dip on the Greenland ice cap. His great passions involved science and nights spent outdoors under canvas in the rain. One of Joe Dodge's crew at the Appalachian Mountain Club, he drove donkeys loaded with supplies to huts into the White Mountains and later became a life trustee of the Mount Washington Observatory. Along the way, he married Peggy Parker of Goffstown, NH a Northfield School gal who could out-hike him and do more with an ax, a match and reflector oven than anyone he'd met. A wizard with chisel and saw, she stayed home to build furniture and raise their three children. Seeking to feed his brood, he left teaching for full-time research and the white shirt and narrow tie of an IBM engineer. From the 1960's through the mid-1990's he took one sick day a decade so he wouldn't miss the fun working in a lab with men and women who were the great poets of their crafts. He retired with Emeritus Scientist status that let him poke around the lab into his 80's. No drone, he spent free moments tinkering with clocks, paddling the Boundary Waters or under sail somewhere between Long Island Sound and Prince Edward Island. Each March, he headed to New Hampshire where sap turns into maple syrup on the north side of Bald Mountain. Predeceased by his wife, Margaret and daughter, Winifred, he is survived by sons, Henry of Kissimmee, FL, and Peter of Newburgh, NY, their families, grandson Parker Wayne of Pflugerville, TX and hordes of relatives and friends. On August 18, the tribe will gather at the head of Mackerel Cove to celebrate the life of an extraordinary man with tales, John Masefield verse and really bad yodeling.

RYAN--Drew, son of John Barry Ryan III and D.D. Ryan passed away August 7th after a long battle with liver disease. He was born December 23, 1961 in New York City. A wonderful father to his son Zephan, a talented musician, a surfer par excellence, a music lover, a lover of the arts and of New York City, Drew touched many, many people in his life. Drew leaves behind an extended family including his son, his partner Stacy Hope Herman, his brother and sister-in-law Beau and Susan Ryan, his nieces Noa and Jesse Ryan, cousins Lauren and Eric Simonson and many other relatives and friends. He will be greatly missed.

An article last Sunday about the International Contemporary Ensemble's performing Messiaen's ''Oiseaux Exotiques'' (''Exotic Birds'') as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival misidentified the avian organization that the festival asked to give preconcert bird-watching tours in Central Park. It is New York City Audubon -- not the Audubon Society, which is not affiliated with the New York group. The article also misstated the name of Suzanne Farrin's work that will be given a premiere by the International Contemporary Ensemble on Aug. 12 at the Park Avenue Armory. It is ''Serenade'' -- not ''For the Birds,'' which is the name of that day's concert.
''I want the last check I write to bounce.''Charles F. Feeney, the 81-year-old founder of the Atlantic Philanthropies, who plans to give away his last $1.5 billion by 2016.

GOLD--Martin, a singular and generous man, died on August 9, 2012. Born in the Bronx on August 30, 1923, he attended DeWitt Clinton High School ('39), CCNY ('43), and Harvard Law ('48). A WWII Army veteran, he lived in White Plains and Manhattan, and practiced law into his 80s. He liked fine wine, opera, and lemon meringue pie. He dearly loved his wife, Gloria; sister, Bernice; children Larry, Matthew, and Emily, and their spouses, Susanne, Lois, and Barney; grandchildren Marisa, David, Diana, Dana, Alice, Owen, Kira, and Clara; and his extraordinary extended family.

THE German photographer F. C. Gundlach is keen on keeping a record of his life. All of his slides, scribbles, prints and nearly every last negative have been painstakingly preserved, which made the task of narrowing down more than four decades of his work at once easy and arduous. The result, '' The Photographic Work ,'' (Steidl, $88), not only chronicles Mr. Gundlach's iconic postwar images -- including black-and-white portraits of cinema greats like Jean Cocteau and Jean-Luc Godard and shots of models like Wilhelmina Cooper and Grace Coddington -- but also explains, in the accompanying text, what Gundlach was after aesthetically. He preferred shooting on 28-millimeter wide-angle lenses and frequently played with distorted proportions, evident in the 1966 shot of the model Karin Mossberg, who looks like a giant dwarfing the Pyramids. AZADEH ENSHA

To the Sports Editor:Re ''Yes, It's a Sport, and Russia's Sinister Dolls Win,'' Aug. 8: Synchronized swimming requires technical skill and athleticism rivaling that of any sport and endurance second only to long-distance running. The crowd's roar for the Russians was not for some sinister portrayal, but for the athletes' supreme skill and artistry. As for the denigrating statements about suits, hair and makeup, should we also use this standard to exclude as Olympians the female athletes in track or volleyball?

When Colorado Rockies Manager Jim Tracy burst onto the field in Los Angeles last Monday to argue a reversed call, a seasoned observer knew what would come next. Vin Scully, the Hall of Fame Dodgers broadcaster, was about to narrate a tirade as only he could.As Tracy ranted in colorful language, Scully interpreted his words in a cleaner way on the air. "That is blinkin' fertilizer!" Scully said at one point, in a clip that circulated quickly on the Internet. By the next day, Tracy had seen it, too.

THE most recent fall and resort collections suggest that handbags be held -- day or night, and almost regardless of size -- in your hand. The ideal options are slouchy but not too unstructured, and large enough to have outgrown the clutch category completely; they tuck under the crook of an arm and rest casually on the hip. Our new favorite in this field: Alexander McQueen's De Manta, a version of which debuted in McQueen's spring 2010 Plato's Atlantis collection. Named after the manta ray, with which it shares an ergonomic hexagonal shape, the De Manta is, today, over a foot wide and comes in midnight satin-silk with a fluid Parrot tulip print. Fresh, for sure. Alexander McQueen De Manta floral-print clutch, $525. Go to net-a-porter.com . CLAIRE KNEBL

THE Nissan NV200 van, the same model chosen to be New York's Taxi of Tomorrow , will also enter service in London.In its new livery, the NV200 seems instantly more dignified and solid than its yellow cousin. Call it a rolling testament to the power of black paint.

To the Sports Editor:Re ''They Win Gold, but a Pot of It Rarely Follows,'' Aug. 4: Today's Olympic athletes might bear in mind that amateurism was a central principle of the modern Olympic Games from its founding. The whole point, until quite recently, was that Olympians should not be in it for the money.

MORE than ever metal has multitudes: at the fringes, where the moody doom and brainy black sub-sub-genres pulse with creativity, and also in the middle. That's the TRESSPASS AMERICA tour, sponsored by Metal Hammer magazine and arriving at the Prudential Center in Newark. The most exciting band on this bill is the most ludicrous, or certainly the most sui generis. Five Finger Death Punch, from Los Angeles, released its third album, ''American Capitalist'' (Prospect Park), last year, a sometimes melodic, sometimes rap-metal-esque, sometimes Billy Joel-recalling semiconceptual album about greed and integrity that's occasionally predictable but never dull. It shares this bill with several bands with irrepressible styles: the smoothed-out post-metalcore of Killswitch Engage, the energetic semideathcore of Emmure, the ambitious mish-mosh of Trivium and the pungent, melodic death metal of God Forbid. Aggression aside, the groups have a sense of humor. In a promotional clip band members in black hoods are transported like prisoners, alongside a jeep with a gun turret. Destination: a news conference. 5 p.m. Saturday, (973) 757-6000, trespassamerica.com ; $36 to $46.

SAND--Joyce Davis, died July 27 at age 65 after a valiant fight against cancer. Beautiful, talented, and vibrant, she held executive positions in New York and California, including vice president at Grey Advertising in New York; director of advertising and marketing for the Jewish Federation, Los Angeles, and at the Stephen Wise Temple, L.A. Joyce was known as a marketing maven. She received a bachelor's degree from Cornell, a master's from Queens College, NY, and later, an MBA from NYU. Joyce did extensive volunteer work for many organizations, mainly for Jewish causes, including a stint with the uniformed volunteer service in the IDF (Israeli Defense Forces). Joyce will be sorely missed by her mother, Rose Davis of Long Beach, NY; her sister Eileen Baumann (Robert); her nephew, Stuart Hellman; her niece, Alison Maider (Robert); her grand-niece, Lily Sophia Maider; aunt and uncle Elaine and Sidney Zelman; cousins Carol and Suzanne Zelman, aunt Rose Zelman; cousin Lois Weiss (Eric), cousin Richard Zelman (Susan); and cousin Nancy Feath. Because of an editing error, an article on July 29 about the Aleppo Codex, the oldest and most complete text of the Hebrew Bible, and how it came to be housed in a museum in Israel, omitted attribution for some new findings about the text. A book by Matti Friedman, ''The Aleppo Codex: A True Story of Obsession, Faith and the Pursuit of an Ancient Bible,'' published in May by Algonquin Books, first reported that Meir Benayahu, the former director of the Ben-Zvi Institute, was suspected of stealing books and manuscripts from the institute. Friedman was also the first to publish the transcripts of the codex trial that began in 1958.
RESNICK--Bryan. Adored sister to Mindy, sister-in-law to David, and "Aunt Brookie" to Danielle, Chelsea and Adam. A true fighter who will be forever loved and missed.

RAMSEY--Robert Lyle. Robert Lyle Ramsey, 89, died peacefully on August 1, 2012, at Norwalk Hospital, in Connecticut, surrounded by his loving family. He was preceded in death by his loving wife, Wanda Galezowska Ramsey; and his brother, Ray. He is survived by his brother, Earl; son Gregory and daughter-in-law Nellie Weston of Manhattan; daughter Katia Ramsey Read and son-in-law Howard Read of Manhattan; granddaughters Georgia Ramsey Read and Claire Elizabeth Read; and niece, Linda Rae Ramsey of Arizona. Born on April 8, 1923, to the late Clyde and Linda Marsh Ramsey, Mr. Ramsey grew up in Gilbert, Arizona. At Arizona State University, he majored in English and minored in language. After serving in WWII, he moved to New York City and enrolled in the drama department at The New School for Social Research. In 1946, he and his classmate Al Hurwitz took over the Cherry Lane Theatre in Manhattan; directing, designing and producing shows. Brooks Atkinson, then a drama critic for The New York Times, gave their first production, Jean-Paul Sartre's No Exit, a "rave" review. Mr. Ramsey and Mr. Hurwitz went on to produce a series of successful plays, winning many awards. In the 1960s, he launched a film career that would span more than 40 years. Mr. Ramsey designed and art directed sets for feature films and commercials, winning many awards. During Lyndon Baines Johnson's presidency, he was honored as a set designer at the White House. With his creative force and wry sense of humor, he was an extraordinary parent, grandparent and friend. He and his wonderful wife Wanda created an inspired and artistic world, unifying Wanda's Parisian French world with Robert's theatrical and design knowledge. A private service for family and friends will be held in September. Please send online condolences to the family at: bobramseywords@aol.com. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Westport Country Playhouse: www.westportplayhouse.org.

THE Newport Vintage Dance Week took place July 29 to Aug. 3 in Rhode Island, drawing 200 participants. This year's balls, tea dances and classes ended a 25-year run in the city's Gilded Age mansions. The sponsor, the Commonwealth Vintage Dancers, will now work on other activities, like weekend conferences. The all-volunteer organization was founded by Hannah Artuso and Patri J. Pugliese after a visit 25 years ago to the Flying Cloud Academy of Vintage Dance of Cincinnati for an event organized by Richard Powers, top far left, who is said to have coined the phrase ''vintage dancing.'' Ms. Artuso's father, who had attended business gatherings in Newport at Ochre Court, an 1892 mansion, suggested the group meet there, and Vintage Dance Week was born, bringing Ochre Court and, in time, other of the city's grand old houses to magical life.The highlights of the week were the formal evening balls, each themed to a different era. Participants were booted, spurred, corseted and coiffured in proper style. This year, for the 1860s ball, some women wore seven layers of petticoat, corset and hoop under their silk dresses. All was not fancy footwork: at Swap and Sell, the dancers parted with excess sewing machines, hats, medals, shoes, kid gloves and spats. At recent tea dances, Deborah O'Connor cut silhouettes of participants.

Mike Trout turned 21 on Tuesday, and naturally, he celebrated by hitting a home run. It gave Trout, the Los Angeles Angels' incomparable rookie, 20 homers for the season. He hit his 21st on Friday, and he entered Saturday with a .345 average and 36 stolen bases, leading the American League in both categories.How unusual is that combination of statistics? Consider this: No player in major league history has ever finished a season with 20 home runs, 35 steals and a batting average that high.

de CANI--John Stapley, 88 of Philadelphia, PA on August 8, 2012. Professor Emeritus the Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania. World War II veteran (Army Air Corps). Survived by his companion Joanna Williams of New York City, his sister Marjorie Salo of Bremerton, Washington, and nieces and nephews, Marjorie Nelson, Mary Rooney, Roberta Grambor, Clement Taylor, Herbert Taylor, John Taylor, Gregory Salo and Paul Salo. Predeceased by his sister Margaret Taylor. Funeral private. Interment in Bristol, RI. A memorial service will be held in Philadelphia on September 22. Contributions may be made in John's name to the ACLU, Doctors Without Borders or the Free Library of Philadelphia.

Funeral services private. No flowers, please. Family will receive friends on Wednesday, August 8; Thursday, August 9; and Monday August 13 from 5:00 to 8:00pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. A memorial celebration will be held on Wednesday, September 12 at 5:00pm at Lincoln Center's Alice Tully Hall, Broadway at 65 Street.

An article on July 22 about Disneyland for grown-ups misstated part of the name of a film that is the inspiration for a holiday attraction at the Haunted Mansion there. It is based on the film ''The Nightmare Before Christmas,'' not on ''Night Before Christmas.'' And the article misstated part of the name of a landmark that visitors appear to clip the top of when riding Soarin' Over California , one of the newer rides in California Adventure. The landmark is the Golden Gate Bridge, not the Golden State Bridge.

MACRI--Salvatore G. - Passed on August 8, 2012. He was born in Acireale, Sicily. Sal was a third generation master puppeteer. He came to this country in the early 1960s and soon after acquired an antique collection of Sicilian puppets from a close associate of his father's Teatro dei Pupi. Sal founded the puppet theater in Stony Creek, CT where his family of puppets was housed for many years. He performed there and throughout the US, sharing the unique and fascinating tradition of the Sicilian Puppet Theater including a public television performance on PBS. Sal was a tremendously gifted artist and his generous talent touched the lives of many. He is survived by his loving family - his wife Linda Colman, of New Haven, two sisters Maria Macri and Rosaria Giardina, brother-in-law Gioacchino Giardina and nephew Emanuele Macri Giardina, all residing in Sicily, sister-in-law Nancy Colman, brother-in-law Alex Reisman, of San Francisco and their two children Eli and Arielle. Sal is truly a bright star in the universe. A gathering will be held in his honor at a later date. For more information, email. colmanmacri@gmail.com

A dedicated father to Zephan Jacob Ryan, loving partner, companion to Stacy Hope Herman. He was courageous, fearless, generous, gentle, and a guiding spirit to those he touched. Survived by Beau, Susan, Noa, Jesse, Lord and Lady Airlie, Lauren, Eric, Oligvy's and friends.

An article on Friday about a project to harness the tides off the coast of Maine to generate electricity misidentified the river in which Verdant Power has tested its turbines. It is the East River, not the Hudson River. The article also misstated part of the name of the Depression-era project championed by Franklin D. Roosevelt. It was the Passamaquoddy Dam Project, not the Passamaquoddy River Project.

LEE--Dr. Mildred "Elsie" Kimble. Born January 2, 1919, in New York, NY, to Ernestine Scott Kimble and Ural Kimble; died August 5, 2012, in Ann Arbor, MI. Educated at Hunter College, class of 1938, B.A. Cum Laude; MBA, The School of Business and Civic Administration, 1943, and Ed.D. from Fordham University of New York, School of Education, in 1977. Permanent Certificate, School Administrator and Supervisor, Effective February 1, 1971. Married 56 years to Granville W. Lee.

WEISFUSE--George. Died August 8, 2012. Social worker, educator, poet. Survived by his wife of 70 years, Lucille, children Martin, David, Susan, daughters-in-law Doreen and Irene, grandchildren Joshua, Jason, Ben, Shira, and Eve. He is in our hearts forever.

CURTIS--Huntington W. Huntington Woodman Curtis spent his 90th and final summer on Bailey Island, ME eating a bit of everything that swam, crawled or lived in the sand and mud of Casco Bay. The son of Pierson and Dr. Winifred Curtis, MD, of Stony Brook, NY, he learned to navigate by the stars with a sextant, chronometer and chart at hand when day broke. The happiest of men, he spent life asking questions and seeking solutions. He died September 13 in Newburgh, NY after a short illness. Claiming to have been an uncertain student until Mt. Hermon School, he waited tables at the College of William and Mary before being appointed a teaching assistant and graduating Phi Beta Kappa in 1942 with degrees in chemistry and physics. A grandson of Presbyterian missionaries who spent 40 years in Japan, he balanced his deep faith with a sense of national duty and enlisted in the Army Signa Corp. He spent World War II and the Korean War teaching at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point and retired years later as a lieutenant colonel in the Reserves. Known as "Hunt," his studies led to a doctorate in electrical engineering and a faculty post at Dartmouth College's Thayer School. He regularly left to romp around the arctic conducting ionosphere research and took a break during the International Geophysical Year to skinny dip on the Greenland ice cap. His great passions involved science and nights spent outdoors under canvas in the rain. One of Joe Dodge's crew at the Appalachian Mountain Club, he drove donkeys loaded with supplies to huts into the White Mountains and later became a life trustee of the Mount Washington Observatory. Along the way, he married Peggy Parker of Goffstown, NH a Northfield School gal who could out-hike him and do more with an ax, a match and reflector oven than anyone he'd met. A wizard with chisel and saw, she stayed home to build furniture and raise their three children. Seeking to feed his brood, he left teaching for full-time research and the white shirt and narrow tie of an IBM engineer. From the 1960's through the mid-1990's he took one sick day a decade so he wouldn't miss the fun working in a lab with men and women who were the great poets of their crafts. He retired with Emeritus Scientist status that let him poke around the lab into his 80's. No drone, he spent free moments tinkering with clocks, paddling the Boundary Waters or under sail somewhere between Long Island Sound and Prince Edward Island. Each March, he headed to New Hampshire where sap turns into maple syrup on the north side of Bald Mountain. Predeceased by his wife, Margaret and daughter, Winifred, he is survived by sons, Henry of Kissimmee, FL, and Peter of Newburgh, NY, their families, grandson Parker Wayne of Pflugerville, TX and hordes of relatives and friends. On August 18, the tribe will gather at the head of Mackerel Cove to celebrate the life of an extraordinary man with tales, John Masefield verse and really bad yodeling.

No character in Shakespeare is as hungry for power as Richard III. And it's hard to think of an actor with a naturally hungrier look than Ron Cephas Jones, the tall, beanpole-thin, snakelike actor who portrays the title character in the production of ''Richard III'' from the Public Theater 's new Mobile Shakespeare Unit. This scaled-down staging has been presented at prisons, homeless shelters and other sites in underserved neighborhoods before returning to the company's home base on Astor Place.With his sinewy limbs and lanky stature, Mr. Jones put me in mind of one of those amazing African long-distance runners in this summer's Olympics. And yet this production of ''Richard III,'' directed by Amanda Dehnert, more closely resembles a 100-meter sprint. Clocking in at a little more than 90 minutes, with no intermission, it's about half as long as the production starring Kevin Spacey last season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

As the article correctly noted elsewhere, he is Matthew Levitt, not Leavitt.

Making a weekly newsmagazine has always been a tough racket. It takes a big staff working on punishing deadlines to aggregate the flurry of news, put some learned topspin on it and package it for readers. But that job now belongs to the Web and takes place in real time, not a week later. Tina Brown may have understood the digital insurgency that was disrupting the publishing business, but that didn't stop her from stepping into the maw at the end of 2010, after Sidney Harman bought Newsweek . She married her Web site, The Daily Beast, with Newsweek in an attempt to put the paddles to a franchise gone cold, but Mr. Harman is now gone and his family has withdrawn its financial support. With losses continuing to pile up, that leaves IAC/InterActiveCorp, which also owns The Daily Beast, holding the bag.

When Google imagines the future of Web search, it sees a search engine that understands human meaning and not just words, that can have a spoken conversation with computer users and that gives users results not just from the Web but also from their personal lives.Last week Google showed a few steps it has taken toward making that all-knowing search engine a reality. The new tools, like a voice search that seems to outdo Apple's Siri, make Google more useful. But some, like a feature that incorporates personal Gmail messages in results, could also unnerve those concerned with privacy.

Three years ago, yoga studios in New York waged a spirited and successful campaign to fend off a proposed state government regulation that some studios said would have led to their demise.The rule would have required schools that train yoga instructors to obtain licenses - a costly process. Yoga studios were eventually exempted from the rule.

In commemoration of the one-year anniversary of the Occupy Wall Street movement, the Civilians theater company will assemble an evening of performance material inspired by more than 150 interviews with activists associated with the Occupy movement that have been conducted over the last year. A cabaret, called "Let Me Ascertain You: Occupy #S17," is to feature monologues and songs created by Civilians artists from their interviews. It will run for one night, Sept. 17, at Joe's Pub at the Public Theater.The company has also allowed the transcripts of the interviews to be posted on its Web site in an effort to encourage other artists, students and activists to participate by setting up similar cabarets in their own communities. Additional groups in Portland, Ore.; Albuquerque; and Cincinnati have already committed to hosting their own events, according to a news release.

Last year, the cycling star Tyler Hamilton sat in front of the ''60 Minutes'' cameras and haltingly described the rampant use of banned performance-enhancing drugs by himself and his teammates, including Lance Armstrong.Now, Hamilton has struck a book deal to tell the deeper story of professional cycling and the Tour de France in ''The Secret Race,'' to be released by Ballantine Bantam Dell on Sept. 18. In a statement, Hamilton said that the story ''needed to be told.''
Dear Diary:A late July evening, 2010. My young Czech friend Pavel, who never travels without a huge camera hanging from his neck, was making his first visit to New York.
InternationalKEY AFGHAN AGENCIES

The Ouya, an inexpensive gaming console that runs on Android , is the latest experimental hardware project to take the Web by storm. It raised more than $8.5 million through Kickstarter, the crowd-funding Web site, in a campaign that ended early Thursday.The project first went live on Kickstarter's site in early July and quickly began attracting game enthusiasts who pledged money to help bring the project from the prototype stages into production. Those who kicked in $95 or more are slated to receive one of the consoles when they are ready to ship next March.

Retail apps offer shoppers electronic features made possible by smartphone technology. Walgreens customers can scan the bar code on their prescription bottles to get refills in the pharmacy section, and users of Out of Milk, a mobile shopping list, can split up in the store, and -- with automatic syncing -- cross items off the same virtual list.Users spent the most time using Shopkick, above, an app that offers redeemable points. With an average time per user of 3 hours and 19 minutes, Shopkick was consulted more intensely than the other top nine apps combined. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Adolescents in states with strict laws regulating the sale of snacks and sugary drinks in public schools gained less weight over a three-year period than those living in states with no such laws, a new study has found.The study, published Monday in Pediatrics, found a strong association between healthier weight and tough state laws regulating food in vending machines, snack bars and other venues that were not part of the regular school meal programs. Such snacks and drinks are known as competitive foods, because they compete with school breakfasts and lunches.

"The Bourne Legacy" managed to sell an estimated $40.3 million in tickets at North American movie theaters over the weekend, a No. 1 opening that was solid if not spectacular. "Legacy," featuring Jeremy Renner, cost Universal Pictures and a financing partner at least $125 million to produce and tens of millions more to market.Financial success now turns on how well Mr. Renner performs overseas, where his drawing power is untested. He has stepped in for Matt Damon, who helped power the last three movies in this series to over $1 billion in global ticket sales. But "Legacy," directed and co-written by Tony Gilroy, received the worst reviews of the series. To compare, opening-weekend sales for "Legacy" were 14 percent better than they were for "The Bourne Identity" in 2002, after adjusting for inflation, and 46 percent below the opening total for its series predecessor, "The Bourne Ultimatum" in 2007.

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about unusual developments in Congressional races this year misidentified the political party of Representative Pete Stark of California. He is a Democrat, not a Republican.

Dr. William C. Reeves, an epidemiologist who fought his own federal agency to obtain money to study chronic fatigue syndrome and then infuriated patients with the ailment by suggesting that it was linked to psychological problems rather than a virus, died on Aug. 3 at his home in Atlanta. He was 69.The cause has not yet been determined, his son, Will, said.

Nobody blew anything up. Rain did not reduce Olympic Stadium to a soggy mess filled with waterlogged athletes and wretched spectators. London's transportation system did not break down or seize up or become the world's laughingstock.To the shock and then relief of a nation used to large events going awry, the Olympics instead went smoothly. People got to where they were meant to be. The food did not run out. Nobody attacked Wenlock the mascot. And everyone, from the most important official to the person whose job it was to confiscate our water and frisk for weapons, remained genuinely buoyant.

For three decades, fans of Bird Talk magazine have dutifully collected issues for their articles and centerfolds. But the September issue is the last that will appear in print, leaving disappointed subscribers with BirdChannel.com , the magazine's related site, as the only way to read the publication's information on all types of birds - from love birds to macaws and cockatoos."This is the end of an era, a sad statement on the current state of the country, and a significant loss to all current and future parrot owners," said Linda LaFleur, a Bird Talk subscriber for more than 20 years, whose parrots have appeared on Bird Talk's covers and as centerfolds.

A credit on July 29 for a picture with a letter to the sports editor about the N.C.A.A. penalties against Penn State and its football team misspelled the given name of the photographer who took the picture of work being done around the area where a statue of the former football coach Joe Paterno once stood. He is Nabil K. Mark, not Mabil.

The same problems that plagued the foreclosure process - and prompted a multibillion-dollar settlement with big banks - are now emerging in the debt collection practices of credit card companies.As they work through a glut of bad loans, companies like American Express , Citigroup and Discover Financial are going to court to recoup their money. But many of the lawsuits rely on erroneous documents, incomplete records and generic testimony from witnesses, according to judges who oversee the cases.
Dear Diary:Time: Noon, July 30.

At nightclubs and festivals around the world, dance music is all about good times. But behind the scenes of this increasingly lucrative and competitive sector of the music business lie the same kinds of disputes over trademarks and exploitation rights that plague any industry.On Friday, two of the genre's leading companies, both named Ultra - Ultra Music, a record label, and Ultra Music Festival, an annual live event - announced a "global alliance." Details were scant other than that Ultra, the label, would release CDs and DVDs from Ultra, the festival, though the deal implies a partnership of independents at a time when electronic dance music, or E.D.M., is attracting new corporate investment .

First, hats off to the British. All sorts of muckety-mucks deserve credit for running so smooth an extravaganza. But what impressed me most were the thousands of volunteers who cheerfully helped visitors navigate their way around. People don't suddenly become that nice for two summer weeks. They had to have the advantage of a long head start.I love the Olympics. But before the Games, the question in the back of my mind was: Wouldn't I be better off watching at home? Isn't this why I splurged on 60 inches of high-def with surround sound?

Months after he arrived in Washington in 2009, Gary Gensler knew he had a big case.Huddled around his assistant's desk with a colleague, Mr. Gensler, then Wall Street's newest regulator, listened to a taped telephone call of two Barclays employees discussing plans to report false interest rates. When the brief recording ended, Mr. Gensler realized the gravity of the wrongdoing.

On London's Olympic stage, athletes, fans and volunteers created a memorable experience. Four New York Times reporters reflect on their impressions covering their first Olympics.The Footnotes Tell a Global Story

If you believe someone has a great future as an entrepreneur, maybe you should own a piece of it.That is the premise of an unusual effort by a former Google executive to promote start-ups through the creation of a new investment vehicle. Through the company, Upstart , successful older executives will give enough money to college graduates to see them through the earliest stages of their business ideas.
Dear Diary:I was on the train on a night in mid-July and noticed a neon blur. A woman had walked by me in one of those flowing, blood-orange dresses made out of some stretchy material.
DEAR DIARY:He was bad by design. Scary bad. Every move he made, every stitch of his clothing, every hair from his fade to his braids, perfectly placed to intimidate.

Periodically throughout the Olympics, we checked in with Dennis Spurr, the owner of the Fantastic Sausage Factory in Weymouth, a pretty town on the English coast where the sailing events took place. Spurr's sausage business was a target of the Olympic branding authorities in 2007 after he put up a sign featuring the Olympic five-ring logo done in sausage links. He took it down on their demands, but replaced it with a sign featuring five squares made of sausage links.Q. So this is it, last day. How you feeling?

An article in some copies on Friday about the possible trade of Dwight Howard from the Orlando Magic to the Los Angeles Lakers misspelled the given name of one of the other players involved in the deal. He is Arron Afflalo, not Aaron.

FITZGERALD--Patrick J.,on August 11, 2012. Native of Tralee, Co. Kerry, Ireland. Retired proprietor of restaurants and taverns in Brooklyn, NY. Beloved Husband of Winifred Horgan-Fitzgerald and the late Ethel. Devoted father of Lynne O'Donnell (Charlie), Patricia Scanlon (George), Joan Thompson (Gary), Kevin Fitzgerald (Liz) and Karen Potter (Brian). Dear brother of the late John, Gerald, Mary Cahillan, Joan Edwards and Kitty Flitsch. Loving grandfather of 17 and great-grandfather of one. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home 91-05 Beach Channel Drive Rockaway Beach, NY 11693 Visiting Monday 2-5 and 7-10pm Funeral Mass Tuesday 9:45am at St. Francis De Sales Church Interment St. Charles Cemetery
Dear Diary:Almost 80 years ago, my friend and I found free access to the Winter Garden Theater. It required climbing seven floors on a fire escape to find an open back entry to the theater.

MENLO PARK, Calif. - Millions of people watched a robot descend last week on Mars , about 154 million miles away, while it shared video, photos and status updates from its own Twitter account .I had my own encounter with a robot last week. I had dinner with one - right here in Silicon Valley.

Now it can be told: there is a lot of Wikipedia in the press section at the Olympics. For every reporter who can tell you that a waza-ari was clearly just a glorified yuko or that the Hungarian is the one to watch, there are quite a few more -- the feature writers, the curious onlookers who normally cover track and field, the poor souls who were assigned a dozen different sports, me -- typing ''judo + rules'' into Google.An argument can be made that this is excusable. There is just so much going on, so many different events in so many different places, all at the same time. Victory ceremonies are squeezed in between long jumps; a fencer's dream is dashed while three other bouts are going on around her; the javelins sail toward the high jumpers.

An article on Thursday about the reaction of officials in London to accusations of money laundering against the British bank Standard Chartered misstated the middle initial of the New York State banking regulator who leveled the charges. He is Benjamin M. Lawsky, not Benjamin W.

An article on July 9 about Na Yeon Choi's victory in the United States Women's Open described imprecisely her triple-bogey 8 on the 10th hole in the final round. After pulling her drive into a steep drop-off a few yards off the fairway, she took a one-stroke penalty and hit again from the tee, then she was in the rough for their next three shots, finally reaching the green in 6. It is not the case that ''after taking a one-stroke penalty, she stayed in the rough for three shots, finally reaching the green in 6.'' A reader recently pointed out the error in an e-mail.
ELVERMAN--Bill. Nov. 14, 1951 - Aug. 13, 1992. Sadly missed, but never forgotten. Your love, friendship & creativity live on.

With the Games completed, it's time to look back at some outstanding features of the Olympics that deserved more attention.STRANGEST ARTISTIC CHOICE Pandering to a heretofore unnoticed wave of Soviet nostalgia, Australia's synchronized swimmers donned suits with what looked like the facade of the Kremlin and performed to ''Back in the U.S.S.R.''
We had been chanting, 'Down, down with military rule.' Today it came true.SHADY EL-GHAZALY HARB,

8 P.M. (Sundance) BRIDGET JONES: THE EDGE OF REASON (2004) Renée Zellweger reprises her role as Helen Fielding's bumbling Londoner, stumbling yet again through career and romantic fiascos with her on-again, off-again beaus Daniel (Hugh Grant) and Mark (Colin Firth, above, with Ms. Zellweger). ''Man, does this one make the first movie look like a masterpiece,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this film directed by Beeban Kidron.11 A.M. (HBO) BEND IT LIKE BECKHAM (2003) A British teenager named Jess (Parminder K. Nagra) finds her dreams of soccer stardom clashing with the wishes of her traditional Sikh family in this sports comedy from Gurinder Chadha. Archie Panjabi is the older sister who doesn't understand why Jess doesn't share her boy-crazy, shopping-centered approach to life. Keira Knightley is Jules, who persuades Jess, her best friend, to train with a local soccer club. And Jonathan Rhys Meyers is the coach with whom Jules and Jess are smitten. ''The title, and some of the local dialect, may require a bit of translation, but the film's warm-and-fuzzy amalgam of multiculturalism and feminism will look very familiar indeed,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. ''It is stuffed to bursting with affectionate stereotypes and the sticky, somewhat oppressive Gemütlichkeit that is the hallmark, at least on screen, of immigrant families, wherever they come from and wherever they reside.''

An article last Monday about the Mets' 7-3 loss to the San Diego Padres the previous day misspelled, in some copies, the surname of the Padres player who led off the second inning with a triple. He is Will Venable, not Veneble. The article also misstated, in some copies, the given name of the Padres player who hit a two-run homer in the third inning. He is Yonder Alonso, not Yadier.
MINSKOFF--Henry H. 1911-1984 You are in our thoughts, our hearts and our memories. All our love.Jim, Jeannie, Grandchildren and Great-Grandchildren

FEINBERG--Nettie. Passed away peacefully Friday morning, August 10, 2012, at the age of 95. Predeceased by her husband of 63 years, Samuel, she is survived by her children Lawrence, Richard, and Alice; her children-in-law, Sandra, Kevin, and Nana; her grandchildren, Jacob and his wife, Yaju, Theodore, and Ian; and her great-granddaughters Hannah and Aja. She was greatly loved and will be so missed. The family requests donations be made to the Middle Country Library Foundation or favorite charity.

Since 2006, when HCA was taken private in a leveraged buyout, profits at its acute-care hospitals have soared. Total margin, a measure of financial performance, has remained far higher at HCA hospitals than at other similar institutions.

Federal court asked to enforce a subpoena against Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., demanding that he produce records on the bungled gun-tracking investigation known as Operation Fast and Furious.

Idaho firefighter died after being struck by a falling tree while working on a fire, officials said. Oregon firefighter was forced to crawl into emergency shelter when winds filled with fire overran the area.
The police in San Diego are investigating a huge midnight water-gun fight that caused an estimated $10,000 in damage to the historic lily pond at Balboa Park.
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released figures showing that the number of states with at least 30 percent of obese adults has grown to 12 from 9.
The Department of Defense has identified 2,064 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
Four teenagers were wounded on Monday in a shooting at a playground in Brooklyn, the police said, the latest in a spate of gun violence involving young people.

Ichiro Suzuki’s sacrifice bunt kick-started a big inning, as the Yankees scored five runs off Ryan Dempster, helped by a grand slam by Nick Swisher two batters later.

Martellus Bennett, the chatty new player on a businesslike squad, has bonded with his teammates. The Giants hope he will be an improvement at tight end after they lost Jake Ballard.

Mixing only 1 part water with 99 parts sand gives a more stable mix, say physicists who see applications for their finding across several fields.

The moderating duties for the four presidential and vice- presidential debates this year will be evenly split between male and female journalists for the first time, the Commission on Presidential Debates said Monday, nearly two months before debate season begins.The moderators will be Jim Lehrer of PBS, Bob Schieffer of CBS, Candy Crowley of CNN and Martha Raddatz of ABC, the commission said after a long and mostly secret selection process.
