The Media Equation column on Monday, about the declining fortunes of magazines, described incorrectly at one point some circulation figures from the Audit Bureau of Circulations. As the column correctly noted elsewhere, the audit bureau reported last week a drop of almost 10 percent in magazines' newsstand sales -- not in their overall circulation.

TESSLER--Janet (nee Feinberg), 90, passed away on August 12. She was a loving mother, grandmother, mother-in-law and great-grandmother to Laurie, Charles, Lenard, Nancy, Fern, Lois, Jodi, Benji , Amy, Jaclyn, Peter, Greer, Alex, Sherry, Jason, Jeff and Monica, Hannah, Dax, Spencer, Ryan and David, respectively. She was a devoted and loving wife to Benjamin. She leaves behind her sister, Blanche and best friend and companion, Alvin. She will live in each of us everyday. Goodbye Mom.

WEINSTEIN--Grace. The American Society of Journalists and Authors mourns the passing of our esteemed past president. A dedicated member of the Board of the Writers Emergency Assistance Fund, Grace's warmth and wisdom will be missed.

The Detroit hip-hop duo Insane Clown Posse used the platform of its annual Gathering of the Juggalos festival to announce that it was pursuing an investigation into why its fans were classified as a gang in a report published by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.In a statement released over the weekend, the Insane Clown Posse members, Joseph Bruce (who performs under the stage name Violent J) and Joseph Utsler (who goes by Shaggy 2 Dope), said they and their label, Psychopathic Records, had "retained legal counsel to investigate and pursue legal action including monetary compensation and/or other injunctive relief on behalf of their fan base." Mr. Bruce added: "We're not attacking the F.B.I., but they got this wrong. The Juggalos are not a gang, and that needs to be fixed."
InternationalNORWAY KILLINGS INQUEST

A theater review on Monday about ''Richard III,'' at the Public Theater, misidentified the corpse over which Lady Anne is seduced. It is the corpse of her father-in-law -- not her husband, whom Richard also killed.

To the Editor:Re '' Persistence Is Key to Treating Vaginal Pain '' (Personal Health, Aug. 7): Treatment by a physical therapist can dramatically enhance the quality of life for women who experience this condition. A women's health physical therapist will perform an examination, identify the cause(s) of vaginal pain and determine whether referral to a physician for additional testing is necessary. Based on the examination results, the physical therapist will design a treatment plan to reduce muscle tightness and improve muscle strength and function.

Pressman--Sasha, 94 years old, died peacefully in her sleep in her West Side apartment on August 6th, just eleven months since she lost her husband, the late David Pressman, who died at the age of 97. They were married for over seventy years, and together they had an extraordinary life. She studied dance with Martha Graham in the mid 1930s and went on to have a successful career as a modern dancer. She joined the Anna Sokolow dance company in 1937 and toured all over the United States. She danced in the original Broadway musical of STREET SCENE, by Kurt Weill, in 1946, and in Helen Tamiris' HOW LONG BRETHREN. She continued a career as choreographer and teacher. She started the dance program at Boston University in 1954 with her husband, David, who began the acting program. She was a woman full of life and passion, and she leaves behind three sons, Gregory, Michael, and Eugene, five grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren. She was a force of nature and will be deeply missed by friends and family. Her wish to join her late husband was granted with grace and serenity.

An article on Saturday about a sharp reduction in crop forecasts as a result of the drought omitted reporting credits. Those contributing were Adam Nossiter in Dakar, Senegal; Rick Gladstone in New York; and John Eligon in Kansas City, Mo.

TRACY--Lazelle Wood, of New York City, age 92, died peacefully in her sleep after a brief illness on August 11, 2012 in Charlotte. Born July 31, 1920 in the Caney Fork community in Cullowhee, NC, Lazelle was the oldest of eleven children born to Thaddeus Dillard Wood and Agatha Elizabeth Stephens Wood. Lazelle grew up on the family farm on Caney Fork, graduated from Cullowhee High School and attended Western Carolina Teachers College (now Western Carolina University). She lived in New York City for 64 years and maintained a home on Caney Fork. Lazelle was predeceased by Billy Tobin Tracy, her husband of 59 years, on May 31, 2003. She is survived by their two children Billy T. Tracy, Jr. (Barbara) of New York City and Elizabeth Tracy Monge (Jay) of Charlotte; her grandsons Thaddeus James Tracy (Michele), Emmett Patrick Tracy (Jennifer), Justin Parry Monge (Meg) and Lindsay Newton Monge (Alethea); and her great grandchildren Sacha Tracy, Tobin Tracy, T. Tomas Tracy, Malia Monge, Makena Monge, Lucas Monge and Jackson Monge. Lazelle's surviving siblings are Jack Wood of Charlotte, Baxter Wood of Cullowhee, Lois Jean Morgan of Sylva and Janice Gentry of Elkin. Lazelle was predeceased by sisters Blanche Campbell, Helen Loosier, Gertrude (Peggy) Smith, Betty Bryant and Barbara Jo Wood and brother Don Wood. Lazelle, a beloved sister, adored mother, dedicated grandmother and devoted great-grandmother, will be missed by all.

CHANGE OF COURSE The activist investor Nelson Peltz, below, is joining the board of Ingersoll-Rand, heading off a potential proxy fight.Mr. Peltz disclosed in May that his fund, Trian Fund Management, had acquired a 7.05 percent stake in the manufacturing conglomerate, saying its shares were ''currently undervalued in the marketplace.'' In June, Trian disclosed that it had turned down an offer of a board seat, but has since changed its mind.

The Crime Scene column on Saturday, about a tenant in the East Village who set up a webcam in his apartment after he realized it had been broken into and eventually captured video of the suspect, misstated the name of the county where the suspect had been involved in three home-invasion burglaries. It is Otsego County, not Ostego.

NBC wrapped up its broadcasts of the London Games on Sunday night with the closing ceremony, which attracted an average of 31 million viewers, the most for a foreign Summer Olympics since the 1976 Games in Montreal. For all 17 days of the London Games, NBC averaged 31.1 million viewers in prime time, 12 percent better than four years ago for the Beijing Games and 26 percent better than the Athens Games in 2004.Live streams of sports from NBCOlympics.com totaled 64.4 million, up from 14 million in Beijing. Total streams of 159.3 million more than doubled Beijing's 75.5 million. The gold medal victory by the United States women's soccer team generated 1.46 million streams, the most of the London Games. More coverage at nytimes.com/sports .

LEWIS--Bernice, beloved mother, wife and grandmother, passed away peacefully and with her usual elegance in Beverly Hills, California. A pioneer of the women's ready to wear industry, Bernice was an admired executive who created successful businesses and enduring friendships. She was smart, funny and kind. Her innate sense of style transcended time and was her hallmark. Her independence and indomitable spirit are her legacy. Pre-deceased by husband Arthur, Bebe is survived by her much-loved children, Jim Lewis and Marcia Smith, son-in-law Mark J. Smith and cherished grandchildren, Amanda and Alexander. Services will be at noon at Hillside Cemetery. Donations may be made to the Bernice Lewis Memorial Fund at Cedars Sinai Medical Center, Suite 2416, and will be deeply appreciated.

MACHOL--Betty Kurzman. A lifelong resident of New York City, died on August 12, 2012, at the age of 90 years, after several years of declining health. She is survived by Erwin Machol, her loving husband of 41 years, and her beloved children, Jayne M. Kurzman of New York City and Daniel J. Kurzman of Derby Line, VT, her daughter-in-law, Karen L. Kurzman, and four grandchildren, Jay F. Kurzman, Anthony K. Rykowski, Jessa K. Francis and Pamela K. Rykowski. Her former husband, Alvin L. Kurzman, died in 1955. Her extraordinary kindness, unfailing graciousness and lively intelligence will be missed by all who knew her. A dynamic educator and leader, Betty spent her entire professional career in the New York City school system, where she brought the joy of learning to countless students. She retired as the principal of P.S. 61 in Manhattan. Betty was an active member of the Women's City Club of New York, the Educational Priorities Panel and the Campaign for Fiscal Equity. She received her B.A. from Hunter College, Phi Beta Kappa, and a Masters Degree from Queens College. Visitation, Wednesday 7-9pm and funeral service, Thursday 10am, both at "The Riverside" West 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City. Interment, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

A picture caption on July 30 with the continuation of an article about the challenges drone pilots in the United States face overstated what was known about the scene shown in a control room at the base at Hancock Field, near Syracuse. While a pilot was shown working the controls of a drone, it was not the case that the drone was on a mission over Afghanistan. A spokesman at Hancock said the only information he could provide was that the drone was on a training mission.

BASSIN--Milton G. York College mourns the loss of former President Milton G. Bassin. Mr. Bassin served as York's indefatigable president from 1971 until his retirement in May of 1991. Under his steady leadership, York survived the fiscal crisis of the 1970s, which had threatened to close the burgeoning college. President Bassin exhibited a steely determination and knack for bringing the external community together with the college community. He led the fight for York's survival and for York to remain in Jamaica, Queens and remain a senior college. The president spearheaded the task of building a state-of-the-art permanent campus housed on 50 acres in the heart of downtown Jamaica. Milton G. Bassin was York's second President and to date, its longest serving. He was a staunch advocate of a tuition-free CUNY on behalf of the students who, like himself, came from humble beginnings. The faculty and staff of York College send condolences to Bernice and the entire Bassin family. Marcia V. Keizs, President

HILLER--Janice. A wonderful friend who inspired only the best in everyone. Our deepest sympathy to Bob, her children, Elyse, Jodi, Arnie and Gary and their families. We will miss her. Edwina and Marvin Marks

8:56 p.m. | Updated SAN FRANCISCO - Google made another foray into producing original content Monday when it announced its plans to buy the Frommer's brand of travel guides from John Wiley & Sons to augment its local and travel search results.Google will pay about $23 million for the brand, according to a person close to the deal who was not authorized to speak publicly about the terms. The companies declined to comment on the purchase price. It is a small acquisition for Google, but important for several of Google's up-and-coming businesses.

White children are more likely than black or Hispanic children to be given CT scans when arriving at hospital emergency rooms with minor head trauma , a study has found.Children with the most troubling symptoms, like changes in mental functioning or signs of skull fracture , received CT scans at relatively high rates regardless of race, the researchers reported. But among children at low risk of trauma, 17 percent of non-Hispanic whites received scans while only 10 percent of black and Hispanic children did .

KELLY--Pat. With particular sadness Solomon Schechter School of Westchester announces the death of Mrs. Pat Kelly. Mrs. Kelly was the Assistant Head of Schechter Westchester from 1974 through 2002. She was a woman who was singular in her educational talent and skill, and distinctive and passionate in her religious devotion. Pat was a master math teacher to generations of Schechter Westchester Middle School students. She was a respected colleague and teacher, a role model for interfaith relations, and a dear friend to Schechter Westchester and the entire Jewish community of Westchester. Viewing and tributes will be held at the Dwyer/Vanderbilt Funeral Home at 90 North Broadway, between 12pm and 2:00pm on Wednesday, August 15 followed by burial at the Sleepy Hollow Cemetery.

Many of the Olympians competing in London are juiced -- though not in the colloquial sense that someone is doping. Instead, the juice these athletes are imbibing is literal, with beetroot juice and tart cherry juice two of the most popular choices. Growing numbers of elite athletes are turning to these natural beverages to provide what they hope will be a legal performance benefit.Recent studies, however, raise questions about whether the athletes are necessarily receiving the benefits that they think they are and what that means for the rest of us who'd love to find fitness in a glass.

An article on Monday about the effects that laws regulating the sale of snacks and sugary drinks in public schools have had on adolescents' weight misidentified the institution where Daniel Taber, an author of a study tracking the laws, is a fellow. He is with the Institute for Health Research and Policy at the University of Illinois at Chicago -- not at the University of Chicago.

KRAUSS--Alisa (nee Fordaus), age 90, died on August 12, 2012, of Philadelphia, PA, formerly of State College, PA, and Great Neck, NY. Wife of the late Milton L. Krauss, who met her during World War II while serving as an officer in the U.S. Army, Persian Gulf Command. Mother of Meyer (Randy), Daniel (Geri), and Ronald. Sister of Puah Venezia. Savta of Michael (Elissa), Robert, Benjamin, Samuel, and Simon. Savta-G'dolah of Nathan and Jacob. Born in Tel-Aviv, a graduate of Gymnasia Herzlia, and member of the Haganah. A great-great-grandaughter of the Chassidic Rabbi Yisrael Bak, who established the first Hebrew printing press in Palestine (Safed) in 1831, and whose son, Rabbi Nissan Bak, founded the Tiferet Israel Synagogue in Jerusalem in 1872. Donations can be made to American Friends of Netiv Ohr. The Krauss Family

Before she cashed in her retirement fund and quit her job to lug a replica of President Obama's Oval Office desk around the country and interview people about their ideas for America, Lori Korchek was a creative director at Kaplan Thaler Group, an advertising agency behind brands including Aflac and Wendy's. Her sometimes business partner, Mike Bade, is an animation director who quit work to focus on what the two are calling "America for President."They have a dream, though yes, they know - it sounds crazy.

The Miami Dolphins receiver Chad Johnson's arrest on a domestic violence charge has caused the cable channel VH1 to shelve his reality show, "Ev & Ocho."The show was to feature Mr. Johnson, previously known as Chad Ochocinco, and his new wife, Evelyn Lozada, who was a star of the VH1 series "Basketball Wives." (She was previously engaged to the basketball player Antoine Walker.) Eleven episodes about the couple's engagement and wedding were taped this year, including a two-part season finale. The first episode was scheduled to be shown on VH1 on Sept. 3.

HILLER--Janice (Feld), 79, of Bellmore, NY, on August 12th. Beloved wife of 59 years to B. Robert Hiller, loving mother of Arnold Hiller, Elyse Shaw Jody Winter and Gary Hiller. Devoted grandmother. Service August 14, 11:30am Schwartz Brothers Jeffer 11403 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills. Interment at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

Incubators have long existed for technology start-ups. But the needs of investment bankers are not quite the same as those of tech entrepreneurs who started a business in a garage and spent all night programming code.Jolyne Caruso, experienced on Wall Street, took a page from the tech playbook to help seasoned financiers run their own firms. In 2010, she created the Alberleen Group , an incubator for investment bankers who have experience in their sectors and entrepreneurial attitudes but lack capital, investor contacts or support in areas like regulatory compliance.

LONDON - The Swiss bank Julius Baer agreed on Monday to buy the private banking operations outside the United States of Bank of America Merrill Lynch , in a deal that will increase the European firm's assets under management by 40 percent.The acquisition is the latest consolidation move in the private banking industry, as firms look to bolster their operations to gain access to the new markets of emerging economies.

A new Washington Post/ABC News poll finds Americans are divided over Mitt Romney's selection of Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin as his vice-presidential running mate, but that favorable opinion of Mr. Ryan rose after the announcement was made.Still, a sizable number of Americans have no impression of Mr. Ryan. A poll taken Sunday by Gallup/USA Today also finds division, with 42 percent of Americans viewing the choice of Mr. Ryan as "fair" or "poor" and 39 percent viewing it as an "excellent" or "pretty good" pick.

GILBERT--Jane Treman. The officers, brokers and staff at Brown Harris Stevens will miss our long-time colleague Jane Treman Gilbert. Jane will be fondly remembered for her wry sense of humor, and generous spirit.

An archive of documents and artifacts relating to Otto Frank, the father of Anne Frank, will be auctioned on Nov. 5 at Doyle New York, the auction house has announced. The archive, which has an estimated price of $20,000 to $30,000, was assembled by Joseph Schildkraut, who portrayed Frank in the 1955 stage and 1959 film versions of ''The Diary of Anne Frank.'' It includes letters and documents from 1941 detailing Otto Frank's efforts to enlist the help of the American retailer Nathan Straus, a friend from his days at Heidelberg University, in the family's effort to escape the Nazi-occupied Netherlands. It also includes some 50 letters between Frank, Schildkraut and Schildkraut's wife, Leonora Schildkraut, as well as annotated vintage photographs, a transcript of a 1939 letter from Otto to Anne, and a monogrammed handkerchief. Otto Frank was the only family member to survive the Holocaust.

A month after confessing to stealing from clients and defrauding banks, Russell R. Wasendorf Sr., the chief executive of the collapsed brokerage firm Peregrine Financial Group, was indicted on Monday by a federal grand jury.The move is the latest development in what prosecutors say was a long-ranging fraud for a prominent figure in the futures industry, which largely consists of money management firms that trade contracts in commodities, currencies and interest rates.

SEMMELMAN--Esther. The Board of Directors of American Friends of Shalva mourn the passing of Esther Semmelman, beloved wife of Shalva Board member Jacques Semmelman. We extend our deepest sympathies to Jacques, David and Alyssa and the entire family. May they be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Norm Alpert & Carol Levin Co-Presidents, Kalman Samuels, Shalva Founder & Director, Leo Klein Executive Director.

ARUEGO--Jose Illustrator, author, calligrapher, father. He died peacefully on August 9th his 80th birthday. Jose Aruego's 82 books for children enchanted a generation of young readers, and critics as well. Working with his wife and long-time collaborator Ariane Dewey, he created a world of joyful animals so full of life that one reviewer termed his style illustrative mime. His characters were spare of line, while still being wonderfully expressive and vivacious. Among their best-known books are Whose Mouse Are You?, Leo the Late Bloomer and Gregory the Terrible Eater. Jose's artistic career was even more remarkable because he was supposed to be a lawyer. He graduated from law school at the University of the Philippines and passed the bar, but his true passion lay in the arts. He came to New York City in 1956 and studied at Parsons School of Design. Jose's career took off when he began penning cartoons. Many were published in the The New Yorker and The Saturday Evening Post. A couple even appeared on The Ed Sullivan Show. Jose and Ariane's first book was published in 1969. He brought his work to life in lectures at elementary schools around the country. Long days in classrooms and auditoriums were made longer by his insistence on sketching a character into every book he signed and teaching students to draw his alligators. Later in life, Jose took up calligraphy and excelled in that as well. Jose's love of travel brought him around the world. Since Jose was such a private person, there will be no funeral service. A memorial will be held in the fall. Jose is survived by his son Juan, the rest of his family and the untold number of people he touched through his art, his quiet charm and his deafening joie de vie. We miss you.

BARNES--Harry G.,Jr., 86, on August 9. Foreign Service Officer of 38 years, served in Bombay, Prague, Moscow, Kathmandu, Bucharest. U.S. Ambassador to Romania, India, Chile. Director General of the Foreign Service. Director of Conflict Resolution & Human Rights Programs, Carter Center. Chairman, Romanian-American Enterprise Fund. Grand Cross, Order of Bernardo O'Higgins, Chile. www.rand-wilson.com

The proportion of adults who said they went on a 10-minute walk at least once a week increased to 62 percent in 2010, from 56 percent in 2005, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has reported .Federal guidelines recommend that adults get at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise (like brisk walking) or 75 minutes of vigorous exercise (like running) each week. The proportion of people who met federal guidelines for aerobic exercise also grew, to 48 percent in 2010 from 42 percent in 2005, the agency said.
I have one son; I have done everything I can to get him this far in life. I'm not just going to throw him the keys.PA M FISCHER,who is pressing for stricter laws on teenage driving inNew Jersey. [A1]

While he prepares for his next act of cinematic provocation, the Danish director Lars von Trier is inviting audiences to engage in their own acts of button-pushing filmmaking as part of a user-generated project that seeks reinterpretations of well-known works by Paul Gauguin, August Strindberg and Albert Speer, among others.On Monday, Mr. von Trier, whose films include "Melancholia," "Antichrist" and "Dancer in the Dark," announced the creation of a project called Gesamt , which is produced by the Copenhagen Art Festival and asks participants to submit their own entries of up to five minutes in length. As a news release for the project explains, the German word gesamtkunstwerk can mean "the universal work of art" or "synthesis of the art"; and entrants can create their works "through the lens of their camera or recording of sound."

He could be mistaken for a Wall Street banker. Or perhaps a hedge fund manager. Or even a managing director at a private equity firm, like Bain Capital. Paul Ryan , with his clean-cut Brooks Brothers looks and wonky obsession with spreadsheets, could be just the archetype of a Wall Streeter.

An article on Monday about the author and book dealer Larry McMurtry's auction of 300,000 used books in Archer City, Tex., on Friday and Saturday referred incorrectly to the intersection toward which he was walking on Friday morning as collectors and dealers lined up to bid. It is Archer City's only major intersection, not its only intersection.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about the ballet dancer Richard Cragun misspelled the surname of the performer he called his ''absolute idol.'' He was Donald O'Connor, not O'Conner.

With the choice of Paul D. Ryan to be the Republican vicepresidential nominee, not one person in a group of top political jobs -- the presidential and vice-presidential nominees of both parties, the Supreme Court justices, the speaker of the House or the Senate majority leader -- is a white Protestant. That group instead comprises nine Catholics (six justices, Mr. Ryan, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Speaker John A. Boehner), three Jews (on the court), two Mormons (Mitt Romney and Senator Harry Reid) and one African-American Protestant (President Obama). For much of American history, white Protestants dominated the top rungs of American government.

Moviegoers got a peek at Ang Lee's next film, " Life of Pi ," earlier this summer when Fox took the unusual step of showing a full uncut scene before screenings of "Prometheus" and other films. But New York Film Festival audiences will be the first to see the director's full 3-D adaptation of the best-selling novel when the film opens the 50th edition of the event on Sept. 28, the Film Society of Lincoln Center announced on Monday. It will be the second Lee film to kick off the festival (after "The Ice Storm" in 1997).The tale of an Indian teenager sharing a lifeboat with a Bengal tiger, "Life of Pi" won its author, Yann Martel, a Man Booker Prize in 2002. The adaptation stars a newcomer, Suraj Sharma, in the title role, and the cast includes Irrfan Khan, Rafe Spall and Gérard Depardieu.

Services Thursday, August 16, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 180 W. 76th St, NYC. In lieu of flowers donations to DOROT, 171 W. 85th St, NYC
HAMLISCH--Marvin. Our family mourns the loss of a great friend and talent. We will remember your big smile and even bigger heart. Dorothy Goldsmith & Family

TAMARIN--Marilyn Michelson. September 26, 1922 - August 11, 2012. Preceded in death by her beloved Harold and son Steven. She is survived by daughter Helene Tamarin and grandsons Sam and Jacob Ruben and Pablo Tamarin. She will be missed.

The Huffington Post on Monday began what it hopes will be a never-ending news talk show on the Internet, HuffPost Live. The online channel is one of the most ambitious attempts yet to rethink what television should look and feel like when streamed over the Internet. Accordingly, a chat box took up the same amount of space as the live video, and a bright red button labeled "join this segment" let viewers sign up to participate through their own webcams.

The Tony Award-winning musical "Once" has recouped its $5.5 million capitalization costs on Broadway in less than six months, the producers announced on Monday, becoming one of the few shows to turn a profit and doing so faster than most.The musical's box office success - grossing more than $1 million a week since mid-June - is unusual given that the show is unlike most Broadway hits. Rather than a high-kicking crowd pleaser with big-name talents attached, "Once" is a low-key and somber tale of lost love, starring largely unknown actors and featuring minimal sets and nontraditional choreography. Yet "Once," based on an indie film of the same name from Ireland, enjoyed strong reviews from critics and prominent television exposure on "America's Got Talent" and other programs after winning eight Tonys - including best musical and best actor - in June.

A mother asked me last week whether I thought she was spoiling her child. It was the typical pediatric exam-room version of the question: In the weary, self-doubting voice of the recently postpartum, she wondered if it was right to pick up and feed her crying baby.These days, a lot of parents are wondering about the spoiling question. A recent book review by Elizabeth Kolbert in The New Yorker compared American children unfavorably with the self-reliant and competent children of a tribe in the Peruvian Amazon ; she discussed "the notion that we may be raising a generation of kids who can't, or at least won't, tie their own shoes."

An article on Saturday about supermarkets' increasing focus on produce, deli and other fresh-food sections misspelled the surname of a partner at the consulting firm Innosight who commented on such practices at Whole Foods. He is Andrew Waldeck, not Waldek.

Iron, an essential nutrient, has long been the nation's most common nutritional deficiency. In decades past, many parents worried that children who were picky eaters would develop iron-deficiency anemia . My mother boiled meat I refused to eat and fed me the concentrated broth in hopes I'd get some of its iron.Now baby foods, infant formula and many other child-friendly foods, like breakfast cereals, breads, rice and pasta, are fortified with iron. Today iron deficiency is more likely in infants who are exclusively breast-fed, young children who consume too much milk, menstruating and pregnant women, vegans and strict vegetarians , and people who take medications that cause internal bleeding or interfere with iron absorption.

Many people do not appropriately use safety restraints for children in cars, a new study shows.University of Michigan researchers analyzed data on more than 21,000 children observed in cars at gas stations, fast-food restaurants, recreation centers and child care centers from 2007 to 2009. The researchers defined age-appropriate restraints according to guidelines from the American Academy of Pediatrics.

Solyndra, the solar-panel maker that received a $535 million loan guarantee from the Energy Department before it filed for bankruptcy, has reached a $3.5 million settlement with former workers who contended that they received inadequate layoff notices.The settlement will resolve a lawsuit asserting that the company failed to give employees 60 days' notice required under federal law when it fired most of its 1,100 employees on Aug. 31, just before seeking bankruptcy court protection last year.

After downing 70 chicken wings in about an hour, Andrew Walen realized he had a problem.Oh, he had known something was wrong over the years. Normal people don't consume 4,500 calories worth of food in one sitting, or order takeout for four when dining alone. But it took a maniacal feeding frenzy for him to finally accept the reality: He was a binge eater, and he had absolutely no control around food.

Adored grandmother of seven, great-grandmother of thirteen. She had a love of life. We will miss her forever. Contributions should be made to Alzheimer's Organization at Alz.org.

10 P.M. (Syfy) COLLECTION INTERVENTION Elyse Luray, above left, a former head of special collections at Christie's who has appeared on PBS's ''Antiques Roadshow'' and ''History Detectives,'' helps those who are drowning in pop-culture memorabilia determine the value of their objects and then decide what stays and what goes. The series begins with a couple from Concord, Calif., whose ''Star Wars'' collection has taken over their house, then heads to Los Angeles, where a husband must part with some of his ''Catwoman'' collectibles to pay off his debt and save his marriage.8:05 A.M. (Cinemax) THE CHRONICLES OF NARNIA: THE VOYAGE OF THE DAWN TREADER (2010) Lucy Pevensie (Georgie Henley) and her brother, Edmund (Skandar Keynes), joined by their chatterbox cousin Eustace Scrubb (Will Poulter), are lured back into Narnia by a maritime painting that turns into a Niagara Falls, sweeping the children out to sea in this franchise's third installment, directed by Michael Apted. Soon they've been rescued by their old comrade in arms, King Caspian (Ben Barnes), and taken aboard his ship, now armed with a crew of clean-cut men and talking beasts, including a mouse-kateer named Reepicheep (voiced by Simon Pegg). ''Though there are times when the movie turns into a congested mess, as in a climactic battle that washes the screen in gray, there are moments when you also see a quieter, less industrial production,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''Such is the case after Eustace is turned into a grand, ungainly, unhappy dragon. When he lies forlornly on a beach, or as forlornly as dragons do, and a monstrous-size tear slides down his scaly face, you don't just see the wizardry magic, you also see the human touch behind it.''

HAMLISCH--Marvin. Dear Marvin: We're writing this letter to Heaven to tell you how much Myrna and I miss you. From our first meeting in the early 1950's at the Juilliard School (when we shared Frances Goldstein as our piano teacher), through all of the adventures that followed and then again, through Ann-Margret and the irony of your coming to me as your attorney to guide you in so many matters as your friend to talk about so many other matters: our trips on the IRT to see Joseph Papp and Michael Bennett and work on Chorus Line as you carried with you the brown paper bag from your mother with the tuna fish sandwich and the mayonnaise stains on the outside of the bag to the dramas and traumas which led up to They're Playing Our Song and the meeting of the mothers at The Bottom Line to the fun of The Sting and The Way We Were to the not-so-smiling-but-frowning Smile with the gifted Howard Ashman and then running to see Jean in London and then your wonderful work on The Sweet Smell, which was not a sweet success and turned out to be a not-so-sweet disappointment only to be reversed in a very private fashion, not to be shared because the redemption of the entire experience which drove you back to the theatre once again, to the disappointments of The Goodbye Girl to which we all said bye-bye and all the other baddies and goodies and the all-time giggling and our trips to Georgetown for the white pizza parties and our time at the Reagan White House, your spirit, energy, charm and warmth, your never-ending charitable endeavors, always rushing to take care of everyone's medical and emotional problems, always maintaining a moral compass of decency, always focused on your commitment to music and keeping live music in concert halls and preserving the experience by bringing a great sense of theatricality and a generosity of spirit; those wonderful shared weekends in Southampton and then in Westhampton, in Connecticut and in Beverly Hills, at Hilhaven Lodge, in Benedict Canyon, on Park Avenue, the surprise 25th anniversary party you gave to us (gimme a break, Marvin! You really blindfolded the string players!), all of the shared confidences, the intimacies, the true friendship, the camaraderie that can only come about when you know someone for about 60 years. We bid you adieu. And Marvin, old friend, nobody ever did so much for so many, and Marvin nobody did it better. Myrna and Freddie Gershon

MEDWAY--Lawrence. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Lawrence Medway, beloved husband of Joan and father of Robert (Laura) and Richard (Leah). Lawrence instilled in his family a deep commitment to strengthening the worldwide Jewish community. We extend our condolences to Joan, to his children, to his grandchildren, and to the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

CHICAGO - Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr., who has been on medical leave since early June, is being treated for "Bipolar II depression" at the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota, according to a statement released by the clinic Monday providing the most recent update on the congressman's medical condition."Many Americans have bipolar disorder," said the brief statement, which the clinic said it was distributing at Mr. Jackson's request. "Bipolar II disorder is a treatable condition that affects parts of the brain controlling emotion, thought and drive and is most likely caused by a complex set of genetic and environmental factors."

Theater producers are pursuing a possible Broadway transfer of the Central Park staging of "Into the Woods" in spite of several negative reviews last week that would usually put a damper on such plans.The commercial producer Joey Parnes said in an interview on Tuesday that he is developing plans for moving the Public Theater's revival of the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical, which is now running at the outdoor Delacorte Theater. Mr. Parnes previously collaborated with the Public on moving its park productions of "Hair" and "The Merchant of Venice" to Broadway; a spokeswoman for the Public said if this transfer happened, the Public would be involved creatively but would not raise money for it.

Standard Chartered , the British bank, has agreed to pay New York's top banking regulator $340 million to settle claims that it laundered hundreds of billions of dollars in tainted money for Iran and lied to regulators.The agreement is a victory for Benjamin M. Lawsky and his 10-month old agency, the New York Department of Financial Services, which took on the bank alone in charging that it schemed for nearly a decade with Iran to hide from regulators 60,000 transactions worth $250 billion.

BASSIN--Milton G. York College mourns the loss of former President Milton G. Bassin. Mr. Bassin served as York's indefatigable president from 1971 until his retirement in May of 1991. Under his steady leadership, York survived the fiscal crisis of the 1970s, which had threatened to close the burgeoning college. President Bassin exhibited a steely determination and knack for bringing the external community together with the college community. He led the fight for York's survival and for York to remain in Jamaica, Queens and remain a senior college. The president spearheaded the task of building a state-of-the-art permanent campus housed on 50 acres in the heart of downtown Jamaica. Milton G. Bassin was York's second President and to date, its longest serving. He was a staunch advocate of a tuition-free CUNY on behalf of the students who, like himself, came from humble beginnings. The faculty and staff of York College send condolences to Bernice and the entire Bassin family. Marcia V. Keizs, President

Taylor Swift , one of the biggest-selling pop stars in recent years, said on Monday that she will release her fourth studio album on Oct. 22. The album, "Red," will have 16 songs, including the title track, she told fans during a nighttime Web chat event filmed in her living room in Nashville."They're all pretty much about the kind of tumultuous, crazy, insane, intense, semi-toxic relationships that I've experienced in the last two years," she said, according to The Associated Press . "All those emotions spanning from intense love, intense frustration, jealousy, confusion, all of that -- in my mind all those emotions are red. There's nothing in between. There's nothing beige about any of those feelings."

During the Great Recession, when many hospitals across the country were nearly brought to their knees by growing numbers of uninsured patients, one hospital system not only survived -- it thrived.In fact, profits at the health care industry giant HCA , which controls 163 hospitals from New Hampshire to California, have soared , far outpacing those of most of its competitors.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Google's plans to buy the Frommer's brand of travel guides misstated, in some copies, the expected growth in local advertising revenue. It is expected to increase to $150 billion over all in 2016, not to $150 billion just on the Internet.

Frank Ocean has abruptly canceled his European tour, including several festival appearances and a series of high-profile concerts with Coldplay. Mr. Ocean, an R&B singer who drew international attention when he revealed last month that his first true love was with a man, did not give a reason for his decision.He cut short a concert on Friday at the Oya Festival in Norway after just four songs, complaining about vocal problems, according to The Hollywood Reporter. Then, on Saturday, he did not show up as planned at the Way Out West Festival in Sweden.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about early glimpses at the Martian surface provided by cameras on the Curiosity rover misstated the day that the rover landed there. The rover touched down on Mars early on Aug. 6, Eastern time -- not on Aug. 7.

BASSIN--Milton G. The Board and staff of Greater Jamaica Development Corporation mourn the loss of Milton Bassin, whose extraordinary service and leadership as President of York College 1971 to 1991 transformed a dream to reality, advancing the revitalization of Jamaica and Southeast Queens. We recall with admiration and appreciation President Bassin's exemplary role in the College's origin and initial years, and in development of its campus. He assembled and energetically led an especially effective staff and dedicated, pioneering faculty. He engaged community, business and political leaders to overcome daunting challenges to the College's financing and development. Our grief is tempered by the enormity and significance of his contributions in accomplishing the centerpiece of a community development initiative of great consequence. York achieves his vision of providing a quality, liberal arts education to the historically disadvantaged, aspiring and diverse families of Southeast Queens. Vincent M. Albanese Lawrence J. Cormier, Founders F. Carlisle Towery, President

William N. Wallace , a former sports reporter for The New York Times and one of the first to cover professional football beyond following the local team, died on Saturday in Norwalk, Conn. He was 88.He had recently been found to have acute myeloid leukemia, his wife, the former Linda De Refler, said. He lived in Westport, Conn.

The Royal Danish Ballet, the director Robert Lepage and an expert on the neuroscience of taste will be featured in the fall season of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum's Works & Process series, which begins Sept. 9. The performances, aimed at giving audiences insight into the creative process, will take place in the museum's Peter B. Lewis Theater. Most events will also be livestreamed.In addition to appearances by the New York City Ballet (with music by Sufjan Stevens) and a performance of excerpts from Mr. Lepage's production of Thomas Adès's modern opera "The Tempest" for the Metropolitan Opera, there will be several events spinning off the visual arts. The choreographer Russell Maliphant's "Rodin Project" will be staged Dec. 3, and there will also be performances of "Desire Caught by the Tail," a surrealist play about the hardships of World War II written by Picasso over four days in 1941, to be presented in conjunction with the museum's "Picasso Black and White" exhibit.

BASSIN--Milton G. The Shor sisters, Anita and Debbie record with deep sorrow the loss of our beloved Uncle Milton, pride of the Bassin family. His integrity and wit were surpassed only by his love for his family. He will always be in our hearts.

The fall books season just got a little more crowded. Bob Woodward's 17th book, "The Price of Politics,'' will be published on Sept. 11, his publisher said on Tuesday, in the splashy, embargoed style that has been a trademark of a Woodward release.The book is "an intimate, documented examination of how President Obama and the highest profile Republican and Democratic leaders in the United States Congress attempted to restore the American economy and improve the federal government's fiscal condition over three and one half years," the publisher, Simon & Schuster, said in a statement.

Fisker Automotive, the struggling manufacturer of luxury plug-in hybrid cars, has chosen Tony Posawatz, who led the development of the Chevrolet Volt , as chief executive, the company announced in a teleconference on Tuesday.Mr. Posawatz, who recently retired from General Motors after a 32-year career, will succeed Tom LaSorda, the former Chrysler and General Motors executive who became Fisker's chief just five months ago .

KRONTHAL--Ellin B. June 9th, 1928 - August 12th, 2012 Beloved wife of the late Bill. Devoted and loved mother of Jeff, his wife Leah and the late Amy. Loving and wonderful "Gran" of Melissa, Lauren, and Daniel. Daughter of the late Louis and Emily Bloomberg. A native New Yorker who loved her city, friends, bridge, theater and ballet. Shiva will be held Thursday from 5-8 at Ellin's apartment and Friday from 4-7 at Jeff's home. Contributions in Ellin's memory may be made to the Amy Kronthal Fund for Liver Cancer Research at Memorial-Sloan Kettering, 633 3rd Ave, 28th floor, NY, NY, 10017 Attn: Anthony Moye or the charity of your choice.

Joe Kubert, a titan among comic-book artists whose work stretched from the Golden Age of the superhero to the gritty realism of the graphic novel, died on Sunday in Morristown, N.J. He was 85.The cause was multiple myeloma, his son Adam said.

Could another Clinton presidency be on the horizon? We'll just have to wait and see - Chelsea Clinton , for one, is not ruling out a run someday for elected office.In a wide-ranging article in Vogue magazine , the former first daughter and close confidants around her were interviewed about Ms. Clinton's personal evolution and how she is embracing the political legacy handed down from her parents, former President Bill Clinton and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton .

Of all the men Helen Gurley Brown charmed in her many years of selling sex, beauty and diet tips to the modern woman (and taking full advantage of them herself), Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan - the country's most influential Roman Catholic bishop - might rank among the most unlikely.But picture this: the burly, 6-foot-3 archbishop, clad in his clerical robe, embracing the frail, 5-foot-4, 88-year-old editor of Cosmopolitan magazine in a tender waltz on the steps of Cardinal Hayes High School , a prominent Catholic boys' school in the Bronx.

An article on Friday about the literary tastes of immigrants in New York City misstated the period during which the most popular serialized Chinese-language romance was checked out about 300 times in the library system and in which ''The Help'' was circulated about 195 times in all 87 library branches. It was just in the month of June, not since the books have been available in the library system.

BASSIN--Milton. The City University of New York mourns the passing of Milton Bassin, distinguished president of York College from 1971 to 1991, the longest presidential tenure in the college's history. An alumnus of the City College of New York, Mr. Bassin successfully lobbied for the physical enhancement of York's campus in Jamaica, Queens. He previously served New York City Community College (now New York City College of Technology) first as a faculty member and then as its president. We offer our deepest sympathies to his family. Benno Schmidt Chairperson, Board of Trustees Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

LEVIN--Harriet Kornberg, died peacefully at home in New York City on August 12 at the age of 92. Loved for 53 years by her husband the late Philip Levin, adored by daughter Patricia and son Jeffrey (deceased), cherished by niece Susan Smith and nephew Roger Smith and by lifelong friend June Schwartz. Harriet devoted 40 years to working for Cancer Care and Memorial-Sloan Kettering Thrift Shops. Extraordinarily kind, wise and caring, she lived her life with grace. Donations in her memory may be made to mskcc.org/giving.

Chris Christie, the governor of New Jersey, will bring his blunt, everyman style of politics to a much bigger, prime-time stage as the keynote speaker of the Republican National Convention, officials announced on Tuesday.Mr. Christie, who briefly considered running for president himself last year, will deliver one of the most closely watched speeches of the week. Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, a Republican rising star who had been considered as a vice-presidential nominee for Mitt Romney, will introduce Mr. Romney at the convention, which will be held in Tampa, Fla.

MALAMUD--Frances Rose (Costa), 90, of Manhattan died on August 10th. Loving mother of Jason, grandmother of Jack and Hilary, mother-in-law of Maria Ruvoldt, Aunt of Laura Aronson, John Rose, Michael Rosenblum and Ilona Steinhart. Services Thursday, August 16, 11:15am at "The Riverside," 180 W. 76th St, NYC. In lieu of flowers donations to DOROT, 171 W. 85th St, NYC

Wells Fargo on Tuesday settled accusations that it sold troubled mortgage investments without fully researching the products or disclosing the risks to customers.The action by federal authorities, the latest mortgage-crisis case against a big bank, yielded a $6.5 million settlement. Wells Fargo earned $16 billion last year.

The Yankees ' catchers have about 10 key words they use to communicate with the Japanese pitcher Hiroki Kuroda when he is on the mound. They are basic phrases of pitching -- relax, keep the ball down, attack the strike zone.On Tuesday night, catcher Russell Martin's communication with Kuroda was kept to a minimum.

CARSON--Beatrice Lamb, Phd. Educator, choreographer and dancer. Cherished sister of Linda Ashbaugh and Jane lamb-Ruiz. Memorial service at 3:00pm on August 16th at Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 E. 90th Street. Donations in lieu of flowers to Carpenter's Kids c/o the church.

HEDGE FUND'S WOES Tiger Asia, a spinoff of Tiger Management, the hedge fund founded by Julian Robertson, told investors that it would be returning their money in the coming weeks. The move comes amid a three-year investigation by Hong Kong authorities into accusations of trading improprieties at the hedge fund, which was founded by Bill Hwang.The Securities and Exchange Commission has also been investigating the fund. Regulators have accused Mr. Hwang of obtaining inside information about placements of shares in the China Construction Bank Corporation and Bank of China, tips that regulators say earned him $5 million. AZAM AHMED

BROWN--Helen Gurley, editor-in-chief of Cosmopolitan magazine's 64 international editions and one of the world's most popular and influential editors, died August 13, 2012, after a brief hospitalization at the McKeen Pavilion at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia. She was 90. Widely heralded as a legend, Gurley Brown exerted a profound impact on popular culture and society that reached around the globe, first with her 1962 bestseller, Sex and the Single Girl, and then for more than three decades with her personal imprint on Cosmopolitan, a feat rarely replicated by editors. "Helen Gurley Brown was an icon. Her formula for honest and straightforward advice about relationships, career and beauty revolutionized the magazine industry," said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., CEO of Hearst Corporation. "She lived every day of her life to the fullest and will always be remembered as the quintessential 'Cosmo girl.' She will be greatly missed." The philanthropy she established with her husband, David Brown, also left an indelible mark on journalism: In January, Gurley Brown gave $30 million to Columbia and Stanford Universities. The gift created the David and Helen Gurley Brown Institute for Media Innovation, housed at both Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism and the School of Engineering at Stanford. David Brown, who died in 2010, attended both universities and was a movie producer whose films included Jaws, The Sting and The Verdict. The woman who redefined womanhood for many coming of age in the early '60s was born in Green Forest, Ark., on February 18, 1922, to Ira and Cleo Gurley, both schoolteachers. The family moved to Little Rock when Ira was elected to the state legislature. He died in an elevator accident when Helen was 10 years old. After trying to support Helen and her older sister, Mary, in Depression-era Arkansas, Cleo Gurley moved them to Los Angeles in the late 1930s. There, Gurley Brown excelled socially and academically, graduating from high school as class valedictorian. She spent a year at the Texas State College for Women and returned home to put herself through Woodbury Business College. Her mother and sister, who had contracted polio, depended on her financial support for the rest of their lives. In 1941, with her business degree, Gurley Brown took on a series of secretarial jobs. It was her 17th job, at the advertising agency Foote, Cone & Belding, that launched her future success. By the late 1950s, she had become the highest-paid female copywriter on the West Coast and one of the few to be listed in Who's Who of American Women. In 1959, at the age of 37, Gurley Brown married Brown, 43, then a film executive at 20th Century Fox Studios, and later an independent producer. During their marriage, Brown was a partner behind many of his wife's projects, even writing Cosmo cover lines. It was he who persuaded her to write a book about her life as a single woman. The result, Sex and the Single Girl (1962), took the nation--and then the globe--by storm. On the best-seller lists for more than a year, Sex and the Single Girl has been published in 28 countries and translated into 16 languages. Quick on the heels of her first success, Gurley Brown wrote the 1964 bestseller, Sex and the Office. Warner Bros. bought the film rights to Sex and the Single Girl for what was then the highest price ever paid for a nonfiction title. The 1964 film starred Natalie Wood, Tony Curtis, Lauren Bacall and Henry Fonda. The Browns then worked together to keep Helen in the public eye. They pitched plays, television shows, more books and new magazines for single women. One, a magazine called Femme, attracted the interest of Hearst Magazines. But instead of a new title, Hearst agreed to let her try to revive Cosmopolitan magazine. In July 1965, Gurley Brown officially became editor-in-chief of Cosmopolitan and launched it into publishing history. She was Cosmo's tireless editor-in-chief, growing the magazine in the 1980s to 300 pages, a third of which were advertisements. Today Cosmopolitan is the top-selling young women's magazine in the world, with 64 international editions. It is published in 35 languages and distributed in more than 100 countries. In 1997, Gurley Brown left the flagship magazine to serve as editor-in-chief of Cosmopolitan's growing international editions. She and Brown, who were married for 51 years, were anchors in the New York publishing and Hollywood film communities, as he and partner Richard Zanuck produced some of the era's most memorable movies, among them Cocoon and Driving Miss Daisy. Named one of the 25 Most Influential Women in the U.S. five times by The World Almanac, Gurley Brown continued to write books, some 11 in all. For her exemplary contributions to magazine journalism, Gurley Brown was awarded a Matrix Award by New York Women in Communications in 1985. In 1986, Hearst Corporation established a chair at Northwestern University's Medill School of Journalism in her name, the Helen Gurley Brown Research Professorship. She was inducted into the Publisher's Hall of Fame in 1988, taking her place with such publishing originals as Henry Luce, DeWitt Wallace, Harold Ross and Norman Cousins. The Magazine Publishers of America honored Helen Gurley Brown with the 1995 Henry Johnson Fisher Award, the magazine publishing industry's highest honor. Gurley Brown was the first woman recipient. She received the 1996 American Society of Magazine Editors' Hall of Fame Award. Donations may be made to The Pussycat Foundation, c/o Karen Sanborn, Hearst Corp., 300 W. 57th Street, New York, NY 10019. The Foundation benefits U.S. women entering the workforce while pursuing their careers and creative potential, as well as providing other charitable assistance. A fall memorial will be announced at a later date. With appreciation, Hearst Corporation Board of Directors

KRONTHAL--Ellin. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved longtime member, Ellin Kronthal. On behalf of all our members we express our deepest sympathy to the entire family. Michael Tannenbaum, President Bryna Sweedler, Secretary

SWERDLOFF--Bluma, on August 8th, age 97. Bluma was a woman of old world elegance and strength. A psychotherapist in private practice and on the staff of Columbia Psychoanalytic Clinic, she is known for her oral histories of early psychoanalytic pioneers and her book, Heresy, on Sandor Rado (1995). Bluma was a generous and insightful friend to many, often leant an ear when it was needed, and was a beloved surrogate parent to more than a few. Her family, son Peter, daughter Alissa, granddaughter Alexis, son-in-law David U'Prichard and daughter-in-law Nancy Foner, plan a memorial in September. Gifts can be arranged in her memory to Columbia University's Oral History Center.

Pressman--Sasha, 94 years old, died peacefully in her sleep in her West Side apartment on August 6th, just eleven months since she lost her husband, the late David Pressman, who died at the age of 97. They were married for over seventy years, and together they had an extraordinary life. She studied dance with Martha Graham in the mid 1930s and went on to have a successful career as a modern dancer. She joined the Anna Sokolow dance company in 1937 and toured all over the United States. She danced in the original Broadway musical of STREET SCENE, by Kurt Weill, in 1946, and in Helen Tamiris' HOW LONG BRETHREN. She continued a career as choreographer and teacher. She started the dance program at Boston University in 1954 with her husband, David, who began the acting program. She was a woman full of life and passion, and she leaves behind three sons, Gregory, Michael, and Eugene, five grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren. She was a force of nature and will be deeply missed by friends and family. Her wish to join her late husband was granted with grace and serenity.

3 P.M. (FX) THE CURIOUS CASE OF BENJAMIN BUTTON (2008) Brad Pitt received an Oscar nomination for his portrayal of Benjamin Button, a man born in his 80s in 1918 New Orleans, who ages in reverse into the 21st century in this adaptation of a whimsical short story by F. Scott Fitzgerald. Cate Blanchett, above with Mr. Pitt, is Daisy, the dancer who loves Benjamin at whatever stage he is in his life. And Taraji P. Henson, who also received an Oscar nomination, is the nursing home caretaker who raises him when his father abandons him. From Fitzgerald's ''odd, somewhat unpromising kernel, the director David Fincher and the screenwriter Eric Roth have cultivated a lush, romantic hothouse bloom, a film that shares only a title and a basic premise with its literary source,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times, adding that the film ''sighs with longing and simmers with intrigue while investigating the philosophical conundrums and emotional paradoxes of its protagonist's condition in a spirit that owes more to Jorge Luis Borges than to Fitzgerald.''8 A.M. (USA) THE AVIATOR (2004) Leonardo DiCaprio received a best actor Oscar nomination for his role as a young Howard Hughes, the eccentric empire builder and recluse, in this biopic directed by Martin Scorsese. The film covers the late 1920s through the '40s, when Hughes was dabbling in filmmaking and aviation. Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called the movie ''visually sumptuous if disappointingly hollow,'' though it went on to win five Oscars, including best supporting actress for Cate Blanchett in her role as Katharine Hepburn, whom Hughes courted. Mr. DiCaprio can also be seen as Jack Dawson, the steerage dreamboat who steals the heart of the upper-class Rose DeWitt (Kate Winslet), in ''Titanic'' (1997), at 1 p.m. on HBO; as Amsterdam, who's bent on revenge for the death of his father, a gang chieftain, in ''Gangs of New York'' (2002), at 8 on BBC America; and as a specialist in corporate mental espionage who penetrates the minds of his sleeping targets to extract information, in ''Inception'' (2010), at 10:30 on HBO Signature.

The New York Times Company has named Mark Thompson, the departing director general of the British Broadcasting Corporation, as its new president and chief executive.Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the chairman of the Times Company and the newspaper's publisher, announced the appointment late Tuesday afternoon. Mr. Thompson, 55, will join the company in November. In addition to his executive roles, he will also sit on the board.

Taylor Swift , one of the biggest-selling pop stars in recent years, said on Monday that she would release her fourth studio album on Oct. 22. The album, "Red," will have 16 songs, including the title track, she told fans during a nighttime Web chat event filmed in her living room in Nashville."They're all pretty much about the kind of tumultuous, crazy, insane, intense, semi-toxic relationships that I've experienced in the last two years," she said, according to The Associated Press . "All those emotions spanning from intense love, intense frustration, jealousy, confusion, all of that -- in my mind all those emotions are red. There's nothing in between. There's nothing beige about any of those feelings."

KRAUSS--Alisa (nee Fordaus), age 90, died on August 12, 2012, of Philadelphia, PA, formerly of State College, PA, and Great Neck, NY. Wife of the late Milton L. Krauss, who met her during World War II while serving as an officer in the U.S. Army, Persian Gulf Command. Mother of Meyer (Randy), Daniel (Geri), and Ronald. Sister of Puah Venezia. Savta of Michael (Elissa), Robert, Benjamin, Samuel, and Simon. Savta-G'dolah of Nathan and Jacob. Born in Tel-Aviv, a graduate of Gymnasia Herzlia, and member of the Haganah. A great-great-grandaughter of the Chassidic Rabbi Yisrael Bak, who established the first Hebrew printing press in Palestine (Safed) in 1831, and whose son, Rabbi Nissan Bak, founded the Tiferet Israel Synagogue in Jerusalem in 1872. Donations can be made to American Friends of Netiv Ohr. The Krauss Family

WADSWORTH--Frank. 1919-2012. Scholar, educator, author, and sportsman, Frank Wadsworth, died peacefully on August 9th, 2012 at the age of 93. He is survived by his wife, Deborah Yohalem Wadsworth, his daughters Susan and Roxalene "Pebbles" (Christian) Wadsworth; his step-children, Adam (Debra), Lisa (Andrew), and Joshua Belsky, and his grandchildren Anna, Jonah, Malcolm, Henry, Asher, Elora and Anna. He was predeceased by his parents, Prescott Kingsley Wadsworth and Elizabeth Whittemore Wadsworth, and his first wife, Roxalene Nevins. Frank graduated from the Kent School (1938), After serving as a naval aviator in WWII, he completed his A.B. degree at Princeton University as well as his M.A. and Ph.D. Wadsworth was a distinguished and creative educator, who taught English literature at UCLA; University of Pittsburgh, and SUNY, Purchase. An unusually gifted administrator, noted for innovative programs and bureaucratic flexibility, he was Director of the Freshman English Program at UCLA, Dean of the Humanities Division, University of Pittsburgh, Founder and Vice President for Academic Affairs, SUNY, Purchase. He was a Founder and Senior Academic Officer of The Cooperative College Center, Mt. Vernon, NY. Numerous awards and academic honors, include: Woodrow Wilson Fellowship, Folger Shakespeare Library Fellow, Guggenheim Fellowship, and honorary Phi Beta Kappa A prolific author of scholarly papers and reviews, Wadsworth is probably best known for his genial defense of Shakespeare's authorship in The Poacher from Stratford. Wadsworth also served as a member of the Selection Committee for The Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation; SUNY Faculty Senator; Trustee, Rye Country Day School; member Advisory Council, Department of English Princeton University. In addition he was Chairman of the Board of Trustees of The Wenner-Gren Foundation for Anthropological Research. In recognition of Professor Wadsworth's commitment and devotion to the scholarly integrity of anthropology, the Foundation renamed the Professional Development International Fellowship the Wadsworth Fellowship Program. Frank enjoyed his time on horseback or at the tiller of his sailboat as much as his scholarly work and interaction with his students. Burial occurred Arlington, VT on August 14, 2012

RAPPAPORT--Seymour Arnold. Died peacefully in his sleep Tuesday morning surrounded by his loving family. He was 92 years old. Born in New York City on July 31, 1920 to the late Lillian and Irving Rappaport, Seymour served in the US Army Air Corps before marrying his adored wife of 66 years, Dollsey Rappaport (nee Gottfried). Following military service, he ran the R.K. Baking Corporation with his father-in-law, the late Charles Gottfried. His passions in life were his ever-expanding family, philanthropy for the State of Israel, and volunteer work in his local communities of Delray Beach, FL, Atlantic Beach, NY, and Rockville Centre, NY. His honesty, integrity and generosity were matched only by his love for his family, friends, and faith. He is remembered by his cherished Dollsey; devoted daughters, Nanette Rosenberg and Marjorie Rozman; beloved grandchildren, Robert and Emily Rosenberg, Michael and Chloe Rosenberg, Aliza Rozman, Avi Rozman, and Dani Rozman; and great-grandchildren, Danny Rosenberg, and Georgia Rosenberg. Seymour was preceded in death by his sons-in-law, George Rosenberg and Barry Rozman. Services will be held Wednesday, August 15th at 3pm at the Jewish Center of the Hamptons in East Hampton with interment at Shaarey Pardes Accabonac Grove. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Jewish Federation of South Palm Beach, (561) 852-5002 ordonorservices@bocafed.org.

Two years ago, the children's-book author and illustrator Jan Brett and her husband, Joseph Hearne, a bassist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, installed a turtle pond on the grounds of their two-acre home in Norwell, Mass. It was inspired by her plan to write a book about an Eastern box turtle with wildflowers and ferns sprouting from its shell. In ''Mossy,'' due out next month (G. P. Putnam's Sons; $17.99), the turtle spends some unhappy months on display at a natural-history museum until a penitent biologist restores it to its habitat.Ms. Brett, 62, waited and waited for a turtle to move into her pond. Now, mere weeks before the book's publication, one is said to be living there. A suspicious reporter had questions, which Ms. Brett answered good-naturedly by phone.

MACHOL--Betty Kurzman. A lifelong resident of New York City, died on August 12, 2012, at the age of 90 years, after several years of declining health. She is survived by Erwin Machol, her loving husband of 41 years, and her beloved children, Jayne M. Kurzman of New York City and Daniel J. Kurzman of Derby Line, VT, her daughter-in-law, Karen L. Kurzman, and four grandchildren, Jay F. Kurzman, Anthony K. Rykowski, Jessa K. Francis and Pamela K. Rykowski. Her former husband, Alvin L. Kurzman, died in 1955. Her extraordinary kindness, unfailing graciousness and lively intelligence will be missed by all who knew her. A dynamic educator and leader, Betty spent her entire professional career in the New York City school system, where she brought the joy of learning to countless students. She retired as the principal of P.S. 61 in Manhattan. Betty was an active member of the Women's City Club of New York, the Educational Priorities Panel and the Campaign for Fiscal Equity. She received her B.A. from Hunter College, Phi Beta Kappa, and a Masters Degree from Queens College. Visitation, Wednesday 7-9pm and funeral service, Thursday 10am, both at "The Riverside" West 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City. Interment, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

HASDAY--Isaac, on August 13, 2012 at age 88. After serving during WWII as an officer in the Army Air Corps, Ike had a successful career as a CPA and the owner of an insurance agency. He is survived by his loving wife of 68 years, Dora, his five sons Robert (Carol), Chester (Sheila), Scott (Denise), Keith, and Craig (Ina), 15 grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren. Donations in his name may be made to Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Foundation, 68 Hauppauge Road, PO Box 9017, Commack, NY 11725-9017.

CHASE--Elwyn Francis, Jr. Ph.D. Passed away at his home, The Watermark, in Philadelphia on August 13th, 2012 at the age of 86 from complications due to congestive heart failure. Dr. Chase was born on August 13th, 1926 in Philippi, West Virginia; son of Elwyn F. Chase, Sr. Ph.D. and Leanna E. Chase; brother of Edgar and Leanna. He grew up in Haverford earning his undergraduate degree from the University of Pennsylvania in 1949 and his master's degree from John Hopkins University in 1950. He then spent 12 years as a Foreign Service Officer for the U.S. Department of State, with posts in Belfast, Baghdad, Genoa, Bangkok and Washington, D.C. After retiring from the government, Dr. Chase received his Ph.D. from Bryn Mawr College in 1968, writing his dissertation on Morgenthau's Realist Theory. Dr. Chase then served on the faculty of Saint Joseph's University from 1969 to 1996 and continued to teach as a Professor Emeritus for more than 10 years after formally retiring. He was an extremely popular teacher, serving as a dorm master for several years, while also leading study abroad programs in London, China and Russia. During his 20+ years as Chairman of the Political Science Department he was able to bring his diplomatic skills to the down-and-dirty world of academic politics, which Henry Kissinger described as "being so vicious because the issues were so small." In addition to teaching he ran the Model UN program for St. Joseph's and led the committee that developed the Haub School of Business. Dr. Chase received the 2010 Brother Bartholomew A. Sheehan, S.J. '27 award given by the Law Alumni Chapter for his long time contribution to the University. This was a tribute from his former students for his mentorship both during their time as undergraduates and throughout their professional careers. Dr. Chase is survived by his nieces and nephews: Kathy Albino, Charles Chase, Judith Geisser, Bruce Goerlich, Patrick Goerlich, and Peter Goerlich, as well as ten grand nieces and nephews, and two greatnephews. He was a gentleman, teacher, scholar and noted author. In addition, he was an avid patron of the Opera Company of Philadelphia, the Philadelphia Orchestra and the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts. He will be sorely missed. "His soul swooned slowly as he heard the snow falling faintly through the universe and faintly falling, like the descent of their last end, upon all the living and the dead." James Joyce - The Dubliners Funeral service will be held at 11:00am, Saturday August 18th, at Saint Mark's Episcopal Church, 1625 Locust Street, Philadelphia PA 19103. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to either: St. Joseph's University, Development Office, 5600 City Avenue, Philadelphia, PA 19131 or the Opera Company of Philadelphia, 1420 Locust Street, Suite 210, Philadelphia, PA 19102. Services by Bringhurst Funeral Home at West Laurel Hill Cemetery. www.forever-care.com.

Will the hit Broadway musical "Newsies" continue to flourish without its breakout star, Jeremy Jordan? Disney Theatrical Productions will soon find out. Disney executives said on Tuesday that Mr. Jordan, who has become an audience favorite as the brooding New York City newsboy Jack Kelly, would give his final performance on Sept. 4 so he can concentrate on his new leading role in the NBC series " Smash ." Disney also announced that a 22-year-old unknown, Corey Cott, who graduated from Carnegie Mellon University in May and joined the "Newsies" company last month, would take over the role of Jack on Sept. 5.Recasting stars can be fraught business on Broadway: Nick Jonas never really caught fire with audiences last spring after replacing Daniel Radcliffe in "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying," and ticket sales to "The Addams Family" fell off considerably when the hugely popular Nathan Lane finished his yearlong contract. But Disney has deep experience with recasting roles in long-running hits like "The Lion King" and "Mary Poppins," and executives there expressed confidence that Mr. Cott had the tenor, training, and boyish charisma to help coax audience members to return to see "Newsies" over and over again, as Mr. Jordan did.

BASSIN--Milton G.,88, Son of Miriam and Max Bassin; devoted husband of 58 years to Bernice; cherished father of Lori and Robert (Alison); adored grandfather of Noah and Maya Sharma; brother of Ruth Shor (deceased); brother and best friend of Gene Bassin; loving nieces Anita, Debbie, Jan and Michelle. Graduate of City College; President Emeritus York College of the City University of New York (1971-1991). President Emeritus New York City Community College (now New York City College of Technology 1966-1971). Champion of access to higher education for all; a man of integrity and humility. Native Brooklynite, fisherman, life-long fan of the Adirondacks and the New York Yankees. His unconditional love for his family, wise counsel and dry wit will be missed. Funeral service to be held Wednesday, August 15th, 12:00 Noon, Temple Beth El of Great Neck, 5 Old Mill Road. The family requests contributions be made to the York College Foundation, 94-20 Guy R. Brewer Blvd., Jamaica, NY 11451.

SHIKES--Ruth Collins, died peacefully on August 6, 2012. Beloved wife of Ralph E. Shikes (deceased), wonderful mother to Jennifer Shikes Haines and stepmother to Katherine Todd Fredman (deceased). She is survived by her daughter, Jennifer; her Godson, Peter O'Hara; her grandsons, Nicholas Fredman and Connor Haines; her sons-in-law, Stephen Fredman and David Haines; and her countless surrogate grandchildren and beloved friends. She was born on March 11, 1924 to Harvey A. Collins and Elizabeth Peters Collins in Jersey City, went on to Middlebury College and finally moved to New York, becoming a copy editor for Good Housekeeping magazine. She married in 1958 and volunteered in education, civil rights and community center projects, traveled widely, and most importantly she was a dear, supportive friend and family member. The words Ruth used most often during her last weeks were grateful and love, which exemplified how Ruth lived her life. She was a sparkling, loving person and the world will be a sadder place for her absence.

An article on Saturday about a hepatitis C outbreak linked to a medical technician, David Kwiatkowski, who is accused of stealing drugs and injecting himself with syringes that were later used on patients, including many at a hospital in New Hampshire, misidentified the city in that state where he is being held in a county jail. LONDON - Heineken's efforts to secure a controlling stake in Asia Pacific Breweries is facing a setback after Thai Beverage increased its stake in Fraser & Neave, the Singapore-based conglomerate that had agreed to sell its rights in the Asian brewer to Heineken for around $4.1 billion.Fraser & Neave announced on Monday that Thai Beverage was increasing its stake to 26.2 percent, making it the company's largest shareholder and putting Thai Beverage in a strong position to dictate whether Fraser & Neave shareholders support Heineken's takeover offer.

YOUNG--Mary. The Advisory Board and Directors of New York University's Center for French Civilization and Culture and La Maison Francaise are profoundly saddened by the death of our dear friend, Mary Young. She shared our commitment to French literature and art and education. Her legendary grace, her keen, soft-spoken wisdom and good counsel, and her warm, heartfelt good humor touched all those close to her. We express our deepest sympathy to John, with whom Mary formed a truly rare partnership, and to their family. The Advisory Board Tom Bishop Francine Goldenhar

An obituary on Aug. 8 about the movie critic Judith Crist erroneously attributed a distinction to her. While she was one of the most prominent and widely read critics of her time, she was not ''the first woman to be made a full-time critic for a major American newspaper.'' (A few women had worked as movie critics before Ms. Crist became film critic at The New York Herald Tribune in 1963.)

An article last Thursday about a house in Juana Diaz, P.R., that resembles a spaceship misstated the number of tones in the sequence from ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind,'' which the house emits. It has five tones, not four.

BURSTEIN--Lucien. The firm of Warshaw Burstein Cohen Schlesinger & Kuh mourns the passing of one of our founding partners, a dedicated and respected leader of our firm. Luce was instrumental in establishing our current firm in 1978 after having been associated with and managing its predecessor firm since 1951, shortly after his graduation from Yale Law School. He had decided to go to law school following his service in the U.S. Army Air Corps as an aircraft mechanic stationed in Guam from 1943 to 1946. He was one of the driving forces in continuing the growth of our firm over the last 34 years. While he specialized in real estate law, he was truly a renaissance practitioner, with a keen understanding of litigation, corporate, tax and trust and estates law. During that period, he developed a large number of clients for whom he was not only their attorney, counselor and advisor but also their friend. A longtime resident of Larchmont, NY, he was unconditionally devoted to Rose Anne, his remarkable and beloved wife of 68 years, who passed away earlier this year. He was tall in stature, but his most memorable physical feature was the frequent twinkle in his eye. For those of us who had the privilege of spending time with him on a daily basis, he never failed to exhibit patience and wisdom, earning the respect and affection of everyone with whom he worked and associated. He will be dearly missed by all of us. He had the good fortune to be able to spend his final years in Davis, California surrounded by his children and grandchildren. The family has advised us that one memorial for Luce & Rose Anne will be held in Davis on Saturday, August 25, and a second in late fall in the New York area. Details and additional information are at www.burstein.org/memorial. We extend our deepest sympathy to Emily, Barton and Daniel, to his grandchildren, and to the other members of the family. Warshaw Burstein Cohen Schlesinger & Kuh, LLP

The super-shock-absorbent material called non-Newtonian polymer inspires a lot of don't-try-this-at-home stunts, like getting whacked in the head with a shovel through a layer of the stuff.But these materials are also used in protective clothing for skiers and motorcyclists, and - no surprise here - cases for phones.

Abby Elliott has joined the ranks of performers like Kristen Wiig and Andy Samberg who are leaving the cast of "Saturday Night Live." Ms. Elliott, who joined "SNL" as a featured performer during its 2008-9 season, told the Web site Splitsider.com that she would not be returning to that long-running late-night comedy series. NBC declined to comment on Wednesday but a person with direct knowledge of plans at the show confirmed the report.In her four seasons at "Saturday Night Live," Ms. Elliott, a daughter of the comedian and onetime "SNL" cast member Chris Elliott (and granddaughter of Bob Elliott, of the Bob and Ray comedy team), provided impersonations of famous figures like Angelina Jolie, Meryl Streep, Zooey Deschanel and Rachel Maddow.
